Volume 41 of The Collected Letters of Thomas and Jane Welsh Carlyle covers the period from September 1864 to April 1865 and is dominated by completion and publication of Thomas Carlyle’s Frederick the Great and by the continued concerns for Jane Welsh Carlyle’s health. Of the 215 letters in this volume there are 20 written from TC to JWC in September and 20 from JWC to TC also in September, the only time in this volume they were apart.

When he published his French Revolution in 1837, TC little expected to be expressing the same sentiments almost 30 years later on approaching the end of Frederick. TC wrote to his brother John A. Carlyle, 20 Oct. 1836: “Thou seest I am to have done with this sorrowful Enterprise of a Book, with France and Revolutions forevermore” (9:79TC to JAC, 20 Oct. 1836), and to Ralph Waldo Emerson, 5 Nov. 1836: “I am as it were within sight of land. In two months more, this unblessed Book will be finished” (9:81TC to RWE, 5 Nov. 1836). In December 1864 he wrote to brother John: “My work is going on; but under endless haggles from toothache, from Printers, from mud, dyspepsia, dispiritt &c &c: I seem to myself nearly ‘over with it’ in more senses than one!” (TC to JAC, 2 Dec. 1864), and to Henry Inglis: “In january coming … I hope to have done with a certain Book, whh has almost literally killed me,—at least it has kept me buried alive for 12 years past; and I am quite killt as the Irish say, and hardly worth resuscitating” (TC to HI, 7 Dec. 1864). Later in the month he wrote to sister Jean Carlyle Aitken that he “dare promise nothing; every page has been full of fash &toil &disgusting fikeries in this dreadful book. … Courage, Courage! Having eaten the cow, who wd weary on the rump!” (TC to JCA, 20 Dec. 1864). The almost 30 years between the two works had not led to TC feeling any more sanguine about the process.

The reviews of these two works, however, were very different. To his mother in January 1837, TC wrote of the French Revolution: “[a]s to the reception the Book is to meet with, I judge that there will [be] ten enemies of it for one friend; but also that it will find friends by and by; in fine, that, as brave old Johnson said, ‘useful diligence will at last prevail’” (9:125TC to MAC, 22 Jan. 1837). TC judged correctly for the reviewer of French Revolution, Times, 3 Aug. 1837, wrote: “Since the appearance of this work, within the last two months, it has raised among the critics and the reading public a strange storm of applause and discontent. To hear one party you would fancy that the author was but a dull madman, indulging in wild vagaries of language and dispensing with common sense
and reason, while, according to another, his opinions are little short of inspiration, and his eloquence unbounded as his genius. … [N]ever did a book sin so grievously from outward appearance, or a man’s style so mar his subject and dim his genius. It is stiff, short, and rugged, it abounds with Germanisms and Latinisms, strange epithets, and choking double words, astonishing to the admirers of simple Addisonian English, to those who love history as it gracefully runs in Hume, or struts pompously in Gibbon—no such style is Mr. Carlyle’s.” Meanwhile Lady Sydney Morgan in the Athenaeum wrote: “it is one thing to put forth a few pages of quaintness, neologism, and a whimsical coxcombry; and another, to carry such questionable qualities through three long volumes of misplaced persiflage and flippant pseudo-philosophy.” Later in the review she relented and admitted that “amidst an all-pervading absurdity of mannerism, there are passages of great power” (Athenaeum, 20 May 1837).

We can contrast these with the reviews he received on the publication of the final volumes of Frederick. The reading public had obviously become used to TC’s manner of writing. TC, however, had no faith in his potential readership. Writing to John Forster, thanking him for his “very kind and very welcome Letter,” he continued: “if all readers were possessed of the sense and patient candour of Forster, it wd be a pleast thing to write big Books! But they (i.e. readers) by no means are; on the contrary they are a miscellany of blockheads by the hundred and of Forsters by the decimal part of a unit” (TC to JF, 29 March 1865). He must, therefore, have felt pleasantly surprised and gratified when the Times reviewer wrote: “Mr. Carlyle has at length reached the conclusion of his great work, and may repose on his laurels. The great soldier of the 18th century is indebted to him for the best conceivable history of his military exploits and his domestic administration” (18 April 1865). The review in the Athenaeum was effusive in its praise: “Mr. Carlyle’s long and laborious work has come to a close; he ends it with thankfulness, and an adieu to both ‘good’ and ‘bad readers.’ Like all biographers, he loves his hero; unlike some, he adores his hero, in his heart, as one who does not belong to the heap of Shams, by which the candid author of these volumes fancies the world is oppressed. This love and admiration, however, are so honestly held and sincerely maintained, that one cannot but respect the man who entertains such feelings. … In the record of this tremendous struggle [the Seven Years’ War] Mr. Carlyle has surpassed himself. His research, his judgment, his peculiar powers, his comprehensiveness, his grandeur and his ‘burlesque’ of history were never more conspicuous than in this portion of his work. The war is told at very great length, the author himself seems to delight in his labour, the reader never tires of the successions of light and shade, and Mr. Carlyle himself almost appears to be joking when, at the close of the narrative, he exclaims, ‘Oh, readers, do not at least you and I thank God to have now done with it!’” (Athenaeum, 25 March 1865). While TC and his closer friends might
have smiled wryly at some of this review, it still provides a pleasing summary of TC’s achievement.

TC was indeed glad to be done with it. His immediate reaction on finishing was relief. He wrote to John Forster at the beginning of March: “Never in my life was I so sordidly indolent, so content to be so. … I have been buried alive, these 12 years … have had such a fill of disgusting labours, mostly unprofitable, as has completely satisfied my appetite in that kind for all time coming” (TC to JF, 6 March 1865). Of course, after so many years of toil, this sentiment was not to last. TC was suddenly at a loose end. “A gloomy but quiet collapse” descended upon him “in mind and in body;—a world left very vacant in comparison” (TC to JAC, 1 March 1865). Writing again to his brother John, three weeks later, he told him: “[I]f a man cannot escape dyspeptic wretchedness by any mode of eating, nor count on sleep as the close of his day’s laborious toil (in the grateful task of doing nothing &enjoying nothing,—except slightly a little tobacco),—what is to become of him” (TC to JAC, 20 March 1865). To his sister Jean he wrote that riding “is the one moral act I do in the 24 hours; the rest of my time I am grieved to say is one tract of idleness, waste laziness, whh is shameful to think of!” (TC to JCA, 18 March 1865). His enforced idleness did not make him happy. A few weeks later he wrote: “My spirits vary; generally verging towards nadir,—best when I am left quietest” (TC to JAC, 12 April 1865). Geraldine Jewsbury wrote to Walter Mantell in New Zealand, 24 March 1865, to tell him that TC had finished Frederick, and “his wife who ought to know declares that he has been kicking up his heels in a wonderful way ever since” (Mantell). This was not to last and in a undated later letter (probably spring 1865), she wrote that: “[h]e is trying to take his ease and finds it difficult—he is just now—what a mere mortal wd be called ‘cross’ very cross—but as he is a hero &a demi-god I suppose the proper formula wd be that he sees keenly &feels acutely the unsatisfactory nature of all human and domestic sayings &doings and he expresses his sentiment very forcibly” (Mantell).

The answer, as it was in 1837, was to journey to Scotland. He had last spent any length of time in Dumfriesshire in 1860 and the urge to go north was very strong. Writing from Seaforth Lodge, Seaton, to his sister Jean, he told her “I look forward to Scotland were the Spring tempests done. Ah me, I am often very sad, if that cd help me at all!” (TC to JCA, 18 March 1865). His intention was to spend some length of time there, arriving about the middle of May, and towards the end of April, he was making arrangements to send his horse, Noggs, by train to his brother James at Scotsbrig (TC to JC, 26 April 1865). The Carlyles always needed time apart, particularly it seems when TC had time on his hands. JWC wrote to Mary Russell in April at this extremely trying time: “It is very extraordinary that Mr Carlyle will hang on here always declaring himself ‘going in a few days,’ when that is what he has been saying
for the last six weeks! I am kept in a perpetual meditation of Flight (his flight) and get no good of the present—everything having to be postponed till he is gone” (JWC to MR, [15 April 1865]).

Returning to the beginning of this volume, although JWC’s health continued to fluctuate, she enjoyed a very much better autumn and winter. She told her Aunt Ann at the end of November: “the comparitive freedom from physical suffering, seems, after the long tortures I endured, positive enjoyment” (JWC to AW, [30 Nov. 1864]). She continued to suffer from the “irritation” telling TC that “[t]he few weeks of relief from that maddening irritation had made it like a new and worse horror when it returned” (JWC to TC, [12 Sept. 1864]). It was “bad enough to spoil all comfort in the present and to keep me in dread of worse” (JWC to TC, [19 Sept. 1864]); in December it was still causing her “special misery” (JWC to MCA, 21 Dec. 1864).

Arriving back from Scotland at the end of September she was greeted ecstatically by TC and her servants and then had visits from Thomas Woolner, George Cooke, John Forster, and Lord Houghton (Richard Monckton Milnes), who all, as she wrote to TC’s sister Mary, “take me in their arms … and kiss me and—burst into tears!! or are struck speechless” (JWC to MCA, [9 Sept. 1864]). She had indeed made a remarkable recovery and wrote to Mary Russell to tell her of all her visitors: “[i]t is a wonder I have not been knocked up by the heaps of people who come and make such rejoicings over me as if I were a queen bee!” (JWC to MR, [17 Oct.]). Thomas Woolner was “especially trying! for he dropt on his knees beside my sofa, and kissed me over and over, with a most stupendous beard! and a face wet with tears! I had seen him last on newyears evening, in my bed dying as I thought!” (JWC to MR, [24 Oct. 1864]). It was only now that she realized how very worried TC had been about her and described to his sister Mary how he was “gentle and good” and “studies my comfort and peace as he never did before” (JWC to MCA, [18 Oct. 1864]). In September he expressed his need for her and wrote “Oh my own Jeannie, cd you but get well to me! I am old, worn-out and weak” (TC to JWC, 14 Sept. 1864). He became quite desperate for her return and implored her to “come home to your own poor Nest agn” to “gird yr soul heroically together; come my little Heroine, and let me see you … by my side agn for weal and woe. We have had a great deal of hard travelling together; we will not break down yet, please God!” (TC to JWC, 29 Sept. 1864).

It is clear that JWC was both physically and emotionally very fragile even though, apart from a short-lived cold, she remained comparatively well until early May after the end of this volume. Her friendship with Lady Ashburton was a great source of comfort to her and she received her many visits gladly even though she “has been in town again, keeping me out of bed till near twelve! bless her!” (JWC to MR, [25 Nov. 1864]). Her intense feelings for the younger woman were expressed directly in a letter to Lady Ashburton when
JWC told her: “I do so want to be your ‘first foot’! on paper; since it cannot be in person. … for true love is a good gift to have laid at one’s feet—a whole armful of it! … next new years day … you shall see if I dont sit outside your bedroom door till you awake … and speak the first ‘God bless you’ and get your first kiss! Oh my Darling! Oh my Darling!” (JWC to Lady ALLA, 31 Dec. 1864). The only way she knew how to reciprocate all this kindness was by supporting Lady Ashburton wholeheartedly in her quarrel with the Baring family over Lord Ashburton’s will. She needed the reassurance of the continual visits from friends, the reassurance that she still played an important part in another’s life. This friendship with Lady Ashburton, extended to TC, was such that in April 1865 Lady Ashburton arranged for and paid Thomas Woolner a hundred guineas to make a bust of TC, though as JWC told Lady Ashburton: “Mr C drives him [Woolner] to despair … by the different aspects he presents” ([17 April 1865]). For the purposes of the bust, Woolner wanted several photographs of TC from different angles. These were taken in sessions with John Watkins and with Elliott &Fry in April; they also took photographs of JWC, which to her delight were given to her “gratis” (JWC to MC, [ca. 25 April 1865]). These photographs of TC were sold to the general public, while copies of both their photographs were sent enthusiastically to friends and relatives.

After her return from Scotland in autumn 1864, TC seemed to become particularly aware of JWC’s continued commitment and loyalty to him and to his work. It was therefore decided that they could well afford a brougham for JWC “all to herself” since, as TC told his brother John, “[t]wo hours of driving is not enough for Jane, and the Silvester Fly is always a hurried strict affair: we are all astir accordingly, to get her a Brougham, horse &driver … (Farie &c very busy), and hope to succeed in a few days” (TC to JAC, [ca. 12 Oct. 1864]). According to TC, JWC had “never sighed for [one] in my hearing, one faint time” (TC to JCA, 20 Dec.1864). He later wrote in his notes to her letters that he had tried previously to tempt her to buy a brougham but she always had avoided the step even when he told her that “‘[n]o wife in England deserves better to have a brougham from her husband, or is worthier to drive it’” (Froude LM 3:229). She shared her delight in the purchase with Mary Russell, suggesting that in the long run it would be cheaper as two hours in the “fly” cost six shillings (JWC to MR, 31 Oct. 1864). The acquiring of the brougham brought a great deal of pleasure to JWC. She could now repay the kindnesses of friends who had loaned her their carriages in the past; she could shop from the carriage window; she could visit friends on the off-chance that they were at home. In December 1864 she wrote excitedly to Mary Russell telling her: “[t]he most spirited thing I have done since you last heard of me was driving to Acton with——Madame Elise!! to see her beautiful place there and take a dinner-tea with her … arriving at home as late as
six o’clock!!” (JWC to MR, [19 Dec. 1864]). Giuseppe Mazzini while visiting London wrote to Matilda Biggs, 4 March 1865: “Mrs Carlyle—who comes in a coach, stops invariably at some distance in the road and compels me to go to her and exhibit myself to a very inquisitive neighbourhood in slippers and hat—came two days ago with the modest request of twelve autographs of mine for a Bazar” (Giuseppe Mazzini, Scritti Editi ed Inediti di Giuseppe Mazzini, 94 vols. [Imola, 1903–43] 80:124).

The Carlyles’ financial state had improved considerably in the last 30 years. No longer was TC having to think about and give public lectures as he had had to do in the 1830s, when to earn £135 was enough to keep them both for a year. He noted later that at that time: “My poor little Jeannie and me, hasn’t it nearly killed us both? … I suppose by this time our money, too, was near done” (Froude, LM 1:70). After the publication of the first two volumes in 1858 of Frederick the Great for which Chapman &Hall had paid £2,800, they were more financially secure and could look forward without the constant need to economize, though through habit they continued to live almost frugally. By the 1860s TC had built up, with the aid of his brother John, Charles Butler in America, and George Cooke, quite an extensive portfolio of shares, mostly in the burgeoning railway companies, both in Britain and in America. His other books were also selling well and he was receiving regular payments from Tauchnitz in Berlin for the English language edition of Frederick published in Germany. Chapman &Hall paid him £1,675 for volumes 5 and 6 in April. He wrote to John telling him that he found “£2,000 to invest” (TC to JAC, 26 April 1865), a quite considerable sum in 1865. On a visit in March to Lady Ashburton’s new house at Seaton in Devon they toyed with the idea of buying a “Devonshire Craigenputtoch” which was well within their budget. Unfortunately when TC commented that JWC should “‘die of the Solitude in six months’” and she replied “Oh, no! for I will keep constant company,” the plan was immediately dropped (JWC to MO, 29 March 1865). TC’s plan was to escape from people, not to encourage them to visit.

Considering the extensive reporting in the newspapers during this volume it is surprising how little the Carlyles commented upon the Civil War that was drawing to a close in America. There is little doubt that the death in March 1864 of Lord Ashburton curtailed the number of people with whom they might have discussed the subject. Much of their correspondence in relation to it involved telling friends of the visitors from America who found their way to Cheyne Row. Earlier some of these visitors had confirmed TC’s beliefs that the slaves in the southern states lived in happy co-existence with their owners in a sort of Utopia. Others, such as Moncure Conway, tried to persuade him otherwise. But he remained ambivalent until he received a letter from Ralph Waldo Emerson in September 1864 when he revised his thoughts on the subject. Emerson, assuming that TC agreed with him, lamented that TC had
never visited America: “[t]en days’ residence in this country would have made you the organ of the sanity of England &of Europe to us &to them”; he longed to “enlist you with your thunderbolt. … Slaveholders in London have filled English ears with their wishes &perhaps beliefs; and our people, generals, &politicians, have carried the like … to the war, until corrected by irre-sistible experience. I shall always respect War hereafter. The cost of life, the dreary havoc of comfort” (Slater, CEC 541–42). These words really disturbed TC’s thinking on the problems facing America. In March 1865 TC wrote to John Reuben Thompson: “Alas, alas; I never heard of such a War in all my reading; I believe in the annals of the Human Species there was never such another!” (TC to JRT, 27 March 1865).

JWC was more concerned with domestic rather than international news. The excitement of the trial of Franz Müller for the robbery and murder in July 1864 of a fellow traveler on the North London Railway had prompted JWC to send Mrs. Russell a copy of a newspaper report (JWC to MR, [31 Oct. 1864]). JWC continued to display her ability to regale and entertain her correspondents with interesting episodes in the life of 5 Cheyne Row. She related excitedly in her inimitable fashion and at great length to Mary Russell the shocking story of her cook Mary’s production of a child in the little room behind the dining room while TC was entertaining Geraldine Jewsbury to tea. What appeared to have upset JWC more than the illegitimate birth was the falseness and disloyalty of Mary who for many months had been “giving suppers to men and women, downstairs” in the Cheyne Row kitchen, and the fact that she had been “made a fool of, and laughed at for my softness” (JWC to MR, 12 Nov. 1864). She also wrote a detailed description of the event to very recently married Kate Stanley, now Lady Amberley.

It is when the Carlyles were apart that we are allowed to witness their true affection for each other. TC displayed his awareness of JWC’s perpetual commitment and loyalty to him and to his work; it was she who organized his home, kept unwanted visitors at bay, always put his needs before her own. Indeed the letters exchanged in September of 1864 almost entirely concern the redecoration of 5 Cheyne Row in preparation for JWC’s return from Scotland, her worries about inconveniencing TC, the everyday running of their home, and, with seeming justification, the trustworthiness of their maids. As always, she felt she ought to be at home in Chelsea with TC, but the thought of the journey south obviously frightened her and the prospect of having TC’s brother John accompanying her was anathema to her as she told TC: “I dare not meditate on my journey—when it is to be or how—It is a terrible prospect!—John was [on the journey to Dumfriesshire] a very disobliging travelling companion” (JWC to TC, [2 Sept. 1864]). His letters, particularly, are peppered with “Dearests” and “Darlings” and his continued worries about her. On the second of September he wrote: “I send my heart’s love to thee,
and all the blessings I can pray for” (TC to JWC, 2 Sept. 1864). He wanted and needed her home with him. Writing on 20 September, he told her “the only thing I can do is to wish you here agn such as you are; quiet at yr own chimney nook where it wd be new life to me to see you sitting never so lame, if not quite too miserable, and in pain unendurable.”

The letters let us into their lives whether they were exchanging gossip or reporting on who had visited Cheyne Row. Through their daily letters—and they both complained if there was not one—we know how they passed their days, their concerns not only for their own health but for that of the other. TC was also feeling his age (he was now almost 70) and complained of a shaking of his right hand in addition to the on-going problems with his liver. They still tended to keep many of their personal concerns to themselves. JWC reported to TC in September 1864 that his sister Jean had told her that her son “‘young James had been to Chelsea last Monday and found his uncle [TC] very cheery and well.’ ‘Maybe he was nae great joodge’!” (JWC to TC, [12 Sept. 1864]). JWC was also careful not to share her problems with other people, telling TC: “I don’t say much about my nights except to you. People get to be such bores with their ‘sleeplessness’!” (JWC to TC, [20 Sept. 1864]). This volume of letters offers readers the opportunity to view the Carlyles in sickness and in health, in work and at leisure. They complemented each other. As they aged they depended more and more on their nearest and dearest friends, in many ways becoming more insular, the behavior and mores of the mid-Victorian era only encroaching upon them as it affected them directly. Even so, the “man of Genius” and his wife, a certain kind of genius in her own right, exist as exemplars of nineteenth century life in all its variety.

div1.p: September 1864-April 1865

1864 September. JWC is in Scotland, “in the valley of the shadow of Blue pill!” ([1]) and TC reports the house is ready for the decorators (1). JWC begins to agitate about traveling home, with or without John A. Carlyle’s escort ([2]); she writes to condole with Charlotte Southam on the death of her father ([6]). JWC worries that TC has to deal with the paper hangers ([6]), but TC assures her that they “give [him] a minimum of disturbance” ([7]) while he continues to struggle with Frederick (9 [8]). JWC tells him that “Dr Russell [is] much the best Dr that I have had” ([8]). TC sends his condolences to Charles Augustus Ward (11) on the death of his mother. JWC suffers a relapse; she is invited to visit Jean Aitken in Dumfries and her aunts in Edinburgh, but says all her strength will be needed to get home ([12]). TC reports that “[t]he Paperhangers have finished!” (13); JWC continues to send instructions about house cleaning ([14]). JWC writes Mary Craik (17) hoping she has not been harmed during the riots in Belfast. JWC is delighted at the engagements of Kate and Rosalind Stanley ([20]), and TC writes to congratulate Lady Stanley (21). In spite of misgivings TC encourages JWC to accept John A. Carlyle as a traveling companion (23) and asks John to be particularly “gentle, patient, patient, and soft and yielding in all respects” with JWC (24). She feels most unwell, but tells TC ([27]) she intends to travel overnight on the following Friday. TC writes encouragingly to JWC, “Gird yrself up … for a resolute adventure” (28), and tells Lady Ashburton “[t]he poor Wife is coming to me tomorrow; travels all night … my Brother escorting … I confess I shudder at the enterprise: but they say it can be done, with care” (30).

October. JWC returns to Chelsea, health visibly improved. She checks household affairs after her absence and drives two hours daily for fresh air (1). TC later wrote that his life has been a “comatose flight” battling with Frederick, but he looks back on the last 18 months of JWC’s life, from this point on, as “a second youth (almost a second childhood with the wisdom and graces of old age)” (4). He writes to ask his brother John to deal with small matters he has no time for (6). JWC contrives to get new milk and fresh cream to keep up her gains in health since Scotland. She writes both to Mary Austin ([9]) and to Mary Russell ([10]) to tell of her many visitors, including George Cooke and Lord Houghton, and she writes to Lady Airlie ([12]), who then visits ([17]). TC asks Joseph Neuberg and Robert Farie to help find a brougham and horse
for JWC’s use (13) and asks his sister Jean in Scotland to procure him winter clothes, while JWC asks Mary Austin to send fresh eggs from Scotland. Though her health is better, JWC confides to Mary: “I can never feel confident of Life and of Ease in Life again ([18]).” Lady Ashburton visits regularly. The Forsters return to London. Prospective servants for Cheyne Row are being interviewed. Woolner pays an emotional visit to JWC (23). JWC tells Mary Russell she is taking quinine regularly ([24]). John Piper, the Carlyles’ former postman (now mentally unstable), visits JWC for confidential advice about a divorce; JWC describes her new brougham to Mary Russell, and reports that TC expects to finish Frederick “about new-year” ([31]).

November. Though catching cold, JWC continues her daily drive, taking a hot water bottle. Neuberg continues to help TC with editorial and manuscript work (1 [9]). JWC describes to Mary Russell the severe cold of the last week, though she continues her daily drive ([12]); she then tells the story (suppressed by Froude) of the birth of an illegitimate child to Mary the maid in Chelsea in July during JWC’s absence in Scotland; there is now a complete change of servants in Cheyne Row. TC tells his brother “My Book goes on,—slower than I wish; but daily does advance” (17). JWC describes to Mary Russell her daily routine, three hour drive (staying in the carriage rather than paying visits), then, after dinner seeing company at home in the evening: “I take pills at a great rate! Can’t help myself. … People begin to come back—and I have more company than I need” ([25]).

December. TC asks Forster if he would like one of Neuberg’s friends to translate his Life of Goldsmith into German (1). TC complains of toothache (2) and JWC again voices her fear, expressed earlier in 1864, that her suffering would drive her mad (2). JWC praises Woolner’s bust of Lord Ashburton to Lady Ashburton (7). TC’s timetable for finishing Frederick begins to slip; he declines an invitation to Alderley (8). JWC writes affectionately to Margaret Oliphant (9) and visits Madame Elise, her very successful dressmaker, in her country house in Acton. London receives a heavy snowfall ([19]). JWC thanks Mary Austin for eggs and butter from Scotland (21). Mrs. Warren, the new cook, proves satisfactory. JWC sends a bracelet as a new year’s gift to Mary Russell, acknowledged as safely received (30), and sends warm new year’s greetings to Lady Ashburton (31).

1865 January. JWC continues to ride two–three hours daily in her brougham; she keeps up a correspondence with her friends and acknowledges gifts of fresh food and whisky from Scotland ([5]). TC asks Lady Ashburton to take back the gray mare that had been pulling JWC’s brougham but was unfit for the work (5). He admits “I really am close on the edge of finis” (5); he sends the last part of Frederick to press on 15 Jan. The weather is very changeable in
London. TC falls from his horse; JWC writes Mary Russell that both Carlyles are lamed, but that she is slowly recovering her power of walking ([13]). On 20 Jan. TC settles his financial affairs and asks his brother to invest £3,000 for him; he expects another £2,000 soon from the proceeds of Frederick. JWC writes George Morrall, who has asked for a good portrait of TC, confirming that neither of them thought such a thing existed, but encloses a carte de visite as an inadequate substitute (28). Late on 29 Jan., JWC becomes violently ill with a cold and is treated by young Dr. Barnes of Chelsea.

February. JWC’s health slowly improves. Printer assures TC he will be finished by 6 Feb.; there are last minute problems with illustrations (6). When JWC’s health improves, they plan to go to Seaforth Lodge, Seaton, Devon, Lady Ashburton’s new seaside holiday residence. TC, in the relief of finishing Frederick, visits dentist and barber and clears off his correspondence (6). JWC is well enough to sit up but still very weak (8). Henry Larkin is asked to combine all the indexes of the volumes of Frederick into one; this proves an enormous task and TC’s impatience causes a breach between them (9). TC asks Rev. Gerald Blunt of Chelsea to board his horse, Noggs, while they are away (10). More eggs and fresh oatcakes arrive from Scotland ([ca. 12]). JWC writes Betty Braid to console her on the death of her son (14). Chapman pays TC for Frederick (15); at Lady Ashburton’s suggestion the Carlyles postpone going to Seaforth Lodge until the weather improves (16). TC tells his sister Jean of his intention of remaining with Scottish-made clothes rather than buying London-made ones (19). JWC resumes her daily ride in the brougham (16), and TC writes John Ruskin to thank him for a box of cigars (22) and proposes a visit (25). Dr. Richard Quain visits JWC socially ([28]).

March. “I am the idlest of all mankind” writes TC; he complains about an increasingly shaking hand (1). The postponed visit to Seaton, Devon, now takes place (8). Both Carlyles are delighted with the house, and JWC writes Mary Russell in superlatives, warmly inviting her and Dr. Russell to visit her in Chelsea after their holiday ends, while TC goes on a round of Scottish visits (10). The Woolners visit Seaforth Lodge. Vols. 5 and 6 of Frederick are pbd. mid-March. TC rides around the countryside, though he complains to his brother John of inability to relax or enjoy his leisure time. He agrees to try to write a memoir of Sir William Hamilton “whom I honour and love so truly.” Larkin’s index to Frederick is finished (20). TC writes despairingly of the American Civil War (27).

April. The Carlyles return (with Lady Ashburton) to London (3). TC begins his sittings for Woolner’s bust (6), commissioned by Lady Ashburton (but not finished until 1866). He resumes riding Noggs (8). JWC writes a friendly letter to Mary Smith (10). TC writes Larkin to acknowledge all his help in
Frederick and sends a check in thanks (13). JWC, writing to Mary Russell, complains of a dip in health after returning to London; she is in the process of acquiring a new horse for her brougham (14). TC is photographed by John Watkins, 15 and 17 April; JWC also is photographed by Watkins. Elliott &Fry photographed TC and JWC at about the same time. JWC addresses Lady Ashburton as “my Dearest, my Beautifulest! My Best!” and begs her to visit in London (17). TC reads reviews of Frederick (26) and attends the Committee of the National Portrait Gallery (27). JWC welcomes Charles Gavan Duffy back to London after a 10 year absence (26), and invites him to visit in Chelsea.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [1 Sept.]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Thornhill, 1 Sept. 1864. MS: NLS 608.662B. Quot: Froude, LM 3:208, combined with an excerpt from JWC to TC, [30 Aug.].
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Dearest—I am in the valley of the shadowCoterie speech; see 36:44JWC to LLA, 16 Jan [1860]; cf. Ps. 23.4. JWC was convalescing after a long illness (see vol. 40) at Holmhill, the home of Mary Russell and Dr. James Russell. of Blue pill! My disposition felt so suicidal last evening, that I, myself, proposed the measure And Dr Russell approved. This one gave me no such blessed sleep as did the first after I came here; still it was a better night than a good many previous ones. and I try to hope that tomorrow I shall be all the better for it. I am profoundly disheartened just now! every way I turn it looks dark, dark to me! I had dared to hope—to look forward to some years of health no worse at least than I had before—and that revival of Hope makes my present Hopelessness doubly bitter for me. You perceive it is best I write no more today—just this much to spare you the anxiety you would have felt at no letter. I cannot write cheerfully. I am not cheerful.
JohnJohn A. Carlyle, TC’s brother. came to dinner yesterday.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 1 Sept. Addr: Dr Russell &c &c / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 1 Sept. 1864. MS: NLS 617.660. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC to JWC

docBody.p:
My poor little Dear, this is but cold comfort; but comfort it is in comparison; and we must try to make the most of it. I had a Note from John today too (at 2 p.m.), whh yields no new light; but corroborates &corresponds to yr own view: “wished to assure you he was ready to come up hither agn with you”John A. Carlyle accompanied JWC on her train journey from London to The Gill, 6 mi. (9.5 km.) SW of Ecclefechan, the home of TC’s sister Mary Austin, 14 July; see 40:133–34JWC to TC, 15 July [1864]. JWC continued to the Russells at Holmhill, Thornhill; see 40:146–47JWC to TC, [23 July]. &c &c— But perhaps you will prefer JeanTC’s sister Jean Aitken. or some other? His hand is apt to be rough on one’s sore places,—tho’ he truly has a kind of real pity (not in great quantity); and means (theoretically) nothing but well, I believe. Do whatever is yr own judgt, Dearest:—the only thing is, Don’t get into “despairing” agn;
Oh don’t,—if you can help it at all! Despairing or not, it seems to me you wd be a welcome sight here!— Poor TwisletnsEdward Twisleton. Letter is good; I will go and call upon Twn.

Last night (6 p.m or so) I left message at Mrs Forster’s door;Eliza Forster, 46 Montagu Sq.—nobody in, but they both came down by and by, and found me absent, still riding, “Man to [be] here”Word omitted by TC; Eliza Forster was organizing the redecoration at 5 Cheyne Row; see 40:214JWC to TC, [29 Aug.]. &c instanter [immediately]. And accordingly he has come (abt 11 this morng), a good intelligt looking little body. Finds all ready (Sweeps, stript floors, and all); goes measuring, prying abt; shews me the Paper (very pretty, but beyond my judging of,—I can merely tell him the Missus is an extremely punctual Individuality, with an eye like a Hawk’s, &that I very much wish her to approve his performance): Paper is still to be made (!) men cannot come till Monday, for whitening of ceilings; work will not be quite done, next week &c. But I believe he will do it all quite tolerably;—and that you will find nothing irremediably awry in our procedures here. Shakspeare,George Shakespeare (b. 1817), dairyman, living at 6 Queen St., Chelsea; he apparently did various odd jobs, including carpet beating; for JWC’s previous unhappiness with his work, see 40:221–22JWC to TC, [31 Aug.]. the little Tick, seems to me at least dear enough (4 shgs for yr bedroom carpet, 5/ for drawingroom &c): but both the girlsThe Cheyne Row maids Helen and Mary. continue to assure me the Carpets are all really clean:—I thot the dud of a creature was ill off, and a kind of charity, whh made me the more readily consent. And so all that is afoot, &tolerably right I think; my (topmost) stair-flight, very clean &carpeted clean; the theWord repeated at turn of page. others lying bare (I suppose only swept till &c); drawing books, big pictures, sofa &c covered as you bid. We will be quiet in ground floor &top ones till the process be complete.

Last night GeraldineGeraldine Jewsbury. &RawlinsonRobert Rawlinson (1810–98; ODNB), civil engineer; see 40:213TC to JWC, 29 Aug.. were at the Door when I arrived: Rawlinson is really a clever kind of man; but all in the Sanitary, Nightingale, CrimeaFlorence Nightingale (1820–1910; ODNB), nursing reformer, particularly known for her work improving the conditions of the Army Medical Service during the Crimean War, 1854–56; for the Carlyles’ reactions to the war, see vols. 29, 30, and 31. Rawlinson was sent to the Crimea to investigate the sanitary conditions of the British army in Sevastopol and became one of the supporters of Nightingale’s work. &c tack;—and barely kept me interested in him, in the wearied state I was in.— — Yr pilluleTC had taken a pill from a box sent to Chelsea for JWC by Charles Rowett Quiller (b. 1829), pharmacist, 15 Sloane Sq.; see 40:221TC to JWC, 31 Aug.. was as ineffectual as its forgoer: is not that a
surprising instance to the glory of potatoes!TC believed that his digestive system was upset because he could not get ripe potatoes; see 40:209TC to JWC, [25] Aug., and 213TC to JWC, 29 Aug.. I still sleep rather fairly, tho’ dullish at eating. I am going to try brown bread (tho’ Mary makes capital white; far better than the Addiscbe that comes).The Carlyles regularly received hampers of fresh produce, including bread, from Lady Ashburton’s farm at Addiscombe. Oh send me good news, Darling! The NotesUnexplained. have come today.—

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 2 Sept. Dr Russell &c &c / Thornhill / Dumfrieshire. PM: London, 2 Sept. 1864. MS: NLS 617.661. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Alas, and must I leave thee, poor little Goody, under the claws of that heart-breaking enemy;That is, hopelessness; see JWC to TC, [1 Sept.].— no better news to be expected till Tuesday morng,TC forgot he was writing on a Friday and could therefore expect another letter the next day. if Tuesday bring them! We cannot help it, Dear; we do our very best, and here we are.

Last night, for the second time, PiperJohn Piper, Cheyne Row’s former postman. came craving “one minute”; tho’ up to the chin in Proofs I gave him one minute. It was to state, in perfectly sane terms, a merely Literary request: a yg Cousin of his, a Farmer from Kent,Unidentified further. great reader &c; wd I permit him for one moment to see me with his eyes as I took my walk by Margaretta Terrace?— And this morng accordly the young man appeared: an intelligt clean creature; quite an honest being; had seen Mazzini,Giuseppe Mazzini. had &c;—I dismissed him with my blessing at the door-sill agn. Piper appeared to be quite unmad agn,—was doing some subsidiary Letter-carrying, he said; the misguided mortal!— My sheets were all got done in good time. My work, I think, will really go;—ripe potatoes, oh that I had a supply!

This morning I sent LarkinHenry Larkin. off with £8.15 of rent: he had no recollectn of tax &c, but thot he wd succeed in ascertaining from the Coutts ClerkCoutts Bank, 58 and 59 Strand, where their rent was paid; see 40:222JWC to TC, [31 Aug.]. tomorrow morning;—from Oughton,Thomas Oughton, Chelsea tax collector; see 40:106TC to HL, 29 May. at any rate, he certainly wd. Enough of that.
The Paper man with an assist was here agn. He made request to me, “May we remove that large Picture?”The copy of The Little Drummer by Antoine Pesne (1683–1757); see 40:214JWC to TC, [29 Aug.]. Removed it (Spare bed room, properly veiled); and I saw no more of him. Helen, on peremptory order from me, has got the balustrade washing carried down to yr bedroom door; had wished much to keep all in wreck till the Papering were over. Everything is up to spare bedroom: built in a stack there; nothing left in the drawingroom at all. All right there, as far as I can judge.

There has been a wonderful annihilatn of rubbish up here today; you never saw such loads of crumpled-up Papers (grate &fender full of them) besides what lie in the two Presses for the last seven years! He even will delivr me at length. Steady, steady!— I have got no other work done, none at all; but this was a most indispensable preliminary. I do really endeavour to hope, “By the end of Novr, I may have done!” Really possible; only it depends on Potatoes &c &c.
I end, my Dearest: I send my heart’s love to thee, and all the blessings I can pray for. Adieu, till Tuesday,—and then Oh be a wee bit better. Yr affecte / T. Carlyle

ps.p: —Oh, I shall hear tomorrow still!—

“Mutual Friend”The 5th installment of Dickens, Our Mutual Friend (May 1864–Nov. 1865) was pbd. 1 Sept. comes duly; and is all lying here. Wd you like it? Or the rest of this (sent today); all of this or of it?Presumably Anthony Trollope, Can You Forgive Her?, also pbd. in monthly parts, May 1864–Nov. 1865; see JWC to TC, [5 Sept.]. Say a word if so.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [2 Sept.]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Thornhill, 2 Sept. 1864. MS: NLS 608.663. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p:
Just two lines between having finished dressing and going out to drive— I have been kept in bed till near midday, that my “joints” might be carefully examined; and afterwards a mustard-blister applied up my spine. It is all right with the joints as yet—except for external stiffness, Dr R says. The spine has “soft places” as Mr Barnes found out long ago; and then I think forgot it, when his own poor wits went soft.Dr. Alfred Barnes, JWC’s doctor in Chelsea; he had been ill for some time; see 40:123TC to LLA, 28 June, and 198TC to JWC, 22 Aug. My own idea has been for some time that my difficulty in walking which has only increased as I gained weight, proceeds from
some mischief in the spine.—and that I shall end in losing the use of my limbs altogether. In the mean time I am to apply frequent mustard blisters— Oh if the horror would only go away, and stay away, as it did for near a fortnight; I should be very resigned to permanent crippledness!
Last night was much like the preceeding one—not sleepless but very disturbed. I had to take to bed again at tea time—
It was not that the irritation was very bad—nothing like what it had often been!— But when I had been free of it for a while, the return even in a mild form was like to drive me wild!

I dare not meditate on my journey—when it is to be or how— It is a terrible prospect!— John was a very disobliging travelling companion—and when he gets into the house he keeps possession. If he went to Chelsea with me he would probably make himself at home there all the winter, which would be no help or comfort to me. JaneJWC’s sister-in-law Jean Aitken. again is not an experienced traveller, nor a comfortable nurse—recognising her superior intellect and good will; there is a total want of tact and of “what shall I say?Coterie speech; see 19:115JWC to TC, [27 July 1845].—tenderness, about her, and a tendency to fuss that frightens me. Let us “leave it open” yet a while—trusting in Providence

To think there was a time and that not long ago, when I could fly over the kingdom without anyone to care for me!— I wish you would send a sovereign to poor SouthamThomas Southam, uncle of Charlotte Southam, the Carlyles’ former maid, d. 3 Sept.—and you may send me a cheque for—what?—ten pounds say—which will bring me home when the time comes when you offered me money I didnt need it— Ever your own
docBody.name: J W C

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAF, 4 Sept. MS: Pierpont Morgan Lib. Quot: Carnegie Book Shop, cat. 200, no. 60 (24 March 1955).
div3.head: TC TO J. A. FROUDE

docBody.p:
Will you work a small miracle for me; and make the Longman Clerk restore me my Fraser.Longman, Green, Longman, Roberts, &Green pbd. Fraser’s Magazine Nov. 1860–June 1865; James Anthony Froude was ed. Nov. 1860–Aug. 1874. I have written either twice or thrice to him, in the plainest hand and the most explicit words; but it is no use: he goes on like gravitatn; and my poor Fraser must agn have gone (I perceive) to St Leonard’s;Presumably Longman sent the July Fraser’s to St. Leonards while the Carlyles were staying there. Larkin forwarded TC’s June copy to Walter Welsh at Auchtertool; see 40:111TC to HL, 3 June.
where the Post-Office Clerk has now forgotten my Chelsea Address! Intervene in pity: the works of Him I call Chaos are really growing too manifold on me!—— ——

Better news from Scotland lately (that is the work of Another Party!)—news fairly rather better there; and my poor Wife coming home to me before long. Adieu,—for a month or how long?Froude was spending the summer at Ringmore House, Salcombe, Devon; see also 39:165TC to JAC, 9 July 1863. Hasten you also, what you can.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [5 Sept.]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Thornhill, 5 Sept. 1864. MS: NLS 608.664. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:298–99 inc. Quot: Hansons, NE 522.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Here we are at the beginning of a new week: and God grant it be better than the last! Up to last night I got no sleep, and the irritation was getting worse and worse: and I had “lost my happetite.”Coterie speech; see 18:87JWC to TC, [26 June 1844]. and was altogether in a miserable way. Last night I slept—an hour at a time—for five or six hours. Curious! every time that I got out of bed and looked at my watch, it was always an exact hour from the time I had looked last—half past one, half past two, half past three, and so on to half past six! Certainly the vagaries of my sleep would make an interesting chapter in a medical book. By Dr Russell’s recommendation I took last night two glasses of wine at once (!) three hours after my porridge and milk—and that made no difference on the one-hour-duration of my sleep!

It vexes me to think of you worried with all that papering As I can be of no use to you, I might at least one would say be of no bother! Oh dear Oh dear! what a lot for me—and I cannot help it—to be of no use any more; but only a burden and a plague!

I wrote a note to Geraldine on Saturday after posttime,—which will go today. Why I should write to her whom I have been so dissatisfied with—at a time when more than usually ill and depressed—needs explanation—in case she make a fuss about having heard from “Jane”—

She wrote to me as she had told you, some weeks ago—a disagreeable letter—the third letter she had written to me thro’ all my illness—every one of them disagreeable about her parties and her new clothes &c &c! I should have delayed answering; into the vague—had not there been inclosed in the
letter to me a note to Mrs Russell—full of passionate anxiety to have news of me (which could have been got any day at Cheyne Row)! and imploring Mrs Russell to write and tell her how I was—quite Geraldinish, the whole thing! Poor Mrs Russell who is very shy and nervous fell into a panic at the idea of having to “write to a Learned Lady whom she had never seen”— So in common humanity and common gratitude, I had to take the answering on myself and promise to write— Every day it was “Oh Mrs Carlyle! have you written to that Lady? I am afraid she will think me so rude.” At last on Saturday afternoon when I was ever so ill and miserable, I “wrote to that Lady”—not however telling her much of myself.

When the rooms are done pray charge the maidsHelen and Mary. not to rub on the clean paper with their abominable large Crinolines and not to push back the chairs against it, as their habit is! and tell Mary to sleep in my bed from time to time—to keep it aired—Mary—not Helen in my bed—She (Helen) perspires so dreadfully that she would do the reverse of airing it!
If your pills don’t act, would you try a little doze—rhubarb and magnesia—which Dr Russell takes every night of his life before supper—I would tell you the quantities— Ever yours
The Trollope came this morning, send Dickens too—
I am reading Macauly EssaysThomas Babington Macaulay (1800–1859; ODNB), historian and essayist; possibly Critical and Historical Essays (1843) or Biographical Essays (Leipzig, 1857). over again

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 5 Sept. Addr: at Holme Hill / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 5 Sept. 1864. MS: NLS 617.662. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: My Dearest,—I was seldom in such hurry in my life! You must know I have now changed to riding at 3, before dinner (for excellt reasons, if the change will fulfil its prognostics!)—and that crumples up my forenoon into nothing at all. Oh I am terribly depressed and wae too (chiefly in the form of sorrow and dispiritment abt my Schatz [Darling] and Compann &Protectress in this weary pilgrimage);—but I will not trouble you abt that.— I have found my ScissorsTC had lost his scissors; see 40:213TC to JWC, 29 Aug., and 217TC to JWC, 30 Aug. (Goody wd have found them in five minutes; these creatures evidtly never): that is a good omen, is it not! Strangely agreeable to me. I saw the StanleysLord and Lady Stanley. yesterday; kind enough, and prosperous. My work does not stand. These beginning with the Scissors are all my good news.

I sent the sovrn to Mrs SouthamElizabeth Southam. on Saty: poor Southam had died at 1 a.m. that same morng— The Paperhangers are here: white-washing (I notice when down the back area). They were talking with vivacity; rumbling abt, very audible, when I awoke this morning (not they that awoke me, and it was time to awake): I ordered their door to be shut, and have heard nothing more of them. Mrs Forster it appears has just called here; has just been writing to you,—and asks me (in supplement) to ask you, “Will you have the 3 poles of the window-curtains lackered? Paperer can do it.” Please tell her,—“Yes” I suppose. I am eating brown bread exclusively for two days back; began my 3 o’clock rides on Saty (a gallop unexampled, never was such a little devil for going as this red-bay,TC’s horse, Noggs.—not ill to ride either): it seemed to do me good. Potatoes will come!

I send my Dearest £11;TC recorded: “6 Sept. r 1864 to my Jane (coming home, poor soul!) £11 .. 0 .. 0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). one is the Sovn you gave for me to poor Mary Hidln:Margaret Hiddleston, JWC’s mother Grace Welsh’s maid at Templand; see 40:179TC to JWC, 11 Aug., where TC also called her “Mary.” Study well how you will come back;—and oh come safe &better!

closer.salute: Blessings evermore on my poor little Woman.

docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-[CS][CSO], [6 Sept.]. MS: Chelsea Public Lib. Hitherto unpbd. Dated by Thomas Southam’s death, 3 Sept.; JWC received the news from TC and Charlotte Southam, 6 Sept. (see TC to JWC, 5 Sept., and JWC to TC, [6 Sept.]).
div3.head: JWC TO [CHARLOTTE SOUTHAM]

docBody.p: Just one line, to say I heartily sympathize with your poor Mother and you. Yet—it is surely a mercy that your FatherCharlotte’s aunt and uncle, who had adopted her, were often referred to as her mother and father. is out of his long suffering since there was no hope of his recovery. You have the comfort of knowing that he was a good man, and, for such, Death is gain not loss

You were right not to throw up your place rashly. It is always best to stay still in a place if it can at all be made to do.JWC tentatively enquired in Aug. whether Charlotte might like to return to work at Cheyne Row; see 40:203JWC to CSO, [23 Aug.]. Presumably Charlotte decided to remain in her place with the marquis of Camden.
As I used to tell you “A rolling stone gathers no moss”
I have been very poorly for a week back—gone quite off my sleep again—and all the rest of it— I suppose the rainy weather has been hurting me

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [6 Sept.]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Thornhill, 6 Sept. 1864. MS: NLS 608.665. Quot: Froude, LM 3:208–9; Bliss, JWC 316.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Dearest. I often think it would have been a better arrangement that you should write, as you do, every day; but i only now and then, when I should feel best up to writing! You should thus have been spared many wretched lamentations, which, by being kept in for a few days, would have been rendered superfluous—if indeed lamentations are ever other than superfluous. Today it is again raining—there has been much rain during the last week. And I think that damp is more injurious to me than cold. all my pains are aggravated by it and my spirits depressed; And the daily drive, which always brightened me up a little in the fine weather; is no good with closed windows and the wet trickling down them!

I had again some sleep last night—little, and bad, what was of it, but a great improvement on none at all. Now that the weather and my sense of propriety (!) both drive me on the thought of return; that thought haunts me day and night! How am I ever to perform such a journey, without the strength of desperation which supported me here?JWC traveled to Scotland 13 July see 40:135JWC to MR, 15 July [1864]. It is not to be wished that I should be strengthened in that wild way again! And after? Oh that it were as easy to put tormenting thoughts out of ones own head as it is for others to bid one do that!

I wish to Heaven you were delivered from these paperhangers I did not think it would have been so long in the wind. I, the unlucky cause, am quite as sorry for the botheration to you as Jane expresses herself;Possibly JWC referred to Jean Aitken’s comments to TC, [21 Aug.]: “You seem very solitary indeed, but you can bear that for the present better than bustle or worry of any sort.” She also wrote: “What a blessing if [JWC] could get out of this long dark lane she has come thro’ since Novr last. It’s a lang lane that has nae turning. There really seemed to be no turning visible for a long while.” tho I have more appreciation of the terrible half-insane sensitiveness which drove me on so bothering you. Oh if God would only lift my trouble off me so far that I could bear it in all silence! and not add to the own troubles of others!

The cheque came all safe—the repayment of the sovereign is amusing—when it is considered that I have long ceased to be on “allowance”For JWC’s satirical response, Feb. 1855, to the need to apply for more money to TC, both for her own allowance and the household budget, see “Budget of a Femme incomprise” (29:251–58JWC to TC, [12 Feb. 1855]).—
There came, besides your letter this morning, one from Charlotte announcing her “Father’s” death—and one from Mrs Forster with a gushing P S from her Husband.John Forster.
I have no news—except that it rains

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, [6 Sept.]. Addr: at Holme Hill / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 6 Sept. 1864. MS: NLS 617.663. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Dearest,—Thanks for yr dear Letter; Oh pluck up a heart, darling; all will go right yet!—— The people are lashing away here; cleaning the walls (doing it really well, I think): I went in to ask if they cd not mark the innumerable holes of the Pictures &c nails, so that one might drive them in agn witht difficulty;—I fear they cannot, tho’ they undertake to try (for form’s sake). Except those of the big Picture, and most or all of those on the top band, the nails are all out.— Don’t fret yrself abt the people’s “bother” here; they do me no ill.
Three striking, Oh dear! I have been up since 7; terribly intent on being thro’ a burble;—tired enough, &better to be driven out
Yesterday I called on Twisleton; tonight he has volunteered to come down. Saves me from Forster’s venison any way (see note inclosed).Forster’s note, presumably inviting TC to dinner, untraced.

Geraldine the flaffing goose! De LaneJohn Thadeus Delane (1817–79; ODNB), editor of the Times 1841–77; see 38:165TC to JWC, 27 Aug. 1862. yesterday gave me the inclosed scrap of Poetry,Possibly the poem written by a prisoner on a slate, then sent to the Times by R.E.R.; Delane might have thought its viewpoint would amuse TC: “I cannot take my walks abroad, / I’m under lock and key; / And much the public I applaud, / For all their care of me. / Not more than others I deserve, / In fact, much less than more; / Yet I have food while others starve / Or beg from door to door. / The honest pauper in the street / half naked I behold; / While I am clad from head to feet, / And covered from the cold. / Thousands there are who scarce can tell / Where they may lay their head; / But I’ve a warm and well-air’d cell, /A bath, good books, good bed. / While they are fed on workhouse fare, / And grudged their scanty food; / Three times a day my meals I get, / Sufficient, wholesome, good. / Then to the British public health, / Who all our care relieves, / And while they treat us as they do, / They’ll never want for thieves” (Times, 1 Sept.). whh he seems to have clipped out for the purpose (able
Editr that he is, &clever swimmer in the mother of Dead DogsCoterie speech; cf. Pope, Dunciad 2:271–72; see also 35:68TC to RWE, 9 April 1859.)
Oh my Darling, write me something good for tomorrow. If you can, if you youWord repeated at turn of page. only can!—— Adieu with my heart’s blessing.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, [7 Sept.]. Addr: Holm Hill / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 7 Sept. 1864. MS: NLS 617.664. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Dearest,—I am still chaced by the Printers Devils at a quite panting rate; and have not a moment. God be thanked that you are not worse. Write me the smallest word,—one word, rather than none, however? Yes; unless you vote otherwise—I hope you will soon be here; and all this writing over, my poor little Goody!

The Paperhangers proper are to come tomorrow (same time?)—hope to be out agn &finished (whh I don’t hope) on Saty night. They seem to me really quite decent people; do their work well, and give me a minimum of disturbance—(I did not know there was anything in Jean’s Letter on that hand; had never noticed the nothing whh it was,—or I wd not have sent it)For Jean Aitken to TC, [21 Aug.], see JWC to TC, [6 Sept.].;—properly no disturbance at all,—were I sound enough of sleep these two last morngs. Nay I really don’t regret being awake at 7,—and getting an hour or more of start upon the chacing Devils! I am hardly quite tired out yet, when the Horse comes.

Yesterday I must have gallopped betn 15 &20 miles: Hammersmith, Wormwood Scrubs, Harrow RoadA circular route, about 15 mi. (24 km.), from Chelsea going W to Hammersmith, N to Wormwood Scrubs, E to Harrow Rd., and then S to Chelsea again.&c &c,—and my cross-grained but indomitable little fellowNoggs. fonder of the work than when he began. Scrag-of-mutton broth (unluckily with only turnips &carrots); after whh 3 hours of wasteful talking with (chiefly to) Twisleton this was bad, bad; but my gallop covered it all;—and I am not amiss today, rather above par.

Oh Darling I tremble with you abt that Journey:—yet at bottom I do not
think it will do you ill. Next week then,—or when is the great thing (great to me too) to be resolved on? Oh God pity us,—pity you my poor weak Lammie, who are all I have. Yrs / T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [7 Sept.]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Thornhill, 7 Sept. 1864. MS: NLS 608.666. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:209 inc.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: I cannot write a letter today. I have passed a terrible night sleeplessness, and restlessness, and the old pain (worse than it has ever been since I came here) and in addition to all that, an inward blackness of darkness! Am I going to have another winter like the last? I cannot live thro’ another such time—my Reason at least cannot live thro’ it!

It is a fact that for a fortnight past I have been getting gradually into the old tack. and I was so much better! had almost ceased to look for the return of the pain! That is why I feel so wild under it now.

closer.salute: Oh God bless you—and help me!

docBody.name: JWC

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 9 [8] Sept. Addr: at Holme Hill / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 8 Sept. 1864. MS: NLS 617.665. Pbd. Bliss, JWC 316–17. Quot: Froude, Carlyle 4:281, combined with a quotation from TC to JWC, [9 Sept.]; Hansons, NE 522. Thurs. was 8 Sept.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Oh my poor little Woman! Your Letter has made me miserable to the heart;—and I must not yield to it, or reflect back the feeling to you in yr weak conditn! But we have been used to vicissitudes; I pluck up Hope again, “Only a bigger backward lash of the tide whh was and is fairly on ebb!” We must be prepared for such things, my Darling. Oh how I wish I had you here again, ill or not ill! We will try to bear the yoke together; and the sight of yr face will do my sick heart good.

I am overhead in disgusting rubbish; struggling not to choke in it, but to get it trampled under my feet. I have had to postpone my ride too (it is now 4 p.m.), and to give up my nap,—on acct of the FuzJohn Forster. note, inclosed. “Come
to me here, 20 min. after six” was my ansr. “Gushing[”]Forster added a “gushing P S” to Eliza Forster’s last letter to JWC; see JWC to TC, [6 Sept.]. TC omitted closing quotation marks. Fuz! excellt too notwithstanding.

The weather is clamy-hot here; I have had to take summer-clothes. The Paper is come; no hanger yet with it; only the old paperer pattering abt, who has cleaned the windows, done the bit of bare wash-board in yellowish “distemper,” and really made everything very feat, poor old creature. Hangers come tomorrow; “certain to finish on Saty”! —

You know doubtless that you might have Maggie WelshMaggie Welsh, JWC’s cousin who lived at Auchtertool, Fife, provided nursing care for JWC Dec. 1863–May 1864. to attend you; Mrs George,Margaret Welsh, widow of JWC’s paternal uncle George, had offered to nurse JWC; see 40:157TC to JWC, 29 July [1864].—anybody you least shudder at. “Get it done,” is one’s notion: the longer you think of it, the uglier it will grow.
Oh that something of good may get to me tomorrow morning. Something,—if I get nothing it will almost be worst of all. God be with you!
docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [8 Sept.]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Thornhill, 9 Sept. 1864. MS: NLS 608.667. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: No worse today Dear; but neither can I call myself better. The pain was worse yesterday evening, than it had ever been since I left St Leonards; and the night, tho’ I slept off and on, was most restless and miserable. My “happetite” has not returned; and I have ceased to “accumulate atoms.” When weighed today I was found to have gained nothing in the last fortnightJWC steadily gained weight during her stay with the Russells; see 40:170JWC to TC, [5 Aug.].—the wonder to me was that I had not lost!

The weather has indeed been most unsettled and Dr Russell thinks it probable that the reason of my back-going lies in that. But whatever it lies in the results of misery and disappointment for me are much the same!

I think Dr Russell much the best Dr that I have had. He does not treat my sufferings as “hysterical mania”Dr. Peyton Blakiston’s phrase; TC wrote later: “His phrase to me one day at St. Leonards—in that desperate time” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:259). JWC stayed with the Blakistons in St. Leonards 8 March–28 April 1864. as something in the air,—that has no
positive existence. Nerves are real things for him, to be seen and acted upon like muscles or any other part of the human body. If I had had him or such a one beside me in the beginning of my illness, I fancy it might have been prevented from attaining such a fearful height and such a grim hold. Now there is little even he can do but hope in Nature and Providence for me, like the others. but that little he does—and with good effect so far as it goes.
I have nothing to tell. except about my pitiful self.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, [9 Sept.]. Addr: at Holm-Hill / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 9 Sept. 1864. MS: NLS 617.666. Quot: Froude, Carlyle 4:281, combined with an excerpt from TC to JWC, 9 [8] Sept.; Hansons, NE 522.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: My own dear Jeannie, I am very wae abt thee, poor little suffering soul: but I was infinitely thankful too for the wee Letter this morning;—indeed it wd have made me quite glad agn, had not my spirits been otherwise already below par. Want of potatoes,—want of regular bodily health: nay it must be admitted I am myself too irregular, with no Goody near me!— Yesternight Forster and Mrs were waiting my return; quite cut me out of my little nap,—the consequence of whh was, I slept two hours after dinner, and then &c &c. The riding before dinner proves a fine thing however; with brown bread &that,—if I were but regular. There will be nothing for it but that you come home and regulate.

Today there are no workpeople;—I foresaw something of the kind from what the man at first said to me. Not coming till Monday I perceive,—wherefore Helen has washed down the stairs; and we are all snug, while waiting. Mrs Forster had got no ansr she said abt the curtn polesSee TC to JWC, 5 Sept. (too ill for answerg, my poor Goody!)— “Have them done, I said; it appears they will look -brighter!”

If you took a notion to be here before these Hangers terminate,—come: your Bed is standing; can be cleaned and furnished in a few hours,—all things clean as need be; &yr sad floor will look more difft that way than any other!—

Possibly you will have to put up with John, as the bad-best, after all? He is perfectly ready to escort you. I cd make him understand (what wd never answer for myself either) that he is to stay in his own lodging.John A. Carlyle often stayed in lodgings at 48 Brompton Row. He was even
speaking of that, in his irritatns sometimes, while at St Leonds! Poor soul, he is dreadfully troublesome; but has a certn amount of genuine affectn too.
Oh dear, oh dear, what will you be saying on Monday!— God bless you, dear little woman.
docBody.name: T.C

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [9 Sept.]. MS: NLS 608.668. Quot: Froude, LM 3:209, combined with JWC to TC, [13 Sept.].
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Dearest I can see from your letter this morning that you will like any sort of letter better than none. Besides after today come the two appointed blank days.Laws on the non-collection of mail in Scotland meant that Sun. and Mon. were “blank days” for letters sent by JWC to TC. God grant that by the time these are over I may have better news to send.

I suffered less from the pain yesterday evening, but there was no improvement in my nights rest. Dr Russell is giving me some very simple thing to try to lessen the need of getting out of bed every quarter of an hour. Mrs Russell to whom he began giving it, for a much slighter affection of the same sort two days before he gave it to myself is already all right. I might have been all right too perhaps, had it been given me in right time— But it is no good thinking of what might have been! There are plenty of aids to insanity which will offer themselves, without indulging in reflections like that!

The weather is again most unfavourable. wind and rain—rain and wind. Still it is too early in the season to expect nothing better. Do not hurry with the rooms on my account. I should wait, in any case, for more settled weather, and for less pain and better spirits in consequence—if indeed such good time be appointed me!

If that be true about Lord AirlieDavid Graham Drummond Ogilvy, 7th earl of Airlie; for a photograph of Lord Airlie taken by Camille Silvy, 6 March, 1861, see 16above. what honour and gladness it will be to poor Blanche!Henrietta Blanche, 7th countess of Airlie, da. of Lord and Lady Stanley.— Noone else I think will rejoice at the appointment.Various newspapers, including the Leeds Mercury and the Manchester Weekly Times, 3 Sept., cited a report from the Montrose Review that Lord Airlie had gone to the U.S. and carried “with him the views of the Government on the present aspect of affairs, and [would] offer himself to the Confederacy as a medium of communication with the British Government.” Cortachy Castle, the Airlie seat, is nr. Montrose.

p.hi: Courtesy of Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University

docBody.p: I could not answer Kate’s letterKate Stanley, Lady Airlie’s sister.— I suppose they have left Dover Street40 Dover St., London home of Lord and Lady Stanley. and you have seen the last of them; or I would charge you with my excuses.
Good by Dear— I am very stupid and low— God can raise me up again—but will He? Oh I am weary weary! But yours ever / JWC

div3.sourceNote: TC-CAW, 11 Sept. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO CHARLES A. WARD

docBody.p: I thank you for remembering me agn by this kind Gift,Presumably onions (see TC to JWC, 12 Sept.) and preserved apricots (see JWC to TC, [15 Sept.]).—whh has a symbolical beauty in it, in the inexorable much-devouring, often enough tragical, Circle of the Year.

I am also well pleased that you think me worthy to be spoken to on that other altogether solemn matter.Charles Ward’s mother, Eliza Ward, d. 25 Aug. Truly can I sympathise with you. To any well-constituted man the Death of his Mother is among the saddest of all the Events that befal him in this Pilgrimage. I too have a pale Loving Shadow,TC’s mother, Margaret Aitken Carlyle, d. 1853.—pale, mute, but meaning so much,—that will attend me till I die. Courage;—and be thankful for the wealth that is still left you of so Grieving.—— Yours sincerely, T. Carlyle

ps.p: I am now in the last Book of my burdensome thrice-tedious History;—in three months more, I almost hope to be out, and in the upper air agn for a little, there to await sundown.

In yr magazine (Eclectic &c),—I read an ArticlePossibly the review of Frederick in the June issue of the Eclectic Review (703–14), for which Ward often wrote; otherwise unidentified. (well enough worth reading), whh I concluded to be by a certn hand: probably!——

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 12 Sept. Addr: Dr Russell &c &c / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 12 Sept. 1864. MS: NLS 617.667. Quot: Bliss, TC 373.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.dateline: Chelsea, Monday, 12? Septr / 1864TC’s “?”; Mon. was 12 Sept. TC had been confused about the dates for weeks.
docBody.p:
My Dearest,—There has nothing gone wrong here, there has nothing occurred; that is all I have got to say, in this breakneck hurry (too usual!)—I
have not spoken to a human creature, since you last heard (I almost think), certainly yesterday I did not,—sat all day at my sheets new and old, striving to sweep Anarchy a little away from my lips and throat; went out timefully to walk, found no Twistleton (whh I rather liked, on calling), found the Park green &9/10 empty do do; slept on getting home, dined on chicken &Portugal onion,White Portugal onion (Allium cepa), introduced from Portugal late 18th century; the bulb is flat rather than round, with a sweet, mild flavor. Ward sent TC Spanish onions, Nov. 1862 (see 38:261TC to CAW, 11 Nov. 1862), so it seems probable these too came from him; see TC to CAW, 11 Sept.—read at idle rubbish (Meredith’s NovelGeorge Meredith (1828–1909; ODNB), novelist and poet; acquainted with the Carlyles since 1862; presumably his Emilia in England (1864); see 40:208TC to JWC, [25] Aug. mainly), and after almost an excess of Sleep (Oh that poor you had got it, even the non-excessive part!) &a new bout with the choking whirlpools in whh I am wading nose-deep,—here is “Horse Sir!” come round agn. Oh it seems to me, if I had my poor Goody here, able to live at all untormented beside me, I shd be content!—

The Paperhangers did come on Saturday; were to finish, and wd have done so,—had not their Paper fallen short! Today there is nothing of them; silence, and new Paper to be waited for. They have done it all well, I shd say, so far: Drawingroom quite beautiful in its damask, colour very soft and bright,—Bedroom do so far— Oh that my Schatz [Darling] may find it inhabitable when she comes! NeubergJoseph Neuberg, presumably recently returned from Langenschwalbach, W of Frankfurt, where he had gone for his health 31 July see 40:159TC to JAC, 1 Aug. is at the door, suddenly emerged;—sauntering to &fro till I come.

closer.salute: May God, in his mercy, grant me good news of Thee tomorrow, oh thou dear suffering one! /

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [12 Sept.]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Thornhill, 12 Sept. 1864. MS: NLS 608.669. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Dearest—you will be wondering how the blank days have passed with me—much like the previous week—not better—but not worse; except saturday evening, when the pain was worse than any time since I have been here. my nights continue painfully restless, tho’ not wholly without sleep.
To-day is dry and bright, with a little frost in the air. Frost does not seem now to have so bad an effect on me as damp; indeed all the Drs say damp is the worst sort of atmosphere for neuralgia

My spirits are terribly crushed down by this relapse. I dont know that I was
ever more depressed in all my illness. The few weeks of relief from that maddening irritation had made it like a new and worse horror when it returned on me.

Surely, surely these wretched paper hangers will get done early this week! I never contemplated the thing lasting above two or three days. Let all the pictures in the Drawingroom as well as in my bed-room and closet lie heaped up till I am there to direct the hanging of them. I may be up to that much surely?— Also tell the paper hanger to leave all the odd pieces—they are needed for repairing in case of accidents. It may not be i that will ever need them—but some one will.

I have a note from Jane at DumfriesTC’s sister Jean Aitken. inviting me to pay her “a composed visit of a week or two”—quite too late even had the thing been otherwise feasable. All my strength, and more, will be needed to get myself straight home. My AuntsJWC’s aunts Ann, Elizabeth, and Grace Welsh in Morningside, Edinburgh. too wished me to try Morningside; when they “would get me to see SimpsonJames Young Simpson, Edinburgh physician and obstetrician. who had made cures where all other Drs had failed.” But there is no hope for me in Simpson, or any other mortal Physicians.

Jane says “young JamesJean Aitken’s son James who lived in London. had been to Chelsea last Monday and found his uncle very cheery and well.” “Maybe he was nae great joodge”!Coterie speech (probably from a family saying); see 30:218JWC’s Journal, 18 Nov. 1855, and 33:255JWC to TC, [27 June 1858].

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 13 Sept. Addr: at Holm Hill / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 13 Sept. 1864. MS: NLS 617.668. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p:
Darling, Thank Heaven the news is at least not worse; in my weak humour I was ready to fear anything this morning! Bullock,John Bullock, the Carlyles’ postman. who always hauls out yr Letter at sight of me, was almost formidable to me.—— I do think, Dear, you make too much of that bit of return of the old monster; did not we always expect returns? The horrible Thing does not quit its hold except by degrees. Oh rally and come home to me: perhaps the Journey itself will do you good instead of hurting you (according to yr terror,—poor little soul, how very natural a terror! Whh strongest soul of might not shudder, with yr experience!)— John writes nothing to me; evidently waiting yr decision abt him. I said I cd at once close the notion of his staying with us after yr arrival. It is a great pity the
Goose had provoked you in any way. He means nothing mischievous, I think almost never; but I have myself found him at times. Do your wisest, Darling; only come safe, and all is said.

The Paperhangers have finished! Came in yesterday, while I was riding; and have all cleared off. The “curtain-pole” (whh I never understood rightly till today) is still in its place; and I think we will say now, “Let it stay.” The Girls have washed out the rooms, cleanThus in MS. yr bedposts; FreureFrederick Freure, Chelsea carpenter. is (to be sent for) to come tomorrow, &nail down the carpets;—tomorrow Evg (at this rate) Mary will sleep in yr Bed!— Mary bade me ask (a week ago, and agn today bids, wretch that I am) Are the furniture covers (chair-covers &c) to be washed (“pretty dirty,” she says); and who is to do it? Mrs CookMrs. Cook, laundrywoman; see 40:167JWC to TC, [4 Aug.]. or who?—or shall they wait till you come!— Weather is brisk &nice here; has all along been rather good. Adieu, my own. T.C.

ps.p: very nr a whole Piece of Paper left;That is, wallpaper.—covered up now, labelled &laid by.—

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [13 Sept.]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Thornhill, 13 Sept. 1864. MS: NLS 608.670. Quot: Froude, LM 3:209, combined with JWC to TC, [9 Sept.].
div3.head:
JWC
TO TC

docBody.p: No Farmer with his crop still ‘out’ could look out on the heavy rain this morning with more disappointment than I did! Yesterday was so bright and like the beginning of settled dry weather; and I thought, if it be the damp that has made me worse, then surely the dry cold will make me better again! And here we have the wettest day of all; so wet that the forenoon drive has had for the first time to be given up; and there has been no time to benifit by the change of yesterday—if indeed benifit be in change of weather

Oh these idiotic paperhangers! not to make sure of having paper enough!— Tell Mary when the rooms are done and ready for occupation to take care that the first fires put on be very small. I have known paper to come rattling all down by being dried too suddenly.

Both the Diningroom and Drawingroom here have a brass rod about the thickness of a man’s thumb—all round, at the top of the walls, and the pictures are suspended from these—so that there may be no breaking of the walls with nails— Mrs Russell says such rods “cost very little”— I will ascertain how much—and you might speak to the paperhanger about it. Oh my Dear! when
I have been giving directions about the House there—a feeling like a great black wave will roll over my breast! and I say to myself—whatever pains be taken to gratify me; shall I ever more have a day of ease—of painlessness—or a night of sweet rest in that House, or in any House but the dark narrow one where I shall arrive at last?—

I had two or three hours of real refreshing sleep in Mrs Forsters bedAt Palace Gate House, Kensington, on her way through London; see 40:133 JWC to TC, 15 July [1864]
.— The first night at the Gill, I slept the heavy sleep of exhaustion—and I had a good night after taking the first blue pill, here. And that, without any exaggeration, is all the sleep to be called human that I have had since we parted. Still, it would seem, the quantity and quality of sleep that I get is enough to keep my brain from flying in pieces! And for that I am deeply thankful.

figure.p: Thomas Carlyle, engraving by Mason Jackson, from a photograph by William Jeffrey

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 14 Sept. Addr: at Holm Hill / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 14 Sept. 1864. MS: NLS 617.669. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head:
TC
TO JWC

docBody.p:
