I grieve for thee, my poor little Woman; but I never cease hoping: That bad weather; I know the dismal Border Country rains:—we have had such beautiful weather, too, all this time; and today it has begun draggling and
half-rain, a great flood of it coming, I judge by the violent west wind;—after whh I depend on bright weather, weeks of it, for my poor Goody were she come!

Nothing goes quite by my prophecy here, only better. Yesterday while I was writing to you, the Paper-man had come agn; got down the curtn “pole & rings,” whh I cd not deny to be much in want of lackering, and making new; so he has them with him. His second errand too he did perfectly: that of hanging up the big Picture;—thanks to him for the Little Children drumming cheerfully as before. The Little Drummer ; see TC to JWC, 2 Sept.
And today since 1 p.m. here is Freure; has the drawing-room carpet all down (“very well dusted,” he politely ansrs);—is now in my bedroom; thinks he will have all done by abt 6, when I apply for a quiet nap after riding. That of “6 & done” I rather doubt, but won’t mind. I have had him up to look at my writing-table too (reckless Helen, in cleaning, had broken away the bit of top-ledge, whh was glued after its breakage on the road from Craigenputtock hither)For the breakage during the Carlyles’ move from Craigenputtoch to Cheyne Row, June 1834, see 7:207 TC to MAC, 12 June 1834
. For TC’s spelling of Craigenputtoch, see TC to JC, 26 April 1865 . : I proposed new gluing; “Better make a new piece?”—and to that also, tho’ rememberg yr experience of Freure, I
acceded,—such my respect, almost reverence, for this excellt Table;Bequeathing the table to Sir James Fitzjames Stephen (1829–94; ODNB ), TC wrote in his will: “[I]t belonged to my honoured father-in-law and his daughter. … I have considered it among the most precious of my possessions” (Blunt, CCH 20). TC had asked Sir James, his executor, to choose something as a memorial of him: “I chose the table—or rather desk. … The table is one of my most cherished possessions, and is constantly used by me” (Standard, 28 April 1886). For Robert Tait’s photograph of TC at the table, 27 July 1857, see 32:frontispiece, available in the CLO on the table of contents page for volume 32; for the table, taken on the same day, see 23 above . It is now in Carlyle’s House, Chelsea. whh I told him had not its fellow in London, “lasted fifty years, and may last 500 more, if you keep hammers off it— Oh the blessedness of doing work instead of scamping it!” To whh my dear friend smilingly assented, as a truth once valid.

figure.p: Thomas Carlyle’s writing desk and chair, attic study, by Robert Tait, 1857
Reginald Blunt, The Carlyles’ Chelsea Home (1895)

docBody.p: Mary makes the most admirable Bread I almost ever tasted,—literally so: Brown or White, both are unsurpassable. That is one of the few things I can promise you. Item Butter from Addiscombe is beyond praise: and that is nearly all of Addisce; its bread comes (eaten in the kitchen); its cream only twice hitherto other than spoiled, its “2 eggs” (what a gift of eggs weekly) small & tasteless as if sprung from grass. The LadyLady Ashburton. does not write to me, nor I to her,—or I shd insist, “Stop that, all but the Butter!”—

Oh my own Jeannie, cd you but get well to me! I am old, worn-out and weak; but still getting on, and hope always! Book 21° is fairly under way; not above 3 months of it surely; and then.— Oh Darling, Darling, send me good news (if you but can), Tomorrow, tomorrow!—
docBody.name: T.C.

ps.p: Nothing came or comes but your,—nor do I want anything. The most remote of all men, for the time being.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [14 Sept.]. MS: NLS 608.671. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: I have had a cruel night, Dear,—no sleep “to speak of”!Coterie speech; see 17:63JWC to TC, 18 Aug. 1843.—and today is the Deluge! NithRiver Nith, flowing past Thornhill to Dumfries and into the Solway Firth. is swollen like a Sea! In the window-place of the room I am sitting in, there are three soup-plates, one hand-basin, and two broken tea-cups catching drops! It reminds me poignantly of certain wet days at Craigenputtoch. Thus circumstanced, especially as regarding Sleep; the less I say about myself the better! Business is the safest topic.

I am thankful the paper-men are out of the House. I hope they have left some bits of paper behind them and that Mary has put them safely by. See to
that, and pray don’t forget what I said about not overheating the rooms suddenly— About the chinz-furniture— Certainly, if it is dirty or even dirtyish, it ought to be cleaned and the natural and proper time for cleaning it would have been while it was out of use. A servant with a head would have needed no telling to that effect. But a servant with a head or even with half a head is a blessing not accorded us in these latter times! Tell Mary to pack it all together, keeping an account of the pieces, and then to call at Elton’sEdward Elton, dyer, 52 and 53 Sloane St. the Dyer and cleaner in Sloan Street—nearly opposite RhindsWilliam Rhind, ladies’ and infants’ outfitter, 189 Sloane St. and tell him to send for it, and make him appoint a time for having it done. It is too good chinz to be risked with poor old Mrs Cook who can no longer do the things herself, nor can she employ women who can. The things of her washing that came to St Leonards were most unsatisfactory—besides some good things changed for bad—a new sheet for an old one &c—a good night shirt of yours for some one else’s old one!—
And remember not to meddle with the pictures!

It is no use setting a time for my return till there is a little bit of dry weather. To travel in such weather as we have had for some time would be a tempting of Providence—Dr Russell says I must be very careful not to catch a cold, that a cold in the state of body I am in “would be the fatalest thing that could befal me.” Well! it cannot rain for ever one would say!— Even if it turn to fine weather, I must not go back, as I came, by night— It is too late in the year for night travelling. I have been thinking that, in the day-time, if Dr Carlyle put me into the train at Carlisle, beside some other woman, I should be just as well cared for as with him going all the way.John A. Carlyle expected to accompany JWC to London; he wrote to his brother James, 14 Sept.: “I have to keep near Jane, so as to be able to go up &see her whenever she wishes it at Thornhill. The weather is now very wet, &I daresay she may soon require me to go back with her to Cheyne Row” (MS: NLS Acc. 9086). I did not find him any help or comfort on the journey down, except in bribing the Guard to give us a carriage to ourselves and he reproached me at the Gill for my “ingratitude for all the trouble he had taken with me”!!JWC was very irritated by John A. Carlyle during their journey north; see 40:133–34JWC to TC, 15 July [1864]. If I get any worse it might to be sure be imprudent to go without escort but so long as I can speak and stand what use is it?—

ps.p: Send my regards and inquiries to Mrs Royston I hope she is recovering faster this timeIsabella Royston gave birth to a da., 31 Aug.; she had considerable trouble breastfeeding her son, William, b. March 1863; see 39:108JWC to CSO, [ca. 12 April 1863]. Send Our Mutual FriendSee TC to JWC, 2 Sept.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [15 Sept.]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Thornhill, 15 Sept. 1864. MS: NLS 608.672. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:299–300.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Dearest—our Letter-carrierPossibly William Milligan (b. 1835); see 40:170JWC to TC, [5 Aug.]. has taken it in his head to come an hour EARLIER so I now get your letter as a finish to my breakfast.

Last night I had a little more sleep—not “balmy” by any means—but any sort of sleep is to be considered as a mercy now! Today the rain has come only in big showers—with bright sunshine between. I hear of no harm done by the flood yesterday except the complete destruction of an embankment the DukeWalter Francis Montagu Douglas Scott, 5th duke of Buccleuch. was making a little below Holmhill “It will be a great loss to the Duke.” Well! He can stand it!— But I wish all prosperity to “The Duke”! He seems to be a good man—whatever other sort of man he may be I have heard many nice things of him. Not merely in the way of giving—but—for example,—an old womanProbably Agnes Brown (ca. 1806–64). had an old cottage in a conspicuous part of the ParkDrumlanrig Estate.— All the other cottages were new and highly ornamental; but this one was not only an eye-sore, but interfered with a new approach the Duke had planned. Nevertheless as old Aggy liked better her old cottage than any possible new one, the Duke promised her “his own self” and left strict orders, that so long as Aggy Brown lived, her cottage was not to be meddled with. That was kind—human! The old woman died two or three months ago and the road is making, over the site of the old cottage.

The DuchessCharlotte, duchess of Buccleuch. finding Margaret Hiddleston no longer in her Laundry (Fancy a Duchess knowing what woman washed for her!) inquired at Dr Russell about her illness, and circumstances—and sent her a quantity of wine and ordered that she should be cared for thro’ the winter. After hearing that, I would have stayed in the room when “the Duchess” and “the Countess”The duchess of Buccleuch was also a countess, as the duke had many titles, including at least two earldoms. called here the other day; could I have executed a decent curtsy; but in the actual state of my legs and back, I preferred making an ignominious retreat—

I am thankful to see the Sun again! If the misery would but fall into abeyance again! But I am never quite delivered from it now—never since the day I was at DumfriesJWC had recently spent a day shopping in Dumfries; see 40:210JWC to TC, [26 Aug.].— Not that I suppose going to Dumfries hurt me—but it
so happened! I can bear all the rest, my neuralgia pains, my lameness, &c with patience, but that seems to be connected with the nerves of my brain! I go wild under it. To keep up pretence of rationality is the most I am up to.

I saw in the Dumfries paper the death of Mrs Allan Cunningham—-modestly recorded, without a word of her HusbandThe Dumfries Courier recorded, 13 Sept.: “On the 8th instant, at her home, 18, Clarendon Road, Kensington, Mrs. Allan Cunningham.” Jean Cunningham, widow of Allan Cunningham, poet and songwriter; old friends of the Carlyles; see 10:111JWC to JWCU, 3 July 1838.—

ps.p: What have you done with Mr Wards preserved apricots? If you have no use for them I have. when I come

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 15 Sept. Addr: at Holm Hill / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 15 Sept. 1864. MS: NLS 617.670. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Dearest,—All yr poor Orders shall be, and are being, punctually complied with. The Carpets are all down; look very clean (I shd say,—excepting some sprigs of dry grass caught in the beating grd;That is, caught from the ground where the carpet was beaten. in my bedroom these are swept off): the Freure is just come agn, busy hanging yr bed. By the way, he had set it yesterday in a way whh was new (and whh I liked)—with its head to the Larkin wall,The connecting wall with No. 6 Cheyne Row where the Larkins lived. where the drawers used to be; it gets fairly in there; bell most handy, jamb of the fire-place free by some inches;—gives of itself a completely new look to the room:—wd you like to have it that way? We can easily shove it there, if yesterday was accidt &Freure have it otherwise.— The Pictures that have nails left (nails close to the ceiling are all left); these I find Mary &he are hanging in their old places (the heap in spare-bedroom is quite formidable);—and I did not hinder as to these, tho’ the others are all taboo (till you come!) Paper-hanger has left a bit of border (at washboard) two yards or so of it minus, “had no more”;—shall have, before fingering money. The chintzes are packed &noted:—in short all things go as you desire them: all ready for you, my poor little Dear!—

What a terrible pity these rains! And nearly all cd have been avoided here. Yesterday we had such a deluge as you seldom saw;—but today it is all over agn; skies blue, woods fresh, really a bright nice day. I said it was “trying to rain” yesterday; and to my cost, it succeeded! I went, in leggins &bad clothes into the Park; where there was a dribble-dribbling; &after abt an hour, I
thot of home;—but remembering Freure &my appointt of time for clearance, I lightly determined on the Regents Park, and an honestly effective ride. KnobbsTC’s horse, Noggs. (so let us call him) became very assids, I cd notice; and at the farthest point of the Rts Park, there began whole torrents of rain, &Ks &I got such a wetting as the Solway Firth cd not have mended. Never mind: Knobbs only mended his pace; came home as if running for the Derby,Annual horse-race at Epsom, Surrey.—rains latterly, almost done agn; and not the least harm to either of us. I changed every thread, &had a good sleep. These two Letters you can read, especially John’s. God keep you my own Darling.
docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [16 Sept.]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Thornhill, 16 Sept. 1864. MS: NLS 608.673. Quot: Froude, LM 3:210; Hansons, NE 523.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Dearest—The weather does not mend—and neither do I mend—last night was very wretched—and unluckily a wretched night is always followed by a wretched day.

No, I should not like the bed in that position. I tried it there, and even when the space was wider by three feet it did not answer— First objection, every time the door was opened a stream of cold air from open doors and windows poured right into the Bed. secondly, the view from the passage of a bed made or unmade, when the bedroom door was left open, did not fascinate the visitor’s or inmate’s eye like the pretty combination of books and pictures thirdly I found the bed uncomfortably near the fire, (when there was a fire) both in regard to dust and heat, fourthly the maker of the bed had, in making it, to squeeze in between the bed and the wall rubbing against the paper—ruinous in a case of crinoline! Oh if there were any sleep to be got in it wherever it stands! But it looks to my excited imagination, that Bed I was born in, a sort of instrument of red hot torture; after all those nights that I lay meditating on self-destruction, as my only escape from insanity! Oh the terriblest part of my suffering has not been what was seen! has not been what could be put into human language!

Dr Russell wrote a note to Dr Carlyle yesterday—so he will probably be here today—he always comes on receiving a note. I read his letter and WaltersPresumably her cousin Rev. Walter Welsh. but could see nothing to explain why you bid me read them! nothing
but second and third news of myself! who have my own news hot and hot! The more’s the pity!
Good by Dear till Monday
docBody.name: JWC

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 16 Sept. Addr: at Holm Hill / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 16 Sept. 1864. MS: NLS 617.671. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Darling—I am quite thankful for yr Letter; I was in terror for something worse (nerves &dyspepsia make me quite pusillanimous sometimes,—especially as the morning was pouring):—and here is something more like yr old self than anything for a week past. Oh if I can get the like of it (or a better) tomorrow, by way of viaticum [company on a journey] over the three days!— Yesterday was the brightest driest day, tho’ showery in the morning. Today is decidedly damp; rain gone for some hours, but the wind up &sky grey. I wish it wd dry, and let somebody home to her new bed!—

“Mrs Royston” (had I remembd it yesterday) “is doing well;After the birth of her da., 31 Aug.; see JWC to TC, [14 Sept.]. much obliged” &c &c. I was astonished to hear of the doing well: I met her perhaps 3 weeks ago in the King’s road; thot her dreadfully prickly, parboiled-looking,—but had not the faintest of what was on the coals! Such is crinoline;—indeed there might the cooking of a dinner be going on, unseen, under some of those travelling cupolas!—

Yesternight DarwinErasmus Darwin (1804–81; see 8:152TC to JAC, 15 June 1835, and 9:148TC to JAC, 17 Feb. 1837), the Carlyles’ close friend since 1835. came upon me at dinner; he and “Ernest Wedgwd”Ernest Wedgwood (1838–98), son of Frances and Hensleigh Wedgwood; Hensleigh Wedgwood was Erasmus Darwin’s cousin. (an extremely efflorescent yg gentn of polite manners):—he, Ernest, it seems &the late M’Intosh’s sonAngus Mackintosh (b. 1845), son of Robert James Mackintosh (1806–64; see 30:224JWC’s Journal, 25 Nov. 1855) who d. 25 April (see 40:82TC to JWC, 28 April); Angus was Ernest Wedgwood’s cousin.&another,Unidentified. were lately at Cremorne;Cremorne Gardens, pleasure gardens, W of Cheyne Row. on the Kings Road, returning, they noticed certn blackguards tumble a wretched ugly drunk woman abt,—they chivalrously interfered, but got their ‘spectacles instantly broken,’ their heads too, and M’Intosh’s almost fractured,—when happily Police arrived, &settled this of the Windmills.Cf. Cervantes, Don Quixote. Darwin was the old Dn; did not stay long. Farie also I saw yestdy, “back from Montgomeryshire,”—
what a blessed sight.Robert Farie; TC was presumably being sarcastic about Farie, whom he usually found tedious. Farie had possibly been visiting Charlotte Williams Wynn whose brother was Charles Watkin Williams Wynn (1822–96), MP for Montgomeryshire 1862–80. No other news here; but these two Letters, one I know from whom, the other not. “Taunton”:The letter postmarked Taunton was from JWC’s school friend Agnes Veitch (1801–78), m., 1822, Thomas Graham (1793–1881), Writer to the Signet, now living at Sparkford Rectory, nr. Taunton, Somerset; see JWC to TC, [19 Sept.]. Their last recorded meeting was in Edinburgh, 1857; see 33:36–37JWC to TC, [18 Aug. 1857]. —have you heard the least thing abt the FergusesJohn Fergus and his sister Jessie (Janet) (b. 1794), of Whyte House, Kirkcaldy; the Ferguses were last mentioned at the time of the death of their sister Elizabeth Pepoli (1792–1862; see 8:223JWC to TC, 12 Oct. 1835, and 13:86JWC to TC, 9 April 1841); see 38:81JWC to MR, [14 April 1862], and 27938:biographical notes. According to his obituary (Scotsman, 25 Jan. 1865), Fergus lived mainly in Italy after his retirement from the House of Commons (1859), then “for two years in the south of England.” for 10 months back?— — I like that of yr Duke and old Aggy extremely. An honest human-hearted man, for certain. Oh my Dear what a gallop I am at; and my time is quite up! Refurnishg (Freure agn visible, nailing lobbies) goes on apace.— Oh send me good news tomorrow! Yrs ever T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MC, 17 Sept. Addr: 2 Chlorine Place / Botanic Road / Belfast Ireland. PM: Thornhill, 17 Sept. 1864. MS: Strouse. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head:
JWC
TO MARY CRAIK

docBody.p:
I did not remember that I had promised to write again, without being written to; when I should have any good to tell. The promise must have been made “in a moment of enthusiasm”; such disinterestedness being quite out of my line! I have had both good news and bad news to tell, several times over, since I came here. After the first three weeks I was in good spirits about myself. For the first time since my illness I thought it possible I should really recover! My sleep continued perfectly inhuman but I was gaining flesh rapidly, was less nervous, and, best of all, the irritation remained in abeyance, so that I was no longer afraid to eat! Since the weather became unsettled, and often wet, I have been worse in every way; except that I have not yet lost any of the weight I had gained (within two pounds of a stone!!! As I still look thin enough, that brings it home “to my business and my bosom”Cf. the dedication to Francis Bacon, The Essayes or Counsels, Civill and Morall, of Francis Lo. Verulam, Viscount St. Alban (1625). what a skeleton I had become! On the whole however, could I but compare my present state with the St
Leonards state, instead of, always, with the state of wellness, which my weary heart longs after, I should find myself, I suppose, considerably improved.

I have had every chance here that could possibly have been given me on this earth! the purest of air, new-milk ad libitum [at will], perfect kindness, absence of all worry, and the best medical skill I know of! I must soon however leave all this for the tender mercies of Chelsea, God help me! It will not do to postpone my journey—terrible to my imagination, now that the wild excitement, on the strength of which I came here, has subsided—till the cold weather sets in. Dr Russell says “to catch a cold in my present state would be the fatalest thing I could do—” so I think of going home in a week or two. All seems prospering there. At least Mr C is considerate enough to not bother me with the short comings of the maids—if they do come short. The Drawingroom and my bedroom are new-papered— But nothing will drive away the terrible associations clinging to these rooms. Oh I wish it were over—the return to 5 Cheyne Row
My kind love to your Father and GeorginaGeorge Lillie Craik and Georgiana Craik. Ever affectionately

ps.p:
I have given up novels I read nothing but Macaulays Essays here—but I shall be charmed to read Georginas new novelGeorgiana Craik’s new novel was probably Faith Unwin’s Ordeal (1865). Georgiana previously sent JWC her Playroom Stories
Winifred’s Wooing. A Novelette
(1862); see 38:239 JWC to GMC, 20 Oct. [1862]
.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 19 Sept. Addr: at Holm Hill / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 19 Sept. 1864. MS: NLS 617.672. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Dearest,—I am very anxious abt tomorrow. Today I got from John Dr Russell’s report, whh is no later than yr own,—but has been a considerable comfort since breakfast time. His words I know are solid; and they positively deny any back-going, tho’ the bad weather &c have admitted little progress (not absolutely none):—most welcome words to me! If Tomorrow will but confirm them!—

For the rest I am in greater hurry than ever;—fool Helen having entered to warn me just as the clock was striking 3! I had a great deal too much of talk yesterday, I think; TwislnEdward Twisleton. appeared at 3, took me a long walk round Kensingtn Gardens &c (sky, green ground, red leaves, all things most beautiful, and pathetic, as they look on a fine day abt now): after dinner, I had more work in view,—but I was only half way thro’ my chop, when an American called Pike (a good fellow, whom I think you didn’t see, “American Minister at the Hague”) walked in, fresh as ever;James Shepherd Pike (1811–82), U.S. minister to the Netherlands 1861–66; for his previous visit, see 39:112JWC to JSP, [29 April 1863], and 122TC to JAC, 7 May 1863. and to him I sat talking, preaching (oh me!) and laughing (not in mirth) till after stroke of eleven! All is aback today; and I slept too long. Oh, don’t I need Goody!—

The wretched Freure ought to have come on Saty and finished some tagrags; I know not if he has yet come. Curtn-pole certainly is not. Sorrow on these haggling, baffling individualities! They wd need somebody with a whip continually in the rear of them. But it must end now before we are much older. The weather too is certainly going to dry: in the intervals when long and the showers slight, all is brisk &bright, dust often flying.— — Read the glorious Alderley news:TC refers to the engagements of Kate and Rosalind Stanley, although Rosalind’s engagement had been public since the end of June; see Illustrated London News, 2 July and Mitford, Stanleys of Alderley 299; see also 40:148TC to JWC, 25 July.—alas, I shall have some word of writing there too; woe’s
me. Amberley is Earl Russell’s Son &Heir,Kate m., 8 Nov., John Russell, Viscount Amberley, son of Lord John Russell, politician, foreign secretary 1859–65, prime minister 1846–52 and 1865–66. For a photograph of Kate, taken by Camille Silvy, 1860, see 33above. a good kind of fellow I thot; so is Howard, and will be Earl of Carlisle if he live.Rosalind m., 4 Oct., George James Howard, nephew of George William Frederick Howard (1802–64; ODNB), 7th earl of Carlisle, who d. unmarried; there were two other uncles between George and the title, both childless; he succeeded to the peerage 1889. Kate wrote to their sister Maude, 3 Sept., about their crossing from Ostend: “George &Rosalind sat side by side on a bench, leaning on one another &alternately sick or in company” (Mitford, Stanleys of Alderley 300). Victors Lady StanleyThat is, victorious in getting her das. married well. Lady Palmerston (1787–1869), wrote to Lady Stanley, 28 Sept.: “your hands must be quite full with this double love story” (Mitford, Stanleys of Alderley 301). “Yrs Yours”: thus in MS.— — Oh my Darling, may Heaven enable you to send me good news tomorrow. Yrs yours T.C.

p.hi: Courtesy of Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [19 Sept.]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Thornhill, 19 Sept. 1864. MS: NLS 608.674. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:301–2 inc.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: There is nothing new to tell, Dear. I continue to have wretched nights—my nights have never been to be called good even when at my best here; but for the last week they have been even worse than usual. My snatches of sleep all added together make scarcely what you would consider a fair allowance for after-dinner; and the quality is as unsatisfactory as the quantity—restless and painful. Still my nights do not react on my days as one would expect. Except in the special ailment. which is indeed the most important of all, I hardly seem to suffer from them! I have not lost flesh, I do not feel weaker, when once up and dressed. Only the irritation is pretty constant not as severe as it used to be, but bad enough to spoil all comfort in the present and to keep me in dread of worse. And to increase my unfitness for the long journey before me. After even the two hours drive in the carriage, I come in every day, uncertain whether I had not better have wanted the air and exercise, than have increased my discomfort to such a degree. Last night I took a blue pill—but it did no good— I lay awake till between four and five after— But neither does it seem to have done any harm. Often when I am lying tossing on my bed the words of poor bewildered Mr BarnesDr. Alfred Barnes. seem spoken in my ear—” You will never get rid of it! never! never!”—

But I had better speak of somebody else—“The Duke”?The duke of Buccleuch; see JWC to TC, [15 Sept.]. An old soldier called Sandy FergussonSandy Ferguson (ca. 1800–68), living on the Drumlanrig estate. occupied one of his cottages— His business was hand-loom weaving (!) his recreation writing down old legends about places in the neighbourhood; and carving sticks and other things, from the Dukes trees. He had presented one of his sticks to the Duke. Some years ago great depradations were committed in the Drumlanrig woods—and an edict was issued that nobody should meddle with the trees, under penalty. On his way from DabtonDabton, estate 1½ mi. (2.5 km.) N of Thornhill. where the Duke had been settling this with the Factor he bethought him of old Sandy—and the minute he got off his horse, he wrote a note to Mr Maxwell,William Maxwell (1807–63; see 39:142JWC to MR, [3 June 1863]), duke of Buccleuch’s factor at Thornhill. and sent it back by his groom,Unidentified further. to the effect that “Sandy Fergusson was to be made free of the woods and have leave to cut as many sticks as ever he pleased.”

Now I will tell you what Mrs Russell has just said of her housemaid’s Father,The housemaid Mary, of whom JWC had become very fond; see JWC to TC, 29 Sept.; Mary’s father, Gabriel, is unidentified further. and then conclude “He is a real excellent man old Gabriel, He is just the Man among them all (meaning the people of his clachan)! He has help for all needs. He kills their pigs for them; he prays with them in illness; and he shaves their heads—when that’s the thing in hand!!”
Thanks for the Mutual friendsSee TC to JWC, 2 Sept.—Mrs Russell will be glad of them.
The Taunton letter was from Mrs Grahame (Agnes Veitch of Hadd!) who lives now in an old Rectory near Taunton

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 19 Sept. MS: NLS 526.18. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
I have a word from you today with the Enclosures (R.’sProbably Dr. Russell’s note to John A. Carlyle of 15 Sept.; see JWC to TC, [16 Sept.]. is better than I hoped); &some days ago there came a very welcome letter, whh nothing but my perpetual hurry kept me from acknowledging at once. I do hope Jane &you will be able to arrange some reasonable plan of getting her safely landed back to me here: oh forget all rubs there may have been or may be; and do yr
very wisest for my behoof! I know [not]Word omitted. that by writing myself I can in any way better the matter; I might worsen it more easily! If you had been coming to live in London here naturally, it wd have been plain, “Come together all the way”;—but as it is, Jane seemed to think, If you cd see her into a Ladies Carriage at Carlisle, it wd do,—and I cd be waiting in Euston Square. I am afraid London has few resources for you at prest, &that Edinr takes the shine out of it? I myself till this Book get done (whh it will surely “in Decr”!) am good for little. Consider well; &do your wisest for me!—

I am not in worse health than usual (except for the unripe vegetables, now nearly done!)—but often enough in a gloom of spirits rather beyond common. Printer RobsonCharles Robson, previously of Robson &Levey, now of Robson &Son. is still haggling upon the last hair of the tailPresumably meaning the final pages of bk. 20. of Book 20°—tho I am, I shd think fairly 2 sheets into Book 21° (Chap II nearly done);—after whh Chap III (Poland a bad chapter), whh will give fash, fash; and no more of much trouble all the way. There are not now 300 pages not done. Oh what a blessing; deliverance from bondage worse than Egyptn, than Algerine!TC refers to the Egyptians keeping the Jews as slaves and Algerian pirates keeping European captives as slaves; see 37:135TC to JCA, 16 March 1861.— Thank Jean for her cheery kindly Letter of this morning: Good be among you one &all. Yr affecte
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p: That Letter got dirtied in the rain of Saty night: I suppose it to be from Jenny.Probably from Jenny Scott, their brother James’s da., now married and living in Birmingham; John A. Carlyle wrote to James Carlyle, 14 Sept.: “I think you told me that you expected Jenny from Birmingham some time this month; &I should like to see her whenever she does come” (MS: NLS Acc. 9086); or possibly from their sister in Canada, Janet Hanning, whom they called Jenny. You can still read it, no doubt.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [20 Sept.]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Thornhill, 20 Sept. 1864. MS: NLS 608.675. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p:
There won’t be much peace for writing today. It is the day of the Thornhill cattle-show flower-show &c &c. Dr Russell is Secretary, a Judge, and what not?The Dumfries Courier reported, 27 Sept.: “The 27th annual exhibition of stock and dairy produce … took place at Thornhill on Tuesday last … . As has always been the case at Thornhill, all the arrangements for the show were perfect, or nearly so, for which the secretary, Dr. Russell, and the committee of management are entitled to great praise.” And Dr Carlyle, with his signal talent for being always mal a-propos
arrived at breakfast time, just after the Doctor had left and I still in bed— He is gone after him to Thornhill. And Dr Russell wont have a moment’s time for him! so he will return here in the midst of my writing.

The Blue pill may be gazzetted a Bankrupt—“no effects”—good or bad—— Didn’t I say he would interrupt me— He is here again—and gone to walk in the garden “till I have finished”— “You will be done in a few minutes I suppose”!

When Dr Russell told me he had written to Dr Carlyle that I had “kept my ground”—I said; “God forgive you”! I meant that he didn’t know the sort of wretched nights I was passing, or the misery I was enduring from the increased irritation. I don’t say much about my nights except to you. People get to be such bores with their “sleeplessness”! Most People thinking to themselves, like Dr Carlyle—“Oh perhaps you sleep more than you are aware of!! Why didn’t you ring sooner for your breakfast, if you were really all the night awake”? And as to the irritation; I am ashamed to complain about that to a man, more than I can possibly help, and the positive fact that I have not lost flesh, but rather gained, is there, to set against my unfavourable statements about myself.
I wish much for a little settled weather, and a little respite from the misery, that I might start on my journey at least, under favourable auspices.

Happy! thrice happy Lady Stanley three daughters Countesses,The Stanleys’ second da., Henrietta Blanche, was the countess of Airlie. (present or future)! “for virtue ever is its own reward unless something very particular occur to prevent it!”Coterie speech; see 25:188–89JWC to TC, 2 Sept. [1850]. As in Maud’s case—who is really, I think the cleverest and sincerest of the lotMaude Stanley never married; she became a noted philanthropist, particularly involved in the welfare of young, working-class women. For a photograph of her, taken by Camille Silvy, 19 March 1861, see 37above.— One of the Duke’s daughters is going to be married to Schomberg Kerr Lord Lothian’s next brother—“a good marriage as he will be the future Marquis.”Lady Victoria Alexandria Scott, da. of the duke of Buccleuch, m., 1865, Schomberg Henry Kerr, later the 9th marquess of Lothian on the death, 1870, of his brother William Schomberg Robert Kerr, 8th marquess of Lothian, who was an invalid. Poor young Lord Lothian! and still more, or as much to be pitied, poor young Lady Lothian!The Carlyles were friendly with Lord and Lady Lothian; see 39:167JWC to MR, 9 July [1863], and 187JWC to MR, 16 Sept. 1863.— Good by

p.hi: Courtesy of Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 20 Sept. Addr: Dr Russell &c &c / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 20 Sept. 1864. MS: NLS 617.673. Quot: Froude, Carlyle 4:281.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p:
Alas my poor little Jeannie, you are too evidtly suffering much, and have a great deal of misery to conquer, every 4 and 20 hours: and I cannot help you at all;—the only thing I can do is to wish you here agn such as you are; quiet at yr own chimney nook, where it wd be new life to me to see you sitting never so lame, if not quite too miserable, and in pain unendurable. Endurable or not, we two and no other body are the natural bearers of it!—— Miss Bromley’sCaroline Davenport Bromley; for a photograph of her, see 39; it was possibly taken in 1863, at the same time as her dog Spark (see 39:201JWC to LLA, [22 Sept. 1863]) whose photograph followed Miss Bromley’s in vol. 2 of JWC’s photograph albums. acct of The Grange and Lady A is interestg to my curiosity and otherwise: I have not been able to understand why for a long time back Lady A sent no word, not even distinctly where she was;—I am very sorry to learn what the reason is; and figure all those chagrins, indignatns, Anti-Baring Controversies, &c with a real distress to think of them.For Lady Ashburton’s conflict with the Barings, see 40:113–14TC to LLA, 5 June; Lady Ashburton finally left The Grange in “the late summer of 1864” (Surtees, Ludovisi 109), presumably about this time.
Caroline Davenport Bromley, ca. 1863
Courtesy of Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University

Of myself there is nothing to record, but a gallop of excellence yesty, an evg to myself altogr (almost incapable, not quite); &a walk under the shining skies betn 12 and 1 a.m. The weather is as beautiful as it can be. Silent strangely (when the infernal Cockneyisms sink away); so silent, brillt, sad, one is like to greet looking at it. I rode to that Devil Freure; not discoverable: Helen went in the evg; “sure to be here at 9 a.m.” (wifeAnn Freure. said);—has not come. Nor indeed has the window “Pole” nor anybody: so that it is, at bottom, all one!——

That of Sandy Ferguson is also quite attaching. I delight to read “Gabriel”See JWC to TC, [19 Sept.]. and it the more, for the life a certain transcriber (in spite of her own sore burden) has put into them!
Good little Woman!—— Yrs ever T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [21 Sept.]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Thornhill, 21 Sept. 1864. MS: NLS 608.676. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Oh my Dear! I should like so much to have something pleasant to tell you, in return for your nice little letters! But there is nothing new! no better night!—no better day! neither am I worse;—making allowance for the ColisynthJWC’s question mark. Citrullus colocynthis, commonly known as colocynth, or bitter-apple; Mediterranean fruit used as a laxative. pill, taken last night, to try and wake up the Blue-pill, unfortunately gone to sleep! I wish that when my education was going on there had been wise women appointed to give a course of lectures to young Ladies on The Bowels! With all the wish in the world to pay the “particular attention” to them (the Bowels) which Dr Russell recommends; I am so much in the dark as to the whole matter, that I don’t know when to take physic and when to let it alone. When I came here first, I was nearly having an attack of jaundice, from the mistaken idea that these same perplexing bowels had returned to a state of primeval innocence! Now, the new lights let in on me have not cleared my mind on the subject, only unsettled and bewildered it! Medical Books, with the most fascinating Titles, lie about in plenty; inviting me to inform myself about every mischance the Human Bowels and Human Body, generally, is exposed to. In old times I should have thought myself in clover as to “mental nourishment!”See 1:382TC to JBW, 1 Sept. 1821. — Now I dare not—touch one of these Books—for “reasons which it may be interesting not to state.”Coterie speech; see 30:209JWC’s Journal, 31 Oct. 1855.

And so I think perhaps that brace of pills had better have been let alone. But I was so anxious to try anything to help the irritation; both because it is an unendurable thing, and because it frightens me with respect to my journey. When I came from London I happened to have had a good sleep, and to be wonderfully delivered from the usual torment. I now only wait for some trifling improvement on my nights, and some consequent lessening of the misery by day, to set out— But in any case I must return soon—probably next week— Tell Mary to sleep in my bed till I come and to put the wool mattrass uppermost.

The sun has just broke thro’ the clouds that have been dropping all morning! and I must go and hobble backwards and forwards a little on the gravel— The sheep have to be “dipped” before we drive today.
God bless you Dear

ps.p: The Tenant of Craigenputtoch got the prize for salt butter yesterday for the third time!John Common (ca. 1827–89); see 34:99–100TC to JWC, 6 Aug. 1858. The Dumfries Courier reported, 27 Sept.: “cured butter class. 1. Mr. Common, Craigenputtoch.”

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 21 Sept. Addr: at Holm Hill / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 21 Sept. 1864. MS: NLS 617.674. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Darling,—you will be content with one word from me today! I am worse off than ever; woke at six (poison of paltry “vegetables”—nothing wrong either! Except only that my Proofs are like to drive me mad; that it is now 3.10 p.m.; and that I have resolved to have the imbroglio cleared up, and my soul relieved a little, before issuing into the air. Noggs must just wait an hour; he shall have his fill of galloping then, the contradictory disobliging little villain!—

Freure is now gone, gone; has left a beautiful new Latch and keys on the door (old was quite ruinous, &had scratched my finger one night): nothing now but the women speeding to get all the furnitures dusted and in. I wish I knew that there was need of hurry! But no, I don’t either: stay, my poor little Goody, as long as you find it best. What can I advise in it; what can I wish but that it may go well with you poor Dear?— I am not in very bad spirits; success with the Book, good news from Holm Hill, sets me into (transient) good spirits soi-disants [so-called]; but joy is very far from my heart this long long while. Courage, push on, all the same!

John was indeed malaprop yesterday: with the best intentns sometimes unfortunate!Coterie speech; John A. Carlyle’s phrase; see 5:263TC to JAC, [18] April [1831]. He has written little to me (nothing but what you saw) this good while:—if you &he have settled on anything, I shall soon hereThus in MS.—— —— Those Stanley Jubilants, and “Hen-chickens of JoveThat is, the Stanley das.; Lady Henrietta Maria Stanley was known as “Hen” by her family; Jove is traditionally the bringer of good fortune.— I have still their Note to write: ruin if I don’t do it soon—Oh me, oh me! But I will bore you no more with my bothers today. Pray that I may vanquish my entanglts,—and oh that you may have something good to report for me. Adieu, my good Goody. T.C.

ps.p: The Stanleys are done; sorrow on me, it is past 4 o’clock

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady S[LST], 21 Sept. Pbd: Mitford, Stanleys of Alderley 300–301.
div3.head: TC TO LADY STANLEY

docBody.p: I congratulate you on the fine eventThe engagement of her da. Kate to Viscount Amberley. that is ahead; surely that is a hopeful &fortunate-looking thing! Sorry only that the bright young creaturesCoterie speech; cf. “bright young beings,” the Carlyles’ name for the Stanley das.; see 36:214JWC to LST, [30 Aug. 1860], and 38:23JWC to [KST], 7 Dec. 1861. are all taking wing so rapidly—as if that cd be helped in a world woven out of time. But truly the epochs do chase one another at a frightful rate. Please give the enclosed to KateLord Amberley, [ca. 23 Sept. 1864], referred to TC’s letter to Kate, thanking TC for his “kind &beautiful letter to my dear Kate, whom I see you appreciate.” &may she both be happy &deserve to be itAmberley also wrote of his admiration for TC: “I have often hoped that my connection with the Stanleys might be a means of my becoming better acquainted with you, &perhaps I should hardly have ventured to address you in Rotten Row, had it not been for the consciousness that you would some day feel an interest in my name at least, if not in me. Pray do not think that you will have no more rides with Kate for I hope she will still be able to ride sometimes, &we should be very happy if you were ever to join us. / May I mention in concluding how large a debt I owe you already, seeing the intense delight with which I have studied your books, &the strengthening influence upon me of the many elevating thoughts I have found in them?” (unless the “both,” which I believe, be a superfluous word.)

My news from the poor Wife are not so good altogether as when I saw you, rather a falling off, in the stormy wet weather they have had, wh the Doctor gives as the reason, denying any retrogression but admitting that there is almost no progress in the interior. So soon as the weather dries she is to return to me. I am kept in boundless hurry; struggling night &day, by all methods to have done with this millstone of a Book wh surely cannot now last much longer.
I send my cordial regards to AlderleyCheshire home of the Stanleys. all round and am ever

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 22 Sept. Addr: at Holm Hill / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 22 Sept. 1864. MS: NLS 617.675. Quot: Froude, Carlyle 4:281; Wilson, Carlyle 5:552.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p:
Dearest,—I was utterly worn out at the end of my days work last night (towards 2 a.m.!)—this morng I awoke (blessed with sleep, my first thot was
of poor Goody who is fatally denied in that essential, woe’s me for her!)—in fact it was past 9; and I had slept too long for my new day &its tasks. That is always it. Oh how I need a regulating Goody; I do!

They are tearing and cleaning &c in the two rooms: Mary shall sleep on yr mattrass tonight, wool upmost, and continue “till you come”: no fire has yet been in the drawingroom; but there shall; I will flit thither, so soon as I definitely hear, if not sooner. But the beggarly “pole” seems not to be “lackered” yet, the fractn of border not forthcoming:—the real intolerability of these people is their mendacity afflicting and insulting the just mind;—no, one shd only call it their want of punctuality, the “puddle of chaos” in whh they are contented to live, poor sinful souls.

I had the pain of excluding poor Farie last night; I knew his rap, and indeed was peremptory before that: “Nobody!” But poor wandering Farie really wishes well to both of us: in my loneliness here, it often seems to me as if there were nothing but nasty Organ-grinding, misguided-hostile, savage or indifft people round me from shore to shore! And Farie’s withdrawing footfall had a kind of sadness.

John writes this morng; all abt railways. He is very willing to come, I see,—if you like to have him! Yes, in that case; No, in every other. He will be to me no accomodn here,—hardly even in his own lodgings,—till I get done with this Book. He speaks of perhaps “going to the Continent” after landing you! Shall I write anything more to him? God grant you a wise settlt, and a safe journey above all.— This demand for an AutographFrom someone German, otherwise unidentified; see TC to JWC, 25 Sept. is almost sublime! I have kept the address; and mean to comply. Adieu Dearest T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [22 Sept.]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Thornhill, 22 Sept. 1864. MS: NLS 608.677. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Only two lines today Dearest, to keep you from imagining worse than the fact. I am not matterially worse; but these pills are still worrying my inside, and I had that horrid neuralgic pain between back and breast during the night, and I got up exhausted instead of “refreshed,” and have been a long time about putting my clothes on. and have since had hot brandy and water, and my letter has to be written before our drive, and the carriage will be round in a few minutes. All which taken into consideration &c &c

The inclosed letter from JohnJohn A. Carlyle wrote, 21 Sept., enclosing a list of various times: “You should allow me to go with you the whole way to London. Now that I have had time for consideration, I should feel very uneasy if you went alone, &in this I dare say Dr and Mrs Russell would agree with me. I dont at all care for the fatigue of going on to London. Perhaps I might make a little tour to the Continent in October, instead of returning direct to Scotland; &London wd be the place to start from. / It would surely be better to arrive in London in the forenoon, than late at night to run the risk of getting no sleep? And the four or five hours rest at Carlisle, with good supper &perhaps some sleep before starting for London, would make the journey comparatively easy; &the nights are not colder than the one we had in coming. Please consider the matter fully, &I shall be most ready to take any plan you think best.” came this morning along with yours. I can’t conceive what he means by saying it is no colder at nights now than when we came down! I was sleeping with one blanket when we came down and I am now requiring three.

If he would go on to the Continent! but that projected “tour on the Continent” is apt to end in staying on, talking about it! I must consult with Dr Russell about the night journey. Oh dear! oh dear! by night or by day would this journey were over! and that I may be able to go on at Chelsea at least no worse than I have been doing, on the whole, here. I shall make up my mind the beginning of next week and give you timely notice as to the day of my return.

closer.salute: God bless you Dearest yours ever—

ps.p: I don’t want the sofa in my bedroom again— Oh mercy! that sofa!JWC had asked that the sofa be removed from her bedroom; see 40:157JWC to TC, [29 July 1846].

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 23 Sept. Addr: Dr Russell &c / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 23 Sept. 1864. MS: NLS 617.676. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Dearest,—Three O’clock has come on me by surprise,—the wretched Helen cannot be made to come punctually at 2¾ (nor indeed to be punctual in anything, tho’ not worthless otherwise), and indeed I thot it was but 2: busy, busy, since an hour before common!—— I forgot what I had to say to you; and the Horse is “come Sir!” Indeed I believe I had very little that you don’t already know.

You will take John I rather conclude; and think it, myself, decidedly advisable. Endeavour to be tolerant to his many anoyances (I know them well), but believe in his goodwill to a certn real and unalterable extent,—real, tho’ far too conscious of itself! You need not be afraid of his staying here. Beyond a
night or two that need not be, nor shall; nay if you wd rather have him go at once,—that too shall be managed.— The nights sure enough are “colder” than the one you had in summer,—unless that one were very exceptional indeed! But when there is not frost, and not rain, the temperature is still moderate, and I think you might by wrappage &eating (even a little is so good,—better I believe than drink) &champagne (have you a drop left? or can you get none!) keep yrself in heat.

God send you to me safe Dearest! Mary was in yr bed last night. The fatal sopha has been down stairs for moths!Thus in MS; in error for “months.” The Venturi LetterEmilie Venturi; for TC’s reply, see TC to EV, 23 Sept. is not ansd, but I have kept the address. Blessings on my Goodykin. T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-EV, 23 Sept. MS: Harry Ransom Center, Univ. of Texas, Austin. Hitherto unpbd. For a photograph of Emilie Venturi, possibly taken around this time, see above. TC wrote beneath the photograph: “Madame Venturi (born Ashhurst?).”
div3.head: TC TO EMILIE VENTURI

docBody.p:
Dear Madam Venturi,——I am very glad to hear of you agn (even tho’ only convalescent, and under the effects of vile surgery, whh I hope are nearly over); hearing nothing I had feared you were back to Italy, and perhaps hidden from us for a long long time.
Emilie Venturi, ca. 1864
Courtesy of Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University

I am very happy to tell you that poor Jane seems to be considerably recovered since she went to Scotland. Fairly better; and hope returning to her poor heart;—once or twice I have had Notes almost like her old self again! Since the weather broke, however, she is getting dim upon me somewhat (not retrograding, the Doctor says, but he admits almost stationary): in not many days (perhaps 7 or 8 if the weather dry) I expect her beside me agn; telle quelle [however so], a very welcome arrival in my Monastery of La Trappe,Site of the first Trappist monastery (see 6:432TC to JWC, 7 Sept. 1833); TC’s metaphor for silence. whh No 5 at prest is.
Her address is
Dr Russell &c &c / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire
By all means write; I have forwarded yr Note, and she will expect. Yr Letters are always, I have noticed, a great pleasure to her.

I hope the SignorEmilie Venturi’s husband, Carlo. is still in this Country; make my kind Compts, and explain (what is true) how sorry I was and am to have been so sunk in whirlpools of sad busss night &day, during this visit of his &yrs. Adieu, dear Madam, it is even now midnight. Yrs sincerely T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [23 Sept.]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Thornhill, 23 Sept. 1864. MS: NLS 608.679. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Oh my Dear! my Dear! Shall I never have anything good to tell you any more? The last night was perfectly awful! The most wretched, I think, both bodily and mentally, that I have passed since I came here. It would be a consolation to have anything to blame. There was rain during our drive yesterday; but for weeks back there has hardly been a drive without rain, more or less. Two Miss WighamsThere were four Whigham sisters: Mary, Jemima Lucy Maxwell, Georgina Helen, and Elizabeth, all living at Burnfoot, Sanquhar, Dumfriesshire. came in the forenoon, and stayed dinner; but i had no responsibility with them, and caring nothing about them; they neither agitated nor excited me. No—I can give myself no reason. My illness is a thing which seems to set all reason at defiance. Where there is cause and effect to be discovered, the effect is always exactly the opposite of what the cause was calculated to produce! So Dr Blakiston said, and all of them!

There is a LadyUnidentified further. now living in the last house where I used to visit Lady Litton Bulwer,Lady Rosina Bulwer Lytton, b. Wheeler (1802–82; ODNB), novelist; estranged from her husband since 1836. Probably JWC refers to a visit to Rosina Bulwer Lytton, late 1850 or 1851, when both Carlyles had sympathetic contact with her; see 25:324TC to LBL, [31 Dec. 1850], 26:5JWC to LBL, [early Jan. 1851], and 9TC to LBL, 7 Jan. 1851; she lived at 97 Sloane St., 1850, and 13 Hans Pl., 1851; she then moved to Brighton, followed by Taunton. who seems to have had an illness quite similar to this of mine; she was in Edinr when taken ill and consulted SimpsonDr. James Young Simpson. and all the best Drs; and there were examinations for cancer &c &c, just as in my case—and no disease discoverable—and one of her Drs dozed her with opium till she was nearly out of her wits. And all went on as with me! only that she seems to have been a much stronger and more thick-skinned woman to begin with. I infer this from her being up to going to Hamburg by herself, in five months after her illness began— I mean however to ask her to come and tell me all about it so soon as I am rested at Chelsea— I was going to say ‘at home’—and the pen scunnered at the word!—
Don’t mind if these poles and things shouldnt be ready, even when I come And don’t let the maids be putting themselves in a fuss there will be plenty of time after I am there.
I still aim at the end of next week— It seems in vain waiting for any betterness (I seem to grow only the longer the more unfit.

I suppose I must accept John’s offer. Dr Russell thinks my idea of travelling
alone “not to be thought of for a moment—I must take Dr C all the way”!— Ach! Ach!— It is a pity but I could have stayed away till your Book was done—
God bless you Dear

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 24 Sept. MS: NLS 517.73. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NL 2:223 inc.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I yesterday saw yr Letter to Jane; I find today she decides to accept yr proferred assistance,—whh is a very comfortable bit of news, among the others she sends whh are rather below average today.

I can give no advice abt the Trains, the Night-or-Day question, or any practical point at all: of course She, you, &Dr Russell will with yr best light consider all these things;—and I need not advise you (what will double and treble the kindness, and is perhaps really the difficult part) to be gentle, patient, patient, and soft and yielding in all respects, as towards a creature without skin in a manner! This you already well know, I am aware; and will, witht counsel of mine, do yr very best in: it will be the greatest favr I can get at prest from anybody living.

I shall not grudge much yr troublesome journey, if you are really for the Continent. A day or two of you here will be a great treat to me, and I shall not grudge a little loss of time:—before Winter quite come (before December end, surely!) I shall be ready for any amount of roving and recreating, if things only go well!

Probably you may get this on Sunday Evg; at this hour, I figure you returning at 20 miles an hour over the ruck of Arrockstane:John A. Carlyle was returning to Dumfries from Edinburgh; Errickstane (also Arrickstane, Ericstane) Brae is a hill about 5 mi. (8 km.) NNW of Moffat, between Edinburgh and Dumfries; see 1:106TC to RM, 5 July 1817.—my kind regards to Jean &everybody. Yr affecte Brr T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 25 Sept. Addr: at Holm-Hill / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 26 Sept. 1864. MS: NLS 617.677. Pbd: Bliss, TC 373–74 inc.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p:
Darling,—I never remembered, in my hurry on friday, that there wd be no more of me till tuesday; and then next morning, what a sad acct came; whh I have had to keep digesting ever since. No wonder you are apprehensive abt
the journey;—alas, alas! Tho’ I don’t think there is any real risk in it, if you take care. The weather is beautiful agn (Jean tells me); here it is has all along been what one wd call good, genlly excellt,—showers now &then but always at night, and followed by such skies. Nota bene [mark well], however, The finer Sunday (yesterday), quite exquisite for the Equinox time, ended in a decidedly frost-tempered kind of night, &there was a tint of fog this morning (for the first time) for a short while. I shd think the Night-journey not the advisable kind,—unless you and John see otherwise: you can judge best. To him, I wrote, Saty (attainable Sunday night); binding him over (so far as politely possible) not to continue. I think more will not be needed, poor well-affected soul; but if it be, you may rely upon it. Oh that you were here, that you were here!—— The window-pole is up; all done &clean (except the two yds of border, whh the man took measure); chintzes are home and on beautifully clean: last night, I shifted upstairs for the first time. Neubg came—to handset the chintz!—(did it no ill, poor fellow): he is grown much older suddenly; deaf, and looks almost pathetic.

I had an immense walk with Chorley,—“cherk-cherk!”For TC’s earlier comparison of John Rutter Chorley’s voice to that of a stane-cherker, or stonechat, see 37:7TC to JAC, 7 Oct. 1860.—the pathetic bright skies, my perpetual racing hurry; all things make me sad of soul, tho’ nothing is the matter with me; sad only so that I wish I cd greet for a day! But can’t the least. I forgot one of these 3 Letters on friday: I have ansd Amberley, poor yg soul, by two words;For Viscount Amberley’s letter to TC, [ca. 23 Sept.], see TC to Lady SLST, 21 Sept. for Germn Autograph I sent an old Proof Slip with pencillings on it. Oh for good news of Thee! Adieu, dearest Goody mine. T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [26 Sept.]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Thornhill, 26 Sept. 1864. MS: NLS 608.680. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:210–11 inc. Quot: Hansons, NE 523.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p:
Oh my Dear! Thank God I got some little sleep last night! for I had been going from bad to worse, till I had reached a point that seemed to take me back to the time just before I left Marina!Marina, the street in St. Leonards on which the Carlyles stayed, May–July 1864. And, to give to that time additional poi-gnancy, I had the quite recent remembrance of some weeks of such comparitive ease and wellness! Oh this relapse is a severe disappointment to me! and God knows not altogether a selfish disappointment! I had looked forward to
going back to you so much improved as to be, if not yet of any use and comfort to you, at least no trouble to you and no burden on your spirits!“Oh, my poor martyr darling!” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:210). And now, God knows how it will be! Sometimes I feel a deadly assurance that I am progressing towards just such another winter as the last! only what little courage and hope supported me in the beginning worn out now, and ground into dust, under long fiery suffering! Dr Russell says, as Dr BDr. Blakiston. said, that “the special misery will certainly wear itself out in time; if I can only eat and keep up my strength, that it may not wear out me.” But how keep up my strength without sleep? Oh dear! you cannot help me tho’ you would! Nobody can help me! Only God—and can I wonder if God take no heed of me, when I have all my life taken so little heed of Him!

John is coming today to settle about the journey. When I spoke so bravely about going alone I was much better than I am at present. I am up to nothing of the sort now, and must be thankful for his escort—the best that offers!— He says Saturday is the best day— But I don’t incline to arriving on a Sunday morning; so I shall vote for Friday night. But you will hear from me again and again before then.
Of course they must get the spare bedroom ready and air the bed— God help us

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [27 Sept.]. Addr: 5 gt Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Thornhill, 27 Sept. 1864. MS: NLS 608.681. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.dateline: Holm Hill MondayJWC misdated “Monday”; John A. Carlyle visited “yesterday,” i.e., on Mon.; see JWC to TC, [26 Sept.]. [27 September 1864]
docBody.p:
Dearest—you must be content with a very short letter. Two of the letters you inclosed were on business—and have had to be answered and be hanged to them! One from MariaMaria Chamberlayne. wanting a character, and one from a Mrs Spencer ThorntonCaroline Adelaide Thornton, b. Dupré (1815–98), widow of Rev. Spencer Thornton (1813–50). at Streatham, inquiring her character, with a view to taking her as Lady’s maid. That matter settled, I have little strength for writing left; for the night was again dreadful bad! and in the early morning I had a spell of neuralgic pain, between back and breast, that left me, after an hour or two,
smashed as if I had had a turn on the rack! Now, it is out of my back, the pain, and has taken to my knees; so that I cannot walk at all!—nice outlooks for my long journey!— If the special misery were driven out by these positive pains, I would bless them! but it is not so!
John came yesterday, and it was settled that we should start on Friday evening.
There are several reasons for going by night rather than by day. The chief one which John does not know cannot be put on paper!
God bless you Dear! wish me well thro’ it—that I need not bid you.—

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 27 Sept. Addr: at Holm Hill / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 27 Sept. 1864. MS: NLS 617.678. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NL 2:224–45 inc. Quot: Froude, Carlyle 4:281–82.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p:
Rather better news, Dear; but still so bad! I say to myself, How gladly wd she send me good, if she had them, poor suffering soul!— But come, we must [not]Word omitted. aggravate the bad prospect to ourselves. It is no wonder, as Jean says, that you are “black ‘based”Coterie speech. (abased, it was a phrase of my Mother’s) “at such a journey lying ahead”:That is, completely brought down at the thought of the journey. but the real likelihood is, it will pass witht essential damage to you, perhaps witht more pain than you suffer in yr chair there;—and you will get to me “on Saty morning abt 10” (John says, who seems in the best dispositns, poor soul); and find me at last, and what “home” we have in this vexed Earth: true to one another, while we stay here! The House is quite ready; really clean and bright; yr bedroom (Mary sleeping in it, every night, and a fire to be, on and after this night) a fine white room witht pictures;—drawingroom do, and looks a good deal bigger; chintzes all fresh,— and heart still fresh, my own poor heavy-laden little Woman! The weather is settled dry (not the least fog visible more), and the nights not so cold but you can easily defend yrself: I find my summer coat (trowsers are generally thicker, but these also I often wore in Marina) still the preferable generally, winter one too warm if I take it out about midnight. Come, Darling; pluck up, I know you will! Mary can make you excellt coffee, do tea (Fortnum &M.’s);Fortnum &Mason’s, high-class grocery store in Piccadilly; see 37:239JWC to LS, [24 Sept. 1861]. you can have excellt white bread of her’s (if you don’t press for the brown as I do), &there is always Addiscombe butter extremely good. But there can be time, as
you say, for all this. Oh may you sleep, sleep till then; and arrive to me unhurt! Dr Russell, whose sound human sense in regard to all these matters is so conspics to me, &such a blessed novelty in the busss, speaks what I have always felt abt yr disease; you can still eat and drink,—and you must; and that, so far as I can understand, is still more vital than sleep itself. Courage, courage, poor little Dear; there are better days coming for us yet!—

I shall not be long with my Book now. I am just at prest in what I almost reckon the worst of all the Chapters in Part Last; and I have cut up, better than expected, today and yesternight. For the rest, no news whatever. On Sunday in Belgrave Square I met the “Dean of Westminster” (innocent heterodox soul, “blasé on toast &water”) coming along with his neat black-eyed (rather bead-eyed) little Scotch WifeArthur Penrhyn Stanley (1815–81; ODNB), dean of Westminster 1864–81; m., 1863, Lady Augusta Bruce (1822–1876; ODNB). (a DrThus in MS; in error for “Da.” of the late Ld Elgin’s whom I think you never saw, and reminding one of him):Lady Augusta Stanley was the da. of Thomas Bruce (1766–1841; ODNB), 7th earl of Elgin and 11th earl of Kincardine, and his second wife, Elizabeth, b. Oswald (1790–1860). oh what inqui[ri]esLetters omitted. &c,—really very innocent people, &really interested in you;—are coming back in Novr; and will then call (absolutely gratis one’s bit of acquaintanceship, friendly relatnship, till then)— Another day, last week, I rode to leave a card for Miss Bromley: approaching the House, I saw her getting into her carriage; cantered up still in time: “Ohee Ohee” (and blushed really kindly)—“just going to Ascot for a visit of 3 days; will call, the end of this week, and hear of her coming” &c. Lady Ashbn she seemed really to be grieved abt; and I have not yet written.

It is striking 4; I had to send Noggs and his Boy-GroomProbably William Silvester, although only seven; see TC to JWC, 12 May. off agn (so belated with my sheets) Noggs is standing with his tail to the manger, impattly expecting me. God bless you, Dearest
docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [28 Sept.]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Thornhill, 28 Sept. 1864. MS: NLS 608.682. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:211–12; Wilson, Carlyle 5:552–53.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p:
Again a night absolutely sleepless, except for a little dozing between six and seven. There were no shooting pains to keep me awake last night; altho’ I felt
terribly chill, in spite of a heap of blankets that kept me in a sweat; but it was a cold sweat. I am very wretched today. Dr Russell handed me the other night a medical Book he was reading, open at the chapter on ‘neuralgia,’ that I might read, for my practical information, a list of “counter-irritants.” I read a sentence or two more than was meant. ending with “this Lady was bent on self-destruction.” You may think it a strange comfort; but it was a sort of comfort to me to find, that my dreadful wretchedness was a not uncommon feature of my disease, and not merely an expression of individual cowardice.

Another strange comfort I take to myself under the present pressure of horrible nights. If I had continued up till now, to feel as much better as I did in the first weeks of my stay here; I should have dreaded the return to London as a sort of suicide. Now I again want a change—even that change! there lies a possibility at least of benefit in it; which I could not have admitted to myself had all gone on here as in the beginning.

I am very sorry for Lady Ashburton. Am afraid her health is irretrievably ruined.“Is again in vigorous health” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:212). See also TC to Lady ALLA, 30 Sept. Pray do write her a few lines.
It has been a chill mist from the water all morning but the sun is trying to break thro’.

closer.salute: God send me safe back to you such as I am everyour

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 28 Sept. Addr: Dr Russell &c &c / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 28 Sept. 1864. MS: NLS 617.679. Pbd: Bliss, TC 374 inc.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Oh my poor Goody why cannot you get a little refresht of sleep before starting on yr Journey! Alas, it seems you cannot; day after day comes the new failure: it is very sad to one’s heart,—but none of us can help it. I am thankful to think of seeing you agn telle quelle [however so] so soon! Tomorrow will be the last of these hurried little scrawls, won’t it,—they were always a galloping time-hunted thing; but they did my heart good! A word from yr living voice, how welcome will it be to me here instead of the Carthusian Silence that has prevailed so long!—

I have not a particle of news; I need not sit writing here;—being due at Robson the Printer’s withal. The day has been most worthless; choked with some kind of dyspepsia beyond common (had mutton-broth yesterday; wrong perhaps),—so that I have hardly had any faculty or clear sense left. Nothing but pottering up and down over Proof-Slips (not yet on the stocks), consulting
Books &c &c And now I have to ride, with Ms., &for consultatn, to Islington to Robson’s.Charles Robson lived at 5 Calais Hill, Islington; his printing works were in Pancras Rd., about 1 mi. (1.5 km.) W of Islington.— I think, if you were here, I shall have a trial of blue-pill agn: don’t I deserve that small luxury?

God keep you, Dearest. Gird yrself up (I need not bid you) for a resolute adventure;—it won’t be nearly so bad as one figures it:—and drop hübsch [happily] abt my neck on Saty 10 a.m. God grant it, and that all may go right. Amen.
docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 29 Sept. Addr: Dr Russell &c &c / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 29 Sept. 1864. MS: NLS 617.680. Pbd: Bliss, TC 374–75. Quot: Froude, Carlyle 4:282; Wilson, Carlyle 5:533; Hansons, NE 523.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Oh my own dear Suffering little Jeannie, yr Letter this morning is very sad, Not a wink of real sleep agn for you! I read it with what kind of heart you may suppose,—in the bright beautiful morning, even Margaretta Terrace looking wholesome and kind; while for poor us there is nothing but restless pain &chagrin! And yet, Dearest, there is something in yr Note whh is welcomer to me than anything I have yet had: a sound of piety, of devout humiliatn, and gentle hope &submissn to The Highest; whh affects me much, and has a great comfort to me. Yes, poor Darling, this was wanted: proud stoicism you never failed in, nor do I want you to abate of it; but there is something beyond of whh I believe you to have had too little. It softens the theWord repeated at turn of page. angry heart, and is far from weakening it, nay is the final strength of it, the formatn and nourishmt of all real strength. I sympathise completely in yr two “strange comforts”; for they both are comforts, each in its kind, and the latter is in no small degree a comfort here as well. Yes, Dearest; come home to your own poor Nest agn; that is a good change, and clearly the best of all. And won’t you send me perhaps a word of better news tomorrow,—as the last from there at prest? Perhaps, perhaps!— At any rate, gird yr soul heroically together; come my little Heroine, and let me see you on Saty morning by my side agn for weal and woe. We have had a great deal of hard travelling together; we will not break down yet, please God!—

Everything is ready here (I think); not a practical word more to be said. I am in the phy[s]icalLetter omitted. way (slightly) today, and not quite so useless at working:
may Friday—Saty be as good days (in the weather kind)! Yesterdy my ride to Robsn &from, with Noggs impetuous, &regardless of his own feet, was wonderful. How to thank Dr &Mrs Russell for what they have done to you, much more how to repay them, beats all my ingenuity! We must lay our heads together were you here. Adieu Dearest, God guide you hither. T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, 29 Sept. Addr: 5 Gt Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Thornhill, 29 Sept. 1864. MS: NLS 608.683. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:213–14.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: This, then, is to be my last letter from Here! Where will the next letter be from? or will there be a next? Blind Moles! with our pride of Insight too! we can’t tell even that much before-hand!

If I had trusted my power of divination yesterday, I should have renounced all hope of seeing you this week. I had to go to bed at five in the afternoon. in a sort of nervous fever from want of sleep. The irritation too unbearable! That clammy, deathly sweat, in which I had passed the previous night, as if I had been dipped in ice-water! then placed under a crushing weight of frozen blankets, seemed to have taken all warm life out of me. So I gave up, and went to bed. At night I took one of Dr Blakiston’s blue pills. (The larger doze had ceased to be beneficial)—and—about twelve I fell asleep. thank God! and went on sleeping and waking till halfpast seven! It was healing sleep, besides being a good deal of it! My first reflection this morning was; “And there are Beggars, nay there are Blackguards, or Both in one, who get every night of their lives far better sleep than even this, which is such an unspeakable mercy to me! Ach! it is no discovery, that much in this world quite surpasses one’s human comprehension!

I have been thrown out of my reckoning. I had calculated that on the principle of a bad night and a less bad, the less bad would fall tonight, and I should have some sleep in me to start with. But two waking nights coming together changes the order; and to night in the course of nature (second nature) no rest is to be expected!
Tell Mary I now take coffee to breakfast, (John takes tea) and to have a little cream in the house that one may fall soft.

And now goodby till we meet oh that I had been a day and night—(and the night a good one) in the House! no mortal can imagine the thoughts of my heart in returning there,—where I was buried from! And my life still unrenewed!—only the hope, often overcast, that it is in the way of being renewed.

ps.p: My little maid asked me this morning, when about to draw on my stockings: “what d’ye think? wouldn’t it be a good thing to have the taes (toes) clippet again, afore ye gang away?” I shall so miss that kind thoughtful girl!

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A[LLA], 30 Sept. Addr: The Grange / Alresford / Hants. PM: London, 30 Sept. 1864. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: I had been long wondering at yr silence; I little dreamt what the cause of it was,—till Miss Bromley’s Note my Wife got round to me! I have since questioned Miss B. once and agn;—yesterday, the last time, when her acct was rather better. Nothing seriously wrong; but enough superficially to cause much misery; “gout-rheumatism” (or whatever they call it) and a great deal of chagrin. Oh dear, Oh dear: the ebullient effulgent Highland heart crushed down for the prest under these bad loads. My poor Wife is quite in alarm; and charges me to write. One word, one short word, if My Lady can muster spirit &strength.

The poor Wife is coming to me tomorrow; travels all night from midnight instant, my Brother escorting; due here tomorrow morning at 10! I confess I shudder at the enterprise: but they say it can be done, with care; and she herself wishes. For the last 4 weeks, since the weather broke, my news are much worse, or rather are always worse, more or less; whh creates a great dispiritmt in me: but I still believe (&even she does, as I see) that there is a great improvet since I last saw her.

At all moments I am either riding sleeping or else writing (and cobbling),—all moments occupied, day or night, to get the Millstone filed from my neck! At this moment Horse Noggs (so I call a self-willed little Horse, not vicious the least and willing to gallop into the Moon,—Horse known to a certn Lady)For Lady Ashburton’s gift of Noggs to TC, see 39:129–30TC to LLA, 17 May 1863. is waiting for me at the door.
Courage, courage, dear Friend; better days are coming: all the days are not done!— One word, if you can. Yours sincerely T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-WDC, 30 Sept. MS: EUL. Hitherto unpbd. William Dougal Christie (1816–74; ODNB), diplomat and author; see TC to WDC, 2 June 1863.
div3.head: TC TO WILLIAM DOUGAL CHRISTIE

docBody.p: The small Paper on Charles Buller (a kind of character, or elegiac expressn of one’s feelings, nothing biographical specially) was in the The Examiner the week of his death,TC’s tribute to Charles Buller (1806–48; ODNB) was pbd. Examiner, 2 Dec. 1848, signed “C.” TC and Buller met, 1822, when TC became his tutor; see 2:4–5TC to JCE, 12 Jan. [1822]; for Buller’s death, 29 Nov. 1848, see 23:164–65TC to LA, 29 Nov. 1849.—Year and Month I cannot give you at this moment. Most likely (but that too I do not know for certain) the Piece is in those 16 voll whh they call Works of mine: if you get the last volume (Chapman &Hall) for a minute or two, there is an Index whh will at once guide you whitherward.TC’s article on Buller was not in his Collected Works, 16 vols. (1857–58); its first publication in a book was in the second edn. of TC’s On the Choice of Books (69) 81–86.
I am in great hurry; busy every moment to finish my wretched Book, and live agn!

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, 3 Oct. MS: NLS 608.684. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:216–18 inc. Quot: Bliss, JWC 318; Hansons, NE 524; Ireland, JWC 292.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.dateline: 5 Cheyne Row MondayTC wrote later in blue pencil: “3 Oct.r 1864.” [3 October 1864]
docBody.p:
Oh my Darling! my Darling! God for ever bless you! You, and dear Dr Russell, for your goodness to me, your patience with me, and all the good you have done me! I am better aware now how much I have gained than I was before this journey—how much stronger I am, both in body and mind, than I was on my journey to Scotland.JWC had traveled to Scotland overnight 13–14 July. see 40:131TC to JN, 14 July. I felt no fatigue on the journey down, but I made up for it in nervous excitement! On the journey up, all my nervousness was over when I had parted with you two! Even when arrived at my own door (which I had always looked forward to as a most terrible moment, remembering the hearse-like fashion in which I was carried away from it)JWC was driven away from Cheyne Row, 8 March. in a special invalid carriage that looked like a hearse; see 40:25–26TC to JWC, 9 March. I could possess my soul in quiet, and meet the excited people who rushed out to me, as gladly as if I had been returned from any ordinary pleasure-excursion! Very excited
people they were! Dr C had stupidly told his Brother he might look for us about ten, and as we did not arrive till half after eleven, Mr C had settled it in his own mind, that I had been taken ill somewhere on the road, and he was momentarily expecting a Telegram to say I was dead. So he rushed out in his dressing gown, and kissed me and wept over me as I was in the act of getting down out of the cab! (much to the edification of the neighbours at their windows, I have no doubt) and then the Maids appeared behind him, looking timidly, with flushed faces, and tears in their eyes! and the little one (the cook)Mary. threw her arms round my neck, and fell to kissing me in the open street; and the big one (the House maid)Helen. I had to kiss, that she might not be made jealous, the first thing! They were all astonished at the improvement in my appearance.
