Mr C has said again and again, that he would not have believed anyone who had sworn it to him, that I should return so changed for the better. Breakfast was presented to me, but tho’ I had still Holm hill things to eat I had not my Holm hill appetite to eat them with. All Saturday there was nothing I cared to swallow but Champagne (Lady Ashburton had sent me two dozen first rate, in the winter.) So I took the Blakiston bluepill that first night instead of the next as Dr Russell had advised. and oh such a heavenly sleep I had! awoke only twice the whole night! It is worth while passing a whole night on the railway to get such blessed sleep the night after! Last night again I slept—not so well as the first night, of course; but wonderfully well for me. and this morning my breakfast was not contemptible. But it is a great hardship to have lost my warm milk in the morning—I thought by paying an exorbitant price, it might have been obtained;—but no! the stuff offered me yesterday at eight oclock, was impossible to swallow!— And my poor “Bowels” perfectly bewildered by all the sudden changes put on them, don’t seem to have any clear idea left, when to ‘act’ or when to let it alone! so I am driven back into the valley of the shadow of pills!

I had a two hours drive yesterday in Battersea Park and Clapham Common.Battersea Park and Clapham Common, parkland areas S of the river Thames. When one hasn’t the Beauties of Nature,Coterie speech; see 35:139JWC to JGCO, [9 July 1859]. one must content oneself with the Beauties of Art.

Today my drive must be townward—so many things wanted at the shops! There is hardly a dish or kitchen utensil left unbroken—all broken by “I—can’t—imagine—who—did—it—”Helen was notably clumsy; see 40:214JWC to TC, [29 Aug.]. Still it might have been worse—there seems to have no serious mischief been done.

Wasnt it curious to have your eternal “Simpson”Presumably Dr. James Young Simpson. given me for fellow
traveller? I might have consulted him at the Carlisle Hotel, with perfect convenience had I wished it! But oh my Dear! No! That man’s appearance inspired no particle of confidence! Your own Drs sensible candid face was worth a hundred such faces as Simpsons, boiled down into one— And he has no more human feeling, that man, than a pig! I could infer so from his way of talking about that poor Mrs Baird.Charlotte Baird of Closeburn Hall, Dumfriesshire, who d. 30 Sept.

Now I must stop; for I have to “consider wi’ mysell,” like the Piper’s Cow,Coterie speech; see 7:269TC to JAC, 15 Aug. 1834. and make out a list of what I am to buy at the shops—before my FlyA covered carriage drawn by one horse, hired from a livery stable; see 39:246JWC to MCA, [18 Nov. 1863]. comes.

Oh my Darling if I might continue just as well as I am now! But that is not to be hoped! Anyway I shall always feel as if I owed my life chiefly to your Husband and you, who procured me such rest as I could have had nowhere else in the world / your own / Jane W C

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A[LLA], 4 Oct. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Quot: Surtees, Ludovisi 105.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: Thanks for yr kind word of news; whh is more comfortable than we might have apprehended. I trust you will get more good of Bath this time; and take yr bonnie little MaryMary Florence Baring, Lady Ashburton’s da. with you, who is naturally the dearest jewel of all you now possess, and will be a constant solacement to you; a bright little Monitress. That the Future is still yours, tho’ the Past lies closed in sacred sorrows,—always to be sacred, sad and holy, tho’ not always so poignant on the feelings as now. Ah me, ah me! It is abt this time last year that we had taken leave of The Grange; and little thot (tho’ we might have been thinking) that the kindest of Friends was never to welcome us agn there.Lord Ashburton d. 23 March 1864. Courage; you must not give way to black thots: the Future is still yours; and noble victories lying in it, if you yourself be noble!—

My poor Wife came on Saturday,TC wrote later: “Saturday, October 1, 1864, a mild, clear (not sunny) day. John brought her home to me again to this door—by far the gladdest sight I shall ever see there, if gladness were the name of any sight now in store for me. A faint, kind, timid smile was on her face, as if afraid to believe fully; but the despair had vanished from her looks altogether, and she was brought back to me, my own again as before. / During all this black interval I had been continuing my ‘comatose flight’ without intermission, and was not yet by four months got to land. To extraneous events my attention was momentary, if not extinct altogether; for months and years I had not written the smallest letter or note except on absolute compulsion. But here was an event extraneous to ‘Frederick,’ which could not be extraneous to ‘Frederick’s’ biographer, never so worn out and crushed into stupefaction. This again awoke me into life and hope, into vivid and grateful recognition, and was again a light, or the sure promise of a light from above on my nigh desperate course. (Oh, what miserable inapplicable phrasing is this! or why speak of myself at all?) / My poor martyred darling continued to prosper here beyond my hopes—far beyond her own; and in spite of utter weakness (which I never rightly saw) and of many fits of trouble, her life to the very end continued beautiful and hopeful to both of us—to me more beautiful than I had ever seen it in her best days. Strange and precious to look back upon, those last eighteen months, as of a second youth (almost a second childhood with the wisdom and graces of old age), which by Heaven’s great mercy were conceded her and me. In essentials never had she been so beautiful to me; never in my time been so happy” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:214–15). as per program: I was astonished to
see the real and considerable improvet in her since that dismal parting at St Leonards. Her face and figure are quite plumped out agn in comparison;JWC gained weight at Holmhill; see 40:200JWC to TC, [23] Aug. She now weighed 123.5 lb. (56 kg.); see JWC to MR, [6 Oct.]. there is hope once more in her countenance, in her heart. The change they say, is to be thanked for a good deal of this; a ride of 350 miles in one night from one scene to another so difft! Every morning I expect to find a great falling off; tho’ as yet there is little or nothing. Sleep every night, the first superlative, the 2d good, the 3d (last night) still not bad,—I tremble to think what the general final level may still be! But let us hope the best. She waits yr coming as do I.

The Museum is perhaps gone to Melchet?Perhaps a collection of artifacts, including manuscripts, collected by Lord and Lady Ashburton, to which TC contributed. For the new sculptures and paintings that Lady Ashburton commissioned for Melchet Court, Hampshire, from various artists of the day, see Surtees, Ludovisi 101–105. This old Puritan scrap has just come: burn it, if it be of as little use there as here.Unidentified.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 6 Oct. MS: NLS 1763.286. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: My dear Brother,—Yr little Note this morng was very welcome, while I sat at breakfast solitary with my thots, whh are none of the gayest usually! I am very glad you find so comfortable a pied à terre [temporary lodging] with kind friends in a pleast place.John A. Carlyle was visiting his friends Elizabeth and John Charles Fletcher at Dale Park, Arundel, Sussex; see 31:110TC to JCA, 20 June 1856. Elizabeth Fletcher was the da. of Mr. and Mrs. Church, Hitchill, Dumfriesshire; they were friendly with TC when he was a schoolmaster in Annan, 1815–16; see Carlyle, Reminiscences 213, 450.

Jane continues tolerably well. The night you went was baddish, not quite to be called bad; yesternight agn was fairly a degree better; and she is out, cheerfully driving, her two hours every day hitherto. I myself have no shadow of news. I am up to the chin in my “worst Chapter;” nearly motionless, and shall not make much way till at length I get quite miserable, and nearly mad upon it,—some morning shortly. (t.o.) Nothing has come for you; only some Ballantyne Newspaper rubbish (by way of “Specimen” to you from Be of what a talent he has)Thomas Ballantyne had recently been dismissed as editor of the St. James Chronicle by its new proprietor, Charles Newdigate Newdegate (1816–87; ODNB), M.P., an ultra-Protestant opponent of free trade.—whh are not worth forwarding, tho’ I have tied a string abt them in the waste-basket here, in case. The wretched mortalBallantyne. came in person last night agn, “to consult me” &c—I had to be plain, and declare to him that I saw only one chance left for him, that of getting some Country Newspr to edit (If you hear of any such thing, you may safely help a little. He does not drink at all, nor &c &c).

Tom Wilson from Weimar, as the inclosed will shew you, favours me with an employmt in Oatmeal,Thomas Wilson (b. 1811; see 26:30426:biographical notes and 39:28039:biographical notes), having returned to Weimar from London, spring 1864, wrote to TC, [3] Oct., requesting “a favour in reference to so homely an article as Oatmeal—we used through your Brother’s kindness, in Scotland, now and then to get a Boll of very superior sort, and should be extremely obliged if you would help us to the needful address towards getting further supply.” A boll is 140 lb. (64 kg.).—tausend Dank [thousand thanks]! If you charitably like (and don’t if you don’t like, for the thing seems egoistic &a trifle impudent) to send Tom the Satur Miller’s Address,John A. Carlyle forwarded Wilson’s letter to their nephew James Carlyle: “I have referred [Wilson] to you for the proper Miller’s address, &he may write to you, stating the quantity he wants &the mode of sending it. … He is quite safe for the money, &I advised him to transmit £2, or any other fixed sum, to be expended in the meal including package, telling him the price per stone is 1/6 to 1/8. And I would have given him W. Little’s Cleughbrae address at once, only I thought Mr L. might be too much astounded at a commission from Weimar. You have only to wait till you hear from Weimar, &then get the needful done for Mr Wilson who is a very good &obliging man himself. Perhaps a strong bag would be the best package for so long a journey” (MS: NLS Acc. 9086). TC had previously arranged for oatmeal to be sent to Wilson, Oct. 1860, from David Little (1787–1866) of Satur Mill, Dumfriesshire, about 2 mi. (3 km.) E of Ecclefechan; see 37:31TC to DLI, 30 Oct. 1860. Presumably David Little was retired and the business now went to his son Walter Little (b. 1828), Cleughbrae, 10 mi. [16 km.] W of Ecclefechan. and send the Satur Miller yr (or my) assurance that he shall be paid by the Weimar Gentn;—and then—then entirely to stop short, &decline farther service of the kind: that will do amply. And don’t do it, unless you like;—I am likely never to do anything in it. “Horse here.” Adieu, till we see you soon.
docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [6 Oct.]. Addr: Holmhill / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire / N.B. PM: London, 6 Oct. 1864. MS: letter NLS 608.685; envelope NLS 608.686. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:219–21. Quot: Bliss, JWC 318–19; Ireland, JWC 292.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p: At Holm Hill at this hour I should have just drank my glass of wine and been sitting down at the dining-room table to write the daily letter to Mr C. The likest thing I can do here is to sit down at the Drawingroom table and write to you. I feel the same sort of responsibility for myself to you, as to him, and to you only, of all people alive! and feel too the same certainty of being read with anxious interest! Oh my dear Mary! It is an unspeakable blessing to have such a friend, as you are to me! Often when I have felt unusually free from my misery of late, it has seemed to me, that I could not be grateful enough to God for the mercy; unless He inspired me with a spiritual gratitude, far above the poor tepid human gratitude I offered Him! And just so with you, I feel as if I needed Gods help to make me humanly capable of the sort of sacred thankfulness I ought to feel for such a friend as yourself! I wanted to say to you, and your dear Husband, something like this when I came away. But words choked themselves in my throat at parting.

I have been wonderfully well since I came home—have slept pretty well—not as on the first night—(that was sleep for only the angels, and for the mortal who had travelled from three to four hundred miles thro’ the night!—) but quite tolerably for me—every night till the last. The last was very bad. But I have the comfort of being able to blame something for it—and that something was my own imprudence. I wearied myself putting pictures to rights, which were hung up all crooked (Dr Russell—will sympathize with me); and then worried myself with the shortcomings of my large beautiful housemaid who justified (and more) all Mr C’s tirades against her! This Creature with her goosishness and self-conceit is unendurable after little Mary.Mary Russell’s maid.

Only think! I get my new milk again at eight as usual!! Our Rectors wife keeps a cow for her children,Frances Blunt, the Rev. Gerald Blunt, and Reginald and Elaine Mary Blunt. and I have a key to their grounds, and going thro’ that way, it is not three minutes walk for my cook, to take a warm tumbler and fetch it back full of real milk, milked into it there &then. I get plenty of cream, quite good—paying for it exorbitantly, but no matter, so that I get it. My eight stones eleven pounds and a half123.5 lb. (56 kg.). would soon have had a hole made in it without the milk &cream.

I go out in a nice Brougham with a safe swift horse whom I know every day from one till three— And when I come in I have added your little tumbler full of excellent Champagne to the already liberal allowance of drink!!! it is to make up for the difference in the purity of the air!!—

The letters Dr Russell forwarded were from Dr Blakiston and Maria (the Maid)Maria Chamberlayne; see JWC to TC, [27 Sept.]. I send them back—the Dr’s for Dr Russell and Maria’s for you—to amuse you with the girls presumption!— “my eternal good”— Help us! if Maria is to preach to me!— Here is a letter from Grace WelshGrace Welsh, one of JWC’s Edinburgh aunts. too— Everybody “praying for me”— Burn them all— I mean the letters—when you are done with them

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MCA, [9 Oct.]. MS: NLS Acc. 7864. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:302–4 inc.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY CARLYLE AUSTIN

docBody.p: I should have liked to give you another kiss, and my thanks and blessing by word of mouth; before going away again beyond all reach of personal communication. But the additional fatigue of going round by the Gill, and the additional agitation of taking a solemn leave, in circumstances so precarious, was not to be encountered voluntarily. I was terrified enough, as it was for the journey back, tho’ the same journey down had done me no harm. But nothing is ever so bad when it comes to reality, as one’s cowardly imagination paints it before hand. I arrived quite safe, and the dreaded moment of reentering a house, which I had left in a sort of Hearse, with a firm conviction of returning no more, was tumbled head over heels by Mr C rushing out into the street to meet me, in his Dressing gown and in violent agitation—John having given him reason to expect us an hour and half earlier— He had been momentarily expecting a telegram to say I had died on the road.
I got a heavenly sleep the first night after my return nothing like it since the first night I slept at the Gill.

To expect the like of that to continue—out of Heaven—would have been too presumptuous! Still I have slept every night since rather better than I was doing at Holm Hill. An immense mercy! if it were only for reconciling my imagination to Home—which I had got to shudder at! For the rest I have been wonderfully well—the irritation almost entirely in abeyance— If it were
not for my feeble, hobbling walk I might be taken for perfectly well. Every body is astonished at me, and so glad and kind—especially the men— They take me in their arms most I have seen, and kiss me and—burst into tears!! or are struck speechless—

I remarked to Mr C that women were always considered to have the tenderest hearts—but George Cooke and Lord HaughtonJohn George Cooke and Richard Monckton Milnes, Lord Houghton. had embraced and kissed me with far most enthusiasm! He answered that “there was nothing very wonderful in that—men have been understood to have more notion than women of kissing women ever since the world began!

I will write soon again and tell you more particularly about us— Today, and all days at present, I am struggling against accumulations of disorder— Yes I should like “butter” very much— Love to James—I hope his back never troubles himMary’s husband, James, possibly hurt his back during the carriage accident in July while driving with JWC and Mary; see 40:141JWC to TC, [19 July].

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [10 Oct.]. Addr: Holm hill / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire / N.B. PM: London, 11 Oct. 1864. MS: NLS 608.687. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:221–25 inc. Quot: Bliss, JWC 319–20; Hansons, NE 524; Ireland, JWC 292, 293.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p:
Nature prompts me to begin the week with writing to you. Tho’ I have such a pressure of work ahead as I can’t see day light thro’—with no help in putting to rights: for my large beautiful House-Maid is like a Cow in a flower-garden, amongst the “curiosities and niceities”“‘Curiosities and niceties of a civilised house.’—Old phrase of my father’s” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:221). of a civilized House!— Oh thank God for the precious layer of impassivity which that stone-weight of flesh has put over my nerves! I am not like the same woman who trembled from head to foot and panted like a duck in a thunder-storm at St Leonards, wheniverThus in MS. a human face showed itself from without, or anything worried from within! Indeed my nerves are stronger than they have been for years! Just for instance yesterday,—what I went thro’ without having “the irritation” increased, or my sleep worsened! as soon as I was in the Drawingroom George Cooke came—the same who wrote to tell you of my accident— Now this George Cooke is a
man betwixt thirty and forty,—tall, strong, silent, sincere,—has been a sailor, a soldier, a New Zealand settler, “a Man about Town,” and a Stock Broker!!! The last man on earth one would have expected to make one “a scene” But lo! what happened! I stood up to welcome him, and he took me in his arms, and kissed me two or three times, and then he sank into a chair and——burst into tears! and sobbed and cried for a minute or two, like any schoolboy! Mercifully I was not infected by his agitation; but it was I who spoke calmly and brought him out of it! He accompanied me in my drive after, and when I had come home and was going to have my dinner, a carriage drove up. Being nothing like so polite and self-sacrificing as you I told Helen, to say I was tired, and dining, and would see no one— She returned with a card—“Please Mam the Gentleman says, if you will look at his name he thinks you will see him”— The name on the card was Lord Haughton—a very old friend whom you may have heard me speak of as Richard Milnes,Richard Monckton Milnes, Lord Houghton.—“Oh yes! He might come up”— Nobody could have predicted Sentiment out of Lord Haughton!—but good gracious! it was the same thing over again— He clasped me in his arms! and kissed me, and dropt on a chair,—not crying—but quite pale, and gasping, without being able to say a word!—

When the emotional stage was over—and we were talking of my stay at Holm Hill—I mentioned the horrid thing that befel, just when I was leaving—the death of Mrs BairdSee JWC to MR, 3 Oct.— “Where?” said Lord H—“at Closeburn Hall”— He sprang to his feet as if shot, and repeated “dead?—dead? dead?” till I was quite frightened. “Oh did you know her? I asked; I am sorry to have shocked you”— “Know her! I have known her intimately since she was a little Girl!— I was to have gone to visit her this month!”

He told me she had had a romantic history— She was granddaughter to a Brother of the Acton who was Secretary of State at Naples.Charlotte Baird was the grand-da. of Joseph Edward Acton (1737–1830), lt. gen. in the service of the king of Naples; his brother was Sir John Francis Edward Acton (1736–1811; ODNB), 6th bart., naval officer and administrator in the Neapolitan service. The family got reduced, but struggled bravely to keep up their rank in Naples—chiefly helped by this girl who was “most brave and generous.” They afterwards came to England; and here too it was a struggle. “The girl” went on a visit, and at her friend’s house, Mr Baird saw her, fell in love with her, and proposed to her. The Girl “shuddered at him! he was a coarse uncultivated man, perfectly unlike her—and she would not hear of such a marriage; but the Father and Mother gathered round her, and implored and reasoned and impressed on her that with so rich a Husband she would be able to lift them out of all their difficulties, and make their old age comfortable &happy, till at length she
gave in. Having once married the man (Lord H said) she made him a good wife and he was a good Husband.”Douglas Baird, her husband, was a member of the recently wealthy Baird family of Gartsherrie for whom James Carlyle Jr. had been working; see 38:101–2TC to JAC, 18 June 1862, and 39:99TC to JAC, 26 March 1863.

After these two enthusiastic meetings, I was sure I should get no sleep— But I slept much as usual during the last week. Not at all as I slept the first night—but better than my fashion of sleep during the last weeks with you.

My bed room is extremely quiet. my comfort well attended to by——-myself! I miss little Mary for more things than the “clipping o’ the taes”!For the clipping of JWC’s toe nails by Mary, see JWC to TC, 29 Sept. Bless her!

I was at Elise’sMme. Elise Delepine, milliner and dressmaker, 170 Regent St. “‘Elise’s.’—Madame Elise, she often told me, was an artist and woman of genius in her profession; and of late years there had sprung up a mutual recognition, which was often pleasant to my dear one.—T. C.” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:221). to get the velvet bonnet she made me last year stript of its finery! white lace and red roses don’t become a woman who has been looking both death and insanity in the face for a year!— I told her (Elise) that I had seen two of her bonnets on a Mrs HenryUnidentified further. in Scotland— “Oh yes she has every article she wears from here”— “You made her Court dress—didn’t you—that was noticed in the morning Post”? Yes—yes I dressed the whole threePresumably Mrs. Henry and two das. Mrs Henry’s dress cost three hundred pounds! but she does[n]t mind cost.”
Dear love to the Dr

ps.p: Interupted in the forenoon and now I am too late for todays post

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady A[LAI], [12 Oct.]. MS: NLS 20767. Hitherto unpbd. Dated by the arrival “two days ago” of Emerson’s letter to TC, 26 Sept.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY AIRLIE

docBody.p: Your letter is adorable! and I thank you for it Lady dear!

I am glad you are coming to London; for I am in London, and shall see you, and I am better, and shall enjoy seeing you! For long I have been in Henry Taylor’sHenry Taylor (1800–1886; ODNB), author and civil servant; see 39:27839:biographical notes. state (as he once described it to me) “incapable of en—jo–y–ing Joy”!

I cannot write long letters as I used to do. I am still too weak! And I cannot
tell you all about myself on paper— It gives me the horrors But come, and be welcomed as a little inburst of sunshine—the least that you deserve!

You shall have that photograph back if you insist. but I pray you to leave me them both!Presumably photographs of Lady Airlie and her sister Rosalind. The photograph of Lady Airlie in vol. 2 of JWC’s photograph albums, see frontis., was taken by Camille Silvy (1834–1910; ODNB), society photographer: “his success lay in his skilful posing of his sitters. … Each sitter was personally posed by the white-gloved master in his luxuriously appointed premises. He used an elaborate system of natural lighting and a variety of elegantly painted backdrops indicating broad landscapes and distinguished interiors” (ODNB). For a photograph of Rosalind, in vol. 2 of JWC’s albums, taken by Camille Silvy, 20 June 1860, see 68; TC wrote underneath: “Rosalind Stanley (since Mrs Howard).” I like them so much! you shall have two photographs of Mr C in return. Who says, by the way, that “to require Rosalind’s (may one say that young-girl-name for a last time?)Rosalind m. George James Howard 4 Oct.; for a photograph of them, also in vol. 2 of JWC’s albums, taken at Alderley (the Stanley home in Cheshire) after their marriage, see 69above. TC wrote underneath: “Rosalind (youngest of the Stanleys) and her Husband then Hon.—Howard (Earl of Carlisle that may be).” to be returned is sheer nonsense! what on Earth should it be returned for?—No!—keep it to be sure!”

p.hi: Courtesy of Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University
Courtesy of Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University

docBody.p: Instead of personal matter which it makes me nervous to write about, I send you an extract from a letter of Emerson’s to Mr C, received two days ago

“I thank you for sending to me so gracious a Gentleman as Mr Stanley,Edward Lyulph Stanley, Lady Airlie’s brother, was visiting America; TC gave him a letter of introduction to Emerson; see 40:24TC to RWE, 8 March. who interested us in every manner, by his elegance, his accurate information of that we wished to know, and his surprising acquaintance with the Camp and with military politics on our frontier. I regretted that I could see him so little. He has used his time to the best purposes, and I should gladly have learned all his adventures from so competent a witness.”
R. W. Emerson
as Mr C keeps all Emerson’s letters this eulogium on your Brother is sure to get publisedThus in MS. to the wide world some day.
My love to all at Alderley who will be at the pains to accept it. And believe me, after those year-long agonies, as affectionately as ever yours
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, [ca. 12 Oct.]. MS: NLS 517.74 inc. Hitherto unpbd. Dated by the recent arrival of Emerson’s letter of 26 Sept., and by the similarity in content to TC’s letter to Neuberg, 13 Oct. Part of the MS has been cut off, probably for the signature; the remainder is torn in places.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: town” cd be, for a ratl man. Ah me, ah me!

[I th]ot these two American Letters (one only, t’other was from ButlerCharles Butler, TC’s American investments advisor. John A. Carlyle had been in contact with Butler regarding TC’s investments; see 40:158–59TC JAC, 1 Aug., and he wrote to Butler, 1 Oct., reporting the improvement in JWC’s health, and thanking him for the financial summary of TC’s account: “I am to acknowledge receipt of the Statement you enclose in your letter, &say that he feels very much obliged for all the trouble you have taken on his account … &desires only that any future Dividends may be invested or remitted just as you think best in the circumstances, he having no immediate need of the money” (MS: EUL). See also 34:265–67TC to CBU, 13 Aug. 1857. worth nothing,—or less then 2 pence!) Emerson’s especially might entertain you for a few minutes; and laid them out for sending yesterday, but was cut short by hurries. Today I take time by the forelock;—the chaos must just wait a little.

Jane continues wonderfully well (last night, I fear, was baddish, the worst night she has yet had, owing to hurries and flurries); none of her nights are good, even like those you saw here: but she always sleeps supportably in comparison; is cheerful; drives punctually her two hours per day: and is in her room by 10 p.m.; I out for a walk (oftenest hurried and cut short) to be home by 11,—and 2 hours silent after that. Two hours of driving is not enough for Jane, and the Silvester FlyJWC’s fly was hired from John Silvester, Chelsea livery stables owner. is always a hurried strict affair: we are all astir (t.o.) astir,Word repeated at turn of page. accordingly, to get her a Brougham, horse &driver of her own (FarieRobert Farie had acquired TC’s previous horse, Fritz, for him; see 32:31TC to JAC, 19 Nov. 1856. &c very busy), and hope to succeed in a few days; whh will be a great comfort to me.

I am myself weltering (nearly thro’, however) in the depths of that Polish ChapterTC probably refers to bk. 21, chap. 4, “Partition of Poland,” although chap. 3 was also about Poland; see Carlyle, Works 19:43–80 and 81–129. (the last of the bad!)— Oh that I were thro’ it! My luckless inside is getting refractory agn, of late days (“Hop pills”TC often used hop pills to treat sleeplessness; see 37:96TC to JAC, 16 Jan. 1861. as impott as bread do) but I must try expedts. My very heart, sometimes I feel, is as if broken. How I have ever managed to drag this huge lumbering enterprize thro’ the viscid whirlpool, wide as a world all agt (read “not-for” as the true word), “agt” or not-for
me or it,—is sometimes an astonisht to [me and yet there is] still a kind of honour in it withal, till once I am fairly out.

ps.p: [MS torn] a beautiful little Note to Jane came from Erskine:Thomas Erskine. honble

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 13 Oct. Addr: Roslyn Park / Hampstead. PM: London, 14 Oct. 1864. MS: NLS 553.269. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Dear Neuberg,—Can you give me the Reference to that passage of Nicolai abt the “Weeping Virgin” who depended upon a Brewhouse? It has got into my Proofsheets: I shall want it perhaps on Saty or Sunday, hardly sooner. Year, Place, vol. p. of Book,—and, of the Fact, at least place &date.TC mentioned the “Weeping Virgin” and cited Christoph Friedrich Nicolai, Travels over Germany, but gave no details; see Carlyle, Works 19:68; presumably he meant C. F. Nicolai, Beschreibung einer Reise durch Deutschland und die Schweitz, 12 vols. (Berlin &Stettin, 1783–96); reference untraced.

My Mrs keeps wonderfully hearty; I tremble every morning lest I find it all altered. Not only a Brougham but Brougham &Horse are wanted (Horse that will both draw &ride, and that is equal to a Brm, whh my prest little Sparrow,Noggs was quite small. it seems, is not). Help if you can!—

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JF, [mid-Oct.]. MS: NLS 1797.100. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:225–26. [To maintain the order established by the editors of the CL, this letter has been assigned a document date of 15 October 1864.]
div3.head: JWC TO JOHN FORSTER

docBody.p: Now that Mr C has me here, before his eyes, in an upright posture, he considers it not only my business, but my wifely duty to answer all inquiries about me, myself.

I have then the melancholy pleasure of informing you and dear “small Individual,”Forster’s wife, Eliza. that I am returned to this foggy scene of things with no intentions of further travels for the present. I not only “stood” the long night journey (they always bid me travel by night) very well; but, as on the journey down, it procured me one night of heavenly sleep; and as nervous illness is more
benefited by change than anything else, I felt, for the first week after my return, even better than in the first weeks of my stay in Scotland. The almost miraculous improvement is now wearing off. I have again miserable nights and plenty of pain intermittently. Still I am a stone heavier (!) and in every way an improved woman from what I was when you did not see me at Marina!Forster hoped to visit JWC in June (see 40:116JWC to EFO, [12 June]), but JWC was too ill; see 40:123TC to LLA, 28 June.

But you will soon be here to take a look at me,The Forsters were expected to visit after their return to London, 22 Oct.; see TC to JF, 22 Oct. and judge for yourself. I hope you wont be so shocked as my CarpenterPresumably Frederick Freure; see TC to JWC, 14 Sept. who told me yesterday; “I am very sorry indeed, Mam, to see you fallen so suddenly into Infirmity! There is a sad change since I saw you last!”— And me a stone heavier!

closer.salute: Best love to Her— Yours ever affectionately

docBody.name: Jane Carlyle
docBody.note: TC wrote later on the MS: “The last then?—I am wae to have done agn. Oh my Lost, my Ever-Loved One! (29 Octr 1869).”

div3.sourceNote: TC-[JCA], [mid-Oct.]. MS: NLS 518.71 inc. Hitherto unpbd. Tentatively dated by TC’s reference to finishing Frederick, by JWC being still unwell, and by Oct. being the customary month for TC to order clothes from Jean Carlyle Aitken in Dumfries. [To maintain the order established by the editors of the CL, this letter has been assigned a document date of 16 October 1864.]
div3.head: TC TO [JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN]

docBody.p: my determination not to be beaten is very considerable indeed.Presumably referring to his determination to complete Frederick.

Practically there is still one thing (or rather two things) I want of you. Pray attend therefore. The first thing is 3 pairs of plaiding drawers (exactly the kind you sent 3 years ago) best wool, soft; and with plenty of room in them, especially in the part BoydTC asked Jean Aitken to get clothes made for him by William Boyd (1811–90), master tailor, Cummertrees, Oct. 1861; see 37:248TC to JCA, 17 Oct. 1861. calls “the stride,”—mentn this latter point to him; the two pairs of black breeches,The clothes, including the black breeches, arrived Dec. 1861; see 38:23TC to JCA, 7 Dec. 1861. whh have excellt otherwise, I cd not wear till altered a little in that part. “A little” tell him, “not too much”: the old drawers were perfect there as everywhere.

The second thing, you must get me thro’ the same Boyd a proper winter Dressing-gown.Jean Aitken sent TC a dressing-gown and woolen drawers in Oct. 1863; see 39:216TC to JCA, 18 Oct. 1863. You; since my poor Jane is not astir. I want it warm, soft, roomy:—Boyd’s last Dressing gn was perfectly well made (breast-pocket with button, two pockets behind, like a coat, &c): And for stuff, I think a bit of
good check plaid, black-and-white, red-and-white:TC was shown wearing a previous dressing-gown in Robert Tait’s A Chelsea Interior (1858); see 33:174TC to JAC, 28 Jan. 1858, and 197JWC to MR, 29 March [1858].—in short exert yr best skill, dear Sister, and fit me the best you can;—that I know is directn enough. I add not a word. The hurry I am in, and confusion all round, are very great! Your affectionate
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-RF, 17 Oct. MS: Hilles. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO ROBERT FARIE

docBody.p: Dear Farie,—Many thanks for yr diligence and despatch. Yr prospect of brougham and horse for us seems altogether good; and we will at once proceed to action upon yr date.

The day after tomorrow (Jane, who is aways on the road by one o’clock, fears you cd not have measure taken in time for tomorrow itself),—the day after tomorrow, i.e. Wednesday, she will (being once furnished with yr credentials &indications) drive up and herself see the brougham &quadruped; her Driver too (who is Silvester our stable-keeper, a very honest rational man, and good judge both of horses &vehicles) will also see and examine; also perhaps, the Revd Mr BlountThus in MS, for Blunt. our Parish rector will (who professes judgt, and has offered help in the matter): if all these people had made up their minds and given their votes, the matter can be at once decided Yes or No. You have therefore to come down, tomorrow, if you will be so good, and leave with Jane yr directions about all these preliminaries: after whh everything will go of its own accord. Tomorrow before one, you will find her; or after 8 (say at 8) tomorrow evg.

In regard to the vehicle, she and her friendly advisers are the sole authority; if they like it, I like it, and all is done in regard to it. As to the horse,—I confess I have my misgivings; and wish you who have good skill in such things, wd yrself investigate farther. A good strong sound horse, able for the carriage; that is the first point: but you know also I mean to ride the creature occasionally; therefore there are two points to be inquired into. If you suspect or dislike the horse actually offered, and know where to find a better at a better price, I shall by no means grudge the price.
In short do yr best for us, dear Farie—I am in such hurry as is absolute frightful; and can say no more.
Silvester drives; a driver &all arrangts are ready, so soon as a machine is.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [17 Oct.]. MS: NLS 608.688. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:304–5 inc., where dated 20 Oct. Dated by Lady Airlie’s visit, 17 Oct. (see JWC to MCA, [18 Oct.]), although she may well have visited on other days as well; certainly dated mid-Oct.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p: Dearest Darling! Why don’t you write me a little word? I dont ask for a long letter—like what you write to Mrs Turnbul!!Unidentified further. but just a line or two to break the strange silence fallen between us, so suddenly, thro the necessities of the case. It still feels strange—and sad—for me when Mary (not your Mary) brings me my warm milk, instead of you, and when, all thro the day, I miss your gentle ministrations. I should be too thankful that I get new milk at all, whoever brought by! Mr C says “it is little short of a daily recurring miracle!” At first they did not make haste enough, and the milk was pretty cold, and the froth fallen; but now it comes frothed up an inch above the tumbler. only it has not the sweet taste of milk made of grass. For cream I do pretty well. A hamper from Addiscombe (Lady Asburtons Farm) brings three times a week new laid eggs, sweet butter, and the thickest cream; besides vegetables and apples. Still, in spite of the similarity of diet, I am bothered about my—bowels, which I look upon as a sort of sacred charge laid on me by you and the Dr! Whether it be the change of air, or the hardness of the water, or some other cause I don’t get on triumphantly on the voluntary principle,Coterie speech; see 32:48JWC to IC, [ca. 10 Dec. 1856]. as I did for most part at Holme Hill (God bless it!) but have to take pills or bits of pills oftener than I like. But for all that, I am still feeling the benefit of change. I have never had a whole night’s sleep since the night after my return; but neither have I had a night wholly sleepless. I have fractions of sleep which pieced together make up an allowance that can be done with in default of better. And so the irritation keeps moderate I have found an excellent substitute for the nettles, one which will not fail me at any season or place—a few drops of chloroform poured on a bit of web-sponge (I will inclose a bit to show you) produces exactly the sort of relief the nettles gave.

It is a wonder I have not been knocked up by the heaps of people who come, and make such rejoicing over me as if I were a queen bee! The social imprudences I have gone into or rather been forced into were wound up the other night to a climax. I had been several times “kissed and cried over” during the day, and I was not bound to sit up longer than was good for me with the two Confederate officersJohn Reuben Thompson, journalist, in London to support the Confederate cause, and John Williams Walker Fearn, diplomatic representative sent to Europe by the Confederate state dept. who came by appointment to tea. Mr C pours
out the tea!! About nine I wanted to go away; but hadn’t moral courage to hobble with my stick thro the room, and raise them all to their feet with “fears of intruding &c &c”—so I sat on from minute to minute hoping they might go away. At ten a carriage dashed up and enter Lady Ashburton and Miss BaringLouisa Baring, Lady Ashburton’s sister-in-law. In an entry in his unpublished journal for 14 Oct., Thompson described the meeting with the Carlyles: “Drank tea and spent the evening (Fearn &I) with the great Thomas Carlyle at 5 Gt Cheyne Row—Chelsea. Mrs Carlyle, who has been for several months an invalid, made her appearance, an unusual thing, as we were told, and remained in the room all the evening. Lady Ashburton &Miss Baring came in after tea. Mr Carlyle said it was his habit to drink tea at the rate of 5 cups. He ran off into some delightful ‘table-talk’ on tea and coffee” (MS: Univ. of Virginia). who staid till eleven!! And then they all went, Mr C walking out with the Confederates.Thompson continued his description of the evening: “Mr Carlyle inquired about the Confederacy its resources, its army, its supplies of food, its powder, and read us a letter from R. W. Emerson in which the Yankee philosopher declared that the struggle going in America was the great Battle of Humanity. Mr Carlyle said he could make no sense of this at all. He amusingly referred to a Lady (Mrs. G[reenhow]—) who had paid him a visit as ‘a flamy, conspicuous sort of person,’ who had a ‘notable song of a voice.’ When he rose to say good night, he called the Servant (a girl) for his coat &boots, (for he had received us in dressing gown &slippers) accepted a cigar which we offered him, and walked with us to within a stone’s throw of the Grosvenor Hotel—2 miles, at half past 11. On the way, passing Chelsea Hospital, he burst out into a beautiful tribute to Sir Christopher Wren, the architect. … We mentioned Tennyson to him, &he spoke of him with great affection—recognised in him some power. … Thought Tennyson very greatly inferior to Burns—but spoke of having known ‘Alfred’ very intimately some years ago when he used to come in hob-nailed shoes &a rough coat to ‘blow a cloud’ with him several evenings in the week. We talked of John Stuart Mill &Mr Carlyle said he thought Mill’s book on Liberty the greatest nonsense he ever read, but that he had heard it was very popular in Russia! … Mr Carlyle warmly invited us to come &see him again, said he should complete the ‘Life of Frederick’ by Xmas, but that he was always at leisure in the evening. And so we parted” (MS: Univ. of Virginia; http://etext.lib.virginia.edu/collections/journals/text-context/cushman.html). TC also talked about Emerson’s letter of 26 Sept. to Moncure Conway who reported TC’s comments: “‘I have tried to look into the middle of things in America, and I have seen a people cutting throats indefinitely to put the negro into a position for which all experience shows him unfit’” (Conway, Carlyle 97). Rose Greenhow, b. O’Neale (1817–64), Confederate emissary touring England and France 1863–64; see 40:87–88TC to JWC, 2 May; Sir Christopher Wren (1632–1723; ODNB), English architect; Alfred Tennyson (1809–92; ODNB), poet laureate; for early descriptions of Tennyson, the Carlyles, and smoking, see 12:239TC to JAC, 5 Sept. 1840, and 19:16–17JWC to HW, [31 Jan. 1854]; for TC on Mill’s On Liberty (1859) when it was pbd., see 35:85TC to JAC, 4 May 1859. At the Door he met the Street PolicemanNot further identified. and sent him up to receive my statement about a dog that had become a nuisance (in the day time happily!)! This was all hard on me. Mr C did not come back till twelve. Very penitent and sorry for me then—
LadThus in MS, for “Lady.” Airlie is in town for a fortnight. Has been here for two hours this afternoon—making me miss the post.
Dr Carlyle is on a visit to some rich stupid people called Fletcher—-formerly Jack.See TC to JAC, 6 Oct. It is to be feared he will soon return here—
Kindest love to the Dr twenty kisses to yourself—

ps.p: I sent Mrs HunterCatherine Hunter, b. Brown (1820–1912), living at Milton in Tynron parish; see 38:149JWC to TC, [19 Aug. 1862]. the Autograph

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MCA, [18 Oct.]. MS: NLS Acc. 7864. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:226–28. Quot: Hansons, NE 524. TC wrote later on MS: “Septr ? 1864 (back from Holm Hill; doing well).”
div3.head: JWC TO MARY CARLYLE AUSTIN

docBody.p: Oh little woman! You will come to our aid, if possible; but if impossible; what on Earth are we to do for Eggs? At this present, Mr C is breakfasting on shop-eggs, and doesn’t know it! and I am every morning expecting to hear in my bed an explosion over some one too far gone for his making himself an illusion about it. All the people who kept fowls round about having, the Maids say, during my absence ceased to keep them. And the two eggs from Addiscombe three times a week are not enough for us both. I “as one solitary Individual”Coterie speech; TC’s father’s phrase; see 9:278JWC to TC, 11 Aug. 1837. needing three in the day! one to breakfast one in hot milk for luncheon, and one in my small pudding at dinner! When I left Holme Hill Mrs Russell was in despair over her hens; thirty of them yielded but three eggs a ’day. Yours too may have struck work. And in that case never mind. Only if you could send us some it would be a mercy

Only think of my getting here, every morning, a tumbler of milk warm from the cow and all frothed up, just as at the Gill and at Holm Hill, to my infinite benefit. The stable fed cow does not give such delicious milk as those living on grass in the open air; but still it is milk without a drop of water or anything in it, and milked not five minutes before I drink it. Mr C says it is a daily recurring miracle. The miracle is worked by our Rector’s wife who keeps two cows for her children, and she has kindly included me as “the biggest and best Child”—and with a key into their garden my Cook can run to their stable with a tumbler and be back at my bedside in ten minutes. Indeed it is impossible to tell who is kindest to me—my fear is always that I shall be stifled with roses! they make so much of me, and I am so weak! The Countess of Airlie was kneeling beside my sofa yesterday embracing my feet!! and kissing my
hands!!! A german girl“Reichenbach’s daughter, probably” (TC’s note in Froude LM 3:227); either Elisabeth or Hedwig, das. of Oskar and Friederike von Reichenbach; see also JWC to MR, 27 Dec. said the other day, “I think Mrs Carlyle a many many peoples love you very dear”! It is true! and what I have done to deserve all that love I haven’t the remotest conception!

All this time I have been keeping better—getting some sleep—not much nor good, but some,—better or worse, every night. And the Irritation has been much subsided— Yesterday afternoon and this afternoon it is troubling me more than usual. Perhaps the damp in the air has brought it on, or perhaps I have been overdone with people and things. I must be more careful. I have always a terrible consciousness at the bottom of my mind that at any moment, if God will, I may be flung back into the old agonies. I can never feel confident of Life and of Ease in Life again! and it is best so!—

I cannot tell you how gentle and good Mr Carlyle is! He is busy as ever but he studies my comfort and peace as he never did before— I have engaged a new housemaid,Not further identified; she did not take up the post; see JWC to MR [24 Oct.]. and given warning to the big beautiful blockhead who has filled that function here for the last nine months—this has been a worry too— God bless you all your affectionate Jane W Carlyle

ps.p: Ever so few eggs will be worth the carriage

div3.sourceNote: TC-JF, 22 Oct. MS: FC. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN FORSTER

docBody.p: Dear Forster,—I rejoice to understand that you and Mrs (&Tommy) are due tonight.The Forsters and their dog, Tommy, had been away for two months. You will find my poor Jane a good deal better (in fact wonderfully, hitherto), when you come down. Tommy must not bite me, nor even bark, tell the little rascal.

Inclosed is a thing that has been lying in wait for you. Long ago you sent it me (didn’t you too the something abt Booksellers whh I have lost?)— I am afraid, a busy man, resuming his tepid masses after two months absence, will find this BurneyForster sent TC, July 1854, some anecdotes from Charles Burney’s The Present State of Music in France and Italy; or, the Journal of a Tour through those Countries, undertaken to collect Materials for A General History of Music (1771); see 29:131–32TC to JF, 18 July 1854. TC quoted Burney’s meeting with Voltaire in Frederick; see Carlyle, Works 19:157–59. rather an unwelcome salutatn! Accordingly, unless you have Burney’s self in yr Library, don’t spend any time on this bit of Print;—merely, bring it down first time you come; I will set Neuberg upon it, in Brith
Museum he will manage it taliter qualiter [one way or another]. I do think I am nearly thro’ the worst of this Book 21° and last;—and indeed it is time, for I am pretty nearly killed as well,—“killt” at the very lowest to speak Hibernica, to Ex-Hibernians!TC presumably refers to the fact that Forster had been awarded an honorary doctorate by Trinity College, Dublin, in July.
Adieu, dear F., then,—till we meet; tomorrow or next day, I hope.

closer.salute: Yrs (in the conditn of a man in flam[e]) /

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TW[TWO], [22 Oct.]. Pbd: Woolner 254–55. Dated by Woolner’s visit, 23 Oct.
div3.head: JWC TO THOMAS WOOLNER

docBody.p:
When your note was delivered here to-day, I was on my way to call for “the young Wife,”Thomas Woolner’s wife, Alice; they m. 6 Sept. and had just returned from their wedding trip. who is and will ever remain associated in my mind with the loveliest roses! The roses were all I could see of her at St. Leonards!Alice Woolner sent flowers to JWC in St. Leonards in June; see 40:125TC to TWO, 28 June. I have since seen her graceful and gracious figure on paper;For the photograph of Alice, taken before her marriage, see 40:187TC to JWC, [17] Aug.. and shall now see her face to face, and if she make you as happy as I want you to be, I shall love her with all my heart. Yes, thank God, I am much better than when I left St. Leonards; but I had best not “crow till I am out of the wood.” I am still but catching a glimpse of open country between the trees! I am not “well” and not strong, am not confident, only less suffering for the time being and with a feeling of Hope struggling slowly and doubtfully to Life in me, like a poor wretch fished out of the Depths by the Humane Society’s drags,The Royal Humane Society, founded London, 1774, by two doctors, William Hawes (1736–1808) and Thomas Cogan (1736–1818); its original aim was to save people from drowning. and this is why that having driven to-day as far as Harley StreetHarley St. is within ½ m. (1 km.) of Welbeck St. where the Woolners lived. to call for your Wife; I suddenly took fright and returned home re infecta [business unfinished]. My back is so weak and stiff from this terrible long illness that I can hardly stand upright, and can walk only a few yards with painful difficulty; getting in and out of a carriage is more trying to me than scrambling over a wall six feet high used to be, in the blessed time when I had “no nerves,” or didn’t know that I had any! Now, if there had been no young wife in the case I could have driven
up to your door and called you out to transact our interview in the carriage. But the nearer I got, the more I felt it too great a liberty, to propose to a young wife, a stranger to me, that she should come out and sit in my “neat Fly!”Coterie speech; see 34:257JWC to MR, 30 Dec. 1858. And to stagger in, after my present fashion of walking, to the young wife and stranger was a disregard to appearances which I could not, at the last supreme moment, attain to! So, I just turned back; more shame to me! If you will come and bring Her here, I shall be greatly obliged to you.Woolner visited the next day but without Alice; see JWC to MR, [24 Oct.]. I drive out every day at one o’clock and come in at three—either before or after these two hours I am visible till nine at night, when I go to my room. I dine at four in the Drawing-room, and have got it so fixed in my head that eating, instead of being a vulgar transaction for me is a benefit conferred on my Husband and Friends; that I no longer feel ashamed to eat before witnesses; so you can choose your hour with the exception of just the two I have named.
docBody.name: JaneCarlyle.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [24 Oct.]. Addr: Holm Hill / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 24 Oct. 1864. MS: NLS 608.689. Pbd. A. Carlyle, NLM 2:305–7 inc.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p: I have a superstition about beginning a week in doing (when capable of doing) something pleasant—and not “unwholesome, nor expensive, nor wrong,” as Lady DufferinJWC presumably refers to Helen Selina Blackwood, b. Sheridan (1807–67; ODNB), dowager Lady Dufferin, an old friend of the Ashburtons, rather than her da.-in-law Hariot Georgina Hamilton-Blackwood, b. Rowan-Hamilton (1843–1936; ODNB), Baroness Dufferin, m. 1862, Frederick Temple Hamilton-Blackwood (1826–1902; ODNB), 5th Baron Dufferin. declared all pleasant things to be! So I begin this week in writing to you; tho’ I have the prospect of being interrupted, very soon, by a TailorA tailor from John &George Sampson, tailors and drapers, of Leicester Sq.; for a previous transaction, see 38:224JWC to JCA, [30 Sept. 1862]. about Mr C’s coats and trousers, a Servant “after the place,” and a groom with a horse for my inspection!! a sufficiency and a variety of businesses “for a wee fellow like me”!Coterie speech; see 30:237JWC’s Journal, 29 March 1856.

I had found a Housemaid and engaged her—her chief attraction for me being a certain similarity in her figure to your Mary’s; but she came, when I
was calmly reposing on my oars and informed me she had the offer of another place which could be entered on immediately, and therefore preferable to mine which had to be waited for, thro Helen’s ‘month’ of warning. When I saw what a bilious cowardly wretch she looked, in doing this thing which she knew to be wrong, I was rather glad to let her go. This morning the Rector’s wife is to send me a woman of fifty to inspect, on the idea of making her my Cook,Mrs. Eliza Warren, who remained at Cheyne Row until July 1866. and Mary my present Cook to be Housemaid. I have a great distrust of women of fifty—but we shall see.

The weather has been warm and moist—often to the length of rain, to which I impute the loss of my appetite (entirely) for some days last week and a backgoingAnglicized form of backgangin, backgaun, Scots for relapse. in several ways. In desperation at a ring, which fitted me when I left Holmhill, dropping off my finger, I betook myself to the bottle of fluid quinine I had luckily brought away with me, and have taken it regular[l]yLetter omitted. twice a day, with good effects on my stomach I think, and with no bad effect on my sleep. Perhaps the air being so much more sluggish here, my brain is more difficult to excite. I mean to go on with it; so please ask the Dr to send me the prescription immediately. my bottle will not hold out above a couple of days, and I forget the proportions of quinine and water. Dr Blakiston wrote, as if in the spirit of prophecy, “should your appetite fail; don’t forget to take the Pepsine” But I never got any good of Pepsine and have always got good of quinine except for the effect real or imaginary on my sleep.

I am perfectly astonished at the impunity with which I do and suffer things that used to ruin me for days at St Leonards! Especially the talking in the evenings. I do not encourage anybody to come in the evening but cannot always keep people out without seeming too ungrateful. Lady Ashburton is still in town, and She has come three evenings last week, and last night Woolner the Sculptor came, just returned from his marriage tours with the graceful Lady who our Mary said “looked awful modest” (in Photograph).Mary Russell’s servant Mary; Woolner sent Alice Waugh’s photograph for JWC in Aug., and TC forwarded it to Holmhill. Woolner was especially trying! for he dropt on his knees beside my sofa, and kissed me over and over, with a most stupendous beard! and a face wet with tears!Woolner wrote to Emily Tennyson, 3 Nov.: “I have seen Mrs. Carlyle … and was charmed to find how well she was looking: she is too weak to do much more than stand upright; but her spirits are good and her state may almost be called a resurrection from the dead” (Woolner 255–56). I had seen him last on newyears evening, in my bed dying as I thought! I had made Mr C bring him, that I might bid him farewell, and he had then kissed my hand, and gone away with great sobs! Forster too had been kissing me in
the forenoon yesterday! I have never in all my life sustained such an amount of kissing, in a given time!— Don’t forget the quinine. I have bought you a Common Prayer Book, which will be sent when I am a little at leisure.
Ask Mary to send me her Photograph and I will send her the shilling in stamps when I have as many.
Dear and grateful love to the Doctor.
Never return any letters or pamphlets I send to amuse you, unless I ask for them back

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MCA, [25 Oct.]. Copy: NLS Acc. 7864. Hitherto unpbd. Dated by the letter’s similarity to JWC to MR, [24 Oct.], and by the receipt of eggs which JWC requested a week earlier; see JWC to MCA, [18 Oct.].
div3.head: JWC TO MARY CARLYLE AUSTIN

docBody.p: It was an immense comfort to receive the Eggs; but a comfort not without a pang! For although it was very pretty of you to send them in my own basket, it was a very great pity you did; the basket not holding anything like hay enough to preserve them whole! Oh my Dear! I am sorry to tell you how many of these precious eggs were smashed!—something like a dozen! I would not indeed break your heart by telling you at all; if it were not, in prospect of future eggs, to prevent a recurrence of such disaster!

Depend upon it; all the new fangled ways of packing eggs, suggested to you, are downright nonsense! plenty of hay, and a paper round each egg is the only safe course. In spite of breakage, we shall now be able, with the six weekly eggs from Addiscombe, and an occasional one, dropt by an exceptional hen at the top of this street, to go on for some time. At the end of last week, we were both put on shop eggs, and i got one that turned me; and I didn’t see very well what was going to become of me, there was so little in the shape of food I could swallow at the time—I suppose it was biliousness, caused by the soft muggy atmosphere that entirely took away my appetite—. When a ring which had fitted me at Holm Hill dropt off my finger one morning, I thought it time to do something; so I put myself on a course of Quinine which is doing me good. Last night however was a bad night, and today I am rather waff.

Dr Carlyle returned last evening from his long visit to the ‘Jacks or Fletchers’; and has established himself at his old lodgings,John A. Carlyle usually lodged with Mrs. Thirza Kingham, 48 Brompton Row. where, he says,
“he can sleep better than in that front bedroom of ours.” It is just as well so; for with the prospect of changing my Housemaid, and nobody now but myself to look after things; his staying here would have complicated my difficulties.
Enter a young Lady!Unidentified further.
Goodby Dear and God bless you.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JRT, 31 Oct. Addr: 17 Savile Row / Regent Street. PM: London, 1 Nov. 1864. MS: Huntington Lib. Pbd: Brent E. Kinser, The American Civil War in the Shaping of British Democracy (Farnham, 2011) 43–44.
div3.head: TC TO J. R. THOMPSON

docBody.p: I have been extremely hurried, with Proofsheets and et-ceteras!

Accept many thanks for yr obliging Gift. Both Pieces are interesting, each an interest of its own. In the Verses, apart from their subject, I find a tone of great tenderness, and of a truthfulness whh verses too often want. The Autograph has been carefully deposited, and is in a safe place, where it will be duly valued as the memento of a brave &good man.Thompson wrote to TC, 24 Oct.: “Reverting to the conversation we had on the occasion of my visit with Captain Fearn to Cheyne Row, and the kind interest you manifested in the affairs of my unhappy country—the Confederate States of America—it has occurred to me that you would value an autograph letter [of 21 Feb. 1862] of our lamented hero, “Stonewall” Jackson, and I therefore ask your acceptance of the one I send with this note. Written upon military business and dated from the Valley of Virginia, where his most brilliant campaigns were conducted, the letter has a certain historic significance.” Thompson also enclosed a “versified tribute” of his own to Gen. J. E. B. Stuart, hoping that “Some evening, when your pipe is aglow, you may find a moment to read the verses, and if they should reward the trouble of the reading, it will be a great satisfaction to one who is conscious of a heavy debt to you for many, many hours of delight derived from books of yours read on the farther shore of the Atlantic, before he had ever hoped to see your face.” Thomas Jonathan “Stonewall” Jackson (1824–63) and J. E. B. “Jeb” Stuart (1833–64), Confederate generals.
Come &see me agn, Captn Fearn &you;—evg is the time to experiment.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [31 Oct.]. Addr: Holme Hill / Thornhill / Dumfries / N. B. PM: London, 1 Nov. 1864. MS: NLS 608.690. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:230–33 inc.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p:
I sent you today the fullest accounts of that wretched Müller trial;The trial of Franz Müller for the murder of Thomas Briggs, 9 July was widely reported in the press. and meant to supplement the newspapers with a letter. But a Madman (our former letter-CarrierJohn Piper. for twenty years) was let in to me, under the mixrepresentation that he had recovered his senses, and remained the whole hour between my leaving my bed-room and going out in the carriage; consulting me about getting a divorce from his wife,Susan Piper. whose “long tounge” was enough to “make him commit suicide.” I began to feel as if a corner of Dr Russells mantle had fallen on me!— Poor man! he was a solid, industrious, religious obliging creature—till five years ago when he became “filled with Devils” (as he says himself) and attempted his Life in a most strangely shocking manner. and he told me today that twice since then he had tied himself by the neck at Hanwell.Hanwell Lunatic Asylum, Ealing, where Piper had been temporarily confined. Not a pleasant morning-visitor! especially after “a bad night,” and with a threatening of sore-throat. I took that yesterday, and thought I was in for a severe cold—but I am better rather since my drive; which was long today and in the country. Yes! my Dear I saw fields of sheep. not white but dirt-colour, and also, I saw a field with a charming lot of little black pigs in it! I am not tied to two hours now for my drive, which was long enough to stay out in a “Fly” costing as it did six shillings! I have now set up a nice little Brougham, or ClarenceThe Clarence, a closed four-wheeled carriage with four seats inside, was similar to the Brougham, which had either four wheels and four seats or two wheels and two seats. (as you call it) all to myself—with a smart grey horse and an elderly DriverUnidentified. (in Mr C’s old brown surtout)!!! I was at half a dozen coachmakers yards seeking that carriage!! examining with my own eyes, on my own legs!! of course I took advice as to the outside quality. Mr Farie and the Livery-Stable ManJohn Silvester. who has kept Mr C’s horse these dozen years both approved my choice and considered it a great bargain—sixty pounds and perfectly new, and handsome in a plain way.“For years before this there had been talk from me of a brougham for her; to which she listened with a pleased look, but always in perfect silence. Latterly I had been more stringent and immediate upon it; and had not I been so smothered under ‘Frederick,’ the poor little enterprise (finance now clearly permitting) would surely have been achieved. Alas, why was not it? That terrible street accident, for instance, might have been avoided. But she continued silent when I spoke or proposed, with a noble delicacy all her own; forbore to take the least step; would not even by a shake of the head, or the least twinkle of satire in her eyes, provoke me to take a step. Those ‘hired flys,’ so many per week, which were my lazy succedaneum, had to be almost forced upon her, and needed argument. It was in vain that I said (what was the exact truth), ‘No wife in England deserves better to have a brougham from her husband, or is worthier to drive in it. Why won’t you go and buy one at once?’ After her return to me the propriety and necessity was still more evident; but her answer still was (and I perceived would always be) that fine, childlike silence, grateful, pleased look, and no word spoken. / Whereupon at length—what I ever since reckon among the chosen mercies of Heaven to me—I did at last myself stir in the matter, and in a week or little more (she also, on sight of this, skilfully co-operating, advising me, as she well could) the long talked of was got done. God be for ever thanked that I did not loiter longer! She had infinite satisfaction in this poor gift; was boundlessly proud of it, as her husband’s testimony to her; believed it to be the very saving of her, and the source of all the health she had, &c. &c. The noble little soul! So pitiful a bit of tribute from me, and to her it was richer than kingdoms” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:229–30). TC noted payments to do with the brougham in his checkbook: “29 oct.r 1864 / to Warren &Falconer (brougham harness) / £7 .. 10 .. 0” and “30 octr 1864 to Branah / (for Brougham) / £60 .. 0 .. 0”; “1 Novr 1864 / To Silvr (2 horses &brougham) / £14 .. 10 .. 6”; “2 Novr / to Jane (for Driver / gradually) £10 .. 0 .. 0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). See also JWC to MO, 9 Dec. It needs no unbleached linen to protect it, being dark
blue morocco and cloth inside, which wont dirty in a hurry, and it is all glass in front like Mrs Ewart’s!Alicia Ewart, friend of Mary Russell; see 40:193–94JWC to TC, [19 Aug.]. so you will see finely about you when I drive you to see the lions hereJWC presumably refers to the lions at the zoo in Regent’s Park; the Zoological Society of London opened 1828.— That prospect is one of my pleasures in the new equipage! I have nothing to show you like the drive to Sanquhar, but the Parks here are very beautiful, and I never drive thro’ them now, without fancying you at my side, and seeing them with your fresh eyes!

Mr C expects to actually finish his Book about new-year—and then, please God that I keep well enough for it, we go to Lady Ashburton at a new place she has got in DevonshireLady Ashburton’s house, Seaforth Lodge in Seaton, Devonshire, which was built 1864; see Surtees, Ludovisi 104; see also JWC to MCA, 21 Dec.—where it will be warmer than here, and evidently I can’t have too much change!— when we come back and the weather is fit for the journey the Dr and you must come!

It has been moist even rainy of late and damp seems to suit me worst of anything. My appetite defies quinine, to bring it back! and the Irritation has been more distressing. Still I am no worse on the whole than when I left you. And I force myself to take always the new milk, and the custard at twelve. There is a weighing machine at our Green Grocers at the bottom of the Street;Mrs. Charlotte Strange (b. ca. 1796), grocer &cheesemonger, 46 Cheyne Walk. but I dare not get myself weighed!

I dont like that photograph of MaryFor JWC’s request for a photograph of Mary the maid, see JWC to MR, [24 Oct.]. at all— The crinoline quite changes her character and makes her a stranger for me— I want the one that is as I have always seen her a sensible girl with no crinoline— I would like best if she would get herself done for me as she is on washing mornings—in the little pink bedgown and blue petticoat. I send a shilling (in stamps) for the purpose— But don’t force her inclinations in the matter—

My friend Mr Forster was at Müller’s trial the last day—saw him receive his sentence, and said he behaved very well. When the sentence was pronounced he merely bowed to the Judge and walked away with the Turnkey. But at the little door leading down from the Court he stopt and said to the Turnkey he wished to say a few words to the Judge, and the Turnkey led him back, and he said something which could not be heard, on account of his keeping his hand at his mouth—to steady it— Forster said the only sign of emotion he had given all thro the business was a quivering of his lips. When told to speak out, he removed his hand and said courteously to the Judge “I have had a most fair Trial! but I cannot help saying some of the worst things said by the witnesses against me are gross falsehoods.” Then he seemed to break down and hurried out.

I am certain, had it not been that every Juryman felt his personal safety on the railway compromised by the acquittal of this man, he would not have been condemned to Death on the evidence. It is clear to everybody he had no premeditation of murder and that Mr Briggs threw himself out of the carriage, and probably caused his own death thereby. The poor wretch returning from his visit to his “Unfortunate,” having taken a second class ticket, had seen Mr Briggs with his glittering watch chain get into the first-class carriage and jumped in after him, thinking that chain would take him to America. It was to take him to a far other land!Müller, a native of Cologne who worked as a tailor in London for several years, had recently lost his job, and wanted to go to America. He apparently followed Briggs, a chief clerk at Robarts Bank, Lombard St., into a first-class carriage at Fenchurch St. station, on the North London railway, assaulted him, and stole his gold watch and chain; Briggs was then either pushed out of or jumped from the train, and d. of his injuries. Müller pawned the chain and went to New York, 16 July. Identified by a coachman and a pawnbroker in London, he was extradited and brought back to England to stand trial; the watch and Briggs’s hat were found in his luggage. The Times carried a full account of the proceedings, 26–31 Oct., which ended with a guilty verdict. Müller was executed 14 Nov. His “unfortunate” was Mary Anne Eldrid (or Eldred), a prostitute; Müller went to see her on the night of the murder, but she had not been in.

Curious that he got off that night without the discovery of his ticket not being second class.JWC means that Müller’s ticket was second class, not first class. The Train had been very late, and contrary to all use and wont the tickets were not asked for in the carriages.

I send you a nice letter from Thomas Erskine—the author of many religious books—which I never read except the first (Evidences of Christianity).Thomas Erskine, Remarks on the Internal Evidence for the Truth of Revealed Religion (Edinburgh, 1820). He is a fine old Scotch Gentleman, such as hardly to be to found extant now—also one from Lady A— — Love to the Dr Has the “young man” from LaichDavid Haining or Hanning, son of Thomas and Eliza Haining of Laight, Tynron parish, Dumfriesshire. been to call for you? Tell me about the poor woman in Thornhill who was to have the operation, Mrs Beck? was that the name.Probably Isabella Beck (b. ca. 1821), living at 24 West Morton St., Thornhill. Kind regards to Mrs Ewart and compliments to———Mrs Macgowan.Possibly Elizabeth (b. ca. 1823), wife of John MacGowan (b. ca. 1813), “Blacksmith master &grocer” (Thornhill 1861 census).

ps.p: Dr Carlyle left for Lancashire this morning— He will be back in Dumfries shortly and said he would go up to tell you about me

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady A [LLA] , [2 Nov.]. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head:
JWC
TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: I will write a few lines in spite of Blue-pill and bad Spirits. I have not been “doing well” since you left us, “Anything but,” as the Housemaids say. I have caught some cold, (I don’t know how or when) and this aggravates the sleeplessness, and aggravates the Irritation, which has been the Torture and is still the Terror of my life.

But I continue my daily Drives; only with greater precautions,—a respirator The respirator was invented, 1836, by Julius Jeffreys (1800–1877; ODNB ), surgeon. For JWC’s first use of one, 1838, see 10:227 TC to MAC, 28 [27] Nov. 1838
. —hot water-bottle—&c &c. I have always been capital at locking the Stable-door after the Horse was stolen!

The Grey is a Jewel! so gentle and so willing! He never needs to be touched with a whip, and is as quiet as a lamb!The horse for JWC’s brougham, a gift from Lady Ashburton (see JWC to MCA, 21 Dec. ), was in fact a mare; see JWC to Lady A LLA , 31 Dec. , and TC to Lady A LLA , 5 Jan. 1865 . The only fear I have about him is, that he is not strong enough for a Brougham; for I notice, when he is returned from going twice round the Regents Park, at a most moderate pace, he is all in a heat. Mr C says, however, that all horses are given to sweating at this time of the year, owing to the length of their hair. May be so!

Oh my Darling! Don’t ever say again, you are “shocked” about the Picture!Pesne’s The Little Drummer, a copy of which was given to JWC by Lord Ashburton in 1858; see 34:240 TC to JCA, 13 Nov. 1858
. See Carlyle, Works 12:371–72. You don’t know the pleasure you gave by owning to a care to have anything that was mine, and especially the thing I designed for you! And not to me only did you give a real, heartfelt pleasure, but to Mr C as well. I told him, that in case of his surviving me (as was most likely); the Picture might be secured to little MaryMary Florence Baring. legally ; as we had seen what came of leaving anything to the good-faith of relations! And he told me with a perfectly enthusiastic burst of satisfaction, that “it was an inexpressible gladness to him to know you would value the Picture, and that it would be in His Daughter’s possession, and cared for by Her when we were all gone”! “It has a History for Her, he said, it is mentioned in my Book, as belonging to Her Father’s Collection. And I know, tho’ He never told me so, that He had the Picture done, entirely that it might be engraved for my Book after.The copy of The Little Drummer was used for the frontis. of vol. 1 of Frederick (first edn.); TC described it as “an excellent Copy”; see Carlyle, Works 12:372; it was reproduced between Carlyle, Works 12:370 and 12:371; see opp. above. He would have helped me in my work by any means in his power; He once proposed that I should lay out a hundred pounds of His, in buying Books of reference for it; and, when that could not be listened to, He fell on this notion to bring over the Picture to make a frontispiece from. He never said that was his motive in getting it—He was too courteous for that—but I saw that it was! Oh yes! Tell Her (you) that “little Mary” is of all Living the One to whom that Picture should belong! and, that it is a positive relief (!) and satisfaction to my mind, to think of there being such a Home for it, when it has ceased to delight our eyes here[”]!The copy remains at Carlyle’s House, Chelsea; see Carlyle’s House 106.—So you see if you have any need to be shocked!

figure.p: Antoine Pesne, The Little Drummer, engraved by Francis Holl
Thomas Carlyle, History of Friedrich II. of Prussia (1897)

docBody.p: You will come on the eleventh?— And we will go—when?—or at all?— Oh I do pray God that we may go to you once more! That the Book may be finished in time! And that I may be well enough!— But I have suffered so terribly and despaired so deeply that it always seems to me now a tempting of Providence to entertain any bright Hope.
Enter a——ManUnidentified.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 8 [9] Nov. MS: NLS 553.270. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 5:560.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Dear Neuberg,—Thanks for the Boston Tea, whh contains, at the shortest notice and in the distinctest form, all I want for explaing my Gentn’s MagneTC gave a brief account in Frederick of the “Boston Tea Party,” 16 Dec. 1773; it was reported in “Summary of the Advices relative to the Tea-Ships sent to America,” Gentleman’s Magazine (1774): 26–28; see Carlyle, Works 19:155–56. &c &c.— The GraffignyFrançoise de Grafigny, Vie privée de Voltaire et de Mme du Châtelet, pendant un séjour de six mois à Cirey (Paris, 1820); see Carlyle, Works 14:190. TC’s copy: HCC. &the RödkKarl Heinrich Siegfried Rödenbeck, Beiträge zur Bereicherung und Erläuterung der Lebensbeschreibungen Friedrich Wilhelms I. und Friedrichs des Grossen (Berlin, 1836–[37]); cited throughout Frederick. TC’s copy: HCC. are much at yr service (Grafy put beside the Rödk that you may find it at once). I expected you before now; and hope it is not new cold or the like.Neuberg was often unwell; see 40:54TC to JAC, 5 April. My poor Jane has fairly caught a cold last week;—whh has brot her a good way down from her former high stage; and indeed fills me with anxiety privately. Meanwhile I am working day &night, as for life,—with the little strength left, and the unabating obstinacy. I am thro’ Poland, all but a little printing (thank (t.o.) (thanked be all the gods!) That brings me near p. 500;—and I am getting anxious abt room.

What I want with you at prest concerns that endless Letter of Mll Conway’sField-marshal Henry Seymour Conway (1719–95; ODNB), army officer and politician; see Carlyle, Works 19:164–65. (have inclosed), and yr capital talent for abridging! Part first of the Letter is worth nothing (or was thot so, when I last handled it); Pt 2d, if you cd reduce it, to the 7th or the 10th wd be very useful to me.Conway’s letters were abridged by Neuberg: “Here are Conway’s Two Letters, with the nine-parts of water charitably squeezed out of them, by a skilful friend of mine and his” (Carlyle, Works 19:165–70). Try! There is ample Paper always (on the opposite page), and by reading the inclosed pieces you will see how things stand.

ps.p: Wedy, Chelsea, 8 [9] Novr 1864

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, [10 Nov.]. MS: NLS 553.271. Addr: Roslyn Park / Hampstead. PM: London, 10 Nov. 1864. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p:
Dear Neuberg,—Help me now, if you ever did! I have read repeatedly in the unutterable blockhead Preuss (also in Frh’s Works somewhere) with all the
particrs and documts,—concerning Elliot the Englh Ambassador, &his stealing of the American Papers at BerlinHugh Elliot (1752–1830; ODNB), diplomat and adventurer, minister in Berlin 1777–82; for the theft of the American papers, see Carlyle, Works 19:182–85, where he cites J. D. E. Preuss, Friedrich der Grosse (1832–34), and Oeuvres de Frédéric. (to “find out Frh,” who was merely intending a Handels-Vertrag [trade agreement] with the Yankees had they been ready for it); also concerning Elliot’s Duel (&instant slaughter of his Wife’s seducer &c &c:Elliot fought a duel in 1783 with a Prussian nobleman, Georg Anton von Knyphausen (1744–89), whom he accused of having encouraged his wife, Luise Charlotte, b. von Kraut (1762–1819), to leave him. Knyphausen was not killed, and he and Luise Charlotte married the following year. The duel is not mentioned in Frederick. The story is recounted in Dieudonné Thiébault, Mes souvenirs de vingt ans de séjour à Berlin, 5 vols. (Paris, 1804) 3:289–300; TC cites Thiébault several times in Frederick, although calling him “always stupid, incorrect, and the prey of stupidities” (Carlyle, Works 15:408); TC’s copy, 2d. edn. (1805): HCC. TC may also have read some details of both episodes in Elliot’s papers, held at Eden Lodge, Kensington; see 36:100TC to LS, 19 April 1860.—and now search for it as I will, I cannot find the least trace of it, and am burning with need of it! Help me, oh help me,—deliver me from the jaws and hoofs of that Jack-Ass.That is, Preuss.
