I have tried him every way: iv.136, he has a Chapter on the American Trade-treaty (bless him!), and not a trace of that in it. “Gesandschaft [Legation],” all ways I try are fruitless.
You did get the Rödk, I now find;—very well, the GrafyRödenbeck and Grafigny; see TC to JN, 8 [9] Nov. stands for you where that did.— In haste &despair
docBody.name: T.C.

ps.p: Chelsea, Thursday

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [12 Nov.]. Addr: Holm hill / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire / N.B. PM: London, 12 Nov. 1864. MS: NLS 609.691. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:234–37 inc. Quot: Hansons, NE 527–28; Ashton 434–35.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p:
Dearest Mary—a small boxSee JWC to MR, [25 Nov.]. has been wrapt up, and addressed to you, for a week past; but not sent off, because there was to be a letter along with it and, for grave reasons, the letter could not get written. I have been so ill! I had gone and done the very thing your husband warned me not to do! gone and caught a dreadful cold! I dont know how—nor how long it was coming on— I rather think the loss of appetite I complained of was just the first symptom of the Cold. For the Quinine did no good, and then my throat got sore a little.
And my bowels struck work— Then a horrible pain began in my chest, and down into my stomach, and down down—like the pain that used to pierce from my shoulder into my stomach during the night at Holm Hill—but this did not pass away soon, it lasted some twenty four hours—in spite of mustard blisters, hot water,—brandy and every thing I could think to try. And, as bad as the pain, was the nausea which made it impossible for me to swallow any earthly thing, except one tablespoonful of brandy in hot water, for six and thirty hours. My only consolation was, that except for the aggravation which feverishness is to all pains, my special pain or irritation was not increased—

Now, had I sent for a London Dr, he would have ordered me to keep my bed and take ‘draughts’ and devilries—and Heaven knows what the end would have been. But I sent for nobody—not indeed knowing whom to send for; now that Mr Barnes is worse than deadDr. Alfred Barnes was apparently suffering from dementia; see 40:123TC to LLA, 28 June.—and just prescribed for myself, according to such lights as I possessed. In the beginning I took a four-grain blue pill—then other physic as I clearly needed it—and bearing in mind all the exhortations of both Dr Russell and Dr Blakiston about driving out every day, I actually did not miss one drive—tho’ in horrible pain and one day retching all the time!! I call that energetic obedience to orders! But if I had begun the shutting up system I should have had to lay my account with continuing it all winter— My cold under this new treatment has run thro’ all the accustomed stages with a beautiful rapidity! I am now in the last stage, the coughing stage—and I rather think won’t last long either. Tho’ eating far too little I dont feel weakened. and the last two nights I have slept better than I was doing before I caught Cold. I have not for years suffered so little from nervousness—unless one is to call that Irritation nervousness. It is amazing to myself the agitations (or what would have been agitations formerly) I can stand, without suffering from them after!—

At the beginning of this cold, during the time I was constantly retching, and could swallow nothing; I got a moral shock which would I think have killed me at St Leonards. and all it did to me, I think, was to astonish and disgust me! I told you I was parting with my big beautiful Housemaid because she was an incorrigible goose, and destructive and wasteful beyond all human endurance. As a specimen of the waste figure three pounds of fresh butter at 20 pence a pound regularly consumed in the kitchen, and half a pound of tea at 4/ made away with in four days!!— Then, as a specimen of the destruction—figure all, every one, of my beautiful fine—and some of them quite new table napkins, actually “worn out” of existence! Not a rag of them to be found and good sheets all in rags. besides a boiler burst, a pumpwell gone irrecoverably dry, a clock made to strike fourteen every hour—and all in the china and
crokery in the house either disappeared or cracked! To be sure the Housemaid was not alone to bear the blame of all the mischief—and the Cook was to be held responsible for the waste of victuals at least But Mary—the one who attended me to St Leonards—tho’ the slowest and stupidest of servants—had so impressed me with the idea of her trustworthyness, and her devotion to me, that I could accuse her of nothing but stupidity and culpable weakness in allowing the other girl, seven years her junior, to rule even in the Larder! Accordingly I engaged an elderly womanEliza Warren; see JWC to MR, [24 Oct.]. to be Cook and Housekeeper and Mary was to be Housemaid and wait on me as usual— Helen (the Housemaid) meanwhile took no steps about seeking a place, and when I urged her to do so—declared she couldnt conceive why I wanted to part with her! When I told her she was too destructive for my means, she answered excitedly; “Well! when I am gone out of the House, and can’t bear the blame of everything any longer; you will then find out who it is that makes away with the tea and the butter and all the things”! As there was no body else to bear the blame but Mary—and as I trusted her implicitly; I thought no better of the girl for this attempt to clear herself at the expense of nobody knew who! especially as she would not explain when questioned. When I told slow innocent Mary she looked quite amazed and said, “I don’t think Helen knows what she is saying sometimes, she is very Strange!”
Well. Mary asked leave to go and see her family in Cambridgeshire before the new servant came home, and got it, tho very inconvenient to me.

When she took leave of me the night before starting she said in her half-articulate way “I shall be always wondering how you are, till I get back.” She was to be away near a week. Mrs Southam who sat up at nights with me last winter, my Charlottes mother, came part of the day to help Helen. She is a silent woman, never meddling; so I was surprised when she said to me, while lighting my bedroom fire the day my cold was so bad. “Helen tells me, Mam, you are parting with her?”— “Full time” said I “she is a perfect goose”— “You know best Mam, returned the woman; but I always like ill too see the innocent suffering for the guilty.” “What do you mean, I asked; who is the Innocent and who is the guilty?” “Well mam said the woman, it is known to all the neighbours round here—you will be told some day,—and if I dont tell you now; you will blame me for having let you be so deceived Mary is the worst of Girls! She had an illegitimate child in your house on the 29th of last July— It was her second ChildFroude omitted from “She had an illegitimate child” to “second Child,” indicating the omission with ellipses (Froude, LM 3:236).—and all the things you have been missing have been spent on her man and her friends There has been constant company kept in your kitchen, since there was no fear of your seeing it, and when ever Helen
threatened to tell you she frightened her into silence by threats of poisoning her, and cutting her own throat!![”]

Now my Dear if you had seen the creature Mary you would just as soon have suspected The Virgin Mary of such things! But I have investigated and find it all true—for two years I have been cheated and made a fool of, and laughed at for my softness, by this half idiotic looking woman and while she was crying, up in my room, moaning out; “what would become of her if I died?” and witnessing in me as sad a spectacle of human agony as could have been anywhere seen; she was giving suppers to men and women, downstairs laughing and swearing, and——— Oh I cant go on It is too disgusting! I shall only say that while she was in labour in the small room at the end of the dining room, Mr Carlyle was taking tea in the dining room with Miss Jewsbury talking to him!!!TC mentioned Geraldine Jewsbury’s visit, 29 July. see 40:161TC to JWC, 1 Aug. Froude omitted from “I shall only say” to “way of interruptions,” without ellipses (Froude, LM 3:237).— Just a thin small door between! The child was not born till two in the morning when Mr C was still reading in the DrawingroomFor the detail from Robert Tait’s A Chelsea Interior, looking from part of the drawing room through the dining room into the small room at the back of 5 Cheyne Row, see 33:121JWC to MR, [19 Nov. 1857].— By that time Helen had fetched two women—one of whom took the child home to be nursed—need one ask where all my fine napkins went, when it is known that the Creature had not prepared a rag of clothing for the Child! Imagine coming to the knowledge of all this when I was retching at any rate!

Of course the wretch on her return in a cab last Tuesday, bringing the wretched Boy-FatherUnidentified further. along with her, in broad day light, to have his dinner, was met by a small packet containing her wages and the news “it was all found out.” She hurried the Papa into the Cab again and they drove off together!

But the Box—I hope it will reach you safe. It contains what has a grand sound a real Indian Shawl!— But I have doubts about its looking as grand as it sounds! The border is beautiful, I think, but the ground colour? Will that be to your taste; yellow! I once heard you say you had something yellow that “you thought became you better than anything you ever had on and the Dr detested it!” Well the Dr is at liberty to detest my shawl if he like, provided only you find it becoming yourself!
It is near midday and I am not up yet—have written this long letter in bed—to be out of the way of interruptions

div3.sourceNote: TC-WHD, 12 Nov. MS: previously at Carlyle’s House, Chelsea, now untraced. Hitherto unpbd. William Henry Doeg (1836–1916), b. Newcastle upon Tyne; bank clerk, of Barlow Moor, Manchester. Text: photocopy of MS.
div3.head: TC TO W. H. DOEG

docBody.p: A good while ago I had in my hands an Autograph of Frh the Great, whh you had purchased, and wished to have verified.For a previous letter from Doeg to TC concerning Frederick, see 39:33TC to JN, 21 Jan. 1863(where identified as a bookseller); it was presumably around the same time, Jan. 1863, that Doeg sent Frederick’s signature to TC for verification. The signature I remember as particularly good, better than any I have seen: and repeatedly since I have had a thot of trying to find room for it (if not too difficult) in the last volume of my Book.

That is still uncertn;—but it has now come so far, that I will ask you. Whether you wd have the goodness to give me not only yr permission, but a loan (for two weeks, let us say) of the Autograph itself for that end?—

By way of answer in case of yr compliance, be pleased to send me the Autograph, as soon as possible (Monday morning is the soonest, I doubt).Doeg sent TC the autograph; for its reproduction, see Carlyle, Frederick, Works, 19:188. It was duly returned to Doeg; see TC to WHD, 2 Dec. And in case of yr having objectn of any kind, be pleasd to write or say simply Nothing,—whh, having myself requested it, I shall take as a perfectly polite ansr, as well as the shortest possible.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 17 Nov. MS: NLS 526.19. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: My dear Brother,—Thanks for yr Letter of this morng; I send you the half word, witht delay,—this being a day so wet that there is no riding, in the state I am in (bluepill with sequences!)—tho’ there is great stringency for walking in Mackintosh; and it has already struck 4.

Jane continues to get out daily her 2½ hours seems mostly to have done with the cold,—tho’ she is weak and languid; and as yet does not eat (or drink) nearly so well as before. But she keeps up her heart wonderfully,—has managed all that nasty subterranean-domestic Hurly burly;For Mary’s disgrace and dismissal, see JWC to MR, [12 Nov.].—and I keep hoping she will be able to struggle on. The poor brougham seems really to be the staff of life for her; no exercise possible witht it.— We have got a nice
decent-looking elderly woman “for Cook” (were there anything to cook), who I hope will take charge below decks, and greatly improve the House. The Rector’s WifeFanny Blunt. recomended her: “an old servant in good Norfolk Country-house,Eliza Warren was listed in the 1861 census with the family of the Rev. Edward Banister (ca. 1819–80), vicar of Besthorpe, Norfolk, and his wife, Eliza Anne (1826–1900); she was probably there until she came to the Carlyles. fallen Widow, &her Children all away.” &c &c: she looks well but has only been 2 days here;—we shall see! Helen, however, it is at last found (so incorrigibly negligent, oblivious, and generally witht human sense or gift of reason), will have to go also; Jane is now negociating abt another in whom she has hope.

My Book goes on,—slower than I wish; but daily does advance. It is mostThus in MS, for “mostly.” piecing, cobbling, correcting that I have now to do. Besides this Chapter 5 that I am upon,—there will I think be four: they are none of them long, and are all written but one.

Ruskin was here; by request, has sent me his Daily Telegraph Fractns;Ruskin wrote three letters (26 and 29 Oct., and 2 Nov.) to the Daily Telegraph which pbd. them 28 Oct., 31 Oct., and 3 Nov. The first letter was responded to by someone signing himself “Economist,” to whose arguments Ruskin replied using mathematical terms; see Ruskin’s Works 17:499–502. they may amuse for half an hour:—send them on to Erskine with my kind and affectionate remembrances, when you have done. Ay de mi,Coterie speech; see 6:241TC to JSM, 16 Oct. 1832. light is done. My blessings to the Household &you.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [17 Nov.]. MS: NLS 608.662A. Hitherto unpbd. Dated the Thursday after JWC to MR, [12 Nov.], where JWC reported her illness.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p: I have no spare time and no composure of mind to write a decent letter, and tell you all I have to tell.

But a line will do today, just to satisfy you I am not fallen into a Consumption (I know how you fly to the most desperate conclusions) My cough is nearly gone, and is not of a dangerous sort—for the rest; my bowels are being “attended to”—and a deal of attention besides physic, they take; I can assure you!— My sleep continues sufficiently inhuman but I get used to it!
On the whole I dont think I have lost ground since my return—neither have I gained any.

I like Mary in the bedgown muchFor the photograph of the Russells’ maid Mary, see 97above. JWC disliked the formal photograph of Mary in a crinoline sent in Oct.; see JWC-MR, [31 Oct.]. The photographs were presumably taken by Thomas Douglas of Thornhill; see 37:109JWC to MR, [early Feb. 1861]. For his earlier photograph of JWC, see 38:177JWC to MCA, [30 Aug. 1862].—tell Catherine I am obliged to her for her capital suggestion of the tumbler of milk. It was really clever of Lady Macbeth!Either the nickname of Catherine (another of the Russell servants, unidentified further) or JWC’s naming of her, from Lady Macbeth’s phrase “the milk of human kindness” (Macbeth 1.5).
Mary, Holmhill servant, [1864]
Courtesy of Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University
I have got home my new Cook and Housekeeper—a woman of fifty—-thoroughbred—I think she will suit— I am now seeking a housemaid—
I am so glad the Dr did not dislike your shawl and abuse it!— Oh how I wish he and you were near me—
Poor young man. Is he to die after all of dropsy?Possibly David Haining, “the ‘young man’ from Laich”; see JWC to MR, [31 Oct.]; otherwise unidentified. Ever your / J W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-CTR, 23 Nov. MS: EUL. Hitherto unpbd. Craufurd Tait Ramage (1803–78; ODNB), writer; rector of Wallace Hall Academy, Thornhill, 1842 to his death.
div3.head: JWC TO C. T. RAMAGE

docBody.p: My Husband being up to the eyes in Proof-sheets, “struggling for his existence,” (so he says), and being at the same time unwilling that your BookBeautiful Thoughts from Greek Authors (Liverpool, 1864). and letter should remain unacknowledged, has desired me to write, and return you his thanks; I was to say, that he has always great pleasure in reading that sort of Books, and looks forward to reading this one, so soon as ever he is done with this “terrible job of work, which has nearly choked the Life out of him”!

It will be a rather curious fatality, if after having assisted at a most diligent reading of the Latin volumeRamage’s companion anthology, Beautiful Thoughts from Latin Authors (Liverpool, 1864); see also JWC to MR, [25 Nov.]. by Dr Russell, I am again to assist at as diligent a reading of the Greek volume by my Husband! But next time I shall have to deny myself the pleasure of making impertinent criticisms; as I don’t happen to know a word of Greek!

If I liked Nithsdale from of old, how must I adore it now, after having
gained a whole stone of weight on my last visit, and shaken off so much of my terrible load of illness? I did not know all the good that Dr Russell’s skill and kindness, and his wife’s angelic nursing had done me, till after my return to London; when I found myself falling naturally into old occupations, and feeling old interests that I had fancied myself shut out from for ever.
If it please God that I return to Holmhill another year; I hope to be more up to enjoying the sight of old Friends.JWC visited Wallace Hall and Ramage with Mary Russell; see JWC to MR, [19 Dec.].

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady Am[KST], 24 Nov. MS: NLS 1808.112. Quot: Ashton 435. Kate Stanley m. Viscount Amberley, 8 Nov., and was now Lady Amberley; she wrote an account of her wedding to JWC; see JWC to MR, [25 Nov.].
div3.head: JWC TO LADY AMBERLEY

docBody.p: Darling! Whether as “a bonnie Lassie,” or as a ‘Lady’-Wife;For a photograph of “Kate &her Amberley” (TC’s later annotation), see 100above; it was probably taken at Alderley at the same time as the photograph of Rosalind and George Howard (see 69JWC to LAI, [12 Oct.]). whether in person, or on paper; you dance into my room always like a stray sunbeam! God bless Her! and keep her a long time as happy and brightTC and JWC often referred to the Stanley girls as “Bright Young Beings.” and good! Especially keep Her a long time as good to me!— (if a person who has been hanging between Death and Life, till she hardly knows which of the two elements she belongs to, may be permitted to speak of “a long time.”)

p.hi: Courtesy of Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University

docBody.p:
“Much bothered”— Yes! that have I been, from the hair of my head to the soles of my feet! I never received such a moral shock in all my Life!JWC possibly wrote an account of Mary’s dismissal (because of the secret birth of her child; see JWC to MR, [12 Nov.]) to Lady Stanley or Lady Airlie, rather than to Lady Amberley herself. It was like a great blow with a stick on the pit of my stomach, and I actually retched for half an hour after, with the disgust of the thing!— The creature had been my attendant all thro’ my illness, and had wept over me, and moaned “what was to become of Her without me”? And to think that she had been all the time maturing a —— Baby! Good Heavens!— And spending my substance on bad characters, and worst of all making fun of my trust in her! But for the pain and mortification her treachery caused me; I could have laughed at the Picture of poor dear Mr C, who never suspects, and has no curiosity, sitting at tea with Geraldine Jewsbury, and talking up to the Stars—if not above
them—while his Cook and Housekeeper was taking the liberty of producing “an insipid offspring” (as a German friendProbably Amalie Bölte (1811–91), German feminist, writer, and governess, friend of the Carlyles from 1841; otherwise unidentified. JWC first used the phrase “insipid offspring” in 1845, referring to a pamphlet; see 19:213JWC to TC, 23 Sept. 1845. of mine would have called it) in the adjoining room!— — Thoroughly disgusted with young servants, I have rushed desperately into an Elderly Cook, of the “highly respectable” sort, and a middle-aged Housemaid,Fanny was 28; see JWC to MC, 28 Nov. whose mouth droops plaintively at the corners indicating no tendency to Babies, I should say!

For the rest; I have, like every body else in London, had a shocking bad cold; but, by dint of not sending for a Doctor, and continuing to drive out every day, I am getting over it. I have got a tidy little Brougham and a grey Horse “all to myself” (as the children say)Coterie speech. and it is the great comfort and best medecine of my Life at present.

We shall be heartily glad to see you in DecemberThe Amberleys were spending their honeymoon at Woburn Abbey, Bedfordshire; they came to Pembroke Lodge, Richmond Park, Amberley’s family home, in Dec. No doubt about that!

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [25 Nov.]. MS: NLS 609.692. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:307–9 inc.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p: Oh my Darling! I should not be writing to you this morning, with so many letters on my conscience which it is more my duty tho’ not so much my pleasure to write! But “Life is short”!See Hippocrates, Aphorisms 1.1. and I feel that truth more poignantly than ever since this horrible illness; and I don’t feel to have time for always sacrificing my pleasure to my duty!! So the others must wait while I talk to you a bit.

The weather has been, as November weather always is here, horrible so raw and foggy and dyspiriting: nevertheless, I have not since my return to London, missed my drive a single day. It is the great support and comfort of my life, that movement thro the open air once a-day. Then it enables me to do my own shopping (at the carriage window) and to make visits (on the new principle of calling out the person visited, to sit in the carriage with me!). My back continuing as weak as ever, and making it too much fatigue for me to go up people’s stairs and that sort of thing! When I have nothing particular to do in the streets, I know where to drive for a sight of sheep (very dirty ones!)
and green fields. I am out from one till about four generally! then I dine, and receive company till six.

Occasionally, not often, some one drops in to tea. but I seldom fail to be in bed by eleven,—and still better, I seldom fail to get some sleep. I have not lain awake a whole night since my return! Tho’ I am still far from sleeping like a human being!— I take pills at a great rate! Can’t help myself. And no matter, so long as the special misery keeps in abeyance.

I have been feeling myself very ungrateful in not going to report myself to Dr QuainDr. Richard Quain. all this time. He was very kind and attentive to me last winter, and couldn’t be persuaded ever to take a fee! But now that the torment, which burnt up all delicacy in me, is abated, I “think shame”Coterie speech; see 30:220JWC’s Journal, 21 Nov. 1855. to see him; after all the dreadful questions and answers that passed between us!

My new “Cook &Housekeeper,” promises well. If I had not had another such perfect and polite servant in the “Old Ann” who was with me six years,“Old Ann” or Anne was a servant with the Carlyles from Oct. 1853 to March 1858; see 28:285TC to JCA, 12 Oct. 1853, 29:113TC to JAC, 6 June 1854, and 33:177–78JWC to MR, [ca. 5 Feb. 1858]. I should live in constant expectation of discovering some serious flaw in her! For this woman’s characteristic is plausibility, and I have a dread of plausible people! But probably as in “old Ann” there will be nothing to discover worse than a large amount of selfishness and an exaggerated idea of perquisites!— The new “House maid and Lady’s maid” is to come on Tuesday. As “Mrs Warren” (the Cook) said, “however she turns out, we cant well be worse off than we are at present.”

Just read that account of Kate Stanleys marriage!Lady Amberley sent JWC a letter with an account of her wedding to which JWC had just replied; see JWC to [Lady Am]KST, 24 Nov.— That beats Helen WighamGeorgina Helen Whigham’s marriage, 29 Sept., to Rev. Henry Bowen Cooke. all to smithers!

Mrs Anstruther and Daughter were here,Mary Frances Anstruther, b. Stewart-Mackenzie (1819–1913), Lady Ashburton’s sister and widow of Philip Anstruther (1802–63), and probably her oldest da., Annie Nairn (ca. 1841–1931); for her 10 additional children, see 38:273–7438:biographical notes. They lived at 17 Norfolk St., Park Lane, London. yesterday—sweet as melted barleysugar!— Lady A has been in town again, keeping me out of bed till near twelve! bless her!— People begin to come back—and I have more company than I need.

The little box?— Yes! it has a history— It was a white deal box containing some presents sent me by Goethe, when we were at CraigenputtochBetween 1827 and 1831 Goethe sent to TC at Craigenputtoch several boxes of gifts, most of which also contained either books or other gifts for JWC; see 5:26–27TC to G, 3 Nov. 1829, and 326–27TC to G, 13 Aug. 1831.— By way of illustrating it, I painted it black and ornamented it with clippings
of chintz!!— I sent it to you, because I thought you would give it a place in your bedroom—and here, if I died, it would have no value for man woman or child!—
Do not neglect to tell me of the young man at Laight and tell me his nameDavid Haining; see JWC to MR, [31 Oct.].—in case I send him a newspaper.

My kind regards to Mrs Ewart. I had such an idiotic note from Mrs HunterSee JWC to MR, [17 Oct.]. about the autograph I sent her—and then another idiotic note from the Miss ThorburnUnidentified further. who had got it!
Beautiful Thoughts, in Greek this time, are come for Mr C and i have had to write Mr C’s thanks for it!See JWC to CTR, 23 Nov.

closer.salute: God bless you both my Dears /

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MC[MCR], 28 Nov. Addr: Chlorine Place / Belfast (care of Professor Craik). PM: London, 29 Nov. 1864. MS: Strouse. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY CRAIK

docBody.p: Oh little Woman! Little Woman! How could you have the face to tell me, that you “are not much of a letter-writer—me, who, for weeks and weeks together, saw you letter-writing, “late and early,” as if you had been a Secretary of State! and saw the packets you sent off by every post, as bulky as the Proof-sheets of a novel!Mary Craik stayed with JWC in St. Leonards ca. mid-May to mid-July. Oh! Oh! never make lame excuses my Dear! Enough to say, you had not felt to have anything to write to me, in particular; or enough to say just nothing at all about it but when the Spirit did move you, then rush right into the middle of Things!

As I shall do now. My Dear the most extraordinary things have Come to pass in this House! Things to make you, and my Cousin Maggie, and Mrs Blakiston, and myself, all ‘hide our diminished heads’See Milton, Paradise Lost 4:35. as good house-wives, and women of discernment!— Before you ceased your kind ministrations hereJWC left St. Leonards first and went to Scotland by way of London; Mary Craik then returned to London with TC before going home to Belfast, 26 July. see 40:151TC to JWC, [26] July.—you made an effort to rid the House of Helen, and consign Mr C wholly to the slow, but trustworthy and attached Mary. But in the uncertainty as to when I should return, and in what state I should return, Mr C thought it best to
struggle on as well as he could with the incorrigible Helen; threatening once a day at least, to “fling her out into the Street,” but never doing it! So on my return, the same Two received me; Mary running out to embrace me in the open Street, and crying for joy to see me “so like myself again.” When I had rested, and to my own astonishment as well as the astonishment of Mr C and everybody, found myself even better than I had been in Dumfriesshire, and capable of looking after my own affairs; I did look after them, tried for two or three weeks patiently and strenuously to manipulate Helen into a bearable Housemaid, and failing utterly, gave her warning, not only there was no getting her to do her work like a civilized being but the destruction and waste in the House for all which she got the blame was intolerable. Imagine four pounds of fresh butter at 20 pence a-pound consumed in the kitchen weekly! and half a pound of tea every four days!! It was too disgusting! So in spite of her extreme unwillingness to go, I engaged a woman of fifty (a widow) to be Cook &Housekeeper and, Mary having shown such incapacity for ruling was to try if she could obey, in the position of Housemaid &Ladys maid. This being settled, Mary got leave to go into Cambridgeshire (to see her Father “who had been dangerously ill”) for a week before Helen left and the new Cook came. Mrs Southam (who sat up with me all the last winter) was brought to assist Helen in Mary’s absence. Mary had not been gone two days, when I was taken with a violent feverish cold; and in the first worst stage thereof I got a ‘moral shock,’ which affected me exactly like a blow with a stick on the pit of my stomach! making me retch for half an hour, and so sick that for six and thirty hours I could swallow nothing but a tablespoonful of brandy in water!

This was the shock— Mrs Southam being at my bedside, giving me some tea, said abruptly: “Helen tells me you are parting with her Mam?”— “Yes, said I, and full time, she is a most unsatisfactory servant”— “Well—you know best Mam! But—I never like to see the innocent suffering for the guilty”!——“Who is innocent? and who is guilty I asked in amaze; what are you talking about?”— “Well Mam, said the woman, it is pretty well known in the neighbourhood, and you are sure to find it out some time, and then you would be angry at me if knowing it I had not told you”— “Out with it for God’s sake!” “It is Mary Mam! Mary is just the worst girl that ever was in your House! While you were putting such trust in her, she was deceiving you in every way, and laughing at you for being so blind!! All the time you were ill, and all the time you were in Scotland she was having constant men in the House! fed at your expense! and even since you came home The Father of her Child has pretty well lived here.”— “The Father of her Child?” I repeated aghast— “Yes; she bore a child in this house, soon after Mr Carlyle returned from St Leonards, while Mr Carlyle was sitting at tea with Miss Jewsbury!!! There wasn’t a rag of clothing prepared for the Child. a woman was brought by Helen at two in the
morning, and carried It away in one of your blankets! But you will now understand the disappearance of all your small napery (!) and all the butter and tea and things that you complained of, and that were laid to Helen”!

Yes my Dear! this “insipid offspring” was born on the 29th of July three days after you left!! It is all true!— I said to Mrs Southam “Oh it is the treachery, the deceit that grieves me; I could have forgiven the baby, that might have been weakness inexperience”— “Well said Mrs Southam “inexperience” it couldn’t be; for it was her second!!”— Every particle of this I have had corroborated on undoubted authority! with oh such sickening details!

When the wretched little animal returned from Cambridgeshire, where she had gone to place her child with a married Sister; never going to her Father’s at all! she drove up in a cab, at broad midday, with the Ex Boots (aged twenty) and was taking him in, to have his dinner comfortable, as usual; but Helen met her at the door with the wages due to to her, and the news that “it was all found out”!— She looked horrified for a moment; and then said; “I knew I should be found out some time, altho’ the Mistress is such a simpleton!! and I don’t care! I can get a place without a character from Her! Come along Ben! Get in!”—and the two remounted into the Cab and drove off——Devilward!

Helen was kept on another month on trial, in the new conditions; with a superior servant over her; but it won’t do! and we are to part tomorrow—in perfect good humour! A woman of eight and twenty comes as Housemaid, of good family, and a good phisiognomy except for a too plaintive droop at the corners of her mouth.

I have stood all this upturning wonderfully. Indeed I am not at all ‘nervous’ now tho’ the special misery, is not altogether gone—and tho’ my back is still so weak that I can walk no better—hardly so well—as at St Leonards!

I have got a nice little Brougham “all to myself” (as the children say) and a smart grey Horse, and a Paternal almost grand-paternal Coach-man! And I drive, in all weathers, from two to three hours daily; so I dont much miss the use of my legs—or rather Back—

People were so adorably kind to me when I reappeared! I never got myself so kissed and cried over in all my life! and that sort of thing does me no harm now—rather it does me good! So you may conceive how wonderfully rehabilitated my nervous system is! I don’t sleep yet like the rest of the world; but a degree better than in Dumfriesshire and several degrees better than at Marina. Oh Heavens! I shudder when I look back!

Mr C is extremely pleased to have me back, and in a comparitively efficient state! He hopes to finish his Book about new years day and then we propose going to Lady Ashburton in Devonshire. There is no one “with me”— My Aunt in Law Mrs George Welsh wished to come; but I did not feel to need anyone in the House with so many visitors Thanks to your Father love to him and Georgina Your ever affectionate / JC

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 30 Nov. Addr: Roslyn Park / Hampstead. PM: London, 30 Nov. 1864. MS: NLS 553.272. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p:
Dear Neuberg,—‘Müller [Miller] Arnold,’ whh I have just been reading, will do with little correctn;—therefore no more of it. Only can you tell me, If his Wife’s name was Rosina or what?Miller Arnold’s wife was called Rosine; for their lawsuit, see Carlyle, Works 19:222–46. Your Notes on the Law-Reform 2d will be welcome any time;Neuberg wrote, 19 Dec.: “you must be approaching the 2d Law Reform. My own old ‘Notes,’ I have searched for in vain! But, knowing how little this signified, it is no great matter of regret. … Succinct information about the Nature of the Code, I could find nowhere. There is not even a Copy of it (of this second attempt at one) in the Museum!” There is only a brief mention of the Second Law Reform in Frederick; see Carlyle, Works 19:222–23. not indispensable for 10 days yet: Potato WarThe War of the Bavarian Succession, 1778–79; see Carlyle, Works 19:189–222. has to come first.— — What I want chiefly to know is something abt the Sans-souci
Miller:When Frederick was building his house at Sans Souci, nr. Potsdam, 1745–47, the Arnolds would not sell their land to Frederick for the gardens; see Carlyle, Works 19:243. Prs iii.414 has an Article upon him; and does not give the smallest particr, not even the date. Ascertain for me, a little if you can; there seem to be plenty of French Books &c,—possibly yr volume of Rödenbeck may (t.o.) give the date? It must have been 1746 or ‘7 I shd guess. Didn’t we see the Windmill (same Edifice, I wonder?), and almost rub shoulders with it, on going up to the Sans-souci Cottage that time.For TC and Neuberg’s visit to Sans Souci, 1852, see 27:324TC to LOA, 7 Oct. 1852. Oh that I were done,—and you!
John Silvester’s account, late November 1864
Courtesy of the National Library of Scotland

p.name: T. Carlyle
p.note: For Silvester’s receipted account for late Nov., see opp.above. TC wrote on the reverse in blue pencil “Silvester rect (Novr 1864).”

div3.sourceNote: JWC-AW, [30 Nov.]. Addr: Craigenvilla / Morningside / Edinburgh. PM: London, 1 Dec. 1864. MS: NLS 609.693. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:310–11 inc.
div3.head: JWC TO ANN WELSH

docBody.p: Oh thank you Dear! I am really grateful for this! You have been long of doing it, but you have done it well at last! I think the likeness perfect!Possibly the photograph of Ann Welsh in vol. 3 of JWC’s photograph albums; see 108above. so does Mr C altho’ he has not seen you for so long a time. Mr C was no better pleased with Grace’s last photographPossibly the photograph of Grace Welsh standing; see 39:75–76JWC to GWE, [2 March 1863]. than I was; altho she consedered my disapproval sheer perversity. He declared it to be “a despicable, half-witted-looking dottle of a body, no more like my Aunt Grace than he was!”— But yours is a great success, and a pleasure to me to have.

p.hi: Courtesy of Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University

docBody.p: I have been very much occupied of late weeks, with changes in the House &c &c. My days are so short to begin with! As I am still too weak for getting up before breakfast, it is near eleven always before I get into the Drawingroom; at half after twelve I go out for my drive, whatever weather it is, and am generally out for three hours. At four I dine, and receive visits—till six. Then, in the evenings, I am too much wearied, to do anything but a little desultory reading. When I try writing letters in the evening, it never fails to give me a restless night, and now Mr C won’t suffer me to take a pen in hand.

Still it is not an unhappy Life. The comparitive freedom from physical suffering, seems, after the long tortures I endured, positive enjoyment. And the pleasure I have in my friends is so enhanced by grateful remembrance of the kindness shown me thro’ the long period of my illness. And I am no longer
obliged to overexert myself, as I used to be. Mr C has had such a fright, that it has developed in him a quite new faculty of Consideration!

Did I mention in my last note that Mary the elder of my two servants, who had been with me two years,—a slow and stupid Servant, but born with, and even cherished, for her trustworthyness, and affectionateness, and distress about me in my illness, so that she was taken to St Leonards and kept with me. the five months I staid there— This Mary, while I was at Holmhill, about a week after my Husband returned from St Leonards with the other Servant, took the liberty of giving birth to a child in the House! While Mr C was entertaining Miss Jewsbury at tea!! She hadn’t a rag of clothing prepared for it, so I suppose she had meant to make away with it. But the other Girl being present at the Birth, she had to let it be carried out of the House to nurse, in one of my blankets The Father of her “insipid Offspring” was an Ex-Boots, from a Hotel, age twenty, Mary being eight and twenty!— This fact came to my knowledge when I was at the worst with my cold, two or three weeks ago; and not this fact only, but a great lot of the most disgusting details, which struck me like a blow on the breast with a stick, making me retch for half an hour after! How she had been keeping the worst company in my kitchen, spending my substance on them all the time that my illness and absence made her safe from my observation, and laughing at me as “a Simpleton” for my trust in her! That was the worst of it! She was turned off without notice; and the other girl went yesterday, not that there was any vice in her, altho’ she had been drawn into making herself a party to the other’s iniquities but she (the Housemaid) was a born blockhead, and the House could never have been restored to order with her in it. Mary was a Baptist, and used always to keep her Bible, with a bunch of ornamental marks in it, on a chair at her bed-head!!

I have got a “respectable” widow, of fifty, for Cook &Housekeeper (!) who has already done more for improving my appetite than all the Quinine and Pepsine that have been tried on me. There is never a speck of dust about this woman: and her manners are the perfection of courtliness! And, so far as I have seen things go on at less expense than formerly. If She only goes on as she has begun, I shall say I have lighted on “a treasure”—at last!

The young Person (eight and twenty) who came yesterday, for Housemaid and Ladys maid also promises excellently. She comes of an excellent family and I have great faith in breed. She “thoroughly understands her business”—one can see that the first day, and she is very modest, and intelligent and I should say from her face is not only honest but honourable
So I feel myself set up in quite a magnificent style—“Housekeeper” and “Lady’s maid” and “Coachman” coming every morning “for orders.”

I feel the comfort of all this better now, than if it had come to me when
I was young and strong. As dear BettyBetty Braid. says “we hae mony mercies, may we be thankful”

I find I have written on a sheet destined for Madame Elise my beloved Dressmaker.The start of a letter to Mme. Elise was on the reverse of the sheet on which JWC was writing this letter; only the dateline is readable, the rest has been scored out. never mind!

My best Love to Elizabeth &Grace. Couldn’t you persuade Elizabeth to send me her photograph. the sitting one on metal is so ghastlyPossibly the photograph of Elizabeth Welsh in vol. 3 of JWC’s photograph albums; see opp.above. TC wrote later underneath: “‘Aunt Elizabeth’ (still living; eldest of the Three).”

p.hi: Courtesy of Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University

closer.salute: God bless you— your loving niece

docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JF, 1 Dec. MS: FC. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN FORSTER

docBody.p: Dear Forster,—For a week past I have had one of the smallest of questions to ask you; and day after day in the whirl of hurries, it is lost. This day I go to it before all else!

The question is, Has yr Life of Goldsmith been translated into German?John Forster, The Life and Adventures of Oliver Goldsmith (1848); there was apparently no German translation yet. Or, more practically: Have you ever heard of its being? Yes, or No: that is the whole matter.

It seems there is a German Lady, well qualified for such a task,Agnes von Bohlen (ca. 1829–1905), listed in the 1871 census as a German teacher living in Kensington; she had already pbd. an anthology, Das Buch der Mutter für Haus und Erziehung Herausgegeben (Berlin, 1859). who has decided on going forward with this Enterprise upon you, provided no other have yet done it. If any other have done it, she thinks you must have heard. Neuberg, my faithful German, is the poor Lady’s friend and sponsor; and I promised him to put the question;—answer me, oh answer! I’ll call thee King, Father, Royal Dane!See Hamlet 1.4.——

Seriously, I suppose the Neuberg Lady Friend is abler for her task, and will be more honest with it, than the generality of such people; and I have often thot the Germans, especially if they cd see all these beautiful woodcutsForster included 40 woodcut illustrations in the 1st edn. of his book; omitted from the 2d edn., they were replaced in the 3d and 4th edns.; in the preface to the 4th edn. Forster wrote: “Mr. Carlyle having always blamed me for suppressing the woodcuts given originally, they are here restored” (Forster, The Life and Times of Oliver Goldsmith [1863] [vii]). &c
&c, wd be delighted with that most lively ingenious and pleasant Book; for they like Goldie no less than we, and have a considerable acquaintance with him.Neuberg wrote, 19 Dec.: “Many thanks for the trouble you have taken about the Goldsmith. Miss von Bohlen is now looking out for a willing publisher, &would be glad to be able to profit at Mr Forster’s generous offer about the illustrations.” She was to publish her translation of The Traveller (1764) and The Deserted Village (1770) with a short biography of Goldsmith (Berlin, 1869); there was no acknowledgement of any connection to Forster’s Life.

The Wife goes on quite tolerably, thank Heaven. I am choking in Paper-clippings (ah me!)—but struggling towards the finis. Let us see yr face agn the instant you return.Forster’s work with the Lunacy Commission required him to travel around the country. Soon, is it not to be? Yrs ever, dear F.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 2 Dec. MS: NLS 526.20. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Here are the Letters referring to Scotsbrig James,Their nephew James Carlyle; the letters were probably copies of letters between William Baird &Co. and their agents in Liverpool, Messrs. Carnegy Davidson, concerning James Carlyle’s search for work as a “sale clerk or shipping clerk” and James’s reply to Carnegy Davidson, 21 Nov., which were attached to a letter from James to John A. Carlyle, 21 Nov. (MS: NLS Acc. 9086). whh were to be returned by me: they came today at 2½ p.m.;—and I have had no time yet to think of the subject. My impression is, that a Factorage in Scotland wd be better than any outlook there is in Liverpool. If you will tell me Hy Inglis’s address,John A. Carlyle replied, 6 Dec., giving Henry Inglis’s address, 16 Queen St., Edinburgh, and adding: “if you write to him it will be best in my opinion to send your letter direct to himself, giving young James’s address of Scotsbrig, Ecclefechan, &stating that he will be ready to go at any time to show himself to Mr Inglis if wanted”; see TC to HI, 7 Dec. and mention when you &James are to make yr attack at Edinr in that direction, I will willingly write to Inglis all I honestly can.
My work is going on; but under endless haggles from toothache, from Printers, from mud, dyspepsia, dispiritt &c &c: I seem to myself nearly “over with it” in more senses than one!
Jane seems to hold out very well: she has never in her life taken half the pains abt regimen, exercise, &c; and that is the main source doubtless of her improvet.

Jean will be anxious abt her young Liverpool adventurer;Jean’s son James Aitken, working in a mercantile house in London from 1858, had recently moved to Liverpool for new employment; John A. Carlyle wrote to TC, 6 Dec.: “No news yet from Jim of his Liverpool work.” I am persuaded, however, there is all probability of his doing himself credit there, &coming to something good.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JS[JRS], 2 Dec. MS: NLS Acc. 7012. Pbd: E. B. Chalmers, “Mrs Carlyle’s Letters to John Stodart,” Times Literary Supplement 25 June 1971:741. John Riddle Stodart (1793–1871), Writer to the Signet and notary public; JWC’s old suitor; see JWC to TC, [5 Sept. 1849], and JWC to JRS, [30 Sept. 1849].
div3.head: JWC TO JOHN STODART

docBody.p:
I have been all my life under a fatality—I mean one particular fatality—this namely; to leave undone the things which I ought to have done;Cf. Book of Common Prayer. not thro’
laziness, nor forgetfulness, nor perversity,—the common reasons for human short-comings; but from a wish and intention to do the thing which I ought to do impossibly well!

So it has been in acknowledging your letter and photograph.Presumably the photograph of John Stodart in vol. 3 of JWC’s photograph albums; see opp.above. I should have done so in a reasonably short time, had not the idea come to me, to enhance my letter and make, what they call in Scotland “a suitable return,”Coterie speech; see 39:40JWC to JAD, [29 Jan. 1863]. by inclosing a photograph of myself, which you had not seen, and which would please you (I was sure) “for reasons which it may be interesting not to state”!Coterie speech; see 38:195JWC to TC, [5 Sept. 1862]. This “touching” likeness, however, was not in my possession, but in the Artist’s;Probably Robert Tait who took many photographs of the Carlyles during his painting of A Chelsea Interior, 1857–58; see 33:197JWC to MR, 29 March [1858]; for a carte-de-visite of JWC from a photograph of that time, see 116; for the detail of A Chelsea Interior showing JWC in the same chair, see 33:17TC to JAC, 11 Aug. 1857. and altho’ I have applied for it several times, my fatality has hitherto prevented my getting it; so I wait no longer, in case you begin to think ill of me, which at this time of day,—after so many years of generous faith—it would be a pity and a shame to do!

p.hi: Courtesy of Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University
Courtesy of Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University

docBody.p: Ah yes! I have been dreadfully ill! I did not know that Life had in it such possibilities of suffering! For nearly a year I was in constant torture, in constant terror that the torture would drive me mad, in constant expectation of Death as the only deliverance! And here I am after all, not only alive, and sane, but in rather better health and spirits than I had been for long, before my illness! I have done a good many strange things in the course of my life but this recovering is the strangest thing of all!

Not that I am to be called well even now—my Back is so weak that I cannot walk six yards without being ready to sink, and I feel a constant tendency towards going on all fours! But then it is so long ago since I was well that I dont remember the least in the world how it felt! and so don’t pine after it!

For the rest, I am not unhappy; I believe in the Doctrine of Compensations.Cf. Emerson’s essay “Compensation,” pbd. in Emerson’s Essays (1841) 91–127; TC wrote the preface to the English edn. (1841); see 13:163TC to RWE, 25 June 1841. It is a nuisance to be unable to walk; but it is pleasant to have a nice little Brougham “all to oneself” (as the children say) and to drive wherever one will three hours, in all weathers, every day of one’s Life! Then the People are so unspeakably kind to me since my return to the Land of the Living! I was never so kissed and cried over in all my life as in the first weeks after my Home-coming. Men even, that I had not supposed to care twopence for me, clasped me to their “manly breasts,” and kissed me, and cried over me
like— —like anything!— And my own Husband shared in the general enthusiasm and was become so considerate! Bless him! He never bids me ring the bell now, without saying; “Oh I beg your pardon! I forgot”!
Dear John! do you never come to London now? I wish you would! I should like to see you again in this world; true friend that you are—in spite of all your perverse ways!
God bless you. It is my hour for driving, and I live like an eight-day-clock

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [6 Dec.]. MS: NLS 609.694. Pbd: A Carlyle, NLM 2:311–14 inc., where dated “Nov’r (?).” Dated in early Dec. as part of the sequence of JWC’s almost weekly letters to Mary Russell.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p:
I had it in my mind, Dearest, to write you a nice long letter today, but the Fates willed that I should get up this morning late, and stupid; having had a worse night than usual. No wonder! considering the way I was used. I went yesterday to have a dress fitted on at Elise’s,Madame Elise’s shop was at 170 Regent St. my black silk tunic which you liked so much, and which I have worn every day and all day since I left you! having fairly gone to tatters—and no shame to it! I was before the time of day for the fashionable Ladies, so Elise was disengaged and came to the fitting room herself, to superintend the process; which I don’t believe she would have done for any Duchess in the Land. And she would not let me have the thing done any how, as I wanted—saying to her French dress maker; “Because Madame will not wear a crinoline and will not be tied up; that is no reason why she should have no waist, and no style!” and so she fingered away at me herself, while I stood for half an hour! Then she brought me a glass of wine, “to put away my fatigues”!! but it didn’t! I went after to see Lady William Russell, who happened to be better up to talking than usual, poor Soul!Lady William Russell suffered chronic ill health; see 39:46–47JWC to LST, [late Jan. 1863]. and I couldn’t get away from her till within half an hour of my dinner time (four o’clock)—Mrs Warren (the new cook) never keeps me waiting; but my dinner was not well over till Mr TwisseltonEdward Twistleton. came, who staid till near seven; and between seven and eight, a Mr BallantyneThomas Ballantyne. came on the voluntary principle, and shortly after Colonel Cunningham, and Miss Cunningham
(Allan’s family)Allan Cunningham’s children, Col. Francis Cunningham and Mary Cunningham. by appointment to tea. And just, I think, because I was so feverishly tired, I thought fit to make tea myself! the first time these fifteen months! It was half after ten when they went away, and Mr C’s walk was not ended till near twelve. Of course I couldn’t sleep, and when I did, couldn’t keep hold of sleep for many minutes together, and awoke finally for good at five. and such long dark mornings these are!
So I will put off the “nice long letter” till another more auspicious day, and just tell you how it is with me.

On the whole, I don’t think I have lost ground. My cold is gone, a little tendency to cough and roughness of the throat—but nothing to speak of. My appetite has improved since I had the new Cook, who makes every[th]ing look nice, however it may taste, and who regulates my dinners according to “her own sweet will.”Coterie speech; cf. Wordsworth, “Composed upon Westminster Bridge” line 12. Nothing so soon destroys all inclination for food in me as having to order it beforehand! So, reflecting that I was eating better I thought I might probably be gaining flesh again and yesterday summoned up resolution to go and be weighed—at the Green Grocer’sCharlotte Strange; see JWC to MR, [31 Oct.].—swung up in the air like a basket of potatoes! It wasn’t half such pleasant weighing as Andrew’sAndrew Hunter (b. ca. 1842), plowman; see 40:200JWC to TC, [22 Aug.].—nor was the result so pleasant—I had lost two pounds and a half since I was weighed last at dear Holmhill! Not much—and the weight remaining 8 stones 9 pounds121 lb. (55 kg.). is fair enough for a woman of my inches. Still I should have liked to keep the “8 stones eleven and a half”— When I came home after, I solemnly announced to Mrs Warren, that she would have to fatten me to the extent of two pounds and a half—whereupon she went and baked some sweet unwholesome biscuits, which gave me the heart-burn. For the rest; my bowels continue very obstinate, and I take a pill or a bit of one every night. but this is natural to me, so not to be complained of. I wish you would ask the Dr if I should take anything for my water— All thro’ my illness it was remarkable for having nothing earthly the matter with it (the Drs said) But ever since I caught cold, tho’ the cold passed, it has been muddy with red sediment. Can the potash-waterPotash water was used as a laxative and general remedy for indigestion. which I take at dinner with wine, and at night with milk have anything to do with it? They prescribed potash-water for me when I was at the worst, and when my appetite failed thro my cold and the iniquities of Mary, I took to it with milk as the only thing I could swallow—

My walking is as bad as ever—constant weakness and aching at the bottom of my back. But I have had no neuralgia during the night—except at the
beginning of my cold. I am not at all nervous. and I certainly sleep better than I did while with you, when I commit no indiscretions like last night’s. Best of all, the special ailment—the most unbearable—continues much in abeyance. I never feel quite right, never forget my strange misery, never cease to have a secret dread of its bursting up again into the old tortures; but the actual suffering if cleared of the aggravations of the Imagination—would be nothing to make a fuss about— Many people—the greater number I believe—have to suffer as much in some form or other! I dare say the exceptionalness of the form in my case has had a great deal to do with the unbearableness.

How is Mrs Menzies?Agnes Menzies, b. Elder (1795–1880), wife of Rev. William Menzies (1797–1869), minister of Keir parish, Dumfriesshire; see 38:143JWC to TC, [15 Aug. 1862]. and the young man at Laight?
My ever grateful love to the Dr! Dear! Dear! I wish He and you were not so far away!

ps.p: Kind remembrances to Mary and Lady Macbeth

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady A[LLA], 7 Dec. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Quot: Surtees, Ludovisi 102.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: Oh my beautiful Darling! I do love you! With all my heart and more than all my strength, that being small! And, to keep up a wholesome balance of feelings, I hate the Barings in the same degree!—all except Louisa, who I believe is true to you.For Lady Ashburton’s conflict with the Barings, see 40:113–14TC to LLA, 5 June.

I began a letter to tell you this, and some more, several days ago; but was interrupted; and then I waited till I had been to Wellbeck Street, to see the Bust, which Woolner had told me was much improved.Thomas Woolner was sculpting a bust of Lord Ashburton; see Surtees, Ludovisi 102.

I have now seen it, and can honestly say I think it very like; quite a wonderful likeness considering the materials Woolner had to work from.Woolner never met Lord Ashburton; starting the bust after Lord Ashburton’s death, he worked from photographs and from the portrait by Edwin Landseer (1802–73; ODNB); for Landseer’s portrait, see 38:112–13JWC to TC, [2 July 1862]. I am sure it is good! for I recognised in the brow and upper part of the face the same look of my Father which first attracted me to Lord Ashburton, and gave him a fascination for my eyes such as no other man’s face ever had. Mr C too is now well pleased with the Bust. “Exactly the look he had when listening
rather abstractedly to the talk going on in his presence.” It is certainly out of sight the best likeness of all you have got. Munro’s Bust is quite contemptible beside it.Alexander Munro (1825–71; ODNB), sculptor; his bust of Lord Ashburton was exhibited at the Royal Academy in 1860; see Surtees, Ludovisi 81.

Now of Miss Baring; what I wanted to tell you was this. Annie FarrerAnnie Louisa Farrer (1818–1910), old friend of the Ashburtons; see 38:27938:biographical notes. came to see me after she had been visiting them, and got upon Emily’sLydia Emily Baring, Lord Ashburton’s youngest sister. “perverse view” of you, I said I had never seen anyone in my life so prejudiced and ungrateful. “Well, said Annie; Louisa makes up for it! I never saw Louisa Baring so devoted to anybody in all my Life as she is to Lady Ashburton. You know, she is very undemonstrative, and she speaks of Lady A with enthusiasm,—stands up for her thro’ thick and thin! And she is entirely in favour of The Will. She said to me, whom should a man leave his possessions to but his own child, and whom so fit to entrust that child to as the woman who had been everything to him and in whom he had the most perfect confidence”? I think you will be pleased to know this. I was.

Annie Farrer was also speaking of Venables’sGeorge Stovin Venables. “devotion to Lady Ashburton” (you) She had met him somewhere and “My Word! said Annie, (her English is rather slip slop) isn’t he Loyal to Lady Ashburton? He won’t suffer a breath against her—is ready to massacre all the Barings for her sake!”

That also I liked to hear. Emily Baring has been in London some days, and was every day lunching with Annie Farrer— She did not come to see me—as she always did on these short visits. And I took her avoidance as a compliment—as a recognition of my belonging to the Enemy!

Annie said that Venables “would never marry Emily Baring if there wasn’t another woman in the World!” that “at the time when they were wanting him to do it, he staid away from the Grange, and only went back when Lady ALady Harriet Ashburton. gave up asking Emily to meet him.” Indeed Venables “had had a life-long engagement to Miss Lushington;Probably Maria Lushington (ca. 1820–91), sister of Venables’s great friend, Henry Lushington (1812–55; ODNB); see Surtees, Ludovisi 106. never carried out, for reasons known only to themselves.”

Oh my dearest Lady Ashburton don’t let them trouble your heart,—these mean people! Who are they? what is their opinion worth? what would the deepest love, they are capable of, be worth to you, that you should vex yourself at their enmity? All that was good and noble in the Baring family belonged to you, heart and soul,—belongs to you still under new conditions;
sweep the rest out of your Life, as you would the dross from which the gold had been shifted!

Up to the last week, Mr C has held to his hope of getting done about new year’s day—and then our going to you seemed a settled thing. And to me, this prospect has been a positive physical support, as well as a mental one! The last two or three days some hitch has occurred in his work, and he is bilious, and despairing of all things—of getting done amongst the rest. I do believe I should cry, like a Baby, if I am disappointed this time!

About the Horse?Presumably the horse (in fact a mare) which Lady Ashburton had given JWC for her brougham. Let me know in time, what day he shall be sent off. To BennetLady Ashburton’s groom. still at your orders? If so, I suppose he will come for him, and take charge of him; if not; Silvester will punctually fulfil your instructions You will find him a most gentle, well-conditioned quadruped with quite speed enough for practical purposes.

I do not wonder that neither you nor the little AngelMary Florence Baring. feel well just now. Everybody here is complaining of weakness, sometimes to the extent of Diarrhea owing to the damp airless weather. But that cannot last for ever.

I enclose a letter from Mrs Oliphant Author of Edward Irvings Life, The Chronicles of Carlingford, and many pleasant novelsMargarent Oliphant’s most recent novel was The Perpetual Curate (Edinburgh and London, 1864); see JWC to MO, 9 Dec.— It will interest you. The poor Soul lost her two first children many years ago—then her Husband, after long years of illness, thro which she supported the family by her writings, died in Rome, and three weeks after, she was delivered of a boy!Oliphant’s husband was Francis Wilson Oliphant; the two children were Marjorie, who lived for a year, and a son who d. at birth; Francis Romano was the child b. shortly after her husband’s death. This girl she has now lost was charming, and the only girl.Her only surviving da., Margaret Wilson Oliphant, d. in Rome, 27 Jan. 1864. Poor little Woman! Her Lot is strangely hard for our finite comprehension! God bless you / faithfully &gratefully / Yours / Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-HI, 7 Dec. Addr: 16. Queen Street / Edinburgh. PM: London, 8 Dec. 1864. MS: NLS 1796.101. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO HENRY INGLIS

docBody.p: It is many a year since you heard of me;The last recorded meeting of TC and Inglis was by chance in George St., Edinburgh, Sept. 1859; see 35:196TC to JWC, 9 Sept. 1859; Inglis’s last recorded visit to Cheyne Row was in 1854; see 29:29TC to JAC, 10 Feb. 1854. and I now come begging: but I know you will permit me willingly; &listen to my request so far as you can. The case is this.

A Brother’s Son of mine,James Carlyle Jr.; see TC to JAC, 2 Dec. a respectable and likely enough young man of 29, who does not want for natural faculty, and I believe has qualified himself in some reasonable degree for the business of Factorage (as we Scotch call it) or the management of Land,—is considerably in want of some employment in that line. You have, as is well known, a great deal to do with Landed Estates; and must often be called upon to appoint or recommend qualified persons as Factors or Managers. Now if you wd have the kindness to investigate this young man, and satisfy yourself abt his fitness,—if you found him really fit, and happened to have before long a place fit, I shall only say you could do me, thro’ him, a very great favour.

Another Brother of mine (John, whom you have heard of) who is equally interested in the case, and knows it better, has written down the inclosed particulars about it;John A. Carlyle wrote, 6 Dec., enclosing “a very brief summary of James’s qualifications, which may save you some trouble in writing to Mr Inglis, if you forward it along with your letter.” The summary noted: “He is a young man of thorough integrity &excellent character &ability, has had a good education &considerable experience, is well acquainted with all kinds of farm work &country matters, &also with the marketing of farm articles both in Scotland &England. Salary is less an object with him than healthy employment. / In a Glasgow mercantile house he acquired a thorough knowledge of book-keeping. He has just been for two years in the employment of Messrs Baird &Co of Gartsherrie, partly under trial &training for the Factorship of Ury, &has given them entire satisfaction as they are ready to testify; but, for reasons which it is unnecessary to explain, that Factorship is not to be had at present” (MS: NLS 1796.103). TC wrote on the reverse: “For Henry Inglis Esq / T.C.” whh I believe are perfectly exact. John GordonJohn Gordon (1797–1882), old friend of TC and John A. Carlyle, living in Edinburgh; see 35:25835:biographical notes. He previously tried to help James Carlyle Jr. find work; see 39:99TC to JAC, 26 March 1863. too is practically acquainted with the young man and his Affair. The young man himself, if you at all wish it, will on a hint from you present himself in person:—his Address is, “Mr James Carlyle junr / Scotsbrig / Ecclefechan”; and the distance, any day, is not above six hours. These, I think, are all the substantial items of
the matter; &I will now leave it with you; nothing doubting but you will do for me in it whatever is honestly doable.

In january coming, or soon after, if no ill accident occur, I hope to have done with a certain Book, whh has almost literally killed me,—at least it has kept me buried alive for 12 years past; and I am quite killt as the Irish say, and hardly worth resuscitating. If things go well, however, I may really see you agn in the body in the course of summer coming; and recal many kind days that are now far away! My poor Wife (who is greatly recovered from a sad fit of illness whh was very threatening, last year) joins me in many kind regards and memories of Auld lang syne. Yours sincerely
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 7 Dec. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. Carlyle

docBody.p: My dear Brother,——I got yr Letter this morning; I have just written to Henry Inglis,—inclosed yr paper, referred to John Gordon, gave the Address,—and said all I had to say. If it do any good, I shall be very glad.
When you go to Edinr, if Inglis is taking any hold of the busss, it will do you no kind of harm to know Inglis. It is impossible for me to correspond upon it at prest!

This Note you will see is for you;TC wrote on the reverse of a letter from John Rutherfurd Russell to TC, 6 Dec. Russell wrote: “Our friend Saffi has kindly consented to give a few Lectures to a small private circle, here, on Italian Literature. The first Lecture is to be delivered tomorrow (Wednesday) evening at 8 oclock—the subject the early Italian poets. It has just occurred to me that possibly your brother is in London &would perhaps like to be present at these Lectures. As I have no means of ascertaining whether he is here, &if he is, where he now lives, I am forced to trouble you with this note, &to request that you will have the goodness to convey to him my hope that he will favour us with his company, at any or all of the Lectures— They are to be once a fortnight and always on Wednesday— The second Lecture is on Dante &your brother’s translation is the textbook used by Saffi.” Dr. John Rutherfurd Russell (1816–66); see 33:246–47TC to JRR, 21 June 1858. Aurelio Saffi (1819–90), count, poet, and politician; see 33:28033:biographical notes; friend of the Carlyles since 1851; see 26:231JWC to JAC, [15 Nov. 1851]. He taught Italian in Oxford, but returned to Italy, 1860, and was elected to the new Italian parliament, 1861, returning to London 1864. Chapman &Hall pbd. John A. Carlyle’s Dante’s Divine Comedy: the Inferno. A Literal Prose Translation (1849) with the original text and explanatory notes; see also 18:263JWC to JW, [11 Nov. 1844], and 24:16TC to AC, 6 April 1849. it came last night,—and remains witht ansr from me. When you get to Edinr, I hope to hear more at large. Goodnight (close on 11!) T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady S[LST], 8 Dec. MS: Strouse. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO HENRIETTA LADY STANLEY

docBody.p: You are very kind to me; and had not I been, ever since yr Note came, the most hurried and bothered of mankind, you need not doubt but I shd have thanked you sooner.

There are few places in the world I shd like better to see agn than Alderley HouseTC last visited Alderley Sept. 1859; see 35:222JWC to TC, [29 Sept. 1859]. with its prest inhabitants. But as to this Winter,—alas, my unfortunate Book will not finish till well on in jany, at the very soonest and best: and so soon as the Book ends, or even as I can carry the end of it with me (to work at it away from home), Wife and I are due at Lady Ashburton’s Seaside Cottage (South, in Devonshire or the border of Dorsetshire)Seaforth Lodge, nr. Seaton, Devon. for I know not what length of weeks. So that as to the North—Alderley is in Cheshire, in the north of England.

Nevertheless my thots do gravitate that way, as may be fancied; I have not seen my poor old Scotland &birthland for four years,TC last visited Scotland Sept. 1860; see vol. 36.—a kind of silent “threap” dwelling in me that I wd finish the Book, first:——I am steady in the hope, therefore, that there is a good time coming to me from the North Quarter too.

Poor Lord Carlisle,George William Frederick Howard, 7th earl of Carlisle, politician; he d., 5 Dec., at Castle Howard, Yorkshire.—gone the way we have all to go! He was an innocent-hearted man as I ever knew or saw.

Some rumour reaches me that Lyulph is for printing his late American Letters. Tell him “not to.” He will himself be strongly of that opinn ten years hence.Edward Lyulph Stanley recently visited the U.S.; TC gave him a letter of introduction to Emerson, who was very impressed by him; see JWC to Lady ALLA, [12 Oct.]. He apparently did not publish the letters.

My Wife keeps wonderfully well considering; I myself ride furiously for life,—and am pretty considerably killt by these 12 years of digging in the quicksilver mines. We send our united blessings &regards to Miss StanleyMaude, the only unmarried Stanley da. and everybody.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MO, 9 Dec. MS: NLS 23194. Pbd: D. J. Trela, “An Unsung Friendship: Jane Welsh Carlyle and Margaret Oliphant,” Carlyle Studies Annual 11 (1990): 38–39.
div3.head: JWC TO MARGARET OLIPHANT

docBody.p:
Oh my Dear! your letter made me so sorry! I knew nothing of this!The death of Oliphant’s da. Margaret in Jan.; see JWC to Lady ALLA, 7 Dec. had not heard of you indeed at all for more than a year! My last news was your own letter from Scotland, which reached me when I was already too ill and spiritless for answering it; tho’ I did not suspect then, that it was a worse illness than usual, and was to last a whole year, and was to bring me to the point of Death. All the four months I was confined to bed at home, and the five months I was being doctored at St Leonards, I had hardly more communication with the outer world than if I had been buried. I could carry on no correspondences, could see no people; it took just every morsel of strength I had, to keep living, and to keep my senses!— My nervous sufferings were so terrible! In the middle of July, no sleep being attainable at St Leonards, I had an inspiration of Heaven to rush off to Scotland whether I could or not! I went by night, with the escort of my medical Brotherinlaw, and the night after I slept! I staid about three months with dear friends I have in Dumfriesshire, the master of the House the best Dr I know, and the mistress the best nurse! I had fallen on my feet! I gained a whole stone’s weight there, and some strength, and some hope, and my special torture fell into abeyance—comparitively! When I returned to Cheyne Row in the beginning of October, I was astonished to find myself able to lead something like my old life—-outwardly at least! I cannot walk yet many yards without being ready to sink; but I drive out some three hours every day; my Husband having given me a little Brougham and Horse and Driver “all to myself.” We have few mutual friends here you and I; I could hear nothing of you; so I thought the surest way would be to go to EalingEaling, now a suburb, then a village about 6 mi. (9.5 km.) W of London, where Oliphant lived from autumn 1861; JWC visited her there Feb. 1863; see 39:69JWC to MCA, [26 Feb. 1863]. According to TC’s account from Silvester’s Livery Stables, JWC hired a horse for the trip, which took place 26 Nov.; see 106. and seek you. This purpose was urged into immediate execution by the arrival of your Chronicles.The Perpetual Curate, most recent of Oliphant’s Chronicles of Carlingford; it was serialized in Blackwood’s Edinburgh Magazine, ;June 1863–Sept. 1864, and pbd. in book form, late Oct. 1864. John Cordy Jeaffreson or Jeffreson (1831–1901; ODNB) reviewed it in the Athenaeum, 12 Nov.: “To readers of this calm, drowsy temperament ‘The Perpetual Curate’ may be confidently recommended as a well written, well printed, perfectly inoffensive, altogether wholesome, and decidedly soporific story. It nowhere offends a prejudice, or startles with a paradox. … [T]he story is unreal, awkward, rambling and inexpressibly tedious” (629). The Athenaeum published a further comment by C.G., 27 Dec., asserting that Oliphant displayed “a wonderful ignorance of the customs and ordinances of the Church of England” (901). You had not forgotten
me then? I should so like to give you a good kiss, and tell you all about me, and get your sympathy! Alas! I little thought you were needing sympathy too!—under what an affliction!

Cambridge villa it was! well here, through a dreadful plunge of mud, I had drawn up at Cambridge villa no 1Oliphant’s address in Ealing.—I remembered the door was at the near side— My coachman rung and inquired. “Mrs Oliphant? No!—no such person lived here!”—“Could she tell where then?”— “No! never heard the name!”— I thought I would try no 2, tho sure that was not the House— There a nice girl came out and said No 1 was Mrs Oliphants House, but she was away in France!She was in Paris, apparently staying at 108 Avenue des Champs Elysées. So I had my drive, a very pretty one, for my pains! When I saw your dear little handwriting on that letter, it was such a pleasant surprise! And a new contribution to my evidences of a Magnetism of Thought which I like to believe in!By “magnetism” JWC appears to mean a kind of telepathy; see 37:224JWC to CCU, [6 Sept. 1861]; for JWC’s earlier discussions of animal magnetism, magnetism, and mesmerism, see 18:282–84JWC to JWE, 13 Dec. [1844], and 308JWC to MR, 29 [30] Dec. [1844]. It was my longing for a sight of you, evinced in the expedition to Ealing, which had drawn you into writing me a letter! Was it not?— I opened the letter so pleased! and then to find you in sorrow—! such a terrible grief added to the heavy griefs of your Life, poor dear Woman! It shocked me more than I can say! Ah it is very difficult to recognise the hand of a loving Father in these terrible blows inflicted on us! The one reason for believing so, that I could ever discover, is, that one must and would go stark mad if one didn’t! But it is very difficult and at first impossible, unless one have been brought up on formulas, from the day [one] was xtened
I wish you were come home Dear! I want to see you and kiss you! A kiss says so much more than any words can—especially written words!

My Husband is at last getting done with his weary task— He speaks of newyear’s day seeing the end of Frederick! If so, we shall go into Devonshire for a little, on a visit to Lady Ashburton, who has got a house at Seaton for the winter. There is nothing so good for my sort of illness, the Drs say, as Change and I have found it so latterly.

closer.salute: God bless and comfort you Darling Your sincere friend

docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, [9 Dec.]. Addr: Roslyn Park / Hampstead. PM: London, 9 Dec. 1864. Envelope only: MS: NLS 553.273; any letter of this date is lost; the letter filed with the envelope at 553.273 is clearly of a later date after Frederick was completed; see TC-JN, [14? Feb. 1865].
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: [Letter untraced]

div3.sourceNote: TC-JF, [10 Dec.]. MS: FC. Hitherto unpbd. TC had written to Forster, 1 Dec., with an inquiry; Forster’s reply would have been on his return to London; letter therefore dated 10 Dec., rather than 3 Dec.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN FORSTER

docBody.p: Dear Forster,—Yesterday &day before I was too ill and botheredTC wrote to John A. Carlyle that he felt “sadly beclouded and loaded”; see TC to JAC, 15 [16] Dec. to say yes;—&really dare not quite yet. But I will if I can (really): right willing, were not the flesh so weak,—and continually galloping 3 miles an hour!
Thanks many abt the Goldsmth.See TC to JF, 1 Dec. Horse waiting. Yrs ever
docBody.name: T. C.

ps.p: (Saty [10 December 1864] 3 p.m.)

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 15 [16] Dec. MS: NLS Acc. 5427. Hitherto unpbd. Friday was 16 Dec. TC wrote on the reverse of Inglis’s note.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
Here from Hy Inglis is a Note,Inglis wrote, 14 Dec.: “It is superfluous to say that I was glad to hear from you; or that anything I can do in the matter of your nephew, is most heartily at your service.— At present, I know of no opening; but should such occur either in my own path, or in any I can influence, you may rely on my utmost exertions.— Meantime, my friend Dr Wm Brown has written to a friend of his, a Sir Walter Trevelyan, on the subject; with what success, we shall see.” He asked TC and JWC (“to whom my kindest regards”) to visit him in the summer at his home in the country, 25 mi. (40 km.) from Edinburgh, “amongst the hills which gird Gala-water;—where you will find tea, tobacco, and welcome. I look upon your consent as an accomplished fact.” He wrote that he was “seldom now in London; but should I chance to be there, I shall not fail in my homage to the Goethe of Chelsea.” whh came yesterday morning; to whh I send no ansr,—but you, if you happened to see him on the streets (for he
knows you by face &name, and his tone here &always is kind), might stop him &say the civilities (I much obliged, dreadfully busy &c);—I suppose, howr, he will really do whatr he can: so if you dislike, don’t. There seems to be nothing open, or practically visible: Jamie will have to wait. That of Sir Wr Trevelyan will do nothing at prest,—sickness of Lady Trn &c &c.Sir Walter Trevelyan; his wife Lady Paulina often suffered ill health.

I was very wae to think of you packing off for Edinr;—a world growing cold and empty to us both: but we must not complain. You by this time, I can see, find yourself more comfortable in Edinr. Today Jean forwarded a Note from her Jas junr, whh I perceivd you had seen,—he bodes fairish there.James Aitken Jr. was now in Liverpool; see TC to JAC, 2 Dec. John A. Carlyle wrote to James Carlyle Jr., 13 Dec., about Jean Aitken’s plan to visit Scotsbrig: “Your aunt Jean talked of going across to see your father &John &you, &‘darn all the stockings’; but she will give you warning if she does go. She has had no speech of your father for a long while, &is always one of the best of sisters” (MS: NLS Acc. 9086). John had apparently just returned to Edinburgh from visiting Jean at Dumfries.

I am sadly beclouded and loaded under this weather,—wild long rides indispensable, tho’ hateful &c. I do make progress: actually “Chap VI” under my thumb (after a struggle); Chap 7 is easy, easy; and then there are but two short ones, more! I (t.o.)
