IRepeated at turn of page. really am near done: God be forever thanked (I ought to be “thankful,” as our dear old mother wd have said).—

Jane drives daily. I do believe her brougham is the staff of life to her, “exercise” (instead of none), kind of “amuset” too, &c &c. I have not another moment. Mud all dried; blistering eastwind,—frost ahead, I doubt.The Times reported, 4 Jan. 1865: “December—Frosts occurred on 19 nights, the greatest cold on the 18th being 15 deg.” Adieu (remces to Erskine)Thomas Erskine spent the winters in Edinburgh.
docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [19 Dec.]. Addr: Holm Hill / Thornhill / Dumfrieshire / NB. PM: London, 20 Dec. 1864. MS: NLS 609.695. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:237–40 inc. Quot: Bliss, JWC 321.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p:
If it is as cold, and snows as hard there as here: you will be fancying me broken down, if I don’t write, and tell you I am taking all that very easily! driving out every day from two to three hours—as usual!! The cold is not so trying for me as the damp, I find. My Horse has not stood it nearly so well! I had him
roughenedStuds were screwed to horses’ shoes to prevent them slipping on the ice; see 37:67TC to JAC, 21 Dec. 1860. JWC still referred to the horse as “he” although she was a mare. the first day of the frost and snow, but nevertheless he managed to get a strain in one of his hind legs; and is now in great trouble poor Beast! with a Farrier attending him, and his leg “swollen awful”! He is a beautiful grey Horse, given me whether I would or no by Lady Ashburton; but young, and I am afraid too sensitive for this world! “Whenever he is the least put out of his way, he goes off his food”; the groom says.— Nobody can say when he will be fit for work again—if ever— Meanwhile I get a horse from the Livery Stables.Silvester’s, Church St.

I should be glad to hear that you had no misadventure with that horse you were trying! It was a piece of conjugal obedience, I am far from feeling myself up to, to go out with a new horse to try it! What a gay life you seem to be leading, now that you have not the tie of me to keep you at home! I should fret myself over the recollection how many invitations you refused on my account, if I did not also recollect that you had no “cold” nor illness of any sort, and slept always well, all the time, while you were taking regular drives and keeping out of parties!— But that doesn’t lessen my sense of your self-sacrificing goodness, and the Doctor’s! Often after it has come into my head, and brought a glow into my heart, and almost tears into my eyes, about that—clock! The thought of its standing for so many weeks, in the lobby, where it was ever in view—standing—!! Many people might have stopt a clock for me, and I should have thought it such a wonderful kindness. But Dr Russell—he who is so correct about everything—who has a constitutional need of seeing everything in its proper place and discharging its proper functions—for him to turn his clock into a practical solecism, in consideration of my nervous fancy which he could not be expected to understand—! indeed it was a piece of hospitality and human kindness that, which I shall never forget to be grateful for!Dr. Russell apparently silenced the clock so that JWC would not be disturbed by its striking during the night.

I meant to have had the poor clock set a-going, just the last thing before I came away. But the shock of Mrs BairdsCharlotte Baird; see JWC to MR, 3 Oct. death made me forget several things—that amongst them.

The most spirited thing I have done since you last heard of me was driving to Acton with——Madame Elise!! to see her beautiful placeMadame Elise lived at Hill House, Acton. there and take a dinner-tea with her, and back with her—arriving at home as late as six o’clock!!

It was a pleasant little excursion, Elise as a woman, with a House and children, is charming. It is a magnificent House, with a dining room about three
times the size of the Wallace HallThe home of Craufurd Tait Ramage; see JWC to CTR, 23 Nov. dining room, and a drawing-room to match. Both rooms fitted up with the same Artist-genius she displays in her dresses!For a photograph of Madame Elise, presumably wearing one of her own designs, see opp.above. It is an old Manor House with endless passages and at every turn of the passage there is a Bust—Lord Byron, Sir Walter Scott, Pope, Milton, Locke!!Lord Byron (1788–1824;ODNB), poet; Sir Walter Scott (1771–1832; ODNB), poet and novelist; Alexander Pope (1688–1744; ODNB), poet; John Milton (1608–74; ODNB), poet and polemicist; John Locke (1632–1704; ODNB), philosopher. The Drawingroom opens into a Conservatory, that would take Mrs Pringles (Pott)Probably Lann Hall, nr. Thornhill, where JWC stayed in 1858 (see 34:165JWC to TC, [29 Aug. 1858]) when JWC’s cousin Janet Pott, b. Hunter (1827–1912) lived there with her first husband, Dr. Andrew Pringle (1820–58); she now lived with her second husband, Gideon Pott (1824–1905), at Knowesouth, nr. Jedburgh; see 38:28338:biographical notes. into a small corner of it. There is an immense garden round the House, with Green Houses, and a great green field beyond the garden with sheep in it—clean sheep!

p.hi: Courtesy of Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University

docBody.p: A middle-aged Ladylike governessUnidentified further. took charge of the three children, perfect little Beauties!Frederick, Violet, and Rudolph. and the nurse and other maidsUnidentified further. had the air of a ‘Great Family’ about them! They all treated ‘Madame’ as if she had been a Princess!—a triumph of Genius!

The only drawback to my satisfaction, was a dread of catching cold. The immense rooms had immense fires in them. But their size and the knowledge that they were only lived in from Saturday till Monday, in a general way, gave me a sensation of chill; and then being abroad so late at this season was very imprudent. I went to bed with a pain in my shoulder and much self-upbraiding. But got some sleep and no harm was done.

Do you know that bottle of whisky you gave me has been of the greatest use! Things affect one so differently at different times! Whisky seemed to fever me at Holmhill. Here it calms me and helps me to sleep! I take a tablespoonful raw when I get desperate about sleeping—and invariably hitherto with good effect. I take no quinine nor other medicine at present except the apperientThus in MS, for aperient. pills. half a one I have to take every night. The potash water I like very much with my wine and my milk; and take from one to two bottles of it every day,

I have not been weighed again but I don’t thingThus in MS. I can have lost any more, as I eat better since the new Cook took me in hand. She continues to be a
most comfortable servant. Such courtesy! such equability of temper! Such obligingness, and all that so cheap! for the weekly bills are less than when I had ignorant servants. The Housemaid is also a good servant but not so agreeable a one. The droop at the corners of her mouth, indicating a plaintive, even peevish nature does not belie her I think! When Mr C finds fault instead of trying to do what he wants she cries and sulks.
When do you mean to give me little Mary?Meaning unclear, unless JWC was hinting (or teasing) that she would like Mary as her servant. my compliments to her and to Lady Macbeth.
My grateful and warm love to your Husband. To yourself a hundred kisses. I will write soon again.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 20 Dec. MS: NLS 531.4. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: My dear Sister,—It looks unkind, and really is so that I sit so silent utterly while you are so diligt in writing. Harrassed as I am with perpetual botheration, toil anxiety and total weariness &weakness I might at least (oftener than I do) send you express word how we are in bodily health. Take one word from me, in a five minutes there has fallen to dispose of.

Jane still keeps up, really wonderfully. We must not brag; but hitherto there is room for great thankfulness, real surprise. She drives out as duly as the sun: has not yet missed a single day;—attends to her diet, regimen of every kind, punctual as clockwork: I often feel as if the poor wretch of a brougham (really pretty carriage, whh I have never yet been in), whh she never sighed for in my hearing, one faint time, but is greatly thankful for (I dare say),—were the life of her in this element. A most excellt investt of money!For the costs of the brougham, see JWC-MR, [31 Oct.]. Due, before all this, had I had time.—

As for myself, I am really very low. I don’t much believe I am in greatly worse health of body than last Winter; but the steam of the mind is taken away, in this close neighbd to the goal; and I often feel altogr brokenhearted, and in some pullishFor “pulish” (English) or “pewlish” (Scots): whining, complaining. moments as if I shd never get done, after all. And yet I have only 3 short Chapters, not 100 pages in all; &two of the Chapters are really almost done, only one of them yet quite to do! It really seems as if I shd be out not long after Newyrsday: but I dare promise nothing; every page has
been full of fash &toil &disgusting fikeries in this dreadful Book. I shd have had at least 10 skilled clerks to help me; and I have rarely had one.Several people helped TC with Frederick over the years, including the ever faithful Neuberg who wrote, 19 Dec.: “The state of the roads, &a threatening fog, prevented my coming to Chelsea last night, as I had fully intended doing.” He had rechecked some information for TC on Frederick’s Second Law Reform (see TC to JN, 30 Nov.): “I went to the Museum to refresh my memory. I found confirmed, what I knew, that I could have gathered only a few biographical notes concerning the Editors of the Code. … These ‘Notes’ I could easily repeat, if you think it desirable. But as your treatment of the subject is to be of the shortest, I do not see that they could be of any use. … On the enclosed slip, I have put down two or three points which may interest the English readers to receive hints about.” Courage, Courage! Having eaten the cow, who wd weary on the rump!— God bless you, dear Jean.— Affectely T.C.
Yr Jim is evidtly doing well. His Letters are really good reading too My regards to him.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MCA, 21 Dec. MS: NLS Acc. 7864. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:314–16 inc. TC later wrote on the MS: “(fragt abt Xmas 1864).”
div3.head: JWC TO MARY CARLYLE AUSTIN

docBody.p:
as I understood from your letter, that the butter was sent off about the same time as the eggs, I waited till I should have received both packages, and could announce the safe arrival of both at one writing. The Eggs came before your letter, and had not come to grief this time, at least there was no egg lost,—half a dozen cracked, but not spillt. The other heavier package only came to hand an hour ago. I don’t know how long it had been on the road; but nothing had taken any hurt. The fowls look beautiful. quite fresh, and the butter all right—only we have not had time yet to taste it. It comes, the butter, exactly at the right moment, just when Lady Ashburtons farmer at Addiscombe had written, that “the hamper” would henceforth be sent only once a week instead of three times, “as he had to send hampers also to her Ladyship in Devonshire.”Lady Ashburton was at Seaforth Lodge. The impossibility is curious, when you consider that in each hamper there is just two eggs, about a gill of cream and twice a week a pound of butter! It is a compensation for those who have no toy-farms, and Farmers and Gardners, to see how a great Lady is imposed upon at all hands!— My grey horse that Lady A’s Coachman gave an “enormous price” for (sixty or seventy guineas!) and which Lady A absolutely forced on my acceptance turns out too soft for
even my gentle uses. The first day of the frost I had it roughened and went out in the carriage as usual. (I have not been one day without a drive since my return) and one of the creatures hind legs got sprained somehow, and it has been laid up in its stable, with a Farrier attending it, ever since, I having to hire a horse in the meantime! The groom says that every time my horse does a little more than usual she “goes off her food.” I shall never have any comfort in driving her again, if ever she gets over this accident. And the best thing will be to sell her and job a Horse.

Mr C does not look to me as if he were going to keep his word and “get done about newyear’s day.” If he get done in February I shall be thankful. I am not now so impatient for getting to Devonshire to Lady A as I was before I knew that her house there only began to be built last June! She affirms it is quite dry nevertheless, but she had only been there for two days when she said so. As she is troubled with rheumatism herself at present, she will not be able to live in it any more than I should be unless it is free of damp. We shall see!

In the mean time I have reason to thank God for the comparitive ease I still enjoy—in spite of the severe changes of weather.— My appetite is improved again since I had the new Cook, who sends up every thing so tidy and pretty! She seems a very nice servant indeed, and not at all extravagant. I pay her a little more wages than I was in the habit of giving; but that is not the difference at the years end. The weekly bills are diminished rather than increased since she came, tho’ we live much better—have all sorts of cakes and “dainties” which no former cook unless Grace MacdonaldThe Carlyles’ servant at Comely Bank and Craigenputtoch between 1828 and ca. 1831; see 4:369–70TC to MAC, 20 April 1828. was up to. And she is a most pleasant servant always so polite, and obliging, with an equableness of temper rare at fifty, and very soothing for the rest of us—who are anything but equable!

The new Housemaid is also a good servant—intensely “respectable” and “understands her business.” but she is nothing like so pleasant. The plaintive, peevish droop at the corners of her mouth which struck me at first sight don’t belie her nature! She is too sensitive for anything but a “sensitive Plant”—in a flower-pot! She cries when Mr Carlyle is impatient, and then sulks. And so far from equable that she reminds me of the children of the “wee wifie that lived in a shoe and had so many bairns she didn’t know what to do”! “She went to the Butcher’s to buy them a sheep’s head,—and when she came back they were aa lying dead. She went to the Joiners to buy them a coffin; and when she came back they were aa sitting laughing.”Nursery rhyme. So with Fanny. No mortal can tell the temper she will be found in! But as Mrs Warren (the Cook) says, “tho’ she is disagreeable I dont see where we should get a better servant on the
whole”! I don’t hear anything of either of the wretches who went away.Mary and Helen. But I am always coming upon traces of them, in the waste and destruction left behind. I was weighed the other day and found that I had lost two pounds and a half since I was last weighed at Dr Russells. Considering my loss of appetite from cold and from worry, it was less than might have been expected. I am certainly sleeping better. Not to be called well yet—but better than I had done since before my illness. The special misery is never so entirely gone that I can get it put out of my head, but sufficiently in abeyance that I can lead my life as if it were gone. Oh mercy what a different state of things from last year at Xmas! Can I ever be thankful enough!
God bless you Dear and all your Belongings! Many thanks for all these things and all your true affection
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

ps.p: I can’t walk any better yet but I feel rather less fatigued by the effort of walking

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, 27 Dec. Addr: Holm Hill / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire / N.B. PM: London, 28 Dec. 1864. MS: NLS 609.696. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:240–42.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p:
Oh Darling, I have been wanting to write to you every day for a week; but the interruptions have been endless, and the unavoidable letters many,—on Xmas day I thought I should have a quiet day for writing Mr C being to dine at Forster’s But a young German LadyPossibly Elisabeth or Hedwig von Reichenbach; see JWC to MCA, [18 Oct.]. that I am very fond of “could not let me be left alone” and came at eleven in the morning, and staid till nine at night; and then our Rector,Gerald Blunt. bless him! came when he left church, and sat with me till eleven!! I wonder how you would have taken a thing that befel me last wednesday? I was waiting before a shop in Regent Street, for some items of Stationary, And a young woman, black-eyed, rosy-cheeked, with a child in her arms, thrust herself up to the carriage window, and broke forth in a paroxysm of begging; refusing to stand aside even when the Shopman was showing me envelopes Provoked at her noise and pertinacity I said; “No! I will give you not a single penny, as an encouragement to annoy other people as you are annoying me.” If there be still such a thing as the evil eye, that beggar woman
fixed the evil eye on me, as she said slowly, and hissing out the words, “This is Wednesday Lady. Perhaps you will be dead by Xmas day! and have to leave all behind you! Better to have given me a little of it now!” and she scuttled away, leaving me with the novel sensation of being under a curse!

Would you have minded that—after the moment? I can’t say I took it to heart, at the same time, I was rather glad when Xmas day being over I found myself alive and just as well as before. Dr Blakiston writes that his wife had been dreaming about me again! Bessey is a most Portentous Dreamer! If I had been told this between the Wednesday and Xmas day; it would have really frightened me I think!

My Dear! I have got five drops of my hearts-blood congealed and fastened together to encircle your wrist,Apparently a bracelet; JWC also called it a “trinket”; see JWC to MR, 30 Dec. as a memorial of my last visit and as a newyear’s blessing. I am hesitating whether to send it by post or by railway. I never lost nor knew personally of anything being lost by post except the Whigham Butterfly!Possibly a brooch in the shape of a butterfly, apparently sent to JWC by one of the Whigham sisters; see JWC to MR, 30 Dec. so I had best risk it—there is such confusion of parcels by rail at this time of year—only I will not register it—as I always think that just points out to the covetous postman what is worth stealing. Please to send a single line or an old newspaper by return of post that I may be sure the thing has not misgone—
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, 30 Dec. MS: NLS 609.697. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p: Thanks, Dearest for so speedily satisfying my mind. After I saw my little packet tossed into the Post-master’s Drawer, an apprehension came over me that we might have seen the last of it! To send away a trinket, which had got a prize at the ExhibitionPossibly the Great Exhibition of 1851; unexplained further. (!) unregistered, looked for the moment like a tempting of Providence! And again the Wigham Butterfly fluttered before my mind’s eye. But my notion is a sound one—not to seek security in pointing out to thievish postmen the articles considered of value, which pass thro’ their hands. No Postman of an ordinary mind will risk his liberty and respectability to possess himself of a packet which the sender has not thought it worth while to pay a shilling to ensure the safety of.
My private opinion about that Butterfly is, that it never got into the Sanquhar Postoffice at all.See JWC to MR, 27 Dec. Some careless Messenger must have made away with it.

I have got such a beautiful Dog for a Xmas gift—not living—printed! it is a copy of a picture by Velasques, (at the Grange)Possibly Velasquez’s A Dwarf, part of the Grange collection, described as a “male dwarf, with a parrot and a lap-dog. … Purchased [by Lord Ashburton] from the ex-King Joseph Bonaparte” (Charles Boyd Curtis, Velasquez and Murillo: a Historical and Descriptive Catalogue [1883], no. 40).—done by Miss Davenport BromleyThe copy by Caroline Davenport Bromley might have been of Velasquez’s Angels Appearing to the Shepherds which her father, Rev. Walter Davenport Bromley, had owned; after his death, 1862, it was bought by Lord Ashburton, 1863.— She is such a Darling Woman that!—for those she likes—those she does not like, and they are many, find her odious. To be an admired virtue Sincerity never makes the persons possessing it admired.

My Horse is almost recovered of his bad leg;See JWC to MR, [19 Dec.]. but they fear if I use him he will “just fall ill again,” and I am going to ask Lady Ashburton to let him spend the winter in one of her stock-yards. Meanwhile I have a livery Horse and the owner drives it, and far too carefully for my taste—I dont feel to have half driving enough in the two hours. How rich people are imposed on! Lady A’s Coachman gave an enormous price for this horse of mine, and she fancied it a treasure. and it turns out “far too soft for a carriage.” Another Horse he bought for her lately he made her give eighty pounds for, and it turns out fourteen years old!

Oh my Dear whereThus in MS. your wits woolgathering when you wrote, in answer to my question, that the name of “the young man at Laight” was David maxwell? I as nearly as possible sent a book to that address But I had a dim feeling that when I was there his name was something else! and I waited till I had asked you; “were you sure?—” Now, when you mention him, you call him Hanning which is so unlike Maxwell my Dear!For David Haining or Hanning, see JWC to MR, [31 Oct.].

I enclose the usual small contribution to the poor peoples newyears day dinners.JWC sent money every New Year for old Templand servants; see 34:258JWC to MR, 30 Dec. 1858. Tell me about Margaret Hiddlestone’s leg.See TC to JWC, 5 Sept.; she had suffered for some time from a bad leg; see 40:177JWC to TC, [10 Aug.]. I don’t like poor Margaret, but one can’t but be heartily sorry for her.

I had an idea of sending Mrs Ewart a BookJWC sent Alicia Ewart a copy of G. J. Whyte Melville, The Brookes of Bridlemere, 3 vols. (1864); see JWC to MR, 14 April 1865.— She was very goodnatured and kind to me—and I—was—to say the truth rather impatient of her— I
have been so busied and bothered of late days that the “devout imagination” still remains an imagination.

I have nothing definitely fixed about the Devonshire visit— Mr C hopes to be done in the middle of January— (I am not at all sure he will) and Miss Davenport Bromley who goes to Lady A before then must first assure me of the House being free from damp— I dont at all like the notion of going in the dead of winter into a House only begun to be built last June (I find)
Love to the Dr

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady A[LLA], 31 Dec. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: My dearest Lady! I do so want to be your “first foot”! on paper; since it cannot be in person! I am sure I should be a lucky “first foot” to you: for true love is a good gift to have laid at one’s feet—a whole armful of it!—on a new years morning! But you will have such a heap of letters to wish you “a good new year”! and how many will you open before mine? Ah well! I dont despair of your being in London next new years day, and of myself being alive to see it; and you shall see if I dont sit outside your bedroom door till you awake, and then glide in before the maid who opens your shutters, and speak the first “God bless you” and get your first kiss! Oh my Darling! my Darling! May this coming year be a better for you than the last! And, at the end of all my wishes for you and your wee Darling; let me add a good wish for myself! may you be as good and true for us in the coming year as you have been thro’ all the years that we have known you!JWC was initially very suspicious of Louisa Stewart-Mackenzie (see 34:231JWC to MR, [30 Oct. 1858]), but was quite won over during her first visit, Jan. 1860, to The Grange after Lady Louisa’s marriage to Lord Ashburton; see 36:45JWC to LLA, 16 Jan. 1860.

Miss Bromley was here the night before last, and told me she “had not heard from you but in the shape of a Turkey”!— I too had heard from you in that same shape! But I want a little morsel of your perplexing handwriting besides! Morning after morning I look at my letters discontentedly—because of the one that never comes!

I should have written, without waiting for a letter from you, to say several things I could not get said in the carriage that day, about the Horse!—that Horse which I felt towards somewhat as the Gentleman of the Omnibus must have felt towards the Baby he had taken to hold; when the mother vanished into space! But the Horse itself introduced a sudden complication into the
business, which I wished to see the end of before telling you. After having done her usual moderate work one day—the third day, I think, after you were here; she turned lame in one of herIn this sentence she wrote “his,” “he,” and “his,” then went back and overwrote “her,” “she,” and “her.” She previously referred to the horse as male; see JWC to Lady ALLA, 7 Dec., and JWC to MR, [19 Dec.]. hind legs, and was in such pain that the Farrier had to be “called in,” and a course of poultices adopted, and castor-oil “thrown into the system.”Coterie speech; see 2:479TC to JAC, 25 Nov. 1823. and “nothing positive could be said about her for some days yet.”— I have had a horse from the Livery Stable in the meanwhile; and it was “all right,”Coterie speech. so soon as I felt some assurance that the poor dear Grey would not need to be shot. But you cannot think how it vexed me the dread of that consumation! Such a way of thanking you for giving me a Horse!—to shoot it!

I have had Bennett to see it; and he thinks as Mr Silvester does, that it would be no use attempting to work the Horse at present altho’ the lameness is gone, “It should be let run in a strawyard over the winter Bennet says and her Ladyship would be quite willing it should run about at Addiscombe.” Would her Ladyship be quite willing? Bennet would take it there himself he says, and “apply some strengthening blister stuff” which he “has plenty of”— Will you say one word of this!

Mr C is working as hard as his Life depended on being done in January—and is so—so—what shall I say? bedevilled—! Naturally! The last mile of a journey is always the worst—and the last mile of such a journey as his has been!— Ach!
And he always speaks as if the next thing to be done after finishing were to go to Seaton. As for me it is my one bit of blue sky at present, that Seaton!
The Brougham is at the door and I must go and get ready for that Driving which my sleep and I may say my Life depends on.
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 2 Jan. Addr: Roslyn Park / Hampstead. PM: London, 2 Jan. 1865. MS: NLS 553.274. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p:
Dear Neuberg,—I wish you heartily, if wishes wd do any good, a right “happy New year,” in the language of the season. It is becoming long since I have seen you:—but the days are now lengthening; in spite of the formidable frost. I am
panting and toiling along; hope (fondly!) to finish my last two Chapters (i.e. rough copy of them) almost in the course of this week;—fond hope indeed!—

You once sent me an Excerpt from a Bishop EilertRulemann Friedrich Eylert (1770–1852), appointed Prussian court preacher, 1806, and bishop of the Evangelical Landeskirche of Prussia, 1817. (or some such name) abt Frh &his Nephew;The anecdote concerned Frederick and his grand-nephew Friedrich Wilhelm (1770–1840).—whh I laid by too well, and have hopelessly lost! “Sa droiture qui fait sa force [its rightness is its strength]”: if you cd in abt half a page condense that Anecdote for me (&say what or who this this ‘Bishop’ Eylert was), I wd still stick it in.TC repeated “this.” The anecdote was from Eylert’s Charakterzüge und historische Fragmente aus dem Leben des Königs von Preussen Friedrich Wilhelm III (Magdeburg, 1843); see Carlyle, Works 19:253–54. But let me not abuse yr goodness; I can do witht this Bp &his story.Neuberg replied, 4 Jan.: “It would be a pity to omit the pretty Anecdote. If the Book is in the Museum, you can have the Extract by Monday evening.” —— —— Great news from Berlin, as you see by the Copperplate part of this paper,—if I only knew who the delighted &delightful people are!TC’s letter was written on a sheet printed in copper-plate with the following announcement: “Die Verlobung meiner Tochter Marie mit dem Kaufmann und grossherzoglich-sächsischen Consul Herrn Alwin Stahr in Lille beehre ich mich ergebenst anzuzeigen [I am honoured humbly to announce the betrothal of my daughter Marie to the merchant and Consul of the Grand Duke of Saxony at Lille Mr. Alwin Stahr]. / Berlin, den 26 December 1864 / Ernestine Gerson / geb. Cohn”; and printed on the reverse: “Marie Gerson / Alwin Stahr / Verlobte [Betrothed]. / Berlin, 26 December 1864.” Alwin Stahr (1836–92), was the stepson of Fanny Stahr, b. Lewald (1811–89), German novelist and friend of Amalie Bölte (see JWC-[Lady A], to [LLA], 24 Nov.], who had met the Carlyles 1850 (see 25:202JWC to TC, [8 Sept. 1850]); she m., 1855, Adolf Stahr (1805–76). Ernestine Gerson, b. Cohn (ca. 1819–91), m., 1838, Hermann Gerson (1813–61), fashion designer and textile manufacturer; their da. Marie is unidentified further. Neuberg replied, 4 Jan.: “If the happy Berlin-Weimar Couple (who, at all events, know you,—as the man knew the Duke of Wellington!) were aware that their ‘great news’ was made the Vehicle of another, about ‘last two Chapters’ about to be finished,—it would, perhaps, make them proud as well as happy.” Arthur Wellesley (1769–1852; ODNB), 1st duke of Wellington. Riding, I fear, is at a nonplus till we get new-shod. Vorwärts [forward], all the same; and let us get to shore,—to shore, out of Dismal Swamp;See Henry Longfellow, “The Slave in the Dismal Swamp” line 1, Poems on Slavery (1842) 18. not quite drowned, tho’ desperate!

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MC, 4 Jan. MS: Duke. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO MARIA CHAMBERLAYNE

docBody.p: Thanks for your new-year good wishes.

I am glad to hear of your wellbeing. I thought should have seen you before now—either that you would come here, or that I should call at your gate someday, in the course of my daily drives. I have got a carriage and Horse now, “all to myself” (as the children say), and I am out driving from two to three hours every day, in all weathers; exercise in the open air being the only means under Heaven by which I can get any sleep, and my power of walking being now limited to a few yards at a time! So—I had it in my mind to call for you someday, when driving about the Commons But I did, not rightly remember your address,Not traced. and my Coachman, (not one of the Silvesters, but an old man who once fell on his head, and has been clear about nothing ever since) could give me no furtherance in finding it.

When I look back on my awful sufferings this time last year; I cannot sufficiently thank god for the comparative ease I now enjoy. ‘Well,’ I am not, and never expect to be; But the agony of suffering, which, for near a year, made me long for death every hour of every day—that is so far subsided that I can now lead my life, outwardly, much as I used to do; except for the weakness in my back and limbs which makes me unable to take long walks, or mount steps (!) or go up stairs three steps at a time!

All my people have been adorably kind to me thro’ my long illness. As for Lady Ashburton, my own Sister, had I been blessed to have one, couldnt have been more to me than she has been! So soon as Mr C has got his Book off his hands,—(in a few weeks—) He and I mean to go to Lady Ashburton at Seaton in Devonshire, where she is passing the winter. The Drs all recommended change for me as the most important remedy. and I like being with Her.
I had a nice little note from your MotherAnn Chamberlayne, who had worked for the Ashburtons at The Grange. this morning. When you write please thank her for me.
You remember Mary my little Cook? She produced a Baby in the house here, on the 29th of July, during my absence in Scotland. And that was far from the worst of her; as it turned out!

p.name: Jane Carlyle
p.note: Maria Chamberlayne wrote later about the Carlyles: “It is now many years ago since I first saw Mrs Carlyle—and from the first day when I saw her, until her life was ended so suddenly—I never realized, what a wonderful woman she was—until comparing her with others in a mental way— The sense of self-devotion, Separation, from everything, and person, which seemed to her the right thing to separate from, a keen observer of character, and a Certain demand that the exterior of a person should indicate moral worth—— Mr Carlyle also had these same views—and unless something of sterling worth, chiefly ‘veracity,’ appeared, why then they didn’t ‘Pass Muster’—and were not in high favour with either,— / Mrs Carlyle had a delicate, eccentric, appearance. Mr Carlyle was tall, handsome, and severe looking (ruddy too, and healthy-looking)—a nice looking couple.— In their younger days, both handsome, and distinguished looking!— / Looking forward” (Anna Maria Chamberlayne Dennison; undated. MS: Duke inc.).

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A[LLA], 5 Jan. Addr: Seaton / Devonshire. PM: London, 5 Jan. 1865. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: So generously obliging as you are to us,—permit me to say candidly what it is that I really do wish in regard to yr last act of munificence, that handsome young Grey Mare. It is that you cd nobly take it back, and put it to the work it was bot for (“at a long price,” as Bennet told our man)! “That is impossible,” you will ansr; “the work is already fallen to other hoofs”? What a pity, what a pity, if that is really so! Perhaps it is not quite altogether; and things cd be revoked if you willed it?— But if it is irrevocable, hear what follows:

This fine little Mare is standing idle, in a stable I don’t much like (for ventilation); her lameness gone for a week past,—but liable to return, says everybody, if she be tried in that carriage agn. In fact everybody’s vote is that she must never be yoked to it more. “A fine shewy horse, too,” our good old Stable-keeperJohn Silvester. says; “very nice temper &c; wd bring a good price in April or May!”— And mark withal, dear Lady; I don’t think yr Bennet has been dishonest,—I do think only misled (if even misled, for he didn’t calculate on a brougham of that weight). He votes however that the Mare be at once turned into looser quarter softer diet, at Addiscombe;—will himself take her over, and give instructions whenever you bid him. Please send him a line! That I really do wish;—and that will settle everything till at least we see Seaton &My Lady!——

How gladly shall we sally out thither, were the hour come. I really am close on the edge of finis; toiling with all my strength every moment. “Day of Publicatn is to be 15 feby at latest!” And two weeks before that I hope to be personally quite out of it.— Adieu, dear Lady.
docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [5 Jan.]. MS: NLS 609.698. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:316–18, where dated “December, 1864.” Dated here by the mention of the whisky JWC brought home from Holmhill; see JWC to MR, [19 Dec. 1864]. Presumably the basket was a New Year’s gift.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p:
If it weren’t, Dear, that the delay might make you anxious about the basket; I would not write this morning; having no time to make a decently long letter. But you will kindly accept a brief acknowledgement in the mean time; and the nice long letter will follow— I wish you had seen the sensation the basket produced; for we couldnt conceive what it contained or where it came from!— “Glasgow!” Mr C said; but who on earth, I asked, is there in Glasgow to send us anything? “Your Cousin JeanieJWC’s cousin Jeannie Chrystal, b. Welsh (Babbie) (1818–95), m., 1853, Andrew Chrystal (ca. 1811–83; see 24:186TC to JWC, 10 Aug. 1849), wine merchant with Ronald &Co., 27 St. Vincent’s Pl., Glasgow; they lived at 14 Queen’s Cres., Glasgow, with their da., Mary (1857–1937). Jeannie’s earlier correspondence with JWC ended after her marriage. perhaps”?— “Bah!—my cousin Jeanie never sent me anything in her life!” “Well let us get into the inside of it,” said Mr C, standing with his long pipe in his mouth, offering no assistance.— Fanny having placed the package in the middle of the Drawingroom floor had disappeared. At last by my unaided efforts I had extricated the basket from its brown paper. “Pooh! Said Mr C, it is more game!”— (Mr C doesn’t eat most sorts of game, and had been aggravated by the quantity sent lately)— “Dye know I have a notion it is fish” said I, rather mournfully, not seeing my way thro’ a basket of Fish!— “I am afraid it is—said he—just fish—and I wish you joy of it.” Then Fanny came back and helped me to open the basket. “Eggs!” said Fanny, solemnly, as if she had been solving the Problem of the Universe!— “Oh! Hang it!” said Mr C—“all broken again of course”— Mr C’s temper had been much tried latterly by boxfuls of eggs from both the Gill and Dumfries, arriving all in a state of mush!The recent eggs sent from The Gill were cracked rather than broken; see JWC to MCA, 21 Dec. [1864]. and he had written to forbid more eggs!— “These seem to be all whole, however, said I; who can have sent them?”— “A person whoever it be, said Mr C blandly, who knows something about the art of packing!”— “Look here! said Fanny, groping among the eggs; if that ain’t a Turkey?” Still, with the fixed idea of Glasgow put into my head, I never thought of Holmhill! Not till we arrived at the whisky. Then a light flashed on my soul! Oh it is Mrs Russell! I cried, where is the address? dont you know the handwriting? Mr C picked up the address and said “to be sure, that is Dr Russells writing!” You cant think what a good the little excitement did us! But I couldnt help a little shudder, on contemplating the dead
body of one of those Turkey that I had seen grow up from babyhood! slain for me! poor Bird!— The Whisky came exactly at the right moment, for only the night before, I had swallowed the last drop in the bottle I brought home with me! And was thinking I should have to put up with the Irish L L whisky the only sort procurable here.JWC presumably referred to Kinahan’s LL Irish Whisky, a blended whisky widely available in England.

There wasn’t a single egg broken—one crakedThus in MS. that was all! a thousand thanks! and I am so glad the package did not come from Glasgow as Mr C said;—it makes all the difference whom a present comes from!
I have been sleeping very badly for the last ten days, without any assignable reason but last night was better so I hope the spell is broken.
I have a great many things to do before going out for my drive; so must stop
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-MC[MCON], 9 Jan. Addr: 28. Notting Hill Square / (With Newspaper). PM: London, 9 Jan. 1865. Envelope only: MS: Columbia. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO MONCURE CONWAY

docBody.p: [Letter untraced]

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [13 Jan.]. Holm Hill / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire / N.B. PM: London, 13 Jan. 1865. MS: NLS 609.699. Letter dated by TC’s fall from his horse, 9 Jan.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p:
Dearest. I had sworn to answer a letter from my Aunt Elizabeth,Elizabeth Welsh in Edinburgh. as in duty bound; before writing to any one else for my own pleasure; and duty-letters always take me so long! after trying three morning in succession I finally paid off Elizabeth yesterday; and tho’ this morning’s Post has brought me three letters, of which at least two require answers, they can wait while I please myself in telling you my news, such as they are! In fact “none to speak of.”Coterie speech; see 17:63JWC to TC, 18 Aug. 1843. Was there ever such uncertain weather? Yesterday I speculated about substituting a shawl for my fur coat; but didn’t do it luckily, for before my drive ended it
had become extremely cold. “Frost again” Mr C said, but when he looked out at bedtime it was falling “a soft warm rain”! During the night, a snow-storm covered everything some inches deep! While dressing I looked out on a white world!— now, already the snow has washed itself away in the rapidest thaw I ever beheld! What is a delicate object, like me, to do amidst such changes? Follow Paddy’s rule I suppose, “just keep never minding”!Coterie speech; see 22:161TC to JF, 18 Nov. 1847. Practically I do that. No weather has yet kept me to the House a day since I left Holm Hill! I am sure that it is the driving, and nothing else, that enables me to get some sleep, more or less every night. I observe that when I stay out three hours, as I do most days, I sleep better than when I have been out only two hours. But it is still some work to get thro’ the nights! Such tossing about before I go suddenly to sleep! such a many and miserable wakings when I have gone to sleep! But I keep to the new habit of having no night-light, and no accepibleThus in MS. watch; and I am sure it is best so!
I still have the tumbler of newmilk at eight—and I eat pretty well—for me, who had never a large “receiver” (as a poor woman at HaddingtonUnidentified further. used to call stomach)
I take no medecine except my old pills—but these I cannot dispense with for a day.

On the whole I get no worse Not much better either I think, I have not gone into the Shampooing; having a perfect horror of the women who come to manipulate one in any way! I have a sort of insane objection to being come close to, or touched by any extraneous person, that I am not in sympathy with! Oh no! I can put on and off my own clothes now, and am so thankful I can avoid a servant fiddling about me!— — Even Dr Blakiston who has as little patience with freaks of the imagination as anybody I ever saw, recognised the fact that the worry of “the woman” who came in to rub me &c at St LeonardsUnidentified further. “did me more harm than her services did me good”! If I walk but little, or no better than I did at Holm Hill, at least I dont feel so much the fatigue of walking lame—am either stronger to bear it, or more used to it! We are an odd pair here just now; for Mr C is walking lamer than I do! He is the most careless, most reckless of riders and has oftener brought his horse down and been pitched over its head, than any man I know. The other day again, his horse, who has no vice, only high spirits, delighted at having his head turned towards home, threw all its four feet at once into the air; and Mr C not so much as thinking he was on the back of a horse was tossed in the air!For TC’s account of the fall, see TC to JN, 16 Jan. In general he
comes out of these adventures perfectly scatheless, never seeming surprised at, or particularly thankful for his escape. This time however he hurt his ancle bone—not a sprain, nor much of a bruise. but a sufficient hurt to make it impossible for him to take his usual walking exercise; tho he can ride as usual.

I bathe it—as much as he will let me with arnica in water—and it is greatly better—the swelling gone down—and he can walk after a sort without pain, but there is no getting him to take care of it—and I am afraid he will take a long walk and play the devil with it again—
I sent Mrs Ewart a book which I hope she will not find too dull—also a volume of Mr C to the young man at Laight.David Haining; see JWC to MR, [31 Oct.].

How strange it is to think of the old Father standing crying beside me that evening, because his son was dying—and now he is dead and his son is alive!The Dumfries Courier noted, 6 Dec.: “At Laicht, Tynron, on the 29th ult., Thomas Haining, farmer, Laight, aged 68 years.” I hope the poor young fellow will recover.

What do they say in Nithsdale about Lady Victoria’s marriage?Lady Victoria Alexandria Scott was to marry Schomberg Henry Kerr 23 Feb. Here, they say three things, first that the marriage had been made up by the Mothers,Lady Victoria’s mother was Charlotte, duchess of Buccleuch; Schomberg Henry Kerr’s mother was Lady Cecil Chetwynd Talbot, dowager marchioness of Lothian. and the young people did not care for each other; second that the Duke interfered, because he was told the young people, as soon as married, would declare themselves Catholic!Lady Cecil converted to Roman Catholicism, 1851, and encouraged her children in the faith; the duchess of Buccleuch also converted to Catholicism, 1860, under the influence of Lady Cecil. third—and, this is the version most believed—that another Lady Schomberg had revealed herself in Germany!!Unidentified further; as Lady Victoria and Schomberg Henry Kerr m. 23 Feb., this was presumably merely rumor. A friend of mine has a Nephew an Attaché (at Frankfort (?) and the nephews wifeUnidentified further. told my friend that she had been so plagued with a German lady whom she thought must be mad always coming to ask for Lord Schomberg’s address, and declaring that she had a perfectly legal right to know— My Friend thought this was probably Lady Schomberg the 2d. I know an aunt of Lord Schomberg very well Lady Gomme,Elizabeth Ann, Lady Gomm, b. Kerr (ca. 1801–77), wife of Field Marshal Sir William Maynard Gomm (1784–1875; ODNB), was Schomberg Henry Kerr’s first cousin once removed. JWC’s “Lord Schomberg” apparently means Schomberg Henry Kerr. and shall ask her about it when she comes to town. Now good-by my Darling— In ten minutes my carriage will be round—
My grey horse is gone to run, for some months in the strawyard at Addiscombe. Meanwhile I have to hire one lovingly yours J W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 16 Jan. Addr: Roslyn Park / Hampstead. PM: London, 17 Jan. 1865. MS: NLS 553.277. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 5:562.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Dear Neuberg,—Mr Forster has sent me the Letter abt Goldsmith; he does not remember to have given the Applicant permission, rather thinks he did not;Agnes von Bohlen apparently thought Forster had been favorable to a trans. of his Goldsmith; Neuberg quoted her, 19 Dec. 1864, as referring to Forster’s “generous offer about the illustrations”; see TC to JF, 1 Dec. 1864.— but supposes any Berlin Bookseller cd at present tell whether the Book was translated. Please return the Letter; I have put the Address upon it, in case you be not sending to me at any rate.

Thanks for yr goodness about the Eylert. I know not who or what wrote the memoirs of Eylert; but it is very evidt no part of that Dialogue betn Frh &his Nephew is the least in the style of Frh; nor does that betn Frh Wm III and his Chaplain wear at all a practically true look. There must have been some faint substance of truth, however, in both; or a Clergyman wd not have been in the habit of mentioning the thing.See TC to JN, 2 Jan. Neuberg wrote, 10 Jan.: “Here is the Anecdote from Eylert. I have not attempted to translate Friedrich’s words, as you will thus be better able to restore to it some of its original colouring. / Friedrich’s pathetic, almost prophetic mood, in the Anecdote, would lead to the supposition of his being, at the time, softened by ill health.” I have next to no room at any rate. Yesterday I sent Finis to press; but shall not be quite rid yet for a week or more. My little villain of a Horse exploded under me, like a powder magazine, this night weekMon. 9 Jan. (suddenly, in the dark,—out of “joy at being done,” not with Frh!)—flung me over his ears, and kicked my ancle rather badly while I was in the air: dextrous Horse! I can now cripple abt again. Yrs always
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 16 Jan. MS: NLS 526.21. Hitherto unpbd. Alexander Carlyle later wrote “Fr.k done!” at the top of the MS and underlined the date.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
Dear Brother,—In yr solicitude you have aggravated to yrself the affair of the ancle. I don’t think it will turn out very serious. Evidently nothing is hurt except the top of the ancle-bone (periostium there, I suppose) and that by no means much; tho’ the whole foot had got dirled and shaken, and is swolen in consequence tho’ the pain genlly lasted only the first night. Today I think the swelling is perhaps rather abated than otherwise; on the outskirts too it
is getting black (like a black eye, going away) as upon the toes, inside of the heel &c, and even slightly over the instep part. No real pain thereabts or anywhere, only a stiffness. I am perfectly strong upon my saddle agn; yesternight (moon shining &night very fine) I walked out, Battersea Bridge &c hardly halting at all, but cautious. The woollen shoesPossibly the knitted “sock boots” made for him by his sister Jean Aitken; see 36:7TC to JCA, 13 Nov. 1859; see also 40:104TC to HL, [26 May 1864]. (originally of Dumfries are a great resource,—so soft and wide (the “rubbing” that I spoke of is in walking, &comes by one of these and the ancle within it). My worst hindrance is the want of walking as exercise! To want riding too,—wd be to want sleep food (digestn), everything: I know not what I shd then do;—I ought to be thankful! It was all joy in the little wretch of a Horse; he exploded under me like gunpowder (had not done so for a year &half before).

Last night my secondary errand out was to put the last leaf of Frk Ms. in a Post-Office.TC wrote later: “Sunday night, January 5 [15], 1865, went out to post-office with my last leaf of ‘Frederick’ MS. Evening still vivid to me. I was not joyful of mood; sad rather, mournfully thankful, but indeed half killed, and utterly wearing out and sinking into stupefied collapse after my ‘comatose’ efforts to continue the long flight of thirteen years to finis. On her face, too, when I went out, there was a silent, faint, and pathetic smile, which I well felt at the moment, and better now! Often enough had it cut me to the heart to think what she was suffering by this book, in which she had no share, no interest, nor any word at all; and with what noble and perfect constancy of silence she bore it all. My own heroic little woman: For long months after this I sank and sank into ever new depths of stupefaction and dull misery of body and mind; nay, once or twice into momentary spurts of impatience even with her, which now often burn me with vain remorse: Madame Elise, e.g.—I sulkily refused to alight at the shop there, though I saw and knew she gently wished it (and right well deserved it); Brompton Museum (which she took me to, always glad to get me with her, and so seldom could). Oh, cruel, cruel! I have remembered Johnson and Uttoxeter on thought of that Elise cruelty more than once; and if any clear energy ever returned to me, might some day imitate it.—T.C.” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:242–43). Uttoxeter is the Staffordshire village where Samuel Johnson (1709–84; ODNB) stood bare-headed in the rain to expiate his refusal fifty years before to accompany his father to the market (Boswell’s Life of Johnson 4:373). Robson actually has Finis now in hand. I felt profoundly serious abt it, sad rather than joyful, in my ride and walk yesterday. Ah me!—— For abt a week I shall still be bothered combing and trimming (not very much either,—were not my head so dull, from the no-walking &c); in a 10 days even Robson will have done; and there will be freedom as air. Rejoice, all my friends— The Kirkpk Testimonials come.Possibly for one of the two eldest sons of Sir Charles Sharpe Kirkpatrick, 6th bart. of Closeburn (1811–67) and Helen Stuart Kirkpatrick, b. Kirk (1814–77): Thomas (1839–80) and James (1841–99); their other sons were Roger (b. 1842), Charles William (1843–1908), Robert Herries (1848–94), and Arthur Renton (1852–1922). John A. Carlyle wrote to TC, 15 Feb.: “Mr Kirkpatrick about whom I wrote has failed to get the Inspectorship in the Highlands for which he was a candidate.” I send a Paris Newspr, whh you may give to Irma.Irma Otthenin (1838–97); she lived in Edinburgh with her mother, Jean Otthenin, and her sister Margaret; see 39:27539:biographical notes. For a photograph of Irma, see 39:173JWC to LLA, 13 Aug. [1863], and of Jean Otthenin, see 39:115TC to JAC, 29 April 1863. Adieu
docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 20 Jan. MS: NLS 517.75. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Dear Brother,—I have £2,000 lying in the Adamson Bank,British Linen Co. Bank, Dumfries, where TC had his main bank account; Samuel Adamson was its manager; see 40:159TC to JAC, 1 Aug. 1864. ready for such an investt; 2 or perhaps £3,000;John A. Carlyle wrote, 19 Jan.: “Do you want now to invest any money, as you did when I enquired of Adamson for you in autumn? If so, I could at present probably get you Guaranteed Caledonian &other Railway Stock … to yield a clear 4½ per cent. One word by return of post, if I am to do any thing in this matter for you.” John A. Carlyle handled many of TC’s investments; see TC to JAC, [ca. 12 Oct. 1864]. TC later wrote on the letter: “first Proposal / 19 jany 1865 /ansr ‘Yes’. … / T.C.”—and in a couple of months more, I may expect to have another 2 (tho’ Chapman possibly will insist on long bills for good part of that).Chapman preferred to pay TC in installments; see 40:65TC to JWC, 13 April [1864], and TC to JAC, 16 Feb. Let us not exceed £3,000 for the moment. I will implicit[l]yLetter omitted. rely upon yr judgt for investing: Do what you think best for me;—only no bother abt it (or none avoidable!) now or after!—

My ancle is improving fast,—especially since I bandaged it, as you advised, in spite of Jane’s apprehensions (abt hurting the swelling) whh Blakistn had taught her: on the contrary, it pushes the swelling away!— — Robson hangs fire; but must let me go shortly. I am still busy every moment (and terribly interrupted)

p.name: T. Carlyle
p.note: JWC’s old friend Richard Plattnauer wrote, 17 Jan.: “I just heard from Lady Downshire that you wish to see me. I shall come to town on Friday afternoon. Please let me know when you can receive me.” Richard Eduard Plattnauer; Lady Caroline Frances Downshire. Plattnauer was tutor to the Downshire children in the 1850s; see 32:151TC to JAC, 22 May 1857.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 25 Jan. MS: NLS 517.76. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Dear Brother,—Thanks for the trouble you are taking. I have slit off the little Leaf, docketed it, put cheque for 2,805 .. 17 .. 9TC noted: “25 jany 1865 to Dr J. A. Carlyle (for Purchase of Stock to me; interest 4½ per cent). £2,805 .. 17 .. 9” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). TC also noted on the envelope of John’s letter of 27 Jan.: “26 jany 1865 / £2,805 .. 17 .. 9 / invested for me.” beside it; and inclosed the whole to Adamson, with a Note, in whh I suppose to him that you have already given him warning of the thing, &that you will send him the Stock Documents to take charge of so soon as they are got. At any rate he is bidden write to you, if in doubt abt anything, and is to do what you [say].Word omitted. The Cheque says ‘Pay’ &c (erasing ‘or Bearer’).. ‘Hanovr Stt Edinr) in the form requested.’ This so far as I can make out (for yr brevity is not quite lucid to me in every point) combines all I had to do.John A. Carlyle replied, 27 Jan.: “You will have to sign a paper for transfer sometime before the 10th of February, &then will get the Stock &send it to Adamson—or rather I shall get it &send it. Please don’t bother yourself any further in the matter. I will take care that every thing be done faithfully &orderly. Of course I did not think it at all necessary to write to Adamson myself when I asked you to send me the order thro’ him, but I wrote him yesterday to prevent all possibility of mistake &he wd get my letter last night after sending off his order.” Will you have to go to Glasgow? I hope, not! Again many thanks.

Today I hoped to get quite done with the last bad difficulty in Proof-correcting; yesterday, rejoicing in the thaw, and well slept, I had great success: but Today is questionable;—already good part of it running off with one bother &another. To work, then, to work!——

ps.p: Yr Note-CoversEnvelopes. are tremendous;—can hardly be opened even with a knife! The Inventor ought to be,—dismissed with costs, to say no more.Stephen Spring Rice (1814–65; see 14:241TC to JOST, 28 July 1842, and 39:260TC to SSR, 28 Dec. 1863) wrote from Albergo Croce di Malta, Spezia, 21 Jan.: “Your time is too valuable to be spent in writing me a letter, &I have no strength to be so employed indeed I am forbidden to write— But that is no reason why we shd not exchange 6d stamp. Will you send me one, &write under it how Mrs Carlyle is, and how you are yourself. … I find I get to care more for hearing of my friends, instead of being hardened by my own difficulties. These latter are less than they were: I am not I think, quite so near death’s door as I was 2 mo. ago.” He d. 9 May on board the Tripoli on his way home from the Mediterranean.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-GM[GMO], 28 Jan. Pbd: London Mercury, 8 (June 1923): 169–70. George Morrall, iron worker from Wolverhampton; he wrote to TC again, Dec. 1866, and also corresponded with Jean Aitken, late 1865 and early 1866.
div3.head: JWC TO GEORGE MORRALL

docBody.p: I have to ask your pardon, as it is mostly my fault that your letter to Mr. Carlyle has lain so long without any sort of answer.

My husband being exceptionally busy in these weeks, just finishing his long laborious work (The History of Frederick), handed me the letter, and desired me to answer it. Not only was he pressed for time, he said, but I “had more knowledge of the subject than He had,” not knowing at all what likeness of him was the best—or rather the least bad! I took the letter and laid it by, and “did intend”Coterie speech. to do his bidding as soon as I should have finished some business in hand, and—forgot it utterly!—till this morning that your letter fell accidentally under my eyes, giving me the sensation of a blow in the face!

I now hasten to inform you that there is positively no good likeness of my husband to be had for love or money. He has been sculptured and painted and photographed over and over and over again, but with always the same ill success—at least the result has been always more or less of a failure.

He promised long ago to sit to Holman Hunt for a portrait;There is no record of a painting of TC by William Holman Hunt, although TC admired his work; see 36:99–100TC to LS, 19 April 1860. as soon as his book was done; I expect something comfortable may come out of that!

For the rest; I send you a carte de visite,Probably from one of William Jeffrey’s 1862 photographs; see 38:frontis.38:frontispiece, available in the CLO on the table of contents page. which would be no bad reminiscence of him for a person who had seen him; but can hardly I think give a fair idea of him to an entire stranger.

p.note: George Cooke wrote to JWC, 25 Jan., announcing the death of “my unfortunate’s” sister, 23 Jan.: “Monday night finished my unfortunate’s sister’s sufferings—and to quote an old hacknied phrase ‘after life’s fitful fever she sleeps well’—she would see none of us, save her own sister— I have been at home all day yesterday having many letters to write— I have a weary task in prospect, to go down to Sevenoaks 24 miles from London to attend the funeral. … Believe my dearest Friend / Ever yours in truest affection.” The “unfortunate” is unidentified; possibly a servant.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 3 Feb. MS: NLS 526.22. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: A short word rather than none. I am not working now; but hurried abt still with a fashery of Notes &etceteras.

My far worst news is, poor Jane fell suddenly ill, Sunday night betn 10 and 11, while getting into bed; not the old story at all, but great pain, sickness, weakness, neither sleep nor food for 48 hours following. I proposed a Doctor; but poor old Barnes is quite done;Dr. Alfred Brooke Barnes, who was probably suffering from dementia. and we were at a loss who, she answerg positively “None.” Tuesday night, I sent for young Barnes;Dr. Herbert Sedgwick Barnes. who proves to be a very sensible fellow: he pronounced the thing at once to be cold (taking the stomach &intestines); &at once produced some relief in it (mustard blister &c); and has gone on improving her and it steadily ever since;—so that we hope it is now fairly on the departing hand. God grant it! In my gloom for the first two days, I was considerable alarmed.
My last Proof is with Robson; he undertakes that I shall be off altogether by Saty night (say Monday Morning)!—

There has long been a hanging engaget that, on this event, we were to go at once to Lady Ashburntn’s, who has built herself a nice little Cottage (or small mansion) by the sea-shore (Seaton the neighbg Town, in Devonshire, close by the Dorsetshire border): of course, we cannowThus in MS. now go there at once; but still intend, as the perhaps eligiblest place of all, till fine weather &Scotland supervene! Ah me, ah me!— — I feel utterly bilious, weak &c; but expect confidently to rally by rest. Yesterday I first put on leather shoes agn; walked, instead of rode. Quite well that. Book comes out I shd think abt March 1; Chapman said yesty “feby 20.”Vols. 5 and 6 of Frederick were pbd. mid-March. Adieu dear Brother; it is now 2, my riding hour today.

div3.sourceNote: TC’s Memoranda[TCM], [3 or 4 Feb.]. MS: NLS Acc. 5074. TC labeled the folded document: “in re Chapman”; he sent it to John Forster as a record of royalties for previous vols. of Frederick for Forster to negotiate with Chapman on his behalf; see TC to JF, 6 Feb.

docBody.p: Mema of the Messrs Chapman &me, in regard to voll 4 &3 of History of Friedrich
1 May 1862, for royalty on 4,000 Copies of vol 3, I am allowed (deducting for Gift Copies of this and former volumes) - - - - £1099 .. 6 (paid half at once, half by bill with interest allowed).

24 April 1864 for Vol IV (royalty &c as above, I supose, but there is nothing written except the bills), I get £1,116 .. 13 .. 6 (payable 1/3 of it (i.e. £372 .. 4 .. 6) ready, 1/3 at 6, 1/3 at quarter;—the finis of whh I find to be paid duly 5 jany 1865).
Voll. 5 &6 are to be as vol IV.Forster wrote on the reverse: “The payment on 5 and 6 / will be only for 3000 Vol. 1. 5000 Vol 2. 5000 / Vol 3. 4500 / Vol 4. 4500 Vol 5 and Vol 6 / 3000 copies.”
docBody.name: T.C.

ps.p: (for John Forster Esq his care)

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 4 Feb. MS: NLS 517.77. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: I did not wish to frighten you; and so have said nothing till now, when I can give a little better acct. Last Sunday night, quite on the sudden, abt bedtime, poor Jane was taken very ill;—lay moaning, when I came in from my final walk, and cd hardly speak to me: she had been out that day, as every day, for a long drive; and complained of nothing all evg. I fancied it might be something of cold; for day (the lazy break of a storm) was a dirty damp-frosty, leaden-coloured day: but she wd not hear of a Doctor;—lay in that moaning miserable way all night, all next day; then agn all next day, totally sleepless, foodless: at length on Tuesday Evg, I insisted on some kind of Doctor (the son of our old Barnes, who has done really well): in two hours, he had produced some relief; and things have gone on well ever since;—so that the poor soul is now in the Drawingroom agn, and takes some food &sleep, and is cheerful of speech; tho’ not permitted to think of driving agn till Monday at soonest.

My Printer was to have sent me the last Sheet this morning; but has not done it, has put it off till night; whh I like quite as well, not being in very fine
key today. I will finish him off on Monday, I think; Book is to “come out abt Feby 20” (guess March 1). Today I am going (heroically!) to have a vile decayed tooth pulled out. I have endless things to sort &sweep away. I have even to have my hair cut; nay even to have my beard clipt,—both of whh have been neglected this long time. Scotland and you, depend upon it, I will see, if we both live. Nay I often think if I had some hadding, I shd be tempted to stay there. This rousing muddy Babylon has become horrible &odious to me. Nothing can exceed the state state Word repeated at turn of page. of bilious wreck I am in; but I confidently hope to improve when turned out to grass &the shoes off.

We are due first at Lady Ashburtons, a small quiet Sea-Mansion in Devonshire (abt 3 hours off us), so soon as Jane is able to travel. It will be as dull as needs; but the silence &clear air will be welcome. As soon as the weather invites at all, I am off, after that, by the Carlisle Rail. I am going to put away my little caper-haddockWhile TC used “haddock” as a derogatory term for people (cf. 3:296TC to JAC, 7 March 1825), he used it as an affectionate term for a horse (see 7:68TC to JCA, 19 [Jan.? 1834]); “caper” was what Noggs did constantly. of a Horse; man never was more tired of thing than I am of riding in the ever raging, jumbling, shrieking and every way disgusting purlieus of this Babylon the Larger (and the uglier surely!)— I have had by computatn near 30,000 milesTC calculated he rode his previous horse, Fritz, 20,000 mi. (32,187 km.) between Nov. 1856 (see 32:31TC to JAC, 19 Nov. 1856) and Feb. 1863; see 39:58TC to JAC, 13 Feb. 1863. He later wrote that he rode 30,000 mi. (42,280 km.) during the writing of Frederick (Froude, LM 3:174; 39:203TC to LLA, [23 Sept. 1863]). of it,—mostly in the dusk &night.

A good Carriage Horse (that cd occasionally ride), strong for a brougham; healthy, quiet soundhoofed &c is, or will soon be, considerably wanted here. If yr James wd make inquiry in Dumfrs neighbd? He is a gleg man, &might hear of somethg. Adieu, dear Sister: Your Affe T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-[FC], 6 Feb. MS: Strouse. Hitherto unpbd. Frederic Chapman is identified as the recipient in TC to [WEN], 6 Feb.
div3.head:
TC
TO [FREDERIC CHAPMAN]

docBody.p:
Dear Sir,— I am afraid yr Letterer Unidentified further. has made quite a botch of both these Inscriptions.Inscriptions to the engravings in vols. 5 and 6 of Frederick. In vol. 5, under the picture of Frederick: “Franke, Pinxit. (Potsdam circa 1770 ) / Mandel, Sculpsit. (Berlin, 1860)”; the picture is then titled: “FRIEDRICH II KÖNIG IN PREUSSEN. / (Ætatis 58.) / From a Picture by Franke, of Potsdam; painted for the Herren Schickler, Bankers, Berlin, in whose Banking-House it still is; / Copies or Repetitions by Franke himself occur in English Collections” (Frederick vol. 5: frontis [1865]; the picture is reproduced but without most of the wording in Carlyle, Works 17: frontis 17:frontispiece ). In vol. 6, under the picture of Frederick: “J. Browne, sculpsit. London 1864”; the picture is then titled: “FRIEDRICH II KÖNIG von PREUSSEN. / Ætatis 73. / From Cunningham’s Engraved Picture of what is called Friedrich’s ‘Last Review’ (‘Frédéric le Grand retournant ä Sans-Souci après Les Manoeuvres, accompagné de / ses Généraux’: Picture containing 39 excellent Portraits besides this of Friedrich; Joseph Cunningham, pinxit, and J. F. Clements, sculpsit. Berlin. 1787) See Vol. VI. p. 680” (Frederick vol. 6: frontis [1865]); this picture was reproduced without most of the wording in Carlyle, Works 19: frontis; see 155. Raging nonsense is mainly what I make of it at prest,—especially
in the “Exhibition” (for repetition) case; tho’ indeed the other too is bad.——Let him come down to me in person at once, and we will try. Between 11 and 12 any day (if tomorrow, he will find me till 2 p.m);—& let there be no delay. Alas, alas, it is a sad job.

figure.p: Joseph Cunningham, Frédéric le Grand retournant à Sans-Souci (detail)
Thomas Carlyle, History of Friedrich II. of Prussia (1898)

docBody.p:
And pray oblige me by paying that Wood-EngraverSee TC to [Wood-Engraver] [WEN] , 6 Feb.
, Unidentified further; possibly J. Browne, who engraved Frederick 6: frontis 6:frontispiece . at once : he well deserves his wages; and I am shocked to have got him such treatment.

If LarkinHenry Larkin was compiling the index for Frederick; see TC to [FC], 8 Feb.
do not make appearance tomorrow, be so good as let me know directly.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-[Wood-Engraver][WEN], 6 Feb. MS: Carlyle’s House. Hitherto unpbd. Wood-Engraver possibly J. Browne (see TC to [FC], 6 Feb.); otherwise unidentified.
div3.head: TC TO [WOOD-ENGRAVER]

docBody.p: Dear Sir,——I am very sorry, and indeed provoked, that you shd have had such bother abt your Account so justly due.

I have written to Mr F. Chapman that beyond all doubt you got the order from me, and also that you did it excellently well in every respect;—and thirdly that you must be paid at once—whh result, you may depend on it, I will myself see accomplished (if there need farther supervision),—well knowing that the Labourer is worthy of his hire;See Luke 10:7. and with what skill, fidelity and punctuality you have all along performed whatever you undertook for me.
Begging many pardons (for the Younger Chapman’s sake,Frederic Chapman was the junior partner at Chapman &Hall. who seems not to know you at all, and may be excused on that ground), I remain

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 6 Feb. MS: NLS 526.23. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I got a Witness yesterday; and signed these things.Papers relating to the buying of stocks; see TC to JAC, 20 and 25 Jan. On looking into them I seem to have a dim understandg of everything,—except of a £28 .. 7 .. 9 (whh you will see marked on the back of yr last Note; whh please return to me with perhaps a word of explanatn added.Untraced.— Robson is still hanging to me by one claw, the wretched mortal (to speak in the language of impatience); but will not be able to spoil more than one other hour for me,—probably on Tuesday night or Wedny morning next.— Jane continues, pretty steadily, to get better; nothing of her old complaint traceable in this: if the weather mend (whh has been cruel &pluisterous to a pitch), I hope she may get into the brougham agn, before this week end. Monday come a fortnight (feby 20th), it is proposed by Lady An that we come to Seaton. My ancle is behaving well; willing to perform if I use caution; swelling, except just abt the ancle-bone, is pretty much all gone. Saturday last, I walked (heroically Oh!) up to Stokes the Dentist’s in Lr Brook-Street;Charles Stokes, surgeon-dentist, 65 Brook St., Hanover Sq.; see 34:122JWC to TC, [12 Aug. 1858]. who, with an art deserving admiration, plucked out a villain of a grinder whh had long been in open mutiny. Tomorrow (or so) I mean to have my hair cut; next day perhaps my beard clipt; and sic de caeteris [thus for the rest]. There lie mountains of lumber &wreck abt me;—and a great quantity of Trashy Notes to ansr; whh I am most impatient with of all. Item, I took a five-grainer (of the blue sort),Blue pill; see 32:111TC to LA, 26 March 1857. Saty-Night; and have not yet got the supplement of caster administered.

When you see Mr Erskine give him my affectionate regards; and say I mean to write (will “Charlotte-Square”Erskine usually spent the winters in Edinburgh at 41 Charlotte Sq. do?) from the sea side. Poor Fergus, whom I hoped also to visit, I was shocked to hear, is dead.John Fergus d. 23 Jan. “at his villa near Plymouth” (Scotsman, 25 Jan.); see also TC to JWC, [16 Sept. 1864]. Plymouth was about 64 mi. (103 km.) W of Seaforth Lodge. Alas, alas!— Write a deliberate word shortly.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JF, 6 Feb. MS: FC. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 5:566.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN FORSTER

docBody.p: Dear Forster,—I hope I shall hear a better acct today when I call.Forster suffered increasing ill health during the 1860s; see Davies, John Forster 121. I cd not get, yesterday,—for abt 5 reasons: the worst was, poor Jane rather on the downward way; but that happily is now mended agn. Abt 1 o’clock this morng I put into the Post-Office (not sooner, such a Key [frame of mind] was I in, &such had been the bothering conditn of the thing itself) my ultimatum of Proofsheet; Wedny or so, it will hold me one hour; then free of it, I hope, to all eternity!—

On Saty, or Friday after seeing you, I sought out the Chapman records (very scanty), and made memorandum; whh I meant for you last night, and here inclose.See TC’s Memoranda, [3 or 4 Feb.]. I think he cannot, practically and in reality, be ready to publish till March 1 (tho’ “feby 20” was what he talked of): you, like the Champn of Xtendom you have always been, will pin down these financial Demons to the place that belongs to them, &save an afflicted worn-out man from such cattle.
I will try at the door of Palace-Gate this day; and at least leave this, &have news. Yrs ever truly
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 7 Feb. MS: NLS 517.78. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p:
We are haggling along pretty well here; Jane eats a little better daily, sleeps do, and is in fair spirits;—totally unable to get out yet, so muddy &raw is the weather; wd go now. I think, if a really fine day came. We are to start for Devonshire (if able) Monday week, “Monday 20th.” Book will hardly be out then; but that need not detain us. I have daily fash with it, tho’ myself done. Sometimes I begin operating on the cartload of rubbish it has left; but not with any vigour yet. I got my tooth handsomely pulled out of my way that day I wrote (a considerable relief to me); I have also, by the younger maid-servantFanny. (who carries a little knife, “blunt all but the point, Sir” for such purposes, and is really expert), got my two worst corns extracted,—whh is almost a still greater relief. Tomorrow or so,—I mean to have my hair cut! Slowly advancing, you see; slow but sure.——— — I have never any difficulty of
packing myself agt the cold; slipper ice is my only bugbear (in spite of steel nails); tho’ nothing dangers has ever even threatened to happen, and we are now abt thro’, thank Heaven! I sleep an hour daily wrapt in the old red quilt you made me, with rug, with oldest cape,—with extremely old wide-awake on side of head. I want for nothing in the muffetee way.Fingerless mittens, or wrist warmers; see 38:23TC to JCA, 7 Dec. 1861. What you can really do, I think, is this: Get me a pair of spats for Devonshire walkings. The spats they sell here are imaginary; fastening on with a spelk (splint of whalebone inside) &sham buttons on the outside for shew. Detestable to my very thot. I care not much whether you get black cloth,—or perhaps drab cassimere. Stout &lasting is the word. As to measure,—that perhaps is the insuperable difficulty? Ask first. A rough fit will do. On the inclosed PaperUntraced. I have sent you some dimensions, exact so far. Inquire &see— Yours ever T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, 8 Feb. Addr: Holme Hill / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 8 Feb. 1865. MS: NLS 609.700. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head:
JWC
TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p: I have just received your letter, and will not lose a post in answering it tho in a day or two I might be able to write more to your satisfaction— I have been ill—very ill, and confined to bed for a week; and tho now able to sit up most of the day, I am so wearied that I cannot do anything but read a few pages now and then of some silly novel.

The Dr said I had got “a chill” (I am sure I dont know when or how) and the result was inflamation of the bowels and I was for three days and nights in such agony as I never felt before—but rather that—then the old nervous business!—
When I could hardly draw breath for pain, I kept thanking god it was good straightforward pain —with a beginning and an ending—a thing that could be acted upon, and that had a name!

Young Mr Barnes,Dr. Herbert Sedgwick Barnes. whom we sent for, knowing of no one near that would be better, brought me, I think, very cleverly thro the business He is thirty—and has seen plenty of practice under his father—and knew all about my former illness—which was an advantage— He continues to see me every day,—orders me warm baths and no end of brandy and potash water I have slept better of late nights than I was doing before this attack— The bath I think puts me to sleep—
Now Darling I cannot write a decent letter today—this is the first time I have had pen in hand since Saturday gone a week

p.name: Jane Carlyle

p.hi: Courtesy of Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University

div3.sourceNote: TC-[FC], [8 Feb.] MS: Osborn Collection, Yale. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO [FREDERIC CHAPMAN]

docBody.p: Dear Sir,—Yr LettererSee TC to [FC], 6 Feb. has been here; a very intelligt man; &I believe we shall get everything right very soon.

Keep Larkin to his Index withal;—&pray take notice of this, viz: That on reflexion, I find it will not ansr to print merely the Indexes of Voll. V &VI; but really (for the Book’s sake, and for yours too, or for the sale of the Book) it will be proper to put the whole index at the end. Nobody can study the work witht that;—&everybody that looks there will be tempted more or less to complete his set.— If you have said nothing to Larkin, nothing will do; for that is the way he understands:—only stir him up to speed. Stir everybody to speed! We leave on the 20th.——
Larkin’s House Address is
“6. Torriano Cottages / Leighton Road n.w.”

div3.sourceNote: TC-HL, 9 Feb. Pbd: Larkin, BQR 79.
div3.head: TC TO HENRY LARKIN

docBody.p:
Dear Larkin,—Everything now waits on you; I hope there will be no delay! More especially as I am to leave Town ‘on the 20th’ (Monday come a week),—which was appointed as Publication Day.See TC to JAC, 3 Feb. The Indexes, as you have long understood, are to go all into one.Larkin later recalled, “Perhaps my toughest struggle, so far as limited time and sheer push of hard work were concerned, was that fusing together of the separate indexes into one. … All these separate indexes had now to be taken to pieces in detail, and carefully re-arranged into one general index, making seventy-three pages in the original edition. Everything was now ready for publication but this; and Carlyle had not the slightest idea of the amount of actual labour it involved. My Wife and I worked at it together, night after night, till one and two in the morning, as we never worked before or since; and yet he got more impatient with me about it than he had ever been before” (Larkin, BQR 79). Some corrections (I think, mainly in
regard to Voll. 1 &2) are marked in my Copy here; you had better call, and copy them off, some morning while still in time.

Silberberg ought to go into your ultimate map; Gross Tinz, I conclude, you have put in; perhaps Silberberg too (nd [nord (north)] of Glatz, sd [süd (south)] of Schweidnitz):Towns in southern Silesia, now in Poland; see map, Carlyle, Works 19:opp. 321. if so, all right.
