KauserFranz Georg Friedrich von Kausler, Atlas des plus mémorables batailles, combats et sièges des temps ancien, du moyen âge et de l’âge moderne (Carlsruhe &Freiburg, 1831); see Carlyle, Works 12:296–97. or big Atlas of Plans belongs to Lord de Grey, Carlton Terrace, (or Garden?George Frederick Samuel Robinson (1827–1909; ODNB), 3d Earl de Grey; radical politician, friend of TC since the early 1850s; see 26:48–49TC to CK, 21 March 1851; he lived at 1 Carlton Gardens. near by Marlboro’ House): clean them as much as you can, and tie them together for deliveryCarlyle “took a sudden panic about those four large Atlases” but Larkin felt that the matter of Earl de Grey’s maps should wait until he had finished “the essential work” of the index: “Great then was my surprise and annoyance, when Mrs. Carlyle one day drove up in her brougham, wearied and vexed, and informed me that he had been imagining all sorts of disasters about them; and that, if they were not already returned, she was to bring them away with her, and return them herself” (Larkin, BQR 79–80). (cannot be too soon, after so many years exile!)—
I do not recollect that I had anything more to indicate, at present. I depend on you for exactitude and dispatch.— Yours sincerely, / T. Carlyle.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-CS[CSO], [9 Feb.]. PM: London, 10 Feb. 1865. MS: Chelsea Public Lib. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO CHARLOTTE SOUTHAM

docBody.p: Many thanks for your pretty mittikens! I could not write sooner. The day after I received your packet—which I took for violets at first—I was taken alarmingly ill with inflamation of the bowels— For a week I was confined to bed, and young Mr Barnes attending me twice a day— I am now up most of the day and even once out in the carriage a little but I am still too weak for writing a decent letter
My new Servants have been so good and kind to me— They are such a comfort after those two BlockheadsMary and Helen, both dismissed Nov. 1864; see JWC to AW [30 Nov. 1864]. that preceded them—
I will write when I am stronger— This is merely to explain my silence

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A[LLA], 10 Feb. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: Jane has continued to improve, on the whole; yesterday, in spite of the frost, she ventured out to drive, for the first time; and today she is preparing agn: betn 2 and 3 hours each drive;—so that I hope we are now fairly looking up; and if all go well, the poor Dame and I shall actually be able for the road on Monday 20th, as per program. But you shall have a more punctual waybill before that. Perhaps you can tell us the best train; and at any rate whh railway it is?London and South Western Railway; the nearest station to Seaton was Axminster, about 150 mi. (241.5 km.) SW of London.— Three hours of it is not much.It was a five hour journey; see TC to JAC, 16 Feb. If we can get Jane brot down witht injury, I calculate there will be less fear after,—on yr more temperate shore, and with so many satisfactns awaiting her there. With three hours or less of daily drive, she does beautifully; can walk, too, in stooping posture, with her stick; and is really cheerful company when I return at dusk. I believe it indispensable that she shd bring her maid “Fanny” with her, this time; Fanny is an excellt quietly active creature, &will do nobody any ill.— As to me I design to be as still as a mouse, &enjoy the clean element (spiritual &physical) and blessed silence, by way of change from what there has been. Will read a little, walk a good deal, ride do (since you are so good),Lady Ashburton arranged for a horse to be available for TC at Seaforth. smoke do,—and thank Heaven for such a resting-place after a long journey thro’ Chaos and the Realms Below!—

I have made a nice arrangt for Noggs: the excellt Rector BluntRev. Gerald Blunt; his wife, Frances Blunt, wrote in her diary: “Feb. 6.— Mr. Carlyle came in the evening; offered G. his horse. / Feb. 7— G. tried Mr. Carlyle’s horse in morning.” Their son Reginald later recalled: “Carlyle came round to the Rectory and offered my father his horse ‘Noggs,’ which he declined to accept, but offered to keep him in the Rectory stables, and to ride him occasionally in Carlyle’s absence. This he did during February and March, but I don’t think he found ‘Noggs’ a very satisfactory steed; he had too long been accustomed to the ways of a pre-occupied rider, who had ambled absent-mindedly about 30,000 miles—the majority of it while he was thrashing out ‘Frederick the Great.’ People had often seen Noggs grazing quietly along the roadside on Clapham Common, the reins loose upon his neck, whilst history was being evolved upon his back; and Noggs, having too long had his own way, resented a rider who had ideas of his own as to whither and at what pace they should go” (Reginald Blunt, Memoirs of Gerald Blunt of Chelsea [1911] 87, 89). is to ride him here in my absence; the capricious tho’ well-deserving Noggs. Bennet was at Silvr agn with the Grey:Lady Ashburton’s groom was overseeing the treatment of the gray mare at Silvester’s livery stables. “Our horse,” he continued to affirm;—is there
no hope, then, if she were left loose at Addisce, she might agn become useful to her former Mistress? Oh save her from being sold, if you can! But I doubt you can’t or won’t?— Book “comes out,” feby 20 (on dit [so it is said]). Compts to Mamselle Petite.Mary Florence Baring. Yours ever T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady C[LCH], 11 Feb. MS: Shakespeare Birthplace Trust, Stratford-upon-Avon. Henrietta Georgiana Marcia Chatterton, b. Iremonger (1806–76; ODNB), miscellaneous writer and traveler.
div3.head: TC TO LADY CHATTERTON

docBody.p: I have this morning received yr pretty little Book;Lady Chatterton, Leonore, a tale: and other poems (1864). several mornings ago the kind Note announcing it;Lady Chatterton wrote, 25 Jan.: “You accepted with such kindness my two little Volumes of Translations from Plato &from the German of Jean Paul Richter, that I venture to recal myself to you again, in sending you with my best wishes for the New Year, my little new Volume ‘Leonore.’ / It has already received most kind commendations from various Literary celebrities both foreign &English—therefore I hope it may not be wholly unworthy of your perusal.” For TC’s responses to her earlier works, see 19:168TC to JWC, 23 Aug. 1845, and 35:21TC to LCH, 6 Feb. 1859. and can only say I am much obliged by these gracious marks of yr attention. I expect to enjoy myself with Leonore not a little, one of these evenings,—all the more as my evenings and days are now more my own than they have been for a dozen years back. Believe me

p.name: T. Carlyle
p.note: She also wrote: “I often hear of you from our mutual friend Miss Jewsbury, altho’ not being strong enough to go to London when everyone is there, I have not seen her for some time.”

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MCA, [ca. 12 Feb.]. MS: NLS Acc. 7988. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:243–44. TC wrote later on MS: “( feby 1865).” Dated during JWC’s improvement from her illness (begun 29 Jan.; see JWC to CSO, [9 Feb.], and TC to LLA, 10 Feb.), and before their intended departure for Devon, 20 Feb.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY CARLYLE AUSTIN

docBody.p:
The box is come—and this time the eggs have been a great success—not a single one broken! Neither were the cakes broken to any inconvenient degree. Already they are half eaten—by myself. Mr C wouldnt take a morsel because
“there was butter in them—a fatal mistake! on the part of poor Mary”! I told him I believed it was not butter but cream, and no ‘mistake’ at all; as the cakes you made for me in that way at the Gill agreed with me quite well. It was so kind of you to take such immediate note of my longing! My dear little Woman! you not only do kind things but you do them in such a kind way! Many a kind action misses the grateful feelings it should win by the want of graciousness in the doing.

I continue improving; but that week of terrible pain has given me a good shake; and I don’t feel in such good heart about the Devonshire visit as I did. Still it stands settled at present that we go on the 20th. God willing For how long will depend on how Mr C gets on with his sleep &c—

I shall take my housemaid with me as Lady’s maid— For I shudder at the notion of being at the mercy of other peoples servants when I am so weak and easily knocked down. She is a very respectable woman the new housemaid, and both she and Mrs Warren (the cook) were as kind to me as kind could be when I was laid up. I never was so well cared for before, and with so little fuss since I left my Mothers house. It is a real blessing to have got good efficient, comfortable servants at last! And I may say I have earned it by the amount of bad servants I have endured.
I have a great deal to do today—and little strength so goodby—I will write soon again.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-BB, 14 Feb. MS: NLS 609.701. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:245–46. Quot: Hansons, NE 5:529.
div3.head: JWC TO BETTY BRAID

docBody.p: My own dear Betty! Oh I am sorry for you!—sorrier than I can say in words! I know what a crushing sorrow this will be for you!The death of Betty’s only surviving son George, 10 Feb.; he was paralyzed for over 10 years; see 31:158–59JWC to TC, [7 Aug. 1856]. I, who know so well your affectionate, unselfish heart, know that the consolations, which some would see for you in poor suffering George’s death, will be rather aggravations of the misery! That you should have found at last rest from the incessant, anxious, wearing cares that have been your lot for years and years. oh so many years! will be no relief—no consolation to you! This rest will be to you, at first, and for long, more irksome, more terrible, than the strain on body and mind that went before. He that is taken from you was not merely your own, only son; but he was too the occupation of your life! And that is the hardest of all losses to bear up under!

Oh Betty, Darling! I wish I were near you! If I had my arm about your neck, and your hand in mine, I think I might say things that would comfort you a little, and make you feel that so long as I am in life you are not without a child to love you. Indeed, indeed, it is the sort of love one has for an own Mother that I have for you my dearest Betty!—
But here I am four hundred miles away, and with so little power of locomotion, compared with what I once had! And the words fall so cold and flat on paper!

I have been dangerously ill—about three weeks ago I got a chill—at least so the Dr said,—and the result was inflamation of the bowels. I was in terrible agony for some days, and confined to bed for a week. I am still very feeble—even for me— But there is no return of the miserable nervous illness which kept me so ruined for more than a year— I cannot write much. Give my thanks to Mrs Duncan,“Not known to me” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:246). Apparently Mrs. Duncan wrote to tell JWC of George’s death; possibly Mary Duncan (b. ca. 1813), originally from Haddington; otherwise unidentified. who seems a most kind nice woman— I will write to her when I am a little more able— My kind regards to your Husband Your own bairn
docBody.name: Jeanie Welsh Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, 14 Feb. Addr: Holm Hill / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 14 Feb. 1865 . MS: NLS 609.702. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p: Just two lines to say I am going on well enough—tho’ the weather is cruel! It was settled between Lady A and Mr C that we should go to Devonshire on the 20th— I dont see the possibility if the snow dont disappear before then— And I am much weaker for this illness—my appetite not returned—won’t I suppose till I get regular exercise again. I have been out in the carriage twice and am going again today—tho it is ever so cold—

That is partly why I cannot write a decent letter— My morning time had to be spent in writing to poor dear Betty whose only son after twelve years of utter helplessness has finally been released from life
She will feel his loss terribly just because he has been such a weary incessant care and anxiety to her for so many years—
Oh there is the carriage and I have to dress

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, [14 Feb.]. MS: NLS 553.273. Hitherto unpbd. Dated by the publication of Vols. 5 and 6 of Frederick and the intended (but soon to be postponed) visit to Devon.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: I remember very well to have read, long years ago, a very insignificant Paper (Abhandlung [treatise] of the Berlin Academy—not many pages 4to by PertzFor the treatise by Georg Heinrich Pertz (1795–1876), see Carlyle, Works 14:385. “4to”: quarto. stitched) upon the Memoirs of Wilha:Frederike Sophie Wilhelmine (1709–58), margravine of Bayreuth, sister of Frederick the Great; for TC’s view of her memoirs, Mémoires de Frédérique Sophie Wilhelmine de Prusse, Margrave de Bareith, 2 vols. (Brunswick, Paris et Londres, 1812), see Carlyle, Works 12:320–21. —whh I understand myself to have got from the London Library (where the Abhandlungen are taken it, but read by nobody), and to have returned it at once. I have not the least traditn of it farther, and have not thot of it much less seen it for the last 10 years. The thing is easily replaceable in Berlin, I dare say. Possible too that it may still lie here (tho’ surely if I knew it to be from Weimar,The treatise was sent to TC, 1854 (see 29:72TC to JN, 28 April 1854), by Bernhard Rudolf Abeken (1780–1866), educationist and scholar, who at one time lived in Weimar; see 27:333TC to JAC, 15 Oct. 1852. TC was apparently replying to a query from Neuberg about the whereabouts of the treatise. I wd have locked it by somewhere!)—of course if it turn up in the now instant Doomsday of Rubbish, I will take punctual care of it.

You may now write to TauchnitzChristian Bernhard Tauchnitz (1816–95), Leipzig publisher, who pbd. a 13 vol. English language edn. of Frederick in his “Collection of British Authors” series (Leipzig, 1858–65). any day; I think he will be able to get a Copy within ten days. We are (if we can, but poor Wife is rather ailing agn) to leave Town for Devonshire on the 20th,—to Lady Ashburton’s Sea-Cottage, where one will at least have clean air &silence.

With frontispiece letterings, and multiple botheration of “driving blind horses over bridges witht parapet,” I am nothing like quite idle yet. Disposing of Noggs, my too fervid little Horse, among other things!— Come Sunday Evg.

ps.p: Chelsea Tuesday [14 February 1865]

div3.sourceNote: TC-JF, 15 Feb. MS: FC. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN FORSTER

docBody.p: Dear Forster,—I quite forgot these two times to say, on behalf of Robson the Printer (“Robson &Sons, 32 Stainton Terrace, Pancras road”) that he now humbly reminds you of yr promise in regard to Murray.Presumably Forster had promised to ask the publisher John Murray [iii] (1808–92; ODNB) to consider employing Robson as printer.

It is now clearly too late to think of it till you come back:Forster regularly traveled in his work with the Asylum Commission. I will therefore report of it to Robson as a thing that will be done (3 weeks hence),—and that in effect, is as good as done. May not I? If I may, say nothing.
And good journey with swift return (to both of us)!—
docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 16 Feb. MS: NLS 517.79. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
I got yr Papers this morng;John A. Carlyle wrote, 15 Feb.: “I have sent your £2500 of Stock to Adamson, &now enclose his receipt for it—which of course you will keep. / The Broker’s receipts, also enclosed, you can look at if you choose, though your best plan may be to throw them into the fire at once”; TC added: “did so.” instantly burnt the torn ones; locked-by the Adamson rect;Samuel Adamson wrote to John A. Carlyle, 14 Feb.: “I am in receipt of your letter of yesterday enclosing Certificates of £1500 5 p.c. preference stock and £1000 5 p.c. guaranteed Granton Stock of the Caledonian Railway Co., all the property of your brother Thomas Carlyle Esq.” John Carlyle wrote on the reverse: “Mr Adamson’s Receipt for £2500 of Caledonian 5 p. cent Stock lodged with him, &belonging to my brother Thomas Carlyle. Paid for the £2500 of Stock £2805 .. 17 .. 9 / Subtract Interest due 30th Jany 59 .. 0 .. 0 / which reduces the sum paid to £2746 .. 17 .. 9.” TC wrote on the document: “Mr Adamson’s Receipt for ‘Certificates’ (finis).” (MS: NLS 20752). wrote to the Railway Secy,John A. Carlyle wrote: “You have to write a little formal word to the Secretary of the Caledonian R.W. requesting him to pay your Dividends to Adamson as they become due; &I enclose a cover with his address”; TC added: “done so feby 16.” The secretary of the Caledonian Railway is unidentified further. announced it also to Adamson;—and hope I have completely finished that little bit of financiering. You have struggled faithfully to give me the minimum of trouble, and to do the wisest
possible for my behoof;—and I can only say I am very much obliged to you for the result achieved.At the end of John A. Carlyle’s letter, TC wrote: “John’s final Note on the subject: recd 16 feb.y 1865.”

The Chapmans have paid me yesterday (3 Bills, 1 ready, 1 at six, one at 9 months,See TC’s Memoranda, [3 or 4 Feb.].—all of whh are off today to Adamson); I have got my Ln Library Books all packed home (with my malison on them); have shovelled out for burning, nearly a cart-full of litter some of it ten years old; have made the Gift Copy List: and believe that I am now nearly altogether washed to the finger-tops of the most transcendt imeasurable &unfathomable Puddle I was ever in since life began with me. Larkin, wretched mortal, is, as I have been predicting to him in vain these 3 years, delaying the publicatn; but will not long, nor is worth speaking of,—I have rolled him off altogether upon the sharp-toothed Chorley;John Rutter Chorley. &decline to take any share farther in the higgle-haggle; “Publicatn Day” may occur when it likes best,—if it even didn’t occur at all, I shd care comparatively little. Larkin does not live here at all now; far off abt Camden Town,—unhappy Larkin instead of things all ready, he sends me an unmelodious shriek (of the unheard of transcendency of difficulty he has had, a thing to be looked at by the gods &c &c),Larkin wrote later: “I think it was when I announced to him that the last stroke was faithfully completed, that I gave vent to my pent-up feelings. I have no recollection of the actual words I wrote to him. … I first expressed my regret for the absolutely unavoidable delay … and then reminded him how I had originally volunteered to do the summaries and indexes, in which work I had been thoroughly interested … how my work had gradually extended to difficult copying, in which I was also interested; and how finally it had drawn me into maps and battle-plans, which had been work so utterly irksome and abhorrent to me, that I had only compelled myself to it out of personal loyalty to himself. … I recollect the feeling of relief to my own conscience, as I fancied it, with which I grimly posted that letter” (Larkin, BQR 80). to whh I have ansd nothing, intending to be done with poor Ln from this time forward on quiet terms.Larkin apparently visited the Carlyles soon after he sent the letter: “I took the earliest opportunity of calling on him again in the usual way, to let him see that I was as loyal at heart as ever, notwithstanding my fine spirit of independence! When I entered his study, he met me very much as usual, but I could both see and feel that he was greatly hurt; and when I looked in at the drawing-room, Mrs. Carlyle received me with wide-open eyes of astonishment; which might have meant—‘Et tu, Brute!’ or might only have meant—‘Are my forebodings at last fulfilled?’ Whatever it may have really included, in the hidden depths of her own heart,—what she meant to express was, simple astonishment; and she perfectly succeeded” (Larkin, BQR 80).

I am totally idle of mind (tho’ bothered still with mechanical details &etceteras); were it not for this hideous weather (streets of glass, whh forbid even
walking, not to say riding) I shd lie content enough. Jane is in brougham agn, valiantly struggling, &not on the sick-list, tho’ undoubtedly weaker. We intended ndedThus in MS at start of new page. for Devonshire on Monday next: but it is a great relief to her, that Lady An writes today “She really advises that we wait till the Greenland weatherThe Times reported, 16 Feb., “The thermometer … during the night of Tuesday [14 Feb.] was as low as 16 deg. [minus 9 C.]. … Even at noon, after the fog had dispersed, and the sun was shining brightly, the mercury rose to only 21 deg. [minus 6 C.].” break.” Poor Jane was intent to keep her word; but is right glad to have had to renounce. “Seaton” is near Axminster; I am sorry to say “abt 5 hours off” (11.40—4.46):The train times from Waterloo to Axminster. I don’t expect we shall stay long
Fie, Fie, this Paper is already written on!The last few lines of TC’s letter were written on a scrap of paper that already had some other words faintly written on it.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady A[LLA], [16 Feb.]. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: Ever kind and thoughtful! Your note this morning has relieved me from a great fear.Lady Ashburton suggested that they delay their visit to her in Devon “till the Greenland weather break”; see TC to JAC, 16 Feb. There seemed no chance of the cold passing away before Monday; and so long a journey in such weather—and I such a poor creature, what would come of it? Yet Mr C seemed to think there would be no danger; and I—no; i would not be the one to draw back!

It is so much wiser to wait till there is a change of temperature— That cannot be far off now! So soon as you think it warm enough will you write and fix a day. We shall be ready at the shortest notice.

I was so frightened a while ago that after all my looking forward I was not to get to you! I was in terrible agony for some days—inflamation of the bowels— But that might have happened to anybody—had nothing to do with the old nervous misery. I am quite recovered now. only very weak from the days of pain and of impossibility to take any food—
My Maids were so kind to me and so helpful!—
Oh my Dear! my Dear! I dream about Seaton!
There is a LadyUnidentified. sitting waiting till I have done.
I have seen Miss Bromley who raves about Seaton

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 19 Feb. MS: NLS 517.80. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: Dear Jean,—Yr SpatterdashesTC’s name for spats; see TC to JCA, 7 Feb. may be considered a complete success. They came yesterday morning abt half an hour after the Letter; are of excellt cloth, and as to fit, are equal to any I have had for a dozen years past; nothing required in there but to pull the leather strap half an inch tighter, and cut off the superfluity at the end. Red flannel and all I buckled them abt me yesterday; and felt better-booted, and “firmer abt the feet,” not to speak of warmth at all (whh is a mighty point) than I have been for many a day. In fact there is nothing equal to the old Edinr fashion of “spats and shoes” for a walking man; and I design to abandon Cockney fantasies altogether, and stick to my early friends in that matter, especially when the weather is cold, or cold and dirty together. The Plaiding Drawers look very solid &comfortable; but have not yet been on: I had just got three pairs of “lamb’s-wool knit”; whh really are very warm,—but of an extent in waistband &hydrastasyTC previously used the word “hydrastisy,” often with different meanings,: a shower bath (see 16:260TC to JWC, 11 July 1843, and 23:49TC to PR, 13 June 1848), a commode (see 24:114TC to JWC, 11 July 1849), or a shower or water closet (see 27:284TC to JWC, 15 Sept. 1852, 28:184TC to JWC, 5 July 1853, and 186TC to JWC, 8 July 1853); presumably here he meant the design of the drawers for excretory purposes. (if you understand that word) whh are fitter for a prize aldermanPresumably TC was using “prize alderman” as an example of someone fatter than him. than for me. Quite disgusting in fact; for tho’ I have had them contracted, no button of them will catch on anywhere, except one &that only in the loosest way.

We don’t go tomorrow to Devonshire; the Lady writes to forbid, for Jane’s sake, “till the stormbreak.” The storm is broken, not a trace of snow or frost left; a wild west-wind blowing, earth all mud, sky all vernal-looking: I know not now when we are to go; but hope it may be directly, any work here being all over, or shoved into corners for the time. Lady An is distinguished for keeping almost no appointt:—but indeed poor Jane was very glad to be let off; being still weak and feckless, tho’ driving abt daily &keeping up her heart. The Book is delayed by foolish Larkin &his maps: practically I don’t expect it to be out before the 1st of March. The Gift Copies are all waiting to be sent off at once, were Publicatn come.—— — Yg James’s Mr DuncanJames Aitken’s new employer; see TC to JAC, 2 Dec. 1864; not further identified. seems to
me to be pro[b]ablyLetter omitted. a very good man; let James be patient, diligt, and arm himself with indifference to flaws of temper that are merely superficial. Adieu dear Sister: Yrs ever T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JEJ, 21 Feb. MS: Hilles. Hitherto unpbd. TC’s letter is written on the letter sent to him, 20 Feb., by John Edward Jones (ca. 1824–93), assistant librarian at the London Library. Jones wrote: “Herewith I send you a list of the books charged to your account, I trust you will find it correct.”
div3.head: TC TO JOHN EDWARD JONES

docBody.p: “Monselet Trib. Rev. 1 Vol.”Jones’s queries are in quotation marks, followed by TC’s replies (if any). Charles Monselet, Histoire anecdotique du tribunal révolutionnaire (17 août– 29 novembre 1792) (Paris, 1853); untraced in London Lib. catalogues; not cited in Carlyle, Works. I never heard of this Book; much less, saw it.

“Zollner Briefe uber Schlessin.”Johann Friedrich Zöllner, Briefe über Schlesien, Krakau, Wieliczka, und die Grafschaft Glatz, 2 vols. (Berlin, 1792); London Lib. catalogue 1888; cited Carlyle, Works 12:400. I thot this had been my own; but here it is for you;—put yr mark on it.

“Verhaltnisse zwisch. OEsth u. Preuss.”Jacob von Kuniaczo, Geständnisse eines Oestreichischen Veterans in politisch-militärischer Hinsicht auf die interessantesten Verhältnisse zwischen Oestreich und Preussen 4 pts. (Breslau, 1788–91); untraced in London Lib. catalogues, but see CL 27:154–55, where TC gets the book and implies that it came from the London Lib.; cited Carlyle, Works 16:120. This I never had, to my knowledge; certainly never read;—nor have.

“Retzow Siebenjahr. Krieges 2V.”Friedrich August von Retzow, Charakteristik der wichtigsten Ereignisse des Siebenjährigen Krieges, 3 vols. (Berlin, 1802–4); London Lib. catalogue 1865; cited Carlyle, Works 15:77. Here it is.

“Hildebrand Anecdoten V.1.2.”Johann Andreas Christoph Hildebrandt, Anekdoten und Charakterzüge aus dem Leben Friedrichs des Grossen, 6 vols. (Halberstadt, 1829); untraced in London Lib. catalogues, but see CL 27:155, where TC says it came from London Lib.; cited Carlyle, Works 14:346. do.
“Preuss Friedrichs Jugund.”TC does not comment. Johann David Erdmann Preuss, Friedrichs des Grossen Jugend und Thronbesteigung (Berlin, 1840); London Lib. catalogue 1888; cited Carlyle, Works 14:318.

“Von Dohm, Denkwurdig. 5 V.”Christian Wilhelm von Dohm, Denkwürdigkeiten meiner Zeit, von 1778 bis 1806, 5 vols. (Lemgo &Hanover, 1814–19); London Lib. catalogue 1865; cited Carlyle, Works 12:341. do.

“Valori Negociations 2V.”Guy Louis Henri, Marquis de Valori, Mémoires des Négociations du Marquis de Valori, 2 vols. (Paris, 1820); London Lib. catalogue 1865; cited Carlyle, Works 14:305. This I had for a long time; if you have it not, Mr Neuberg may have got it.

“Rudtorffer Milit. Geog. v. Europa.”Franz von Rudtoffer, Militar-Geographie von Europa (1839); London Lib. catalogue 1865; not cited in Carlyle, Works. I think I saw this once for an hour or two; but did not keep it, and certainly have it not. Ask of Mr Neuberg.

“Khevenhuller Leben Maria Theresia.”Adam Wolf, Aus dem Hofleben Maria Theresia’s: nach den Memoiren des Fürsten Joseph Khevenhiller (Vienna, 1859); London Lib. catalogue 1865; not cited in Carlyle, Works. Know nothing of this.

“Busching Beitrage 4 Vol.”Anton Friedrich Busching, Beyträge zu der Lebensgeschichte denkwürdiger Personen insonderheit gelehrter Männer, 6 vols. (Halle, 1783); London Lib. catalogue 1865; cited Carlyle, Works 14:32. 6 volumes, now sent.

“Trenck Lebensgeschichte.”Friedrich von der Trenck, Nähere Beleuchtung seiner Lebensgeschichte (Lausanne, 1788); London Lib. catalogue 1865; TC cited the French version, La vie de Frédéric baron de Trenck écrite par lui-même et traduite en français par M. le baron de [Bock] (Metz, 1787), Carlyle, Works 16:157. Had the French Trenck; never this; have it not.
“Leopold I. Leben.”Leopoldi von Anhalt-Dessau Leben und Thaten (Leipzig, 1742); London Lib. catalogue 1865; cited in Carlyle, Works 13:314. Never heard of this.
“Commons Journal Vol 24.”Journals of the House of Commons Vol. 24 (1741–45); London Lib. catalogue 1865; not cited in Carlyle, Works. Have this; too bulky for dispatch today.

“Gesch. d. Feldzuge des Ferd. 2V.”Christian Heinrich Philipp Westphalen, Geschichte der Feldzüge des Herzogs Ferdinand von Braunschweig-Lüneburg, 2 vols. (1859); London Lib. catalogue 1865; cited Carlyle, Works 17:189. I think Mr Neuberg must have this? If it is by Westphalen (or some such name) I had it 2 years ago, not now.

“Longchamp et Wagniere Voltaire.”Sébastien G. Longchamp and Jean-Louis Wagnière. Mémoires sur Voltaire et sur ses Ouvrages, 2 vols. (Paris, 1826); London Lib. catalogue 1865; cited Carlyle, Works 16:237. Returned, I believe thro’ Mr Larkin, a good few months ago.
“Beaumelle Vie Maupertuis.”Laurent Anglivel de la Beaumelle, Vie de Maupertuis (Paris, 1856); London Lib. catalogue 1865; cited Carlyle, Works 16:274. Sent now.

“Memoires de Napoleon Vol 7.”Napoleon Bonaparte, Mémoires pour servir à l’Histoire de France, sous la règne de Napoléon, écrits à St. Helène, sous sa dictée, par Montholon et Gourgaud. 9 vols. (Paris, 1830); London Lib. catalogue 1865; cited Carlyle, Works 17:281. Sent now.

“Schoning Siebenj. Kriege 3V.”Kurd Wolfgang von Schöning, Der siebenjährige Krieg, 3 vols. (Potsdam, 1851–52); London Lib. catalogue 1888; cited Carlyle, Works 17:422. came to you by yr Porter, 2 weeks ago.
“Gross Hofinger Joseph II.”Anton Johann Gross-Hoffinger, Geschichte Josephs des zweiten (Leipzig, 1847); London Lib. catalogue 1865; not cited in Carlyle, Works. Had this twice; return it now.

Coxe’s Ld Walpole 2 voll. 8 voWilliam Coxe, Memoirs of Horatio, Lord Walpole, 2 vols. (2d edn. 1820); London Lib. catalogue 1865; not cited in Carlyle, Works. (returned now).—— No other Book of yrs is discoverable at prest in my possessn. I do not imagine any of them can have been lost: but Mr Neuberg was occasionally borrowing some few of them; mistakes of entry there may have been, too? Please questn Mr Neuberg on such as you cannot elsewhere discover. Sorry to give you so much trouble; but it won’t occur agn.
T. Carlyle (21 feby 1865

div3.sourceNote: JWC-GLC, 22 Feb. Addr: 2 Chlorine Place / Belfast / Ireland. PM: London, 22 Feb. 1865. MS: Strouse. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO GEORGE LILLIE CRAIK

docBody.p: Look here dear Mr Craik! I am going to write you a letter, without thinking how brief or how stupid it must be; for I find it is just the desire of doing the thing extra well that has kept me so shamefully long from doing it all! One cannot write long letters; when one has only about an hour and half daily to write in, and about a hundred and fifty correspondents! neither can one write amusing or interesting, or edifying letters when one is being continually told that one’s Life, and what is far more, one’s freedom from mortal agony, depends on being “stupid.” So why on earth not resign myself to “circumstances over which I have no control”Phrase attributed to the duke of Wellington, 1839. and send you two words of civil answer, at least!

Your letter about MacaullWilliam Maccall, known to TC since 1848; see 23:89–90TC to JWP, 5 Aug. 1848. TC helped him with recommendations to magazine publishers, and by supporting his application to the Royal Literary Fund in 1853; see 28:64–66TC to OB, 6 March 1853. I did answer, after a fashion—practically, that is! I persuaded Mr C to write to him,TC sent William Maccall a check: “9 jany 1865 to Maccall (“Subvention”) £20.0.0.” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753); the money came from Lady Harriet Ashburton’s bequest; see 34:83TC to LOA, 29 July 1858. For a discussion with Lady Harriet in 1848 about Maccall and his need for philanthropic support, see 23:150–51TC to LA, 4 Nov. 1848. at once, tho he (Mr C) was ever so busy and hating to be interrupted for extraneous objects.
We also told Froud about Maccaul and Froud w[r]ote to him.J. A. Froude was ed. of Fraser’s Magazine; see TC to JAF, 4 Sept. 1864. I hope something good may come of the introduction

Your last letter was in the house three days, with a number of others, before it even got itself read!! It came when I was confined to bed with sudden, violent illness. Nothing to do with the old nervous misery; thank God! But an inward inflamation produced, the Dr said, by “a chill.” (anybody as well as me might be chilled by such bitter weather!) For three days and nights I “suffered martyrs” (as a french friendCoterie speech; a phrase of Etienne Paulet (1796–1850); see 31:201JWC to TC, [29 Aug. 1856]. of mine used to say—) and swallowed no earthly thing but a few spoonfuls of water! But the whole illness had passed in ten days. The weakness left by it continues but I am able to take my daily three hours drives again and, so soon as the weather permits, Mr C (now an idle man) and I are going to Devonshire on a visit to Lady Ashburton—Mary will be able to conceive the different state of my nervous system when I tell her the House I am willingly going to stay in looks over the sea!

By the way, tell that dear little Party that I am perfectly astonished at her! My sins as a correspondent are nothing to hers! everything considered! I wrote her the longest letterSee JWC to MC, 28 Nov. 1864. I had written for months to anybody—all about my household affairs which I dont write of to most bodies—and not one word of notice has she ever taken of my letter Love to Georgina Your ever affectionate Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JR[JRU], 22 Feb. Pbd: W. G. Collingwood, Life and Work of John Ruskin, 2 vols. (1893) 2:35; Cate 107–9. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 5:566. Text: Collingwood.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN RUSKIN

docBody.p: You have sent me a munificent Box of Cigars; for whh what can I say in ansr? It makes me both sad and glad.Ruskin’s father, John James Ruskin (d. 3 March 1864), had often sent TC boxes of cigars; see 38:9TC to JJR, 14 Nov. 1861. Ay de mi [Woe is me].

lg.l: Then think, and smoke Tobacco”For the “Song on Tobacco,” see 39:183TC to JAC, 16 Sept. 1863.

docBody.p: The Wife also has had her Flowers; and a letter whh has charmed the female mind. You forgot only the first chapter of Aglaia;The introductory chapter of Ruskin’s “The Cestus of Aglaia,” pbd. Art Journal, Jan. 1865. For Aglaia, see TC to JRJRU, 25 Feb. don’t forget; and be a good boy for the future.

The Geology Book wasn’t Jukes;Joseph Beete Jukes (1811–69; ODNB), geologist and author; Collingwood noted: “Mr. J. B. Jukes, F.R.S., with whom Mr. Ruskin had been discussing in the Reader,” but any contributions by them to the Reader at this time are untraced. I found it again in the Magazine,—-reviewed there: “Phillips,”John Phillips (1800–1874; ODNB), Oxford prof. of geology and author; friend of Ruskin; the 5th edn. of Phillips, A Guide to Geology (1864; first pbd. 1834), was reviewed in the Geological Magazine, Dec. 1864. is there such a name? It has agn escaped me. I have a notion to come out actually some day soon; and take a serious Lecture from you on what you really know, and can give me some intelligible outline of, abt the Rocks,—bones of our poor old Mother; whh have always been venerable and strange to me. Next to nothing of rational could I ever learn of the subject. That of a central fire, and molten sea, on whh all mountains, continents, and strata are spread floating like so many hides of leather, knocks in vain for admittance into me these forty years: who of mortals can really believe such a thing!Ruskin replied, [23 or 24 Feb.]: “Pray come—as you kindly think of doing—and let us have talks—and looks. / Geology is just in its most interesting stage of youth. … Its general principles and primary facts are now … certain … but of—Central fire we as yet know nothing. … I will stay in any day for you after Friday. You are sure to catch me before I go out any day—if you are as early as me.” And that, in descending into mines, these geological gentn find themselves approaching sensibly their central fire by the sensible and undeniable increase of temperature as they step down, round after round,—has always appeared to argue a length of ear on the part of those gentn, whh is the real miracle of the phenomenon. Alas, alas: we are dreadful ignoramuses all of us!— Ansr nothing; but don’t be surprised if I turn up some day.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-WHB, 25 Feb. MS: NLS 3823.260. Pbd: Charles and Frances Brookfield, Mrs Brookfield and her Circle (New York, 1905) 2:512. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 5:567. William Henry Brookfield (1809–74; ODNB; see JWC to WHB, [1 April 1846]), clergyman and inspector of schools, m., 1841, Jane Octavia, b. Elton (1821–96).
div3.head: JWC TO WILLIAM H. BROOKFIELD

docBody.p:
You are very absurd!—a great merit let me tell you in these sensible times! But you must not come to night! you must come tomorrow night or Monday night. Because you see there are two “terrible blockheads”Unidentified further. coming tonight, by their own appointment, and Mr C says he “wouldnt for any consideration
have Brookfield there, along with such a pair of Jackasses”!— I suggested that the very Jackassness of the people might amuse you— But he declared: “No! no! such a combination is not to be thought of!”
You will come tomorrow evening? or Monday?— —we shall be going away presently to Seaton; now the weather is auspicious. But Lady Ashburton was to fix the day

div3.sourceNote: TC-JR[JRU], 25 Feb. MS: Yale. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN RUSKIN

docBody.p: If Monday27 Feb. prove dryish, &the roads not glass, I am aiming to come and get my lecture that day. About 1 o’clock, or not much after, I will hope to be with you. My miserable liver is far out of order, and indeed these last two days I am quite unwell; but if this don’t mend to the degree necessary and expected, you shall have notice in time.

I read the Jany Aglaia:For Ruskin’s “The Cestus of Aglaia,” see TC to JF, 23 Feb. very good indeed;—tho’ there is nothing said of the Lady herselfAglaia was the goddess of beauty in Greek mythology, a da. of Zeus, and one of the three Graces. in that Paper either; and we all wait to be introduced to her a little, in the Author’s good time. I went thro’ the PleioceneIn his letter to TC, [23 or 24 Feb.], Ruskin wrote: “I wish you would read the tenth chapter … in the book of Lyell’s which I send—with some care. The facts are those closest to us, and they are distinct—and very wonderful.” Sir Charles Lyell (1797–1875, ODNB), Elements of Geology (1838; 6th edn. 1865); Ruskin presumably sent TC a copy of the recently pbd. sixth edn.; chap. 10 was “Recent and Post-Pliocene Periods.” story, too; where there are a number of ingenious interpretations of riddles: somehow a questn always rises with me, whether that is really science, or is scientific amusement? Well; one’s curiosity on the matter is very great; and that perhaps is an ansr. Monday, then.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 25 Feb. 1865. MS: EUL. Hitherto unpbd. The letter follows TC to JRU, 25 Feb. 1865. [This letter, pbd. at CL 44:235, is now placed at its proper chronological location.]
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p:
Dear Jean,I suppose you will get this tomorrow; so I send it as better than nothing, to keep matters quiet. We are going on here in the old way; Jane still daily occupied with regimen, with driving
JWC was driving out every day for two hours in the brougham that TC had bought for her; see 41:8485 JWC to MR, [31 Oct. 1864] . as the main point; and pretty much up to her old point agn, I shd hope. Our whirlpools of bad weather are away for the prest; The weather had been very bad the previous week but was now much improved; see 41:170 JCW to LLA, [16 Feb. 1865] , and 178 JCW to MR, [28 Feb. 1865] . went yesterday in a deluge of westerly rain, whh lasted till 3 p.m., and then left me (what was beyond expectatn and very handsome) room for a fair ride. No news comes from Devonshire; but I suppose there will soon, & that we shall get into that part of our adventures, Lady Ashburton had invited TC and JWC to her house at Seaton in Devon, but wrote advising them not to come until the weather improved; see 41:170 TC to JAC, 16 Feb. 1865
. They eventually went to Seaton on 8 March; see 41:182 TC to JAC, 9 March 1865
. whh is of course the first step for getting out of it agn, and having Scotland ahead. TC traveled to Scotland 22 May (see 42:32 TC to JWC, (23 [22] May) 1865
) while JWC remained at home until 17 June when she went to stay with Mary Russell at Holmhill near Thornhill (see 42:87 JWC to TC, [17 June 1865] ). I am idle as a dry bone; never was so idle in my life: I decline to meddle in the smallest with anything abt the Book: maps, index &c &c, settle it all yrselves; TC had finished writing Frederick the Great, but Henry Larkin (182099; see 41:23233 41:biographical notes ) was still working on the maps and index; see 41:169 TC to JAC, 16 Feb. 1865
. I have had enough! I read a little, idly; lounge and loiter abt, idly. I am sunk together into bilious collapse; greatly done out in fact; but expect to rally by slow degrees, and be better to some extent for a while. A letter from the Dr Their brother John A. Carlyle, currently lodging in Edinburgh. whh I may as well inclose came yesterday; I shd have written to him, but was just on the road out, yesterday when his letter came, & today or tomorrow there is no post that way. I am concerned for poor Jamies eye, Their brother James Carlyle, suffering from a cyst on his eyelid; see 41:204 TC to JCA, 8 April 1865
. and wish I heard of the case being accomplished. My own ancle
TC had been thrown from his horse, 9 Jan., hurting his ankle; see 41:14546 JWC to MR, [13 Jan. 1865] , and 147 TC to JAC, 16 Jan. 1865
. is now of no moment to speak of. Oh dear, oh dear, what a loiterer & laggard I am! The days brightness is brief; and I sit spending it here, instead of better.

postscript.p: The hideous mass of litter (wd fill a cart-body) whh had been accumulating nine years from that Book: I tumbled it out, & it is gradually lighting fires. It really was worth nothing even for yr kind object.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [28 Feb.]. Addr: Holm Hill / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 28 Feb. 1865. MS: NLS 609.703. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:318–19 inc.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p: I sent the Dr a Book yesterday; pray don’t let him be writing to thank me for it, or the bother to him will outrun the satisfaction! I don’t even know if it is a sort of book that will interest him; but he can try, and if he cares no more for the subject, than my Husband does; he can——give it to Mrs EwartMrs. Alicia Ewart; see JWC to MR, [31 Oct. 1864]. who seems to find everything printed worth reading! The Author is a Quaker and a Copper smelter, and has bestowed great pains on this Book,The book was probably Edward Burnett Tylor (1832–1917; ODNB), Researches into the Early History of Mankind and the Development of Civilization (1865), pbd. mid-Feb.; Tylor was b. into a Quaker family which owned a brass foundry in Camberwell; he became an anthropologist after ill health forced him to retire from the family business. which he presented to Mr C, and Mr C wont so much as look at— So it is as much to procure the Quaker a reader as to procure Dr Russell reading, that I sent it to him—and so you see he owes me no thanks.

The weather is much improved in the last week, and I suppose we shall go to Devonshire very soon. I will write before we start—that you may not have the excuse of not knowing where I am to make for silence.

I suppose I am bilious just now; I feel so bad at writing—so bad at doing anything—I would like to lie all day on the sofa reading novels!—the “last sad refuge of the noble mind!”Cf. Milton, “Lycidas” line 71.—I will take a blue pill tonight.

I had a visit the other day that gave me the knife in my back! Dr Quain!Dr. Richard Quain; see JWC to MR, [25 Nov. 1864]. It was very goodnatured in him to come so far to see me; considering that I had never announced my return and my recovery to him. Not that I did not feel grateful for his kindness last winter—but I remembered how wildly I used to talk to him, imploring him to give me poison &c &c, and all the horrid questions he had to ask; and I could not look him in the face now that I found myself in my normal state of mind! He was very good and put me at my ease at once, and scolded me for not sending for him in my last inflamatory attack— How could I; when he would never accept a fee from me! I have such a pretty story to tell you about a baby left at Dr Quain’s door and a great many stories laid by in my mind to amuse you with when you come here.
For the present I must get ready for my drive
Love to the Doctor Oh please say to Mrs Ewart I would have answered her nice long letter if I hadnt been so poorly

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 1 March. MS: NLS 517.81. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NL 2:225–26 inc. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 3.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I wd have written to you on friday;TC wrote on a Wed. but yr Letter, for whh I was much obliged, found me just in the act of mounting Noggs;—after whh till Monday there was no chance. On Monday I had engaged myself to Denmark Hill, for a sight of Ruskin’s superb mineralogical Collection and a free discourse upon the same:—an Adventure that proved pleasant enough while it lasted, but whh had considerably lamed me for busss on the day following. You see how my poor hand shakes even now;—I have been sending Forster’s Books home to him; oh what a grovelling in London dust, and bundling &tying, there has been with London Library,See TC to JEJ, 21 Feb. with one &the other (Forster now for finis) with all that!

For the rest I am the idlest of all mankind; feel as if I had not only got done with Frh, but with all the work I had to do in this Planet. A gloomy but quiet collapse there is, in mind &body;—a world left very vacant in comparison, and much less lovely to me than it once was. I know not whether I am not quite at the bottom of the process: but it is curious to see how the liver and all things take a new &revolutionary course, and say each in its own dialect, “We have done, then, Master; haven’t we?”— — I do nothing but ride a little, walk a little, &read any supportable thing I can find. I don’t feel as if there were much of ruined in me; but everything is in such a smashed &completely tired out conditn as never before. In particr this right hand (the left not yet) has for almost 2 years back taken to shaking at a new &unpleasant rate;TC’s handwriting was particularly shaky in this letter. especially shakes, if I have been muscularly working at any thing. It must take its own way!—

The Devonshire speculatn seems to hang fire; and I am now &then impatient at hanging in the vague, waiting for it, not knowing my times &days. I shd think it probably will take effect “early next week.” For my own part, I shd like as well if it said it wd not at all. But I am determined to see the Spring skies somewhere witht London defilement.—

—Jane is pretty well; diligt in driving. I often wish you were accessible to me somewhere.— FaireyRobert Farie. is in dreadful Hemorrhoidal dumps; poor soul, really ill that way, prisr these good few weeks, &much leaner last time I saw him. Noggs is at the door (2 p.m.); I stop for today. Yrs ever, dear Brr T. Carlyle

ps.p: Rosetti has published an Inferno Translatn; praises you, but hopes he may get in “between” you &Pollock in some way!William Michael Rossetti (1829–1919; ODNB), art critic and editor; his blank-verse translation of The Comedy of Dante Allighieri. Part I—The Hell (1865) had just been pbd. In his preface he distinguished his version from various previous trans., particularly those by John A. Carlyle (pbd. 1849), Charles Bagot Cayley (1823–83; ODNB) (pbd. 1851–55), and Frederick Pollock (pbd. 1854). Rossetti explained: “Cayley gives substance, form and spirit [but was not a literal translation]. … Carlyle gives the substance, and its spirit, with that literality which is due to earnestness and scholarship, and to the absolute neglect of form in metre,—his translations … being in prose. Between Cayley’s completeness … and Carlyle’s literal prose, with its entire abnegation of form, there remained a middle course. … Pollock adopted this middle course. … My attempt is of precisely the same class as Pollock’s. Like him, I have aimed at unconditional literality in phraseology … and like him I have kept to the metre” (Comedy ii–iii).—His Transln is very literal; but can’t be understood, tho’ it is clever
If you care the least for a sight of Rosetti I will at once send it for good

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 3 March. MS: NLS 526.24. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: My dear Brother,—Knowing yr probable interest in our Devonshire movements, I write one word to say that our Day is agn appointed, since last night; and that you are to figure us as making diligtly ready for Wednesday next,The Carlyles traveled to Devon Wed. 8 March.—oh whh day, if nothing sinister occur, we are to take the road. The journey, I am sorry to say, is 150 miles odd; so far to Axminster, after whh are six miles of driving: so that I suppose it will be sunset before can arrive, tho’ 11.40 (from Waterloo Station, route is by SalisburySalisbury, Wiltshire, ca. 85 mi. (136.5 km.) SW of London. &c) is our hour of starting. The thing is dull of outlook to me; but it will include fresh air &silence. Sir Wr Trevillyan (and convalesct Lady)Sir Walter Trevelyan and his wife, Paulina, were building a house nr. Seaforth Lodge; see TC to JCA, 9 March. is our one neighbr there,—a man tacit almost as the very rocks are. Jane takes “Fanny” (a goodhumoured kind of maid) with her; &is in as good case for the Journey as one cd expect. Weather beautiful, tho’ cold. Adieu, unless the Post still bring me something. Yrs ever T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JF, 6 March. MS: FC. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN FORSTER

docBody.p: We have never yet got to Devonshire; but are now actually going the day after tomorrow. It was not our blame; nor indeed anybody’s blame, only that of the wild weather, hospitably taken to be dangerous for invalids;—and now we are not to hang off and on any longer, but to go. My own prospects of benefit or pleasure are as moderate as possible: but there will at least be cleaner air to breathe; and a completer silence, shd one take to reflecting in any profitable way; whh I confess I have not yet in the least managed or hardly even attempted to do. Never in my life was I so sordidly indolent, so content to be so,—“Cui bono [What is the good of it]?” the ansr to every suggestion, that rises on that score. Whether I am even yet got to the bottom of the rotheap, I don’t know; but shall be prepared for deeper descents, I hope, if such are in store. The truth is I have been buried alive, these 12 years, as few men ever were; and have had such a fill of disgusting labours, mostly unprofitable, as has completely satisfied my appetite in that kind for all time coming.

The only thing, except rummaging in dust seeking out borrowed Books &c, whh I have accomplished since you saw me, is the reading of Eliot,John Forster, Sir John Eliot: a biography 1592–1632, 2 vols. (1864).—my other “readings” being unworthy of the name in comparison. That Book kept up its character to the last; and led me gallantly along, thro’ a broad field of illumination both as to the Hero and his Time, such as only the best kind of Books can accomplish for an old hand like me. Intolerable are the common sort of Books to me; especially the common sort of “Histories.” Witht fear or favour, I can call this an excellt solid well-elaborated History; greatly elucidative of its man &his work; clear as sunlight (dated &c &c to perfecn), and really entertaining to read, in spite of its lengthiness here and there whh one well sees to be unavoidable in this first breaking up of the mine. Well done, I will vote, &by no means easy to do! We expect more from the same hand (Strafford, for instance, and a per-contra side of things?)Sir John Eliot 1592–1632 and Thomas Wentworth, Earl of Strafford 1593–1641 (1836) were previously pbd. as vol. 2 of the Cabinet Cyclopaedia’s Lives of Eminent British Statesmen (1831–39); see 8:333TC to JOST, [12 April 1836]. Strafford and Eliot were political enemies. Forster did not republish his life of Strafford.—this of Eliot being the best we have had from him. That is candidly my finding. Adieu dear Forster: you have the Devonshire address, recollect. Yours every truly T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 9 March. Addr: 62 Hanover Street / Edinburgh. PM: Edinburgh, 10 March, 1865. MS: NLS 526.25. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: My dear Brother,—I got yr Scotsbirg Note; and saw a line you had written to Jean after arriving to Edinr again: I merely at prest write a word, having no convenience for more, to say that we set out yesterday morning, as per program, and, after a safe, swift and really pleasant whirl of 150 miles, arrived safe; and have dropt anchor so far in our present new locality. The House is beautifully situated in a solitary place overhanging the boundless bright blue Sea, a short furlong from the old Village of Seaton, with Axmouth &Axmouth Harbour abt a mile to eastd;—altogether a fine airy picturesque old Country; and a great relief from the murky uproar we have left. Our welcome too is perfect; House new and good,—if only the sleeping arrangts prove furthersome (but that is difficult to fidgetty creatures!)—and on the whole if things were once shaken into set with us, I calculate we shall really do well. Jane has brot a maidFanny. with her;—maid too is very strange in her new element; will need shaking too! Give us a few days for survey &consideratn; surely nothing more is wanted!—— Sir Walter &Lady Trevillyan are guests here;On the evening of 9 March TC was reading “Tacitus on the Jews, with a running commentary. ‘Most delightful’ Pauline [Lady Trevelyan] found it” (Surtees, Ludovisi 112). no others: pleast people all. This pen is too bad. Adieu; write.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 9 March. MS: NLS 517.82. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.dateline: The Dowr Lady Ashburton’s Seaton Lodge, Seaton Devonshire, 9 March 1865
docBody.p:
Dear Jean,—Your Note yesterday morning found us just getting under way; and acted like the “old shoe” you wished. We came along beautifully; had the carriage, a great place like a drawingroom all to ourselves two; discovered Lady Ashburton herself in the train (who had run up to London on some busss the day before); and got all home together, witht skaith or discomfort of any kind to speak of, a while before sunset. The country is all beautiful, earth and air clean as the salt sea; sky bright as diamonds, sun out strong, tho’ the
north-wind in places is a little stronger. I have walked two hours this morning by myself, am afterwards to ride, &c &c: and reading, any work especially, I perceive, wd be difficult or impossible, but that is small matter at prest; the less of that, I suppose, the better for me. Jane has brot a maid with her; and we hope will manage to make a tolerable shift, poor soul: she is to have a bout of Bath-chair (under the Cliffs where the Sun has it all his own way), after that to go driving, open, I regret to say, but in all imaginable wrappages &furs, whh she hopes will break the vice of the elements. We have two guests; an excellt silent Gentn (Sir Walter Trevellyan, who is to ride with me this afternoon), and his Lady an Invalid: they are elderly intelligt very worthy people; from Northumberland by usual habitat; but are building themselves a Sea Villa here,The Trevelyans’ house, Calverley Lodge (now called Check House), Seaton, was built in the neo-Gothic style by builder and architect Joseph Good (1795–1875), under the supervision of local architect Charles Frederick Edwards (1837–97) and based on a design by the Irish architect Benjamin Woodward (1816–61; ODNB). It was completed early 1866 (Frederick O’Dwyer, The Architecture of Deane and Woodward [Cork, 1997] 532–34). Joseph Good also built Seaforth Lodge. beside our Lady here, who is an old friend of theirs.

The “Book,” it wd appear, is to be out “next week”: well and good; any week or time; for a month past I have avoided naming the name of it to any mortal; and am studious at all times to wish my poor hands cleaner &cleaner of it.

We were very glad indeed to find that yr alarming pluister of distresses seemed to be really mending agn. The first Note with “scarlet fever”The Dumfries Courier reported, 21 Feb.: “Diphtheria and scarlet fever have [occurred] in a few families in the southern part of [Tinwald] parish. The former has now disappeared, without any fatal result; the fever has likewise all but left, after causing but one death.” Tinwald village is ca. 3½ mi. (5.5 km.) N of Dumfries. in it really alarmed us. Write soon agn. I have sent a word to John. Yr affecte Brr T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-Mrs. W[EWA], [9 March. MS: Duke. Hitherto unpbd. Dated by the Carlyles’ journey to Seaforth Lodge Wed. 8 March.
div3.head: TC TO MRS. WARREN

docBody.p: To Mrs Warren. There is, in the little brown Box, whh stands on the flat Table in the Study, and is not locked,—a Packet of Postage Stamps (16 or 18 dozen, in a Cover marked stamps):—be so good as lock them up in some safe place till our return.
We had a favourable journey;—and are all as well as when we left you or better
T. Carlyle (Thursday [9 March 1865])—

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, 10 March. Addr: Holmhill / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire N.B. PM: Axminster, 10 March 1865. MS: NLS 609.704. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:247–50 inc. Quot: Surtees, Ludovisi 112.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p: I was to have written before I went on my travels; but adverse circumstances were too powerful. First, the nausea, which I think I complained of in my last letter,See JWC to MR, [28 Feb.]. kept increasing; so that I had no heart to do anything that could be let alone, till the last possible moment, and my last days were crammed full of shopping, and packing, and leave-taking, and settling with workmen about repairs and whitewashing to be done in our absence; so that any moment left me, to bless myself in, was devoted to lying quite done on the sofa rather than to letter-writing.

When we started on Wednesday morning, with, on my part, no sleep “to speak of”—and five hours of railway before us, besides a carriage drive after, my mood was of the blackest. But George Cooke was at the Station to look after our luggage, and, halfway, the Sun broke out, and it was new Country for me, part of the way, and very beautiful; and the sheep, bless them! were not only white as milk, but had dear wee lambs skipping beside them! And the river, that falls into the Sea near here, was not muddy and slugish; like all the rivers (very few indeed) I had seen since I left dear Nith;The river that flows near Holmhill. but clear as crystal and bright blue! And, at the end, such a lovely House, on a high cliff, overlooking the bluest sea! and such a lovely and loveable Hostess!“Seaforth (near Seaton, Devonshire) is the Dowager Lady Ashburton’s pretty cottage, who waited for us at the station that Wednesday evening, and was kindness itself. It was Wednesday, March 8, 1865, when we made the journey. The day was dry and temperate; we had a carriage to ourselves, and she (though far weaker than I had the least idea of—stupid I!) made no complaint, nor, indeed, took any harm; though at the end (Lady Ashburton having brought an open carriage unfit for the coldish evening of a day so bright, we had to wrap our invalid in quite a heap of rugs and shawls, covering her very face and head; in which she patiently acquiesced, nor did she suffer by it afterwards. / I think we stayed above a month; and in spite of the noise, the exposure, &c., she did really well, slept wonderfully, and was charming in her cheerful weakness. She drove out almost or altogether daily. Sir Walter and Lady Trevelyan were close neighbours, often fellow-guests. Sir Walter and I rode almost daily, on ponies; talk innocent, quasi-scientific even, but dull, dull! My days were heavy laden, but had in them something of hope. My darling’s well-being helped much. Ah, me! ah, me! We drove to Exeter one day (Lady A., a Miss Dempster, and we two); how pretty and cheery her ways that day! Lady A. came up to London with us. From a newspaper we learned the death of Cobden (which may serve to date if needed).—T.C.” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:246–47). Richard Cobden (1804–65; ODNB), radical politician; he d. 2 April. TC had first met him in April 1846; see 20:181TC to JCS, 20 April 1846. For Miss Dempster, see TC to JAC, 27 March.— So
truly the latter end of that woman was better than the beginning!Cf. Eccles. 7:8.

I am glad to find the insane horror I conceived of the Sea, all in one night, at St Leonards has quite passed away. I love it again as I had always done till then—and rather regret that no sound of it reaches over the Cliff. But there is something I want to say to you, more interesting to me than the Picturesque. Something that my heart is set on. About your coming to see London. I know you would make no difficulty—for my sake if for nothing else!— It is that calmly obstinate Husband of yours, who carries his love of home to such excess, that is the “Lion in the way”Cf. Prov. 26:13. for my imagination. Yet if he knew how much good I expect to get of having you in London with me, and what efforts I will make to repay him for his effort; he who is so kind—so obliging—to the poorest old women of the countryside—will surely not resist my entreaties.
You are to understand that besides the pleasure of the thing to me, your coming at the time I ask you would be doing me a real service.

Mr C is going on his travels, shortly after our return to London from this place—some two or three weeks hence, if all goes right here—and I am to be left alone at Chelsea. Accompanying him would not suit me at all—indeed several of the houses he is going to could not receive us both at a time as we need two bedrooms. And then I should prefer doing my outing (as the Londoners call it) in Autumn So I shall be alone, needing company—and of all company I should like best the Drs and yours!

Then; when he is away I have plenty of House room, which is not the case when he is at home; seeing that he occupies two floors of the House “all to himself”!— And I have my time all to myself to show you all about London, and my carriage to take you wherever you liked! Oh my Dear it would be so nice!— I have heard you say the Dr could leave the Bank“Dr. Russell’s special employment for years back was superintendence of a country bank; but his gratis practice of medicine, and of every helpful thing in that region, continued and continues (1869)” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:250). for a fortnight whe[n]ever he liked— Well? if he could not stay longer than a fortnight. he might bring you up, and see and do all that could be seen and done in one fortnight and then leave you for a good while longer. You would have no difficulty in going back alone the road you had come—or I might find some one going that direction to take charge of you—or—if you were very good and staid long enough I would go and take charge of you myself and stay—not three months next time (!) but a week or two. Oh my Darling it would make
me so glad! Surely surely you and the Dr will not refuse me. Mr Carlyle spoke of writing to you himself to toRepeated by JWC. beg the Dr and you to come and take as good care of me at Chelsea, in his absence, as you had taken of me at Holmhill.“Alas! they never came” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:250). He has a fixed idea that he owes my life to your and the Dr, cares and cheering But he would defer writing till he had fixed the precise time for his starting northword. And i cannot wait to know whether my wish is to be granted me!

He is going first to Mrs Aitken. And if you had seen the letters she has written, urging him not to wait for the Devonshire visit; but to “come away at once”—Cutting me out of the journey and change which was expected to do me so much good, with as much indifference as if she had quite forgotten my existence! you would understand at last why I am so aggravated by that woman. Indeed it is not one letter out of a dozen, she writes to her Brother, that mentions my existence or indicates the slightest remembrance of it!

Now Darling write to me at once—or no!—wait two days; in case your or the Drs first impulse should be to refuse me—and remember that you have it in your power to make me happy or to make me—cry!— If the Dr will absolutely not leave Home—(my heart dies in me, when I think over the instances of obstinacy I have seen in that man!—about the photographPossibly Dr. Russell refused to be photographed; otherwise unexplained. &c &c) you are not obliged to disappoint me— He could go to Carlisle with you and put you into a carriage out of which you would never need to move till you reached Euston Square where I would receive you into my protecting arms! What I have done so often alone surely you could do alone— I think it will be towards the end of April that I should want you—should have a bed, fit to hold you and the Dr, gaping ready! But I will tell you particularly—so soon as I know—
Oh Mary dear be kind, and kiss the Dr till he says you shall both come!

Lady A has had to go off this morning for three days into Cornwall— She asked Mr C to escort her and he——refused!!! “shouldn’t be able to sleep &c &c”! There is a Sir Walter and Lady Trevillian staying with us till she returns.

div3.sourceNote: TC-Mrs. W[EWA], [ca. 10 March. MS: Duke. Hitherto unpbd. Dated shortly after the Carlyles’ arrival at Seaforth Lodge.
div3.head: TC TO MRS. WARREN

docBody.p: To Mrs Warren.

Put the inclosed AddressUntraced. on the Copy of Public OpinionPublic Opinion, weekly review 1861–1951; see 40:13TC to CAW, 16 Feb. 1864. (Newspaper) whh you have;—or give Paper and it to Mr Bullock,The Carlyles’ regular postman. with request to put it on &despatch
n.b. also: Mr B. is to say “Seaforth Lodge” henceforth (not “Seaton Lodge,”Seaforth Lodge was in Seaton. whh was a mistake of mine).

div3.sourceNote: JWC-BB, 12 March. MS: NLS 609.705. Pbd. A. Carlyle, NLM 2:319–22 inc. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 5:568; 6:4; Hansons NE 529.
div3.head: JWC TO BETTY BRAID

docBody.p: Thanks, from the bottom of my heart, for your letter, which was all the more pleasure to me that I was not expecting such an effort from you. I know how difficult it is, to concentrate one’s thoughts and put them into written sentences, when one is full of sorrow or pain! to do it at all, one must hold very dear the person one writes to! And you and I hold one another very dear by that, and by other tokens. When my bodily torments were nearly greater than I could bear, and I had dropt all correspondences in the outer world, I recollect of writing a few lines to you; and now, you write to me when bowed down with sorrow as I was with pain!

Dear Thomas Erskine wrote me a kind letter about you after he had seen you. He told me the manner of George’s end.George Braid d. 10 Feb.; see JWC to BB, 14 Feb. In my life I never heard anything so Sad!—and yet how merciful!

Yes, Dear! be sure I shall make Mrs Duncan’s acquaintance if ever an opportunity offers. She has two irresistible claims on my regard; the one her likeness to my Mother, the other her kindness to you.

I was not thinking of a journey to Scotland this summer, until I had the news of your loss. Now, I should like to go, that you might see the child
remaining to you,JWC herself. which would be a comfort to you, would it not? If I were not still in such weak health, that I can stand no knocking about, I should decide to go. For Mr Carlyle, who has lately finished the great Book, in six big volumes, which has kept him busy for ten years, is going to Scotland in a little while, and to pay several visits up and down; so that I should not be needed at home. And it would be too much fatigue going from place to place along with him, besides that, among his own people, there is not accommodation for us both at one time—as we are both bad sleepers and need a room a-piece! So, if I had but strength for it, there would be nothing to hinder me from going back to Thornhill—and andWord repeated in MS. on for a few days to Edinr. To Thornhill is not a difficult journey, and there is such beautiful rest and welcome at the end of it! and I should find just the same welcome this year, as if I had not staid near three months there (!) last year. But the journey from Thornhill to Edinr is more complicated and bothering. And I dont feel at home with my AuntsJWC’s aunts Ann, Elizabeth, and Grace, in Edinburgh. as I do with the Russells. I need a great many tender attentions now, which I could perfectly dispense with when I was stronger, and it is not in my Aunts to be tender towards anybody! However—we shall see! perhaps as the weather gets warmer I may be less of an Invalid. Meanwhile I have written to Mrs Russell to beg her to come to me,—and the Dr if possible,—in London; when Mr C goes north, and leaves house room for them. After showing them London I would perhaps return with them I said—as an inducement to their coming!

At present we are on a visit to Lady Ashburton in Devonshire; so your letter did not reach me till yesterday. As we left London on Wednesday—forgetting to leave the address with the Postman. I had been much plagued with a constant nausea for some time, and was glad to get a change of air and scene, which the Drs say is the only remedy for nervous illness; and certainly that is my own experience.

I am just as much at home with Lady Ashburton as with Mrs Russell. They are the two kindest hostesses on Earth. So I doubt not but I shall improve here, so soon as my sleep gets settled; which is always driven away by a new bed.

The House is within a hundred yards of the edge of a high Cliff, overhanging the Sea. So we have fresh air enough! The Country all round is extremely beautiful, and new to me. Chiefly I am delighted to see clear, running waters—like what we have in Scotland—also the wee lambs, quite white, are a treat to see, after the sooty sheep near London!
We shall stay here some two or three weeks.

Mr Carlyle was for me not continuing to send Punch—as the sight of it might make you sorry.The Carlyles had regularly sent copies of Punch for George; see 38:136JWC to TC, [12 Aug. 1862]. But I thought your HusbandAlexander Braid. might care to look at it—and at all rates that you took the address in my handwriting as an assurance of my welfare.
God bless and comfort you Dear!
docBody.name: Jane Welsh Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-FC[FCU], 13 March. MS: Strouse. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO FRANCIS CUNNINGHAM

docBody.p: We are come down hither, my Wife and I, for a little visit to friends and the Country air; and I think shall be back before very long. So far as my own guess can extend, the National-Portrait people ought to have no feeling but gladness and gratitude towards the pious contribution you intend for them: but perhaps our best way will be not to stir farther in the matters till I come home, &can report that I have seen the Bust with approval;There were three busts of Allan Cunningham: by Richard Westmacott Jr. (1799–1872; ODNB), professor of sculpture at the Royal Academy 1857–67, exhibited at the Exposition Universelle in Paris in 1855, otherwise untraced; by Henry Weekes (1807–77; ODNB), sculptor; and by Sir Francis Leggatt Chantrey (1781–1841; ODNB), sculptor. Allan Cunningham had acted as Chantrey’s secretary, 1814–41. See also TC to FCFCU, 20 April.—and in the meanwhile, I will endeavour to have a word with Lord Stanhope,Philip Henry Stanhope (1805–75; ODNB), 5th earl of Stanhope, chairman of the board of trustees of the National Portrait Gallery, London, 1857–75. Known to TC since 1839 (see 11:47TC to JAC, 11 March 1839); Stanhope, partly inspired by TC, had been instrumental in setting up the National Portrait Gallery. TC had been a trustee of the gallery since 1857; see 32:100TC to LA, 9 March 1857. and take soundings as to the people’s notion otherwise, before we launch this Enterprize in a formal meeting.

You shall hear of me, or see me on my return; meanwhile commit me to my otherwise entirely idle existence under the Chalk cliffs here on these pleasant shores. With many kind regards from Wife and Self to Miss Cunningham &you,Francis and his sister, Mary Cunningham, visited the Carlyles Dec. 1864; see JWC to MR, 6 Dec. 1864.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 17 March. MS: NLS 517.83. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: My dear Brother,—It is really a shame that in the utterly idle life I am leading here, there has not already been time found for a little scrap of Answer to the Note you sent. Twelve days here, and except a line on the second morng, not a word of report to the only friends in the world that are truly interested in our good and evil! One reason is, we are not yet got into the fair road, or feasible course of habitudes in this new scene; and have nothing that is fairly satisfactory and pleasant and successful to send you. “New habits”:Cf. 16:172TC to [CHDI], 18 May 1843; cf. also the Carlyles’ use of “hefted” [accustomed], i.e. “hefted to our new element” (see 28:103TC to MAC, 9 April 1853) and “hefted in my new position” (15:14JWC to TC, [14 Aug. 1842]). oh what a botheratn to a poor old lazy worn-out being is all that! Hitherto I cannot for my life get over those extraordinary eating arrangts, or know how to pick out sleep and a support to the digestive departt from such a quantis non egeo [how many things I do not need], arranged at such hours. Breakfast at 10 till near 11 (omelets, fries, steaks, chops,—cup of coffee always cold, egg do and half raw, whh with half a hundred no, thank you’s is my share of the lot); then luncheon, excellt solid dinner at 2 p.m. (i.e. in abt 3 hours),—to me entirely impossible,—then at 5 tea; and at 7½ till 9, dinner proper,—that is to say, the food of the day to be swalledThus in MS; presumably for “swallowed.” within 2 hours of yr going to bed! I cannot yet find out a way; but I will &must or else——! Poor Jane, who seemed to manage much better than I, is today flung down with “sick headache” (poor little soul) and is lying quiet in bed, as yet (1 p.m.) witht breaking fast. Alas, alas!— But I flatter myself it will soon change in her case. And that in fact we shall all come to some kind of supportable ship shape, and be able to get the benefit of this beautiful wholesome country, swift poney-exercise, and the warmest hospitality possible for human nature even of the Highland type!—

Till yesterday, the Trevellyans were here (people whom you know, &who remember you well); Sir Wr has escorted me on various poney-rides; a man that knows every inch of the country, knows geology, antiquity, all the Ologies &Sciences, and is a heartily courteous honest and good man,—not nearly so dull as he looks at starting. Day before yesterday the Trevellyans withdrew to their own Lodging in the Village, to make room for “the Woolners” here,Thomas and Alice Woolner. Thomas Woolner wrote to Emily Tennyson, 24 March. “I returned last night from Seaton, having spent a most pleasant time. Lady Ashburton was kindness itself and there was no state or grandeur. Carlyle was charming, and his talk was interesting in every way; he, Sir W. Trevelyan and I used to go out riding together nearly every day. … [H]e said that as soon as the Seaforth Lodge engagement was over he was due in Scotland to stay with some of his family for a long time, and he does not expect to be back before the end of autumn or something like that, so that I shall be all that time without seeing the dear old philosopher” (Woolner 258–59).
whom I cannot reckon an improvet. On the whole, our Party is equal to the average in intelligence, and beyond it in kindliness of mind: I have a beautiful little galloping Poney“Rubbish”; see TC to JF, 29 March. (used to know it at The Grange); &daily wet &dry I insist up 2 or 3 hours upon it. Yesterday to Shute HouseEither Shute House, built 1787–90, or Old Shute House, a fortified medieval house with considerable alterations and extensions; both in the village of Shute, about 5 mi. (8 km.) N of Seaton. (along with Sir Wr &Woolnr on 2 ponies hired by the Bart,—good gentn); the day before, to Axminster &back (14 miles or so) by myself whh was pleasanter, &at a far more dietetic pace. I also walk daily: hill &dale, or fine little undercliff road, if you like to go back &forward (whh I don’t quite). In spite of all whh I did not get asleep this morning till past 4. Whh shall end my despicable report; &indeed must,—Woolner &I being due at the Trevn LodgingCalverley Lodge. for a morning call.

Pray send this on to Jean; from whom I had a Note on Tuesday last. This is Friday: I hope the Note will continue to find you on Saturday night;—but it has to go round by Bristol &c, and I am not sure. Erskine’s Letter to Jane came punctually: I remember well &will fulfil my intention in his respect,Thomas Erskine; TC’s “intention” unexplained.—but wait till the hurlyburly cease a little. It is a melancholy fact forced home upon me that I have a difficulty in doing as others do, even in the way of dieting and resting—and that apparently I ought to keep most away from my fellow creatures! What in Nature can be sadder? Well well.— — Adieu, dear Brother; write agn when you have time.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 18 March. MS: NLS 517.84. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.dateline: Seaforth Lodge (n.b.! and no need of more)Inserted above Seaforth Lodge by TC., Seaton Devonshire, 18 March 1865
docBody.p:
Dear Jean,—I wrote yesterday to the Dr, who will probably forward you my Note; but today I become convinced that he will not himself get it till Monday,—before whh time this may on its own footing reach you. So here goes;
from my Tower of Laziness, on the seabeaten Cliffs here, amingThus in MS; possibly a conflation of “among” and “amidst.” the piping of the dry March winds (cold but clean) &the sounding of the angry waves.

We are doing quite tolerably here, tho’ there have been, and still a little are, difficulties abt dieting and sleeping,—whh, however, are now on the diminishing hand, &we hope will disappear altogether or nearly so.
