The Lady here is certainly the kindest of all Hostesses;—discovering yesterday by accidt that her dining-hour (7½ or 7¾ p.m.) did not quite suit my custom, she has insisted on changing it to 6½, whh really is a great deal suitabler:—and this is only one of all manner of instances that might be given.Lady Ashburton wrote to Lord Houghton, 17 March. “The dear Carlyles are here. He is like my beloved one in so many ways—loved him so truly—that I cling to him. I know you will believe how much I feel having him here, as the day comes round, which took from me that husband who was my stay and comfort” (Surtees, Ludovisi 112). Lady Ashburton refers to the anniversary of Lord Ashburton’s death, 24 March; apparently that evening TC read aloud from his French Revolution (Surtees, Ludovisi 113). Yesterday Jane was under headache, &confined to her room; but today, to the joy of everybody, she is afoot again; &it is hoped may go on agn rather improving than otherwise, whh till that exceptional day she seemed to be doing. Poor weak soul; so full of vivacity &shift when there is any chance at all!

This is the beautifullest country possible: swift brooks &rivers (clear and lively, not equal to Scotch, but agreeably reminding you); everywhere Hill &Dale, all cultivated, hedged &trimmed to the very summits; strong ancient-looking quiet little Towns, and such Hamlets &villages in their curious old nooks as are quite a pleasure to look upon after huge London &its screameries. I have a little demon of a black Pony, fit to gallop to all lengths; I go out riding daily (oftenest with some kind of company, but quite as willingly with none): this is the one moral act I do in the 24 hours; the rest of my time I am grieved to say is one tract of idleness, waste laziness, whh is shameful to think of! I look forward to Scotland were the Spring tempests done. Ah me, I am often very sad, if that cd help me at all!— I know not whether the Book is out or not; but suppose it is a day or two ago. No matter whatever. Adieu dear Sister. Yrs ever T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JBJBUL, [19 March]. MS: NLS 1797.240. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO MR. BULLOCK

docBody.dateline: Seaforth Lodge / Seaton Devonshire Sunday [19 March 1865]
docBody.p: Please, Mr Bulock, if you get any more letters in this handwritingJWC presumably enclosed the envelope. dont forward them: but refuse to take them in.JWC first wrote “throw them in the fire!” then crossed that out.

They come from a MadmanUnidentified; see also TC to JAC, 20 March. who has a phrenzied hatred of Mr Carlyle (who is quite unacquainted with him) and ever now and then he sends him a letter of abuse neglecting to prepay it.
Mr C would rather not have his temper ruffled at the cost of twopence—to himself.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 20 March. MS: NLS 517.85. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
I wrote to you on Friday; but reflected soon after that you cd not get my Letter till this prest (Monday) morning: I therefore wrote also a word to Jean, abt our genl wellbeing, in hopes she might get her Note much abt the same time, and not need to wait for the Edinr one. It has since occurred to me, as a scarcely pardonable omission, that I took no notice of yr Lady-HamiltonLady Janet Hamilton, b. Marshall (1802–77), widow of Sir William Hamilton (1788–1856; ODNB), philosopher, whom TC had known and admired in Edinburgh in the 1820s and 1830s. She lived at 16 Great King St., Edinburgh. request. Pardon me; and impute it to the unutterable puddle, of thick ink, uncomfortable paper (shame on me, for it is gratis too!), a ricketty table, and still worse of unendurable (pretty continual) dyspepsia, want of sleep, and general misery under arrangets that are at once the most munificently hospitable, &completely unsuccessful for me. Last night was my worst night of all. No use that I gallop 3 hours daily, walk as if for a wager &c &c: my life here is as detestable to me as cd well be imagined;—and this very day I think, if it were not that Jane seems to be doing a good deal better and wd object, I shd be tempted to be off for home. Alas, alas, what a mockery are flunkies, luxuries, endless wealth (presided over by do kindness) to unfortunate me, who
cannot eat with my fellow creatures! Last night I lay awake till 6 a.m.; was awoke agn at 7,—and had fairly to take into the bath-tub, thence into the fierce east-wind, and walk in sheltered lanes for 2 hours instead of sleeping!— Tomorrow I expect to get round agn; for all else is perfection!

Express to Lady Hamilton (with compliments) my very great desire to do anything that wd be pious to the memory of Sir William whom I honour &love so truly; but the doubt, very sincere too, whether anything of reminiscence I could practically muster will be practically worth committing to print. I cannot even try, in my prest state:—say however that I will try; actually so.It is not known why Lady Hamilton wanted TC to write a reminiscence of her husband at this time; a subscription was started this year to fund the Hamilton Philosophical Fellowship at Edinburgh University; John Stuart Mill pbd. his highly critical Examination of Sir William Hamilton’s Philosophy (1865), late April. TC wrote a Reminiscence of William Hamilton in 1868, which was pbd. in John Veitch, Memoir of Sir William Hamilton, Bart. (Edinburgh, 1869) 121–27; see also Carlyle, Reminiscences 427–33. And that is all we have to ansr at prest.

This country is beautiful, and might be extremely beneficial &helpful to me: but if a man cannot escape dyspeptic wretchedness by any mode of eating, nor count on sleep as the close of his day’s laborious toil (in the grateful task of doing nothing &enjoying nothing,—except slightly a little tobacco),—what is to become of him.

The Woolners are still here;—I feel as if I shd be much better alone, given up to my own gloom: but it will not last. Sir Wr &LadyFor a photograph of Sir Walter and Lady Paulina Trevelyan (possibly taken around this time) placed in vol. 2 of JWC’s albums, see opp.above. TC later wrote underneath the photograph: “Sir Walter Trevellyan, &his (first) Wife:—(in Devonshire with us; ah me!).” are the most excellt people, and they are not too near me. Courage: I will add no more today. Forgive me dear Brother;—&don’t waste any of yr pity. At bottom, I believe I am really somewhat better than when we left Town. Yes, truly so, in spite of all!—
Sir Walter and Lady Paulina Trevelyan, ca. 1865
Courtesy of Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University
Many Letters have followed me out hither,—but with the small exception of yours and Jean’s, they are by impertinent people, partly madmen, partly beggars &c &c.

Larkin, for one, announces that with an effort approaching the superhuman he has, at last, in 3 months, finished his Index &c, &that the Book is to be “out next week.” From me, altum silentium [great silence] in that directn. On the whole, if the violent weather were past, I must try Scotland, &so be at the end.

Adieu, dear Brother: did you ever read such a Letter? Victory over Frk, has not hitherto led to Goshen,Cf. Gen. 46 and 47; after many years of famine, Israel and his children came to live in Egypt, in the rich and fertile land of Goshen. you perceive!

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 27 March. MS: NLS 517.86. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Dear Brother,—I got yr Letter yesterday morning; and very welcome it was to me, among the heap of others, mostly mad &useless to me. I have recovered my sleeping faculty (so far as indispensable); that is, I make out some five or 6 bad hours of it by night; eking, in the way you hint, a half hour or a 10 minutes now and then by day: so that, what with galloping two hours abt the breezy lanes, what with strict attention to diet, and suffering in abstaining, I rub along better or worse— The Woolners went on Thursday; but lo, next day, the Trevelyans, to entertain us, were brot back! There is a Miss Dempster (from Forfarshire)Possibly a member of the Dempster family from Dunnichen, Forfarshire, with connections to Skibo, Sutherland (near Lady Ashburton’s family home); unidentified further. really a pretty phenomenon; an actual young Lady cleverish, handsome, and of the perfect Scotch type: she is our best achievt at prest. I caught face-ache, gum-ache, doing a “scene of Loveliness” (Cleaveland I think they call it, 7 miles off);Untraced; Woolner wrote to Emily Tennyson, 24 March. “I went on Wednesday to see Clevelands … and it was without exception to my mind, the loveliest place I have ever seen even as it stands now; so that what it must be in the time of the leaf surpasses my imagination to perceive” (Woolner 258–59). Clearly not Clevelands House, Axmouth, about 3 mi. from Seaton, but its old name of Pinhay House, also the name of Pinhay Bay and Pinhay Cliffs (to the W of the bay), about 3 mi. (6 km.) E of Seaton, might have led to some confusion. TC and Woolner might have ridden along the cliffs to the bay and seen the grounds surrounding Pinhay House, built 1845, just W of Lyme Regis. but have kept resolutely quiet ever since. Jane does really rather well,—tho with “headache” pretty constant; whh she says is new to her, but better than what it has displaced. The Lady Hostess excels in warmth of hospitality all Ladies: on the whole, I am getting no mischief, the contrary rather;—nevertheless I call it really good news whh I have got to tell you (what is the summary of this Note), That it is settled we are to return home on Saturday next. Saturday Evg: if you have a little word lying for us then, it will be very welcome, &we shall read it in our old moorings agn.

I am a little disappointed to have heard nothing from Dumfries. Jean seemed to be really in a bad hubble of sickness, some of it dangerous, in her Household,—scarlatina &c the sound of whh is alarming;—pray let her know our news, and ask her for hers on my part. I am sending her a Newspr today;The Carlyles often put pen strokes on newspapers (sent free of charge) to family members to indicate that all was well. but nothing of written.— I intend privately to take yr advice abt Sir W.;See TC to JAC, 20 March.—i.e.
not to give myself much trouble abt it. He was a braw, loveable kind of man; but has gone, in my opinn, just to what you say!— I wrote to Erskine the other day; you were to announce Letter recd; and E. not to bother himself with writing.— My best Book at prest is Froude;Probably Froude’s History of England from the fall of Wolsey to the death of Elizabeth, 12 vols. (1856–70). Eight vols. had been pbd. so far, vols. 7 and 8 in 1863. According to Carlyle’s House,noted that TC owned vols. 3, 4, and 7–12 (96). See also TC to JAC, 11 May. but it too is rather baddish. Adieu, dear Brother: wish us safe home agn; and have a small Note lying. Your affecte
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JRT, 27 March. Addr: 17. Savile Row / Regents Street. MS: Princeton Univ. Lib. Pbd: Brent E. Kinser, The American Civil War in the Shaping of British Democracy (Farnham, 2011) 45 inc.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN R. THOMPSON

docBody.p: We have been on these Southern Coasts for a three weeks past, among friends, in a friendlier climate; but are for coming home on Saturday next. Some evening after that, pretty much any evening, tea will be in progress at 8 o’clock, and a welcome ready, if you please to venture to experiment. I had heard already that Captn Fearn was safe thro’,John Williams Walker Fearn accompanied Thompson on his first visit to the Carlyles, 14 Oct. 1864; see JWC to MR, [ca. 18 Oct.]. He returned to the Confederacy late 1864. —a very welcome bit of intelligence to my Wife &me. Send him our respects &kind wishes when you have opportunity.

Last night, yr acct of Charleston was read, to her company, by the Lady of this House (who herself takes in The Index);The Index: A Weekly Journal of Politics, Literature, and News, Confederate propaganda newspaper, pbd. London 1862–65. The 23 March issue contained a historical account of Charleston from the original English settlement of 1672 to its evacuation by Confederate forces in February 1865: “the ‘capture of Charleston’ in the strict sense of the term never was accomplished by their fleets and armies. … Charleston never did surrender. No demand was made for her surrender. No one was probably more surprised than the Federal commander himself to discover that the sad, silent, sorrowful, ruinous, beautiful city of magnolias, which had so long repelled the approaches of the invader on land and sea … had suddenly been deserted by its defenders. … The Confederate forces had folded their tents … and stolen silently away.” and tragically interesting we all found it. My expectatn is, and that of most people whom I see, that the “Conquest of the South” is no whit nearer than ever; nay my own private
conjecture is that if perhaps Genl LeeRobert Edward Lee (1807–70), Confederate general, commander of the Army of Northern Virginia 1862–65. were on the field (and no longer in a city) with his Army,Gen. Lee and his army had been defending the city of Richmond, Va., the Confederate capital, for the previous nine months. and happened to have (whh I am assured is the fact) something of Strategic Faculty and actual knowledge of campaigning,—he might work such woes on those Yankee Gentleman as wd be miraculous to the Editorial mind! “Generals” are not to be made by clapping cocked hats on them; and “Creation” objects to be “whipped” by a War-ministry of Able Editors. You have a boundless extent of Territory for battlefield; a ditto of Nescience on the part of yr Enemies: unless you yourselves lose heart, it has always seemed to me, &still seems, their Enterprise is impossible. Alas, alas; I never heard of such a War in all my reading; I believe in the annals of the Human Species there was never such another!—

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Mrs. W[EWA], 27 March. MS: Hornel. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO MRS. WARREN

docBody.p: We have made out our visit, you see, with greater deliberation than I predicted, in leaving! Not that Mr Carlyle has not talked of being off “this very day,” every morning after a restless night! And he has had too many of these; since his habits have been turned all heels over head, and there has been no punctual Mrs Warren at hand to measure out his dinners!— So I have been in constant uncertainty all the time; and no woman living hates uncertainty more than I do! It would spoil my pleasure in Heaven itself!

Tho’ I am in no haste to go, then; and never wearying of either the Sea or Lady Ashburton; still it is a sort of a melancholy satisfaction to know, that our departure is finally fixed for Saturday next.“Saturday next” was 1 April.— When, I hope to find you well, and glad to see us! And to find the kitchen smartened up, and the cistern cured of leaking!

I dont know yet what hour we shall arrive; but it will probably be in time for a late dinner. Mr C likes mutton-broth after a journey, and I like——nothing!! so I can dine with Him that day. And you must get in things for Sunday; but I need not be telling you what to do; for, thank God, you have sense; which is not so common a qualification as one might think! Oh dear me! there
hasn’t been a day here, that I have not wished I could have brought one half of you with me, and left the other half to take care of the House! The times and times I have been put into a rage is quite disgraceful!
Please tell the Postman of our coming; in time to prevent his sending off the letters that may come on Saturday.
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

ps.p: I dont forget, that I only left money up to Wednesday. But what you afterJWC inserted “after” between “you” and “need.” need till Saturday had best be put down in the BillsJWC wrote “Books” first, then deleted it. as I have no means of sending money from here except in a letter, which wouldnt be safe

div3.sourceNote: TC-UC, 27 March. Pbd: Myers catalog 336 (Spring 1951); MS described as 3pp., 8vo., written from “Seaforth Lodge, Seaton, Denston”; “Denston” presumably a misreading for “Devon.”
div3.head: TC TO UNIDENTIFIED CORRESPONDENT

docBody.p: For nine or ten years back I have been chained to the wheel overwhelmed with such loads of disgusting labour as I had never known before but happily I am now out of that. … after some weeks of these pleasant Southern shores, …

div3.sourceNote: TC-JF, 29 March. MS: FC. Quot: Davies, John Forster 201.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN FORSTER

docBody.p:
We are very glad to hear of yr return;From his travels for the Asylum Commission; see TC to JF, 15 Feb. and you have written me a very kind and very welcome Letter,—for whh, doubt not, there is due gratitude, in the silent form. Truly, if all readers were possessed of the sense and patient candour of Forster, it wd be a pleast thing to write big Books!Forster had presumably just received his copy of the final two vols. of Frederick; John A. Carlyle wrote to his nephew James Carlyle, 27 March. “The two vols of Frederick have come for the Libraries here, &I know not why our copies are delayed” (MS: NLS Acc. 9086). But they (i.e. readers) by no means are; on the contrary they are a miscellany of blockheads by the hundred and of Forsters by the decimal part of a unit;—and in fact the
only thing one can handsomely do is to forget their existence altogether, and be thankful that one is alive, delivered into daylight agn, on the other side of the hill from them. I incline, in sincerity, to the private opinion that this is a Book much unsuitable to them: nay that it is in itself a baddish Book,—tho’ verily it is the best I could make it; and has been a job, whh, blessed be Heaven, I have now done with to all Eternity! Whh latter is a most comfortable reflexion for the rest of my existence.

My best news out of these parts is, that we have got no mischief by the adventure, nay the poor Wife if not myself too has evidently rather profited; and that we are all coming home on Saturday next, if it please Heaven! The coasts and countries hereabouts are very beautiful: chalk cliffs with azure or sea-green Ocean singing its world-old Song at the base; excellt hills and vallies, with the blessedest old villages nestled in the hollows watered by clear-flowing brooks,—everywhere a silence, a solitude, a purity of sky and earth, whh, to a denizen of London soot, London mud &noise of madness day and night, is strangely pleast. But then agn, in the multitude of Flunkies, and sumptuosities culinary and other, lurks dyspepsia:—on the whole, my staff &hopeCf. Psalm 23. has been and is a little masterpiece of a gallopping Pony (called “Rubbish”) who flies with me daily thro’ the hills and dales in really a salutary &gratifying way for a couple of hours; and keeps me on a level with my conditions. The Wife has her old spell of driving; oftenest with company she likes. Poor Mrs F. &her cold! Tell us Sunday next that this is better; there is nothing else requiring mentn in comparison. Adieu, dear F. Yrs ever truly T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MO, 29 March. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:322–23. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 5:568, 569; Hansons, NE 530; Fielding and Sorensen 303. Text: dateline and first two paragraphs: A. Carlyle; last paragraph and signature (from a privately owned MS): Fielding and Sorensen.
div3.head: JWC TO MARGARET OLIPHANT

docBody.p: I give you now, Dear, the only piece of news I have had to give since I went away, viz., that we are coming home on Saturday. It is very perverse of Mr. C. to be in such haste, seeing that we are only now beginning to feel the benefit of the change, and that we are not wished to go. Indeed a more cordial, more generous Hostess than Lady A. does not I believe exist on this Planet! Every time I see her I like her better than last time; and she seems more kind to me, tho’ that had seemed impossible.

But I will tell you all about everything by word of mouth—which is much
easier than with pen and ink. Writing continues a horrid bore to me; and if Letters from me have “been flying about,” I can only say they have flown very wide apart, and with very drooping wings!

Oh, what a Place this is for lovers of the Picturesque! Such a sea! Such cliffs! the one so blue, the other so white! My head was quite turned at first, with all this “beautiful nature”;Coterie speech; see 35:139JWC to JGCO, [9 July 1859]. and I had a “moment of enthusiasm” in which I was near persuading Mr. C. to buy a Devonshire Craigenputtoch to be sold extraordinarily cheap! Pine trees, and wild heaths, and black bog! a hundred acres of it; and in the midst, a charming House built in the style of a Convent!Thomas Woolner wrote to Emily Tennyson, 24 March “Last Tuesday the whole party made an expedition to the house I told you of (St. Mary’s), and had luncheon in the open air, on the step of the terrace on which the house stands. / Carlyle has given up the notion of buying it, but says that if he were ten years younger and able to enter a new kind of life he should not wish a happier looking spot. The house is built of solid stone; the rooms are wainscoted all round, the ceilings also are of pine polished; and most beautifully finished throughout. There are 100 acres of land with a cottage for farm man &c., and the price asked is £2000” (Woolner 258). The speculation was wrecked by my answering to Mr. C.’s fear I should “die of the Solitude, in six months,” “Oh, no! for I will keep constant company.” George 2d’s “Non! J’aurai des maîtresses! [No! I will have mistresses!]”The reply of George II (1683–1760; ODNB), king of Great Britain and Ireland, to the suggestion of his dying wife, Caroline (1683–1737; ODNB), that he should remarry; see Carlyle, Works 14:213. couldnt have given a greater shock!— My chief, indeed only discontents, have been from my Lady’s Maid,Fanny. who has put me in a rage at least once every day. Ever Affly / your Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-NPG, [29 March]. MS: National Portrait Gallery, London. Hitherto unpbd. A printed form letter, with name and date of receipt added in writing; only the signature was by TC.
div3.head: TC TO NATIONAL PORTRAIT GALLERY

docBody.p: I am of opinion that an original Portrait of The Marquis of Dalhousie. K.T.James Andrew Broun Ramsay (1812–60; ODNB), 9th earl and 1st marquess of Dalhousie, politician; gov.-gen. of India 1847–56. K.T.: knight of the thistle. painted by Sir Watson Gordon P.R.S.A.Sir John Watson-Gordon (1788–1864; ODNB), painter, president of the Royal Scottish Academy 1850–64; his portrait of Ramsay (see ODNB) was completed 1847. would be a desirable accession to the National Portrait Gallery.The trustees’ meeting, 16 March, decided that the offered portraits of Ramsay and Thomas de Quincey (see second TC to NPG, [29 March]), could not immediately be accepted as “the dates of the decease fell within ten years of the present time,” which pre-empted their acceptance under NPG rules. The printed forms were issued to each trustee individually. At the next trustees’ meeting, 27 April(see TC to FCFCU, 20 April, it was reported that the printed circulars signed and returned were unanimously in favor of acceptance of both portraits. The consultation was necessary as people were expected to have been dead for at least ten years before their portraits were accepted.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p: Received March 30 1865.

div3.sourceNote: TC-NPG, [29 March]. MS: National Portrait Gallery, London. Hitherto unpbd. A second printed form letter, with name and date of receipt added in writing; only the signature was by TC.
div3.head: TC TO NATIONAL PORTRAIT GALLERY

docBody.p: I am of opinion that an original Portrait of Thomas De QuinceyThomas de Quincey (1785–1859; ODNB), essayist. painted by Sir Watson Gordon P.R.S.A.Sir John Watson-Gordon; for the portrait, ca. 1845, see ODNB. would be a desirable accession to the National Portrait Gallery.The trustees were unanimously in favor of acceptance of the portrait; see first TC to NPG, 30[29 March].
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p: Received March 30 1865.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Mrs. W[EWA], 30 March. MS: Hornel. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO MRS. WARREN

docBody.p: We are not coming on Saturday after all. Not till Monday.Mon. was 3 April. Lady Ashburton said, if we would stay till Monday; she would go up to London along with us. And Mr C has been sleeping better; so there was no reason why we should stick to our day.
I believe we shall go by the train which reaches London about half past six; and so, we should reach Cheyne Row about seven.

You must be very good and kind to me when I am back; for I have been so cared for, and petted here, that I shall feel as dull and discontented at first, as a spoiled child come back to school, from its holiday!

ps.p: Fanny is having a prolonged bowel-complaint. The result I suppose, of high living. To[o] severe a penalty to pay for it I should say.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 6 April MS: NLS 526.26. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: My dear Brother,—We didn’t get on Saturday after all. Not many hours after that was settled and announced, a new plan rose on the Noble Lady’s part: “Of her going to London with us on Monday”;—whh had of course to be complied with. Whh took effect accordingly;—and whh has kept both of us two in a state of complete turmoil; panting abt in continual chaos of as it were nothing at all: so that I have not yet found time even to write to you (whose Letter &c lay punctually waiting here);—last night on return from my final walk, it was to be done; but the pen (of the Drawing room) was intolerable; &I had to renounce. And today (hour already come) I am to give Woolner his first sitting for a Bust;Lady Ashburton had commissioned a bust of TC by Woolner. The sessions ended just before TC’s departure for Scotland, 22 May and the bust, completed 1866, was exhibited at the Royal Academy 1868. It was eventually purchased by Edinburgh University Library.—then probably (if mercy prevent not) to Holman Hunt for a Portrait:This had been proposed (see JWC to GM, 28 Jan.) but did not happen. all my Lady’s doing! Such an exuberant creature for kindness of heart, for impetuosity, hasty confusion, and disregard of the inflexible courses of Time, I have never met before.

We have got no hurt; perhaps, if anything, I feel a little wholesomer;—-infinitely thankful, at any rate, to get back to my own poor noiseless bedroom, and simplicity of diet.———— You must have got yr Books by this time?See TC to JF, 29 March. Neuberg wrote, 6 April: “Yesterday I received from Chapman’s Vols 5 &6; made doubly valuable by the ‘honourable mention’ of my poor services, in your kind inscription.—Thanks!—/ These latter volumes contain much that I had not, in any shape, seen before; and thus afford me the relish of more continued reading and total impression. They are very beautiful Books; shewing once more … History as a ‘tale of wonder.’ / The last Chapter of the Book I read first of all. The ‘end’ is very appropriate, solemn and impressive;—all the more for the entire absence of design to be so. / I think I may say that, next to yourself, there is, probably, no-body so well acquainted with this Book as I am, and it is my deep conviction that the time will come when this ‘History’ will, in its way, be regarded by men as Shakespere is now regarded, in his way.— Pardon this outburst of sincerity on the part of a ‘faithful Attendant.’” TC later wrote on the letter: “Neuberg! Eulogy (!) April 1865.” After Neuberg’s death he wrote: “Poor good Neuberg; this Paper gave me pleasure, when I first read it:—he is now suddenly lost to me (died, March 1867); while working at his ‘Translatn,’ near the end of Vol. V, when for him the world itself ended! The loyallest and truest of Helpers any man of my Time has had. / 1 May 1867, put this in a cover, and reposit it. T.C.” TC then wrote on the cover (envelope): “Neuberg, on receipt (5 April, 1865) of voll V and VI. Has not lived to finish his Translatn,—the ever-faithful, good and loyal soul!—I forbore to destroy this heretofore; and will never now, tho’ not likely to see it agn. Adieu my poor Neuberg; yr death too falls heavy on me, heavier than I thot!—(1 May 1867.—T.C.”
Scrubby Letters on the subject are beginning to come in; nothing better at all.The Examiner announced the publication of vols. 5 and 6 of Frederick, 25 March; it described Frederick as “one of the chief publications of our time. … [A] great and sincere work, containing the results of an undaunted spirit of labour, and of as undaunted originality of thought plainly outspoken according to the exact nature of the thinker, and of the events told as they appear to him. Mr. Carlyle’s peculiarities of style are of his idiosyncracy; and where they seem most affected are absolutely the reverse of affectation, representing an avoidance of the customary formulas that for his own mind want reality, his struggle to be, what every true man, whether in life or literature, desires to be known for, exactly and honestly himself.” But the article also thought TC’s defense of Frederick’s actions in Poland “to be most absolutely in the wrong.” Adieu, dear Brother. Yrs ever T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 8 April. MS: NLS 517.87. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: Dear Jean,——We got home, not on Saturday as had been anticipated, but on Monday Evg (our Lady Hostess having put in a new plea that she wd herself accompany us then): we all had a pleasant enough ride thro’ the beautiful Spring Country; and cd say, Jane &I, that we seemed to have got no hurt by the sojourn on the South Shore. Since Monday (owing partly to her Ladyship) there has been such a racket of hurries as rarely was; so that poor Jane has suffered a little (tho’ still gate-going &cheery poor weak creature);—and I myself have at this moment no time at all for what I am doing! Happily the worst is over: impetuous Lady A. is as good as gone agn; I myself “(sitting for my bust” &c) shall be quite loose this day week,—and will very seriously indeed consider when I can come to Scotland. The sooner the better I shd say, if this beautiful weather do but hold (whh it won’t and can’t!)— However, I believe I actually shall not be long now.

It delights me to think of you at poor old Scotsbrig:Their brother James Carlyle had a small cyst between his eyebrow and eyelid, and John A. Carlyle wrote with advice to James Carlyle Jr., 25 Feb.: “In my young days the lancing of such tumours was done from the outside, but the usual plan now is to do it from the inside turning back the eyelid, &then touching with the caustic before letting the eyelid fall down to its usual position. No other treatment than lancing would do any good. The caustic destroys the little cyst, &so prevents it from filling again. I would advise your Father to have the thing done without any unnecessary delay, as the tumour would irritate the eye if it became larger.” It is not clear whether James took this treatment, but John wrote, 27 March: “I was glad to hear by your last letter that your Father’s eye was getting better; &I should like to hear if the little lump still continues to get smaller.” John A. Carlyle wrote to James Carlyle Sr., 29 March: “Please meet me there [Dumfries] on the Friday or at the Gill on the Saturday for I want to see your eye again &ascertain how it is going on. I expect to be at Dumfries by one o’clock on Friday. Jean wants you to stay with us over the Sunday at The Hill, as she has ‘seen little of you for a long time past &wishes much to have some talk with you.’ Do accept her invitation if you can” (MS: NLS Acc. 9086); presumably Jean decided to visit James at Scotsbrig instead. repairing rents &
button work; sauntering abt in silence or trustful talk, in old haunts whh are so interesting to us all! Tell Jamie I will turn up upon him soon, if all go right!— By the way you may mention what it is he has got to draw that new dogcart; and furthermore whether (whh I doubt) there is either at Scotsbrig or the Gill, anything I cd get for a little riding while there? A good pony of Jamie’s, I understand latterly, came by its ruin on poor Jane’s acct last year:The hind legs of James Carlyle’s horse were badly cut in the carriage accident, July 1864, when JWC, Mary Austin, and James Austin were driving back to The Gill from Scotsbrig; see 40:141JWC to TC, [19 July 1864]. this I of course feel to owe him ever since.

My own “Noggs” (such the name of him who capers with me here) is an excellt fellow; &cd come for some £5 odd:—I have him in the Parish Rector’s (Minister’s)Gerald Blunt. hand ever since we went to Devonshire;—&am to ride him myself again (in a couple of minutes) hence for the first time since my return. Up to “Woolner the Sculptor’s”: oh dear oh dear!— Heart’s love to everybody. T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MS, 10 April. Pbd: Mary Smith, The Autobiography of Mary Smith, Schoolmistress and Nonconformist (1892) 1:315–16. Mary Smith (1822–89; ODNB) had corresponded with JWC since 1854; see JWC to MS, 16 Jan. 1854; their last recorded contact was in Nov. 1860; see JWC to MS, [late November 1860].
div3.head: JWC TO MARY SMITH

docBody.p: I am always glad to hear from you, and like to read your verses; tho’ I often wish you had taken to writing practical prose, rather, that is, for your own sake. There is so little appreciation for poetry in these “hard times,” and, alas! so little remuneration for it; while the appetite for magazine Tales and three-volume novels is getting to be a positive lupusClearly not the current meaning of “lupus,” the immune system disease; probably the voracious appetite of a wolf; cf. “dog appetite” (OED).——? something! I forget the full medical name of that disease which makes the victim gobble up, with unslaked voracity, pounds on pounds of raw beef and tallow candles! or anything that comes readiest.

I returned to London—by Carlisle again—about three months after I saw you,This meeting must have taken place on JWC’s journey north, when she breakfasted in Carlisle, 14 Jul. 1864 (see 40:133JWC to TC, 15 July [1864]); Mary Smith described her last meeting with JWC: “The last time I saw her, after the first salutation—still holding my hand, and leading me to the couch on which she sat—she said kindly; ‘Come and sit ye down by me, and tell me all about yourself; what ye’ve been doing, and how ye’re getting on.’ So she sat me down close to beside her, and told me many things about herself and home, and Thomas, as she invariably called him. Before leaving, she said: ‘I suppose you come to London sometimes. Everybody comes. Now, whenever ye do, be sure to come to Chelsea to see us” (Autobiography 1:246). This was probably the 1864 meeting as JWC only stopped for around two hours on her last visit to Scotland, traveling via Carlisle, 16–17 June 1865 (see vol. 42). Mary Smith also described a July meeting, sometime between 1861 and 1864, possibly this same one though she implies otherwise: “Dr. John Carlyle came down to Finkle-street once to fetch me to see Mrs. Carlyle. It was July, and he was dressed in loose light clothing, very old fashioned in make, and a white hat. When I got to the County Hotel, I found him walking up and down in front, fearing, as he said, lest I should go to the wrong place” (Autobiography 1:245). but I could not ask you to meet me at the station, even [if] it hadn’t been
too late at night. I felt too sick and nervous from the parting with my friends, and the long night journey before me, and the return in the morning to my poor old home, which I had been carried out of eight months before, with no particle of hope that I should ever set eyes on it again! I felt a sacred horror of the house in which I had suffered such tortures and such despair.

But so much had been done to change the aspect of my rooms, and I was received back with such enthusiasm,JWC traveled home from Scotland overnight 30 Sept. 1864, having left Cheyne Row for St. Leonards, then Holmhill, 8 March 1864; she was received home with great enthusiasm by TC and her maids; see JWC to MR, [3 Oct. 1864]. that all my morbid repugnance soon passed away, and all changes having a good effect on me, so even the change back to London had a beneficial effect on my health. I am still a very feeble, rather suffering creature, but so much better than I was a year ago, that I can never be thankful enough.

I am just returned from a month’s stay in Devonshire, and it was there your letter reached me, when I was being driven thro’ the loveliest country all days, and wearied to death at nights, so wrote not at all to anybody.

I wish you could have given me better news of yourself; and I wish most heartily that I could aid you in finding some position more suited to your needs and tastes. But my wishes are one thing, and my powers, alas! a quite other thing! At least be sure I will let slip no opportunity of serving you.Mary Smith wrote later: “No help, in the way I desired, came from my acquaintanceship with Mrs. Carlyle, and yet it was a help. I felt that I had been recognized as a fellow sufferer with higher and nobler souls than myself, and I felt encouraged and strengthened to hope and hold on my way” (Autobiography 1:247).

ps.p: Miss Smith,
16 Finkle-street, Carlisle.Mary Smith had moved to Finkle St. in 1861 (Autobiography 1:217).

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 12 April. MS: NLS 517.88. Quot: A. Carlyle, NL 2:227; Wilson, Carlyle 6:4.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I am dawdling along here, in a very idle way; tied up so far, till the end of this week, by a daily journey to Welbeck Street,To Thomas Woolner’s studio. and dull session of two hours there, under the sculptural manipulation of Woolner,—who, it does not appear to me, will make a Bust of much resemblance to me at the end of the job! It is a very sad way of spending one’s time: but I had to do it;—Lady Ashburton’s special &repeated request &c &c:—after that I have, for similar compulsory reasons, to attend a Photographer (name forgotten)John Watkins; TC’s sittings with Watkins were on Sat, 15 April, and Mon., 17 April; see TC to JWJOWA, 21 April; he also sat for Elliott &Fry at about the same time although the dates are not known. one time next week; whh I hope may complete my sorrowful taxation in the Limner way; &release me from such beggarly employt for the rest of my life. How many dreary hours first &last I have spent “sitting” now to this fine Artist now to that,—never in any one instance realising anything but a disgraceful blotch witht likeness recogniseable to me, and in more than one instance, of an ugliness altogether transcendant, and fearful to contemplate! Hang them all!— But it shall soon end. Meanwhile I catch up daily, tho’ in two halves, my gallop from Noggs (kept in a Bait StableA stable for temporary rest and feed during a journey. hard by while I sit, &then mounted agn doubly willing); and on the whole rather seem to be improving than otherwise, tho still badly off with stomachic departt &c. My spirits vary; generally verging towards nadir,—best when I am left quietest. Nothing that is joyful to me is apt to apply for speech here: wretched beings, coming with this or that, with whh poor I have nothing to do. Applicatn by a blackhaired flowery yg man,Unidentified further. “Won’t you give your name to Mr John S. Mill’s Election Comitee?”John Stuart Mill was adopted as Liberal parliamentary candidate for the Westminster constituency at a meeting in St. James Hall, 6 April, and was duly elected in the July election. (save the mark!):Coterie speech; cf. Merchant of Venice 2.2. “it is for a thing not local but national!” That was the last “No” I had to ansr.

I think of soon being off to Scotland. The weather is splendid,—if it only last. We are busy buying a brougham horse: poor Jane has not been very well, since we returned; but she keeps up her regimens; and seems to be improving agn for the last two days.— Have you yourself no notion of a run to BabylonOne of TC’s names for London.
perhaps for a 10 days? Or have you made any plans for summer? Adieu; write, dear Brr. Yours ever— T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-HL, 13 April. Addr: 6. Torriano Cottages / Leighton Road / N.W. PM: London, 13 April 1865. MS: Duke. Pbd: Larkin, BQR 81; Wilson, Carlyle 5:571.
div3.head: TC TO HENRY LARKIN

docBody.p: We are got home from the Country; and I have at length got sight of the Book in its complete state, and have been looking over it hither and thither,—your part of it as well, tho’ not yet with a critical eye. The Plans &c are very neat and pretty, so much I can testify; nor do I hitherto see above one or two even slight points on whh I could have advised alteration, had there been the freest chance for it.Larkin wrote later: “At last, to the inexpressible relief of all concerned, the index was not merely completed, but printed; and the last volumes of Frederick were published, Carlyle being then away from town on a visit. Soon after his return, I received [this] brief letter of thanks, which (notwithstanding the comparatively stinted, and perhaps slightly injured tone of it), considering all the irritations we had struggled through together, I now prize as highly as any letter he wrote to me. This, at least, was written with clear consciousness of the distance which hopelessly separated us. / After the completion of the general index—having faithfully struggled with him, almost with my life in my hands, through what Mrs. Carlyle well called ‘the Valley of the Shadow of Frederick’—I considered my long apprenticeship to Carlyle fairly and honourably ended. There were many little friendly services which I still continued to render. Perhaps for some time I was there almost as frequently as before; and certainly we never afterwards met in any other spirit than that of the friendliest cordiality” (Larkin, BQR 80–81).

I am very sensible of the great pains you took, the true wish you have had all along (even in yr own confusions and distresses)TC presumably refers to the death of Larkin’s baby da., Nora; see 40:44TC to JWC, 25 March 1864; and possibly also to the Larkins moving at least twice during the preceding year; they moved into the Carlyles’ house, June to July 1864, subletting their house in Cheyne Row; see 40:133JWC to TC, 15 July [1864]; Larkin then went to stay with his sister while his wife went to Northampton; see 40:161TC to JWC, 1 Aug. 1864; towards the end of 1864 they moved to their new home (Larkin, BQR 79). to be helpful to me; and your loyalty in this sore Enterprise from first to last is a thing I shall always remember. Let us be thankful we have seen the end of it; whh, at one time, and indeed more times than one, seemed almost desperate!—

I inclose you a Checque,TC recorded: “13 April 1865 / to Larkin / (as finis) / £70 .. 0 .. 0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753).—crossed so that nobody can steal it;—and need not add that if I can ever help you in any honest purpose I gladly will. An[d] so, with my best wishes to Mrs Larkin &you, and the kindest auguries I can form, I remain

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, 14 April. MS: NLS 609.706. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.dateline: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea Good Friday [14 April 1865]
docBody.p: Oh my Dear! I have been wanting to write to you every day this week! And hindered by a laziness, so oppressive as to amount to illness.

I dont know whether it has been the change from pure sea air to London air, or the change from the cold of winter to the heat of summer, so sudden and extreme!The Times, 12 May, printed a letter claiming that April 1865 in London was hotter than any April for at least 94 years: “the heat of last month is not only unprecedented, but considerably (2.2 deg,) above the highest previous record. / I may add that the temperature in the sun exceeded 100 deg. [38 C.] on 19 days, and on the 22nd was 125 deg. [52 C.].” or rash exertions I made in the first days of my return, driving about with Lady Ashburton to look at Pictures &c &c! or what! But the fact is, I have been in a very poor way, sick, and weak, and sleepless, and pusillanimous! And I can think of nothing to do, beyond taking a blue pill—which I have done—with no beneficial results. I am now, just waiting, with what patience I can, and avoiding over fatigue. The last two nights have been a degree less miserable—and it is to be hoped I shall come round by degrees.

But how is it that you so often catch cold? You—with a Dr (and just the best of Doctors) “all to yourself” and always beside you? It is clear to me you need a change of air to brace you up—and London air would be a complete change from Nithsdale air, as good as another! A friend of mine who lived at a beautiful country House in Lancashire used to fly off for a few days into the smoke of Manchester whenever she got quite out of tone, and that always set her up.Possibly Elizabeth Paulet, b. Newton (1806–79; see 13:189TC to JWC, [19 July 1841]) who had lived at Seaforth House, Seaforth, 4 mi. NNW of Liverpool, rather than Manchester. There is still plenty of time for you to “tak a thoct and mend”—and how nice it would be. I am just in treaty for a handsome strong black Horse“Bellona”; see JWC to Lady ALLA, [17 April]. (The beautiful Grey Lady Ashburton gave meSee TC to Lady ALLA, 10 Feb. having proved too light for the work) and it would carry us about to all the beautiful places so swiftly And there really are beautiful places here, in spite of the horrid notions “the Dr” has taken up of London—

Mr C has still not fixed his time for going North. He is sitting for a Bust—to Woolner—at Lady Ashburtons request—and that, giving him daily occupation (of a sort), has kept him quiet hitherto. I suppose it will be into May before he can bring himself to lift anchor again—So you see it is still time! And, I have positively said No to Lady A’s entreaties that I would go back and take possession of Seaforth Lodge “till winter if I like”— She goes to German
bathsLady Ashburton went to Wiesbaden, spa town in SW Germany, late July. for her rheumatism and will not be needing the Place till winter. But living on the top of a cliff overhanging the sea, with all the picturesqueness of the thing, would be rather dull all by oneself! and Lady A’s suggestion that I “could have people constantly down with me from London” did not give all the encouragement she fancied!
Do you know how the young man at Laight gets on?David Haining, who had been ill; see JWC to MR, [31 Oct. 1864].

Poor Margaret Hiddlestone!Margaret Hiddleston had been ill for some time; see 40:177–78JWC to TC, [10 Aug. 1864]; she was now dying; see JWC to JH, 15 May. What a commentary on Dr Carlyle’s Theory of the healthiness of poor working women!John A. Carlyle seriously upset JWC the previous summer by telling her that “no poor women with work to mind” had time to get ill; see 40:147JWC to TC, [23 July 1864]. I shiver to think of her at nights sometimes when I am lying awake. There is another whom I sometimes recollect with pain. The girl who left Mr RemilysName unclear; not further identified. service with a cancer in her tongue Is she dead yet do you know?

Mrs Ewart is never yet done writing me thanks for that Novel!! I must send her another, to put the Brooks of BridlemereFor G. J. Whyte Melville’s novel, see JWC to MR, 30 Dec. 1864 out of her head and her letters!—
How beautiful it will be beginning to look about dear Holm Hill! God bless it and all belonging to it

Love to the Dr—“mitigated” (as Sir Robert Peel used to say)Sir Robert Peel (1788–1850; ODNB), politician; for Peel’s reported (by JWC) use of the phrase “mitigating circumstances,” see 32:105TC to HL, 17 March 1857. by his obstinacyIn reference to Dr. Russell’s extreme reluctance to come to London.
docBody.name: J W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-FMB, 15 April. Pbd: William Michael Rossetti, The Rossetti Papers: 1862–1870 (New York: Scribners, 1903) 97. Ford Madox Brown (1821–93; ODNB), Pre-Raphaelite painter and designer.
div3.head: TC to Ford Madox Brown

docBody.p:
Dear Sir,—Might I ask you to put my Wife’s name, instead of mine, on the inclosedPresumably an invitation for Brown’s exhibition at Piccadilly Galleries, opened 10 March; Brown’s Work, painted 1852–63 and retouched 1865, was the centerpiece of the exhibition; for Brown’s painting of TC, who was on the right of the painting, see 35:88–91TC to FMB, 5 May 1859; for the photograph from which Madox Brown painted TC, see 35:90TC to FMB, 10 May 1859. which you have been so kind as to send me. I have already been twice
(and she as well)JWC probably went with Lady Ashburton; see JWC to MR, [14 April]. to No. 191;191 Piccadilly. and feel very likely to return: but the female mind seems to be still more adventurous in this affair, and wishes to be independent of me.— Yours very sincerely, / T. Carlyle.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady A[LLA], [17 April]. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Quot: Fielding and Sorensen 303–4. Letter dated by the purchase of the horse Bellona.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: My Darling! My Darling! If I have not written; it hasn’t been for want of thought! God knows I have thought of you every hour of the day, and I may almost say every hour of the night too! I have lain awake so much! That (sleeplessness) and its consequences, nausea, and languor, and deadly stupidity thro’ the day is the reason I have not written. I wanted to write you a good letter,—a letter with some comfort in it,—above all, with some adequate expression of my feelings for you in it and each day, a pressure of bodily weakness has made a sort of human Tiny of me—“looking out into things with a confused glimmer of intelligence”—all my meanings running out into the Vague! On Saturday night however; “in a moment of enthusiasm,”Cf. 17:284TC to ELRI, 28 Feb. 1844, and 30:189JWC’s Simple Story. Tiny was probably one of Miss Bromley’s pugs. I swallowed five grains of blue pill, and slept! Last night again I slept—half the night. So, today I feel somewhat less Tinyish, and would have written; even if I had not got your dear letter—a little coal of fire on my head, the first thing when I got out of bed!

Miss Bromley came to tea on Saturday night. I was glad to hear her say you had been to see her. For whatever little pets she may take; I am sure she loves you dearly and constantly at heart. Her cough is very bad again; and I have had too much experience of consumptive people to hear that incipient little hacking cough of hers without dread.

Mr C has a rest from his Bust this week—Woolner wishing to work at it solely from photographs for a time. When I saw it, there was no likeness “to speak of”! Mr C drives him to despair, he says, by the different aspects he presents. But certainly Mr C never has a post-chaise face like what Woolner had given him last week—it was as hollowed out as Miss Cushman’s or Macready’s!Charlotte Cushman (1816–76), actor; friend of JWC since 1861; see 37:264–6537:biographical notes. William Charles Macready (1793–1873; ODNB), retired actor and theater manager; friend of the Carlyles since 1839; see 38:28138:biographical notes.

Dropmore?Dropmore, estate near Taplow in Buckinghamshire, about 25 mi. (40 km.) W of London; owned by the Hon. George Matthew Fortescue (1791–1877), it was the childhood home of Charlotte Williams Wynn; see 25:228JWC to TC, [23 Sept. 1850]. You cannot go there, can you, without coming to London? And I shall see you soon again? Oh my Dearest, my Beautifulest! my Best! I love you better than words can tell! And Mr C loves you or he wouldnt (don’t I know his ways?) take the trouble of reading your letters (to me). This morning, I thought I heard him go into the Drawingroom just as I finished reading the last. (He breakfasts there while I am getting up in the adjoining bedroom. There is a door out of the one room into the other, thro’ which I sometimes hand him a letter from you, while I am only half-dressed. So this morning, being in my petticoat, I opened this door, extending into the room a bare arm, with the letter, saying, “There is for you Dear”! Receiving no answer, I looked into the room, and so brought my whole petticoated person in evidence! and, my Heavens! it was not Mr C at all but George Cooke! Come to look at a Horse for me, that I was just about buying; my petticoat was red too!

For the rest; he admired my Black Mare,TC recorded: “17 April 1865 / to Hy de Caville (for Jane’s Horse) / £45 .. 0 .. 0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753); Bellona. and I have completed the purchase and am going to take her (the Mare) to Hampstead this afternoon. Miss Mulock (the novelist)Dinah Maria Mulock. having asked me to drive her there.
When will you go to Dropmore? That is, when shall we see you?

Oh what a pity it is that Life being so short one has to spend so much of it among those one dislikes or is indifferent to; when there is here and there a person in the world that leaves one nothing to wish for when there!
But one might just as well say; what a pity that this is Earth and not Heaven we are appointed to live in!
Will you give the PetMary Florence Baring, Lady Ashburton’s daughter. my fondest remembrances
docBody.name: Henrietta Muff
docBody.note: Apparently Mary Florence’s nickname for JWC.

div3.sourceNote: TC-FC[FCU], 20 April. MS: Yale. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO FRANCIS CUNNINGHAM

docBody.p: Mr Secretary Scharfe,George Scharf (1820–95; ODNB), artist and gallery director, sec. of the National Portrait Gallery. Scharf was to do a pen and ink sketch of TC in 1874; see www.npg.org.uk/collections (no. 2794). whose Note I inclose, instructs you how to proceed abt the Bust, if you persist in offering it to the Nl Pt Gallery.See TC to FC, 13 March. Henry Weekes’s marble bust of Allan Cunningham (1842) was given anon., 1947, to the Scottish National Portrait Gallery (SNPG), Edinburgh; Sir Francis Leggatt Chantrey’s plaster bust (n.d.) was purchased by the SNPG in 1889. Weekes also didsculpted a marble bust of Francis Cunningham (n.d.), given anon., 1947, to the SNPG; for this bust, see Francis Cunningham’s ODNB entry. I have tried cautiously to examine a little what the notions of the Trustee people might be on such an offer; but am unable to satisfy myself altogether as yet that their welcome to it will be as warm as the Gift deserves. My own tendency, were I in your place, wd be, to keep the Gift where it is for the prest! But I know not whether that either were the right course. If you come to me any morning or any evg—— Or stay, it will be better that I come to you; and so (unless you forbid in the interim) I will appoint Tomorrow (Friday 4½ p.m.) when I can both see the Bust and you.

If I miss you altogether let me say farther that the Next Meeting of Committee is this day week (Tuesday 27),TC inserts a macron above the m in Committeewrites “Tuesday,” in error for “Thursday.” and that I intend at any rate to be there.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JW[JOWA], 21 April. MS: Hilles. Hitherto unpbd. This letter was to John Watkins, identified by the reference to TC’s daguerreotype, taken in a studio in which John had worked. The MS has attached a small cutout of TC’s profile, apparently taken from Watkin’s profile of TC without a hat (see above). The National Portrait Gallery, London, lists six photographs of TC by Watkins and his brother Charles, “1860s.” NPG also lists several Charles Watkins’ photographs of TC in a hat, 1860s–1870s. They show TC in the same clothes as the Watkins’ 1865 photographs, so are certainly from these sittings in 1865 and were probably mainly by John, rather than also by his younger brother Charles.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN WATKINS

docBody.p:
Of the nine Photographs, three seem to me excellent, and worthy to be circulated among those curious about them. The rest I will request you to
annihilate, tho’ some of these also are, in parts, highly meritorious. The Three that I wish to live are as follows:

1° The big Head, Profile (or nearly so) with Hat; whh was done on Monday. This I consider to be the truest likeness ever taken of me hitherto. Considerably like the old Dauguerreotype,—whh perhaps you also had a hand in, long ago.John Watkins previously worked for Richard Beard (1801–85; ODNB), photographer, in one of whose studios TC had a daguerreotype made in 1850; see 25:285–86TC to JCA, 16 Nov. 1850, and 305TC to JCA, 6 Dec. 1850.

figure.p: Thomas Carlyle to John Watkins, 21 April 1865 (detail)

p.hi: Courtesy of Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

docBody.p: 2° and 3°. The two small Portraits (sitting, each with a whip in its hand),For one of the photographs where the whip is just visible, see 216above. TC stabled Noggs nearby during his sittings; see TC to JAC, 12 April. whh were done on Saturday. The background there is dark; in No 1 (as usual in such case) it is a white background. I hope you will have no difficulty in recognising whh 3 I mean: in any case, on Tuesday, Mrs C. will be able to confirm if doubts remain.

figure.p: Thomas Carlyle, by John Watkins, 15 April 1865

docBody.p: There are 2 big Portraits of the Monday session whh (especially the Profile had it not been for that gape produced by the beard!)Probably the profile of TC without a hat that Watkins attached to the MS (see opp.above); it is listed as “after 1873” by the National Portrait Gallery, but is clearly from these same sessions with Watkins and taken on 17 April. are very near being excellt[:] the other 4 can be destroyed without any remorse; tho’ these 2 deserve a little.

closer.salute: With many thanks for the pains you have taken,

ps.p: Mr Watkins Photogrr &c

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JW [JOWA] , [25 April]. MS: Huntington Lib. Pbd: A.H. Joline, Meditations of an Autograph Collector (London and New York, 1902) 85.
div3.head: JWC TO JOHN WATKINS

docBody.p: I should tell you that Mr Carlyle is highly pleased with these photographs of me—declares them to be the only likenesses of me he has ever seen; tho’ I have been drawn, and painted, and photographed times without number!
He likes them all; but the profile one the best, and the full-face one the least.The National Portrait Gallery has no photographs of JWC by Watkins.

I hope you will find some way of making people know, that the three photographs of Mr C, which he selected,See TC to JW JOWA , 21 April . are the ones of all that have been done of
him he himself thinks the likest. It would be a pity that those wretched looking things of Jeffrey’s should go on being circulated when people can have so much better likenesses for their money.William Jeffrey; for one of his photographs of TC (which pleased TC and JWC when they were taken, Sept. 1862), see 38:frontispiece, available in the CLO on the table of contents page for volume 38.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MCA, [ca. 25 April]. Longhand copy: NLS Acc. 7864. Hitherto unpbd. Dated “(1865)” by copyist; late April confirmed by the photographs taken “last week.”
div3.head: JWC TO MARY CARLYLE AUSTIN

docBody.p: My dear little Woman! A thousand thanks for your kind letter! I haven’t time to make a suitable returnCoterie speech; see 19:227JWC to JW, 29 Sept. 1845. just now; but I will soon.
In the meantime I want you to have these photographs (done last week).Either by John Watkins who photographed TC Sat., 15 April, and Mon., 17 April, and JWC around the same time, or by Elliott &Fry.

I have found the photograph of the Frederick picture,Presumably a photograph of the Carlyles’ copy of Pesne’s The Little Drummer (see JWC to Lady A[LLA], 2 Nov. 1864), probably taken by Robert Tait at the same time as his photographs for the painting of A Chelsea Interior; see JWC to JSJRS, 2 Dec. 1864. which you shall also have when I have time to pack it.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MC [MCR] , [ca. 25 April]. Addr: Chlorine Place / (Professor Craik) / Belfast / Ireland. PM: London, April 1865. MS: Strouse. Hitherto unpbd. Dated by John Watkins’ photographing of JWC; see JWC to JOWA, [25 April].
div3.head: JWC TO MARY CRAIK

docBody.p: This is too absurd! I am constantly getting a box on the ear of my conscience on your account! every time that I open a certain drawer! and for a penny stamp and ten minutes time, I might go safe so far as you are concerned; seeing that I cannot accuse myself of neglecting to think of you, and love you, and be grateful to you, good little woman that you are!Mary Craik nursed JWC the previous year at St. Leonards; see JWC to MC, 28 Nov. 1864 .

I suppose you know that we have been a month in Devonshire with Lady
Ashburton. At least as I hear pretty often one way and another, all about you; there is reason to suppose that you may also hear the particulars of me, indirectly. What however I am sure you do not know is that in rumageing in those “wardrobe drawers” for long left aside finery; (that I had never expected to need again) to pack a different sort of portmanteau from that little melancholy one I took, as all my luggage, to Dumfriesshire; I came upon—only think:—two tags of your gown! which I remember telling you to look for, as they had been taken off— You wouldn’t have been so careless, had it been for me you were looking instead of for yourself! Well I caried these tags in my writing case (!) to Seaton, meaning to inclose them forthwith. And every day they met my eyes, and every day I was so tired with the drivings and dinings and talkings of a Country House that I went to bed every night without having written! Then I came home, just when the weather became insufferably hot, and the sudden heat, or the change from the pure sea air of Seaton to the airlessness of London, or both together, or something else, made me quite ill—not nervous (thank God) but sick, and sleepless again, and terribly tired always—and incapable of putting pen to paper— I have continued my drives for three hours a day; and kept “about.” But it needs the recollections of past horrors of illness to make me patient with the present state.

You will have seen that Mr C’s Book is “out” at last. He has talked of going to Scotland “for a long time” ever since our return from Devon, but is not gone yet nor has he fixed his time. I do not accompany him If I go to Scotland this year at all it will be later. I suppose I must have “a change”Coterie speech; see 25:61 JWC to TC, [7 April 1850] . like everybody else; but I would rather stay at home if my health permitted

Meanwhile I have begged Dr and Mrs Blakiston to pay me a visit when Mr C has vacated his rooms—and they have promised to come. Mercy! What unwearied adorable kindness these people showed me! and the Russells in Dumfriesshire! and Dr QuainDr. Richard Quain wrote to TC, 22 April, thanking him profusely for sending him a copy of Frederick; he continued: “May it be long before you or dear Mrs Carlyle again know sorrow or again need help but if that time should come—will you remember where there is a heart and a head or a hand full ready &ever willing to be useful.” here! Oh dear! Oh dear! I wish I could repay them! I dont think their medical skill did anything almost for me, my case was beyond the reach of medecine. but their kindness, their comforting and encouraging saved my Life—or my Reason.

Miss Mulock has been to see me and told me all about it. She spoke most warmly of your Father’s exertions on her behalf. I dont as a general rule like marriages with the superiority of years on the woman’s side; but in this case the young Husbands loss of a leg may be set off against the ten years of disparity in age And Miss Mulock is such an exceptional woman that one may
excuse her marrying in a way of her own— I hope they will be as happy or even half as happy as she expects.Dinah Mulock m., 29 April, George Lillie Craik, Mary Craik’s cousin; she was eleven years older.

Love to your Father and Georgina. When shall I see you again little Woman? Wouldn’t you find a difference on me? Chiefly in the steadiness of my hand and the style of my Caps! Please come soon!— En attendant [in the meantime] I will send you a photograph just done of me (gratis)Either by John Watkins or Elliott &Fry.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 26 April. MS: NLS 517.89. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NL 2:227–28.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
Thanks for the Notes (last of them this morning), for the Saty Review &c.The article in The Saturday Review, 22 April, began: “The concluding volumes of Mr. Carlyle’s Frederick the Great have appeared, and a premature death cannot now intervene to add one more melancholy example to the long list of great historical works left half finished.” It discussed TC and his admiration for heroes: “Frederick … presents many of the qualities which Mr. Carlyle has spent his life in trying to make the world admire. He was very hard-working, very despotic, with a stern purpose to which he succeeded in making other men bend, and full of bulldog courage. … But the life of Frederick totally fails to give Mr. Carlyle scope for his power of seizing that which is pious, noble, and good in the characters of pious, noble, and good men. … To do things moderately good, with a perfect indifference to the feelings of every one, is the ideal of human life which Mr. Carlyle, amid some waverings, has set himself to preach up for the last thirty years; and Frederick the Great approaches this ideal sufficiently to warrant Mr. Carlyle in choosing him as a representative man.” It continued with praise for TC’s attention to detail: “He loves to take the utmost pains to make his geography and his chronology right. He is not satisfied with knowing that Frederick and his army crossed a brook; he wants also to know whether this brook had a gravelly or a muddy bottom. He is not satisfied with knowing that the brook was crossed on such a day of such a month, but he wants also to know what was the hour and the minute. Frederick’s history offers an ample field for this sort of labour, for Frederick was continually, for near thirty years, crossing brooks, and the glory and delight of finding out these brooks is much increased by the dismal character of the country where they are to be discovered. … In spite of all the pains Mr. Carlyle has taken to make [the Seven Years’ War] lively, the history of the struggle remains as dreary as ever. It is nothing but a long mournful series of marches across brooks at 2 p.m. and into bogs at 5 p.m.The brook and the bog are minutely described to us, and the hour precisely noted; but we can neither realize, nor persuade ourselves to care about, the contest.” The latter I found really entertaining in a degree,—and greatly superior to some balderdash of the TimesThe Times review of vol. 5, 18 April, began: “Mr. Carlyle has at length reached the conclusion of his great work, and may repose on his laurels. The great soldier of the 18th century is indebted to him for the best conceivable history of his military exploits and his domestic administration.” The review continued by summarizing the contents of vol. 5 of Frederick very much in the prose style of TC himself, concluding: “Here Mr. Carlyle calls in the aid of Prometheus and the Titans, and at this stage of his ecstacy, at the close of his fifth volume, we leave him.” The review, presumably of vol. 6, was “to be concluded in our next,” but it was apparently not published. whh Miss Jewsbury left here one day; and whh
was totally enigmatic to me till I heard incidentally that the creature who wrote it was given to liquor, &had (as I then saw) gone at it raging drunk!Unidentified further. Sordid canaille will be canaillish; why not?—

The thing I write abt today, is to tell you that I find myself still with a £2,000 to invest; &shd be privately glad of yr advice abt it. Chorley (apropos of my American outstandings) was, the other day, recommending the Indian Guaranteed (Something), “Govt responsible for it, interest on the very border of 5 per cent &c,” said Chorley: price was only abt £101 per 100 &5 was the percent; but I heeded him little, not knowing at the time that I had, still to invest.— Pray give me advice, abt this “India” or whatr be the advisablest.

I am beginning to think of being off abt May 10: but I have not written to Jean yet, to fix the day. Pray send her this Photograph when you write.—— “Bust” still a botheratn to me: hang it! But I have now only 2 sittings this day!

div3.sourceNote: TC-JC, 26 April. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JAMES CARLYLE

docBody.p: I am in great hurry, and in bad fettle for writing; but must not delay send you a word in reply to Jamie’s Letter.

It is bad news to me to hear of the almost impossibility you find in getting farms, while ready to pay a fair rent; especially that you are actually thinking of the likelihood of being obliged to leave Scotsbrig (whh I shd much grieve at); and that you have turned your eyes on such a sad refuge as that of banishment to CraigenputtockTC was increasingly using the spelling “Craigenputtock.” and the Galloway Wilderness far away!

You know very well, dear Brother, how ready I am, and shall at all times be, to do anything for you that I can;—and surely a far greater favour than that of “allowing you to offer for Craigenpk” when it falls vacant might well be expected of me! Clear it is in fact that if you were in Craigenpk, and contentedly and prosperously living there, it wd be a very great pleasure to me, and a visible increase to my small resources of comfort or enjoyt for the poor
remainder of my life. But I much doubt, for yr own side of the matter, it wd be very questionable, when you came to approach it practically or to try it. There are some objections to Brother being tenant to Brother (as you well enough know, &have seen in my own case):TC’s brother Alexander (Alick) had farmed at Craigenputtoch, 1828–31, during the time that TC and JWC lived there; the place was then under the control of Grace Welsh, JWC’s mother. but perhaps these are not insuperable;—and in fact it is not these that alone, or perhaps chiefly, raise my doubts in the case. My fear is you might all be rather miserable there, and not “contented” and “prosperous”; whh wd be a very sad result to me to witness!

However, we need not prosecute the subject farther just yet: I am just abt gathering myself for Scotland as you have often heard; and in 3 or 4 weeks I expect to be in my old home, namely in your old Scotsbrig, once agn: there will then be opportunity to talk the matter over between ourselves two, till we are fairly at the bottom of it, and have ascertained to the satisfactn of us both what really can be done in it. Not only an honest, but an honourable, candid, practical &prudent man I have always found you to be; and I believe we shall be able to arrive at a result whh both of us can agree to be the right and wise one.

Meanwhile I will not mention a world of it to anybody (Jane excepted, who already knows), nor need any of you; so that it will remain silent between us, whh is much the best way for it, being withal so easy a case.

I have not yet fixed a day with Jean for Dumfries; but am thinking of the 10th or so of next Month. I must rouse myself, say when; and get out of this element, the sooner the better. Jean &I will soon be down at Scotsbrig; &she will “do” for me while there.

I have a fine little Horse here, whh I am thinking of forwarding to Carlisle &your keeping till I come. “Noggs” they call him: a “little bay chestnut”; hardy as a flint &a most innocent useful fellow, tho’ of (superficially) obstinate &thrawn turn of mind. He is in the height of “condition”; higher than he has any need to be: if you have any grass (whh will soon be the case) he wd be delighted to live on that,—passionately likes grass even in the withered state:—if you gave him a fair bite of oats twice a day or perhaps once, &let him run abt foraging, he wd be much obliged to you. I doubt he will have to be sent for when he arrives at Carlisle? But perhaps the Station-Master at Ecclefechan can tell you whether I can have him booked and paid at London all the way to the Swaugh or to the Galls:Stations near Ecclefechan; see 22:108TC to AC, 2 Oct. 1847. I cannot learn here witht difficulty, if well at all. Pray ask, some time soon. I am thoroughly tired of riding the creature here; &come he must soon. Last time I inquired here (years ago), there was only one train for Horseboxes: 6 in the morning; no other all day.
What a mass of scribble I have put down: ten times more than I intended!—

div3.sourceNote: JWC-CGD, 26 April. Addr: Grosvenor Hotel. MS: NLS 609.707. Pbd: Duffy 214–15; C. G. Duffy, My Life in Two Hemispheres (1898) 2:254–55. Date and address noted in another hand on MS: “(April 26 1865)” and “addressed / Hon. Chas Gavan Duffy / Grosvenor Hotel.”
div3.head: JWC TO CHARLES GAVAN DUFFY

docBody.p: Mr Carlyle read in a newspaper ten days ago that you had “returned from Australia”Charles Gavan Duffy, now living in Australia, was in Europe for an extended holiday; he traveled aboard the Great Victoria, which arrived from Melbourne 11 April (Times, 12 April); the newspaper report of Duffy’s arrival untraced. and was “stopping in London.” I said it couldn’t be true; you wouldn’t have been many hours in London without coming to see us!Duffy recalled later: “For a couple of weeks, I found it impossible to visit Cheyne Row, and my dear old friend Mrs. Carlyle was impatient that I did not find her earlier. … In all England, and in all Ireland afterwards, there was but one woman each to welcome me with the frank and cordial salute, and I rejoice always to remember that Mrs. Carlyle was one of the two who so honoured me” (Duffy, My Life 2:254, 255). But Mr C thought otherwise—that you might have found no time yet—and he desired me to put George Cooke (a friend of ours who can find out everything) on discovering where you were lodged. Had this failed, I suppose he would have advertised for you in the Times;—if still you had made no sign!

You may figure then how glad I was, when your letter and basket arrived to me this forenoon, just as I was starting off for my long daily drive. Since I came back, I have done nothing but admire the various presents you have sent me, and think how kind it was of you to collect these things for me so far away!
But we want to see you! when will you come?

p.hi: Courtesy of Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University

docBody.p: Mr C says he is going to call for you to morrow morning; but most likely you will be gone out. So it would be best to make an appointment to meet here— At dinner—say at six o’clock—when a Man’s day’s work is, or ought to be done? Name any day you like? only let it be soon if you please! For I am impatient to see you!During the rest of his stay in England, Duffy paid regular visits to Cheyne Row: “On Sunday I generally went to Chelsea, and after a pleasant gossip in the little sitting-room at the foot of the stairs with Madame, I sallied out with Carlyle and walked for several hours in Hyde Park or Battersea Park, talking as of old” (Duffy, My Life 2:258). During one of these meetings, Duffy later recalled, he asked TC “whether he would follow Frederick by any other historical study. No, he said, he would probably write no more books; writing books was a task to which a man could not be properly encouraged in these times. Modern literature was all purposeless and distracted, and led he knew not where” (Duffy 221). For a photograph of Duffy, probably taken around this time, see opp. above. It was photograph 39 in vol. 3 of JWC’s photograph albums, and, according to TC’s note underneath, it was the last photograph she inserted: “(That is the last of Her insertions).”

div1.p: Notes on the Carlyles’ contemporaries referred to more than once in the present volume are given below, cross-referenced to earlier information. Some relatives or old friends who died before the starting date of this volume are retained because of frequent references to them. Otherwise, individuals are accounted for in headnotes and footnotes as they appear in the letters.
Adamson, Samuel (1831–80), British Linen Co., Dumfries, where TC had an account; son of Robert Adamson (1787–1861; see 10:23TC to JA, 14 Feb. 1838, and 37:26137:biographical notes).

Airlie, Henrietta Blanche, b. Stanley (1829–1921; see 26:30226:biographical notes), 5th countess; m., 1851, David Graham Drummond Ogilvy, Lord Airlie (1826–81; see 26:28926:biographical notes), 5th earl; for their children, see 37:26137:biographical notes. They lived at Cortachy Castle, Forfarshire (now Angus).

Aitken, Jean (“Craw”) Carlyle (1810–88), TC’s sister; m., 1833, James Aitken (1809–87) from Troqueer, housepainter of English St., Dumfries; they moved from Assembly St., Dumfries, to their new house, The Hill, Lochmaben Rd., Dumfries, 1863. They had two sons who d. in infancy (1834–36 and 1855–56), both named Alexander; their surviving sons were James or Jamie (1836–71), who worked in a mercantile house in London from 1858, then moved to work in Liverpool ca. Nov. 1864; Thomas (1841–69), who had been at an inst. for the deaf in Glasgow (see 29:186TC to JAC, 4 Nov. 1854), but was apparently now living at home; and John (1843–1911). Their das. were Anne (1839–1919), Margaret (1845–1932), and Mary (1848–95), who m., 1879, her cousin Alexander Carlyle.

Amberley, John Russell (1842–76: ODNB), viscount, politician, and writer; son of John Russell (1792–1878; ODNB), 1st Earl Russell, politician, and Frances Anna Maria, b. Kynynmound (1815–98). He m., 8 Nov. 1864, Kate Stanley (see Stanley).

Ashburton, William Bingham Baring (1799–23 March 1864; ODNB; see 11:40TC to MAC, 8 March 1839, and later vols.), 2d baron; politician and partner in Baring Bros., bankers. He m., first, 1823, Harriet, b. Montagu (1805–57; ODNB; see 11:40TC to MAC, 8 March 1839, and 26:ix–xv26:introduction); they met the Carlyles 1839 and became close friends. Ashburton m., second, 1858, Louisa Caroline, b. Stewart-Mackenzie (1827–1903), da. of Mary Elizabeth Frederica, b. Mackenzie (1783–1862; ODNB), chief of Clan Mackenzie, and James Alexander Stewart (1784–1843); on their marriage (1817) the name Mackenzie was added to that of Stewart. JWC expected not to like her, but was swiftly won over.
The Ashburtons had one da., Mary Florence (1860–1902). They lived at Bath House, Piccadilly, London, and The Grange, Alresford, Hampshire; they also had a farm at Addiscombe, near Croydon. In 1861 Lord Ashburton bought Melchet Court, a country house 6 mi. (9.5 km.) W of Romsey, Hampshire, on the border between Hampshire and Wiltshire, for Lady Louisa; see 38:8JWC to LLA, [11 Nov. 1861]. His brother Francis Baring (1800–68; see 36:27636:biographical notes) -became 3d Lord Ashburton. Where necessary for clarity, we refer in notes to Lord Ashburton’s first and second wives as Lady Harriet Ashburton and Lady Louisa Ashburton respectively, although these are not the correct forms.

Austin, Mary Carlyle (1808–88), TC’s sister, m., 1831, James Austin (1805–78), farmer of The Gill, 6 mi. (9.5 km.) SW of Ecclefechan. They had eight das.: Margaret (1831–74), who m., 1859, Thomas Stewart (1832–69), farmer at Hollybush, they had a da., Mary (b. ca. 1861) and a son, William (b. 1863); Grace (b. 1833), who m., 1856, William Yeoward (b. ca. 1824), of Toronto, Canada; Jessie (b. 1836), who m., 1859, George Grierson (b. 1835); Jane (b. 1840); Mary Anne (b. 1842); Catherine (b. 1844), who m., 1866, her cousin James Carlyle; Isabella (b. ca. 1846); and Mary Carlyle (b. 1851); and one surviving son, James (b. 1848).

Baird, Charlotte, b. Acton (1818–30 Sept. 1864), m., 1851, Douglas Baird (1808–54), Glasgow ironmaster; of Closeburn Hall, Dumfriesshire. Her parents were Henry Acton (b. 1790), capt. in the 12th royal lancers, and Charlotte, b. Clugson, of Bombay.
