Ballantyne, Thomas (1806–71; ODNB; see 11:32TC to TB, 23 Feb. 1839, and 30:xviii30:introduction), author and journalist; associated with several publications including the Manchester Guardian, the Leader, the Illustrated London News, the Statesman, and the St. James’s Chronicle; he anthologized TC and other writers.
Baring, Louisa (1804–88) and Lydia Emily (1814–68), Lord Ashburton’s -sisters.

Barnes, Dr. Alfred Brooke (ca. 1802–67), physician, living at 182 King’s Rd., Chelsea; JWC’s doctor in Chelsea; he had been ill for some time (see 40:123TC to LLA, 28 June 1864, and 198TC to JWC, 22 Aug. 1864); m. Susannah (ca. 1804–ca. 1855); their eldest child, Laura Susannah (b. 1829), was now dead; the other children were Rev. Brooke Cremer (b. 1833), Dr. Herbert Sedgwick (ca. 1835–65), and Isabella Emily (b. 1837, d. by 1899), who m., 1862, John Simmonds (b. 1829, still alive in 1899), barrister. John and Isabella Simmonds lived at 82a Oakley St., Chelsea, with their da., Ethel Jane (1863–65; see 40:100TC to JN, 18 May 1864); Isabella was close to JWC from their first meetings in 1859.
Barnet; see Blakiston.

Blakiston, Bessy, b. Barnet (ca. 1810–91), m., 1862, Peyton Blakiston (1801–78), M.D.; they lived at St. Leonards-on-Sea, Sussex. Blakiston’s first wife, m., 1825, was Frances, b. Powell (d. 1858); their sons were John
Richard (1829–1917), Peyton (1831–65), Douglas Yeoman (1832–1914), and Matthew Folliott (1835–1906).

Blunt, Abel Gerald Wilson (1827–1902), m., 1851, Frances Mary, b. Forssteen (1820–99); they had seven children, including Reginald (1857–1944) and Elaine Mary (b. 1862). Gerald Blunt was appointed rector of St. Luke’s, Chelsea in 1860. His sister was Julia Sophia (1823–95), and his elder brother was Henry George Scawen Blunt (1821–99), who m., 1846, Charlotte, b. Daniell (1818–86).

Braid, Betty, b. Pringle (1795–1875), Grace Welsh’s Haddington servant, close to JWC (see 21:82JWC to SS, [29 Oct. 1846] and 24:221JWC to TC, 5 Sept. 1849); b. in Prestonkirk, E. Lothian; m. Alexander (1792–1874), stonemason and shopkeeper. They had one surviving son, George Pringle (1827–10 Feb. 1865), who suffered ill health. Three other sons d. in infancy: Alexander (b. 1826), James (b. 1829), and James (b. 1831). Previously living at 15 Adam St. (see 17:127TC to JWC, 12 Sept. 1843), they moved in 1858 to Upper Stenhouse, Liberton, S Edinburgh.

Bromley, Caroline Davenport (1820–91), da. of Rev. Walter Davenport Bromley (1787–1862) of Wootton Hall, Staffordshire, and his first wife, m., 1818, Caroline Barbara, b. Gooch (1791–1827). A friend of Lady Louisa Ashburton, she became a close friend of JWC. The Carlyles called her “Lark,” “Die Lerche,” or “Flight of Skylarks.” Her London home was at 32 Grosvenor St. Her brother was William Davenport Bromley (1821–84).

Browning, Robert (1812–89; ODNB), poet, TC’s friend since the mid-1830s (see 30:74TC to JAC, 26 Sept. 1855, and 133TC to RB, 4 Dec. 1855). He m., 1846, Elizabeth Barrett, b. Moulton Barrett (1806–61; ODNB), poet. Robert Wiedeman Barrett (“Pen”) (1849–1912) was their only child.

Buccleuch, Walter Francis Montagu-Douglas-Scott (1806–84; ODNB), 5th duke of Buccleuch and 7th duke of Queensberry, magnate and politician; m., 1829, Charlotte Anne, b. Thynne (1811–95; ODNB); they lived in Drumlanrig Castle, Dumfriesshire, and had four sons and three das., including Victoria Alexandria (1844–1938), who m., 1865, Schomberg Henry Kerr (see Lothian).

Bullock, John (1815–90), from King’s Lynn, Norfolk, letter carrier, who had succeeded John Piper as the Carlyles’ postman; see 33:64TC to JWC, 1 Sept. 1857. His son was John Joseph Bullock (b. 1846), listed in the 1861 census as an errand boy and in the 1871 census as a letter sorter.

Butler, Charles (1802–97; see 28:314TC to JCA, 18 Nov. 1853), U.S. lawyer, financier, land speculator, entrepreneur, and philanthropist; welcome in Britain for his part in handling the threat by some U.S. states in the 1840s to default on their bonds; met TC Nov. 1853 and looked after his Illinois bonds and other American investments. He m., 1825, Eliza, b. Ogden (1803–78); they had five children: Abraham Ogden Butler (1832–56), two other sons who d. in infancy, and two das., Emily (b. 1840) and Anna (d. 1877).

Carlyle, Alexander (Alick) (1797–1876), TC’s brother; emigrated with his family to Canada, 1843; settled at the Bield, 4½ mi. (7 km.) W of Brantford, Ontario. He m., 1830, Janet, b. Clow (1809–91), they had six surviving sons: Thomas (1833–1921), John (1839–1924), Alexander (see below), James (1846–1924), William (1849–1935), and Robert (1851–1932); and three surviving das.: Jane Welsh (1831–84), who m., 1852, Robert Sims; Janet (1836–1916); and Margaret (1847–1935); see 1:166TC to AC, 23 Feb. 1819. An unidentified son (1832–33), Margaret (1835–36), James (b. 1840), and Euphemia (1853–54) all d. in infancy; see 32:4TC to AC, 3 Oct. 1856.

Carlyle, Alexander (1843–1931; see 16:153TC to AC, 4 May 1843 ), Alexander and Janet’s son; m., 1879, his cousin Mary Aitken; lived with TC from 1879 and ed. various collections of the Carlyles’ letters and writings of TC.

Carlyle, James (Jamie) (1805–90), TC’s brother, farmer at Scotsbrig; m., 1834, Isabella, b. Calvert (ca. 1813–1859). Their children were James (Jr., the younger) (1835–71), who had been working in Glasgow as a clerk but was now back home; m., 1866, his cousin Catherine Austin; John (1836–1901); Thomas (1839–41); and Janet (Jessie or Jenny) (1843–74).

Carlyle, John (ca. 1792–1872), TC’s half-brother; emigrated to the U.S. in 1837, then moved to Canada (see 12:228TC to AC, 15 Aug. 1840 ); he lived on a small farm at Mount Pleasant, nr. Brantford, Ontario. He m., 1817, Margaret (Peggy), b. Benn (1798–1867), they had six children: Janet (1818–89), m., 1844, John Randall Ellis (1811–1911), carpenter; Mary (1821–50); John (1825–26); John (1827–97), m. Mary Catherine, b. Smith; James (1830–1900) qualified as a doctor but worked for most of his life as a teacher; and William (1833–1911), a teacher and later a school inspector, m., 1860, Emily b. Youmans (1835–1912); their da. Florence Emily Carlyle (24 Sept. 1864–1923), became a prominent Canadian artist. William visited TC in London, Aug. 1864.

Carlyle, John Aitken (Jack, “The Doctor”) (1801–79; ODNB), TC’s brother, physician, and translator. He m., 1852, Phoebe Elizabeth Hough Watt, b. Fowler (1810–54), wealthy widow of Fitzjames Watt (1809–48), from Leek in Staffordshire, with four sons; she d. in childbirth; the child was stillborn. John A. Carlyle assumed responsibility for his stepsons: Thomas Fowler (1838–62), went to sea in 1856 (see 32:29TC to IC, 12 Nov. 1856 ), went to Australia, July 1861, and d. on his return; Henry (b. 1839), at sea from 1854 (see 29:121TC to JCA, 30 June 1854), m., 1863, Jane Wilson, b. Hunter (1837–1908), da. of John A. Carlyle’s friend John Hunter (1801–69; see 8:161JWC to SS, [June or July? 1835]) and Helen, b. Vary (1804–85); Arthur (b. 1840), at school in Edinburgh from 1856, joined the civil service 1862; and William (b. 1842), at the Royal Military Academy, Woolwich, from 1858.

Carlyle, Margaret Aitken (1771–1853), TC’s mother; she had lived with James
and Isabella Carlyle at Scotsbrig. TC’s father was James Carlyle (1758–1832); they m. 1795.

Chamberlayne, Maria, from Hampshire, servant at Cheyne Row July 1861–Nov. 1862. Her mother was Ann, b. Weldon, m., 1838, Jeremiah Chamberlayne; she previously worked at The Grange; see 39:187JWC to MR, [16 Sept. 1863].
Chapman, Edward (1804–80; ODNB), senior partner in Chapman &Hall, TC’s publisher since 1842 (see 14:37TC to JF, 5 Feb. 1842); he m., 1841, Mary, b. Whiting (b. ca. 1820).
Chapman, Frederic (1823–95; ODNB), Edward Chapman’s cousin and junior partner in Chapman &Hall; he m., 1861, Clara, b. Woodin (d. 1866); they had one son, Frederic.

Chorley, John Rutter (1806–67; ODNB; see 19:135TC to JWC, [early August 1845]), poet and scholar of Spanish literature, reviewer for the Athenaeum; highly regarded by TC. He helped supervise the building of the soundproof room in the attic of 5 Cheyne Row in 1853 (see 28:245TC to JCA, 11 Aug. 1853 and Carlyle, Reminiscences 154) and assisted in proofreading Frederick (see 34:146TC to HL, 18 Aug. 1858).

Conway, Moncure Daniel (1832–1907; ODNB), American Unitarian minister, abolitionist, and author; m., 1858, Ellen, b. Dana (d. 1897); they had two sons, Eustace (b. 1858) and Emerson (1861–4 Aug. 1864). Friend of Ralph Waldo Emerson, who introduced him to TC. He came to Britain 1863; pastor at South Place Chapel, 11 South Pl., Finsbury, London, 1864–84; they lived at 28 Notting Hill Sq.
Cook, Mrs. (b. ca. 1785), Chelsea laundry woman; by 1865 she was in a workhouse; see 39:82JWC to EFO, 5 March 1863, and Carlyle, Reminiscences 186.

Cooke, John George (known as George Cooke) (1819–80), stockbroker; he had met JWC in 1856 (see 30:252JWC’s Journal, 18 May 1856) and became a close friend. She described him in 1864: “a man between thirty and forty; tall, strong, silent, sincere; has been a sailor, a soldier, a New Zealand settler, ‘a Man about Town,’ and a Stock Broker!!!” (JWC to MR, [10 Oct. 1864] 319). He previously lived at 47 Mount St.; in Jan. 1865 he was at 18 Pelham Place, Brompton. He had five sisters, including Charlotte (b. 1811), Margaretta (b. 1815), and Louisa (b. 1817).

Craik, George Lillie (1798–1866; ODNB; see 8:207JWC to SS, 20 Sept. 1835), author, prof. of English lit. and history, Queen’s Coll., Belfast, 1849–66; friend of the Carlyles since 1835; m., 1826, Jeannette, b. Dempster (d. 1856; see 10:159JWC to TC, 30 Aug. 1838). They had one son, George Lillie (b. ca. 1825), and three das.: Mary (1827–1909), Isabella (1829–42; see 15:221JWC to JW, 8 Dec. 1842), and Georgiana (1831–95), novelist. Mary came to St. Leonards, May-July 1864, to be JWC’s nurse

Cunningham, Francis (1820–75; ODNB), army officer and literary editor, youngest son of Allan Cunningham (1784–1842; ODNB), poet and songwriter, and Jean Cunningham, b. Walker (1791–1864), m. 1811; old friends
of the Carlyles; see 10:111JWC to JWCU, 3 July 1838. His sister Mary Cunningham (1822–67) lived with him at 18 Clarendon Road, London; see Carlyle, Reminiscences 139.

Delepine, Elizabeth Marie Louise, b. Jâger (b. ca. 1831), known as Madame Elise, milliner and dressmaker at 170 Regent St.; she inherited the business from her aunt, Jane Clarke (d. 1859), milliner (see also 33:141JWC to DD, 29 Dec. 1857). TC noted on her photograph (see 130): “‘Madame Elise’ I think a fashionable Dressmaker, whom she [JWC] thot a real artist, and who valued her approval in a marked manner” (Thomas Carlyle Photograph Albums, vol. 2; Rare Book and Manuscript Lib., Columbia Univ.). She m., 1857, Frederick Wooton Isaacson (1836–98), silk merchant; they had three children: Frederick (b. ca. 1858), Violet Elise Marie Louise (ca. 1861–1910), and Rudolph (b. ca. 1863). They lived at Hill House, Acton.

Dickens, Charles (1812–70; ODNB), novelist; friend of the Carlyles since the early 1840s; m., 1836, Catherine Thomson, b. Hogarth (1816–79); separated from her since 1858; see 33:233TC to RWE, 2 June 1858.

Dods, William (1795–1873, see 33:79JWC to LAI, [11 Sept. 1857]), Haddington bank agent; childhood admirer of JWC. He m., first, Harriet, b. Shirreff (ca. 1804–53), with whom he had seven sons and two das.; see 37:26537:biographical notes. He m., second, 1854, Jane, b. Wilkie (ca. 1809–85). His photograph, 39:63, is incorrectly captioned. His brother was Thomas Dods (1800–1878; see 33:88JWC to WDO, [19 Sept. 1857]).

Downes, John (1827–15 May 1864), writer; originally intending to be a minister in the Free Church of Scotland, he abandoned theology for philosophy, writing later, “Carlyle tore my nature to pieces; Thackeray built it up again” (William Knight, Some Nineteenth Century Scotsmen [Edinburgh, 1903] 118). He m., 1859, Elizabeth, b. McNeil (b. ca. 1829) and they had two das., Annabelle (b. 1860) and Margaret (b. 1863).

Downshire, Lady Caroline Frances, b. Stapleton-Cotton (1815–93), m., 1837, Arthur Wills Blundell Sandys Trumbull Windsor Hill (1812–68), 4th marquess of Downshire; they had three children; see 32:247–4832:biographical notes.

Duffy, Charles Gavan (1816–1903; ODNB), Irish nationalist, lawyer, and politician; emigrated to Australia 1855; known to the Carlyles since 1845; see 19:64–66TC to MAC, 28 April 1845. He m., 1847, as his second wife, his cousin Susan, b. Hughes (1826–78); they had six children.
Elise, Madame; see Delepine.
Elliott, Joseph John (1835–1903) and Clarence Edmund Fry (1840–97), photographers, 55 Baker St., London; they photographed TC and JWC, April 1865.

Emerson, Ralph Waldo (1803–82; see 6:425TC to JAC, 27 Aug. 1833), philosopher, essayist, poet, and transcendentalist. He first met TC in Aug. 1833; in spite of their differences they had close ties; he introduced many Americans to TC and played a leading part in arranging the publication of TC’s works in the U.S.

Erskine, Thomas (1788–1870; ODNB; see 10:18TC to JAC, 1 Feb. 1838), theologian and retired advocate, living at Linlathen, Dundee; known to the Carlyles since the mid-1830s. He had two widowed sisters who lived with him: Christian (1789–1866), who m., 1817, Charles Stirling; and David (1791–1867), who m., 1821, Capt. James Paterson.
Ewart, Alicia, b., Yourstoun or Yorston (b. ca. 1789), friend of Mary Russell, living at Nithbank, Thornhill; see 40:193–94JWC to TC, [19 Aug. 1864].
Fanny, age 28, was the maid at 5 Cheyne Row, Nov. 1864 to June 1865.
Farie, Robert (1813–82; see 21:96TC to JAC, 20 Nov. 1864), translator of German works, old friend of the Carlyles.

Fearn, John Williams Walker (1832–99), from Alabama, U.S.; lawyer and diplomat, formerly secretary to the U. S. legations in Belgium and Mexico; sent in 1861 and again in 1863 as a diplomatic representative to Europe by the Confederate state dept.
Fergus, John (1797–1865), owner of John Fergus &Co., flax spinners and bleachers, Kirkcaldy; MP for Fife 1847–59; he and his sisters were old friends of the Carlyles; see 34:27534:biographical notes.

Fletcher, John Charles (1798–1875), m., 1838, Elizabeth, b. Church (1816–88), of Twynholm, Kirkcudbrightshire. They lived at Dale Park, Arundel, Sussex. Fletcher’s name was previously John Jack; he had changed it to Fletcher by the time he bought Dale Park in 1860.

Forster, John (“Fuz”) (1812–76; ODNB; see 6:118TC to JHLH, 8 Feb. 1832, and 11:7TC to JF, 17 Jan. 1839), historian, journalist, and biographer; ed. of the Examiner 1847–55; sec. to the Lunacy Commission 1855–61, and a commissioner from Feb. 1861; friend of the Carlyles since the late 1830s and TC’s literary adviser. He m., 1856, Eliza Ann, b. Crosbie (ca. 1819–94), widow of the publisher Henry Colburn (ca. 1784–1855; ODNB); they previously lived at 46 Montagu Sq.; from late 1863 they lived at Palace Gate House, Kensington.
Freure, Frederick (b. 1835), Chelsea carpenter, m. Ann (b. ca. 1830). “The Chelsea carpenter” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:284); he was also listed as a builder in the 1865 post office directory.

Froude, James Anthony (1818–94; ODNB), journalist and historian, ed. of Fraser’s Magazine 1860–74; he m., first, 1849, Charlotte Maria, b. Grenfell (1812–60); they had two das., Georgina Margaret (1850–1935) and Rose Mary (b. 1852), and a son, Pascall Grenfell (1854–79). He m., second, 1861, Henrietta Elizabeth Warre (1824–74); they had a son, Ashley Anthony (1863–1949), and a da., May (b. 1867). They lived at 6 Clifton Pl., Hyde Park. Henrietta’s father, John Ashley Warre (1787–1860), had m., as his third wife, Charlotte Froude’s sister Caroline (1809–86).
Haining or Hanning, David (1834–65), son of Thomas (d. 1865) and Eliza Haining of Laight, Tynron parish, Dumfriesshire.

Hanning, Janet Carlyle (1813–97), TC’s sister; m., 1836, Robert Hanning
(1796–1878), who had emigrated to Canada in mysterious disgrace in 1841; she joined him in Hamilton, Ontario, Aug. 1851, with their two das., Margaret (b. 1838) and Mary (b. 1840), who m., 2 May 1864, Charles Coates Holden (b. 1836). In Canada they had two more das., Catherine (b. ca. 1852) and Jane.
Helen, Hellen, or Ellen, Cheyne Row servant, hired early March 1864, possibly by Margaret Welsh, dismissed Nov. 1864.

Hiddleston / Hiddlestone, Margaret (ca. 1800–4 May 1865), widow of William Hiddleston, tailor; maid to JWC’s mother at Templand; see 14:160TC to JWC, 21 April 1842. Her das. were Margaret (1831–1904), m., 1855, Joseph McCaig (1829–76), cabinet maker, living at 62 West Morton Street, Thornhill; and Jessie (1835–1904), recorded in the 1861 census as with the family of Andrew Bennet, Closeburn Manse, Dumfriesshire, but now living in Edinburgh; she became the Carlyles’ maid, 1865–66, then m., 1866, Robert Broadfoot (ca. 1828 or ca. 1833–90), butler to Archibald Watson Goldie (1793–1872), Writer to the Signet, and his second wife, Henrietta Townsend, b. Hare (d. 1904), m. 1860, at 8 York Place, Edinburgh.

Houghton, Richard Monckton Milnes (1809–85; ODNB; see 9:8–10TC to JAC, 14 July 1836, and 12:9TC to RWE, 6 Jan. 1840), 1st baron (from 1863), author, and politician; lived at 16 Upper Brook St., London, and Fryston Hall, Yorkshire; the Carlyles’ friend since the late 1830s despite political differences; Milnes supported religious and civil liberties and championed progressive causes such as education for the working class and prison reform. He m., 1851, Annabella, b. Hungerford Crewe (1814–74); they had two das. and a son; see 37:27037:biographical notes.
Hunt, William Holman (1827–1910; ODNB), Pre-Raphaelite artist.
Inglis, Henry (1806–85), Writer to the Signet, Edinburgh lawyer, living at 16 Queen St., whom the Carlyles had known since the late 1820s; see 5:12TC to HI, 31 March 1829.
Irving, Edward (1792–1834; ODNB; see 1:92TC to RM, 12 Feb. 1817, later vols., and Carlyle, Reminiscences), the Carlyles’ great friend; religious leader and preacher.

Jeffrey, William (1826–77), photographer; he took a series of photographs of TC and JWC at his studio, 114 Gt. Russell St., Sept. 1862; see 38:217TC to JAC, 19 Sept. 1862, 220JWC to MR, [21 Sept. 1862], and 28038:biographical notes.

Jewsbury, Geraldine Endsor (1812–80; ODNB; see 12:103–4TC to GEJ, 12 April 1840), novelist, reviewer, and misc. writer; a friend of the Carlyles, particularly of JWC, since 1841. She lived at 41 Markham Sq., London. She met Walter Mantell (see below) late 1856 and fell in love with him; he did not reciprocate, but they remained close and exchanged over 500 letters in the course of their friendship.
Kerr; see Lothian.

Larkin, Henry (1820–99), collector or cashier for the Chelsea Steamboat Co.; partner in an engineering business. His Extra Physics and the Mystery of Creation (1878) included an appendix (written in 1858) giving an
analysis of Sartor Resartus; also author of Carlyle and the Open Secret of His Life (1886). For TC’s early contacts with him, see 25:322TC to HL, 29 Dec. 1850, and 27:78TC to HL, 29 March 1852. He worked on TC’s indexes and maps from 1856; see 34:57JWC to TC, [19 July 1858]. He m., 1862, Louisa, b. Wagstaff (b. 1837), and they lived at 6 Cheyne Row until 1864, when they moved to 6 Torriano Cottages, Leighton Rd., NW London. They had a son, Alfred Edward (b. 1863); a da., Nora, b. 22 March 1864, d. within 12 hours.

Lincoln, Abraham (1809–65), lawyer and politician; 16th president of the U.S. 1861–65. He m., 1842, Mary, b. Todd (1818–82), and they had four sons, only one of whom survived into adulthood. Lincoln was shot by John Wilkes Booth (1838–65), 14 April 1865, and died the following day.

Lothian, Lady Constance Harriet Mahonesa, b. Chetwynd-Talbot (1836–1901), marchioness, m., 1854, William Schomberg Robert Kerr (1832–70), 8th marquess of Lothian, a noted bibliophile, and an invalid for much of his life. His brother Schomberg Henry Kerr (1833–1900; ODNB), 9th marquess of Lothian, diplomat and politician, m., 23 Feb. 1865, Victoria Alexandria Douglas Scott, da. of the duke of Buccleuch. Their mother was Lady Cecil Chetwynd Talbot (1807–77; ODNB), dowager marchioness of Lothian.
McCaig; see Hiddleston.

Maccall, William (1812–88; ODNB), impoverished writer, Unitarian preacher, and lecturer; m., 1842, Alice, b. Haselden (1813–78); they had one da., Elizabeth (b. 1843). See K. J. Fielding, “Carlyle, Charles Dickens, and William Maccall,” Notes and Queries n.s. 1 (1954): 488–90.
Mackenzie; see Stewart-Mackenzie.

Mantell, Walter Baldock Durant (1820–95), politician and naturalist; b. in England, he settled in New Zealand in 1840. He was politically active in trying to obtain rights for the Maori; see 33:276–7733:biographical notes and 37:27037:biographical notes. See also Jewsbury.

Mary (b. ca. 1838), servant at Cheyne Row Dec. 1862–Nov. 1864. She gave birth to an illegitimate child in the small room next to the dining room in Cheyne Row, 29 July, while JWC was in Scotland; the Carlyles were unaware of this until Nov. 1864. The father of the child was a young man apparently aged 20, formerly a boot cleaner in a hotel.

Mazzini, Giuseppe (1805–72; see 11:225TC to JSM, 6 Dec. 1839, and 28:xiii–xiv28:introduction), Italian revolutionary; friend of the Carlyles since the late 1830s. He was usually based in London, but continued to encourage active Italian resistance to Austrian domination. His photograph, 39:64, is incorrectly captioned.

Mill, John Stuart (1806–73; ODNB), utilitarian philosopher and economist; m., 1851, Harriet Taylor (1807–58), who strongly influenced his thinking. Mill met TC in Sept. 1831 (see 5:398TC to JWC, 4 Sept. 1831); they remained on friendly terms even after the MS of vol. 1 of The French Revolution was burned while
in Mill’s keeping (see 8:66–68TC to JFR, 7 March 1835), but later became estranged because of many differences in temperament and attitudes to social questions; Mill also believed that TC and other friends disapproved of his marriage. Elected Liberal M.P. for Westminster 1865.
Milnes, Richard Monckton; see Houghton.

Mulock, Dinah Maria (1826–87; ODNB), writer, known to JWC since 1852; see 27:387JWC to HW, [30 Dec. 1852]. She m., 29 April 1865, George Lillie Craik (1837–1905), an accountant, son of Rev. James Craik (1802–70) and Margaret, b. Grieve, nephew of the Carlyles’ friend George Lillie Craik (see above).

Oliphant, Margarent Oliphant Wilson (1828–97; ODNB), novelist, biographer, reviewer, and misc. writer; she m., 1852, her cousin Francis Wilson Oliphant (1818–59; ODNB); their children were Margaret Wilson (1853–64), Marjorie (1854–55), a son who d. at birth (1855), Cyril Francis (“Tids”) (1856–90), and Francis Romano (“Cecco”) (1859–94). Her mother was Margaret Oliphant Wilson (ca. 1789–1854) and her father was Francis W. Wilson (ca. 1788–1858). Friend of JWC since 1860; see 37:62JWC to MO, [12 Dec. 1860].
Paterson; see Erskine.

Piper, John (1817–83?; see 22:59JWC to TC, [11 Sept. 1847], and 292JWC to TC, [25 Sept. 1847]), from Eltham, Kent; had been the Carlyles’ postman until 1857; see 35:26235:biographical notes. After the death of his first wife, Eliza Jane (ca. 1817–1855), he m., 1862, Susan, b. Chandler (b. 1818). Piper had been mentally unstable for several years, had been temporarily confined at the Hanwell Lunatic Asylum in Ealing, and by 1881 was in the Middlesex Lunatic Asylum.

Plattnauer, Richard Eduard (b. 1814), son of Nathan Plattnauer and Jeanette Breit; originally named Salomon, he was christened, age 24, at Sankt Nikolai, Brandenburg, Prussia, 17 Nov. 1838; political refugee from Prussia; see 22:10JWC to HW, [5 July 1847]. Friend of the Carlyles since the mid-1840s; see 18:194JWC to JW, 29 Aug. 1844; he suffered periods of insanity. For his sister Friederike, see Reichenbach.

Pollock, William Frederick (1815–88; ODNB), lawyer and author, m., 1844, Juliet, b. Creed (1818–99). His father was Sir Jonathan Frederick Pollock (1783–1870; ODNB), 1st baronet, judge, lord chief baron of the exchequer 1844–66; m., first, 1813, Frances, b. Rivers (ca. 1787–1827); m., second, 1834, Sarah Anne, b. Langslow (1815–95); see 29:33TC to JAC, 17 Feb. 1854.

Quain, Richard (1816–98; ODNB), physician, specializing in heart diseases, and with many wealthy and influential patients; he lived at 67 Harley St. He m., 1854, Isabella Agnes, b. Wray (1828–91); they had four das. He treated the Ashburtons and JWC.

Reichenbach, Oskar von (1815–93), Silesian landowner, liberal deputy to the Frankfurt parliament 1848–49, exiled to London in 1850. His wife was Friederike or Fredrike (called Hedwig in error before vol. 39), b. Plattnauer (b. 1817), sister of Richard Plattnauer, and their children were Elisabeth (b. 1843), Hedwig (1844–92), and Oskar (b. 1845). They emigrated to the U.S. 1853; by 1871 they were living in London again; they may have moved back permanently by 1865 or may have been visiting.

Robson, Charles (b. 1805), TC’s printer since 1837; of Robson &Levey, which went bankrupt early 1864 (see 40:6TC to JAC, 12 Jan. 1864). In partnership with one or both sons John (b. ca. 1837) and Christopher (b. 1843), he then formed Robson &Son, Great Northern Printing Works, St. Pancras Rd.
Royston, William Haylett (1822–71), m., 1847, Isabella, b. Harris; they had a son, William Haylett (b. 1863), and a da. (b. 31 Aug. 1864); they lived at 1 Cheyne Row.

Ruskin, John (1819–1900; ODNB), author, artist, and social reformer; m., 1848, Euphemia Chalmers, b. Gray (1828–97); marriage annulled 1854 (she then m., 1855, John Everett Millais [1829–96; ODNB], artist). Ruskin lived in the family home at 163 Denmark Hill, S London, with his mother, Margaret, b. Cock (1781–1871). His father, John James Ruskin (1785–1864), wine merchant, d. 3 March. Ruskin was J. M. W. Turner’s foremost admirer and was strongly influenced by TC.

Russell, Elizabeth Ann, b. Rawdon (1793–1874), widow of Lord George William Russell (1790–1846; ODNB), soldier and diplomat; she had two sons, Arthur John Edward (1825–92), M.P. for Tavistock 1857–85, with whom she lived at 2 Audley Sq., and Odo Leopold William (1829–84; ODNB), diplomat. She was always known as Lady William Russell; see Carlyle, Reminiscences 187.
Russell, John; see Amberley.

Russell, Mary, b. Dobbie (1802–75; see 6:145TC to AC, 7 April 1832 ), close friend of JWC and her mother. She m., 1829, Dr. James Russell (ca. 1796–1878); they had moved to Holmhill, nr. Thornhill, by Oct. 1859. Her father was Rev. Edward Dobbie (1773–1857; see 14:65TC to JWC, 9 March 1842).
Scott; see Buccleuch.
Silvester, John (b. ca. 1799), livery stable owner, Upper Church St., Chelsea. His wife was Phoebe (ca. 1800–1865); they had a son John (b. ca. 1829) and a grandson William (b. ca. 1857).

Simpson, James Young (1811–70; ODNB), Edinburgh physician and obstetrician, well known for his introduction of chloroform as an anesthetic in 1847 (see 35:238JWC to SS, [21 Oct. 1859]); awarded a baronetcy 1866.

Sinclair, Sir George (1790–1868; ODNB; see 24:18–19TC to JST, 10 April 1849), politician; living in Thurso Castle, Caithness. He m., 1816, Lady Catherine Camilla, b. Manners (1792–1863). They had a son, John George Tollemache Sinclair (1825–1912), m. Emma, b. Standish (1827–89), who lived at The Mount, Upper Norwood, nr. Croydon, SE London; and three das. (see 36:28636:biographical notes); the youngest, Olivia Sophia (1823–94), became a travel writer. Sir George’s sister Catherine (ca. 1801–64) was also an author. His father was Sir John Sinclair of Ulbster (1754–1835; ODNB), politician and agricultural improver.

Southam, Charlotte, b. Watson (1842–1905), the Carlyles’ maid until June 1861; see 37:27337:biographical notes. Now housemaid at the Kent home of George Charles Pratt (1799–1866), 2d marquis of Camden; see 39:103JWC to CSO, 29 March 1863. She continued to visit and correspond with both Carlyles. She m., 1866, Adolphus James Mills (b. 1842), a carpenter; they had five sons: Adolphus Berby (b. 1869), Thomas (b. 1871), Alfred George (b. 1875), Ernest (b. 1876), and Edward (b. 1880). Orphaned in childhood, she had been adopted by her uncle and aunt, Thomas (1806–3 Sept. 1864), a waterman, and Elizabeth (b. ca. 1805) Southam, whose surname she took; Elizabeth and Thomas are often referred to as Charlotte’s mother and father; they lived in Lawrence St., near Cheyne Row.

Stanley, Henrietta Maria, b. Dillon (1807–95; ODNB), m., 1826, Edward John (1802–69; ODNB; see 12:59TC to JAC, 27 Feb. 1840), Whig politician, who succeeded as 2d Baron Stanley of Alderley, 1850; living at Alderley Park, Cheshire; their London home was at 40 Dover St. Both were friends of the Carlyles. Lord Stanley was nicknamed Lord Ben after Sir Benjamin Backbite, a character in Richard Brinsley Sheridan’s School for Scandal (ca. 1780) (see 35:26435:biographical notes). They had nine surviving children: Henry Edward John (1827–1903; ODNB); Alice Margaret (1828–1910), m., 1853, Augustus Henry Lane Fox-Pitt-Rivers; Henrietta Blanche (see Airlie); Maude Alethea (1833–1915; ODNB); John (“Johny”) Constantine (1837–78); Edward Lyulph (1839–1925; ODNB); Katherine (Kate) Louisa (1842–74; ODNB), m., 8 Nov. 1864, John Russell, Viscount Amberley (see Amberley); Algernon Charles (1843–1928); and Rosalind Francis (1845–1921: ODNB), m., 4 Oct. 1864, George James Howard (1843–1911; ODNB),
artist and politician, only son of the Hon. Charles Wentworth George Howard (1814–74) and Mary Priscilla Harriet, b. Parke (1822–43).

Sterling, Sir Anthony Coningham (1805–71; ODNB; see 9:103TC to JAC, 2 Dec. 1836, and later vols.), soldier; m., 1829, Charlotte, b. Baird (d. 1863), who suffered attacks of insanity and was jealous of JWC (see 18:266–67JWC to HW, 12 Nov. 1844, and 19:9JWC to HW, [9 Jan. 1845]); they lived at 3 South Pl., Knightsbridge. His brother John (1806–44; ODNB), writer, had been a particular friend of TC; see CL vols. 8–18 and Carlyle’s Life of Sterling (1851); for John Sterling’s children, including Julia Maria Sterling (1836–1910), see 35:264–6535:biographical notes.
Stewart-Mackenzie, Maria Louisa, b. Marriott (b. ca. 1826), m., 1850, George Augustus Stewart-Mackenzie (1824–52), brother of Lady Louisa Ashburton; always referred to as “Mrs. George.”
Stirling; see Erskine.
Sylvester; see Silvester.

Tait, Robert Scott (1816–97), portrait painter and pioneer photographer; a friend of the Carlyles since 1853; living at 14 Queen Anne St., Cavendish Sq. He painted TC’s portrait (see 31:84TC to AGI, 6 May 1856) and A Chelsea Interior (see 33:197JWC to MR, 29 March [1858]). He photographed the Carlyles and their house in preparation for the painting, and he also took photographs for TC’s use in Frederick. He m., 1859, Harriet, b. Wilson (b. 1832); they had a da., Mildred (1860–1950).

Thompson, John Reuben (1823–73), from Virginia, U.S., poet and journalist; ed. of the Southern Literary Messenger 1847–60. He came to England in 1864 to promote the cause of the Confederacy, writing for the Index, a Confederate propaganda paper pbd. in London 1862–65, and pursuing social and political relationships with many important and influential people. He returned to the U.S. in 1866.

Trevelyan, Sir Walter Calverley (1797–1879; ODNB), naturalist; m., 1835, Paulina, b. Jermyn (1816–66; ODNB), art patron; they lived at Wallington Hall in Northumberland. Lady Trevelyan was a great friend of Lady Louisa Ashburton.

Twisleton, Hon. Edward Turner Boyd (1809–74; ODNB), close and respected friend of the Carlyles (see 28:184TC to JWC, 5 July 1853); he m., 1852, Ellen, b. Dwight (1828–62), from Boston, Mass., JWC’s close friend and confidante; she wrote, 1855, an account of JWC’s early married life at Craigenputtoch (see 30:267–74Ellen Twisleton’s Account of Life at Craigenputtoch). He lived at 3 Rutland Gate.

Venables, George Stovin (1810–88; ODNB), lawyer and journalist; contributor to the Saturday Review from its founding, 1855, and to the Times, 1857–88; friend of Tennyson and of Thackeray, who claimed he was the model for Warrington in Pendennis (1848–50).

Venturi, Emilie (ca. 1819–93; ODNB), da. of William Henry Ashurst (ca.
1791–1855; ODNB; portrait painter), supporter of Italian independence and campaigner for women’s rights; unhappily married to Sydney Hawkes, whom she divorced 1861; see 30:215JWC’s Journal, 13 Nov. 1855, and 23527 March 1856. She m., 1861, Carlo Venturi (ca. 1830–66). A strong supporter of Mazzini and the Young Italy movement, she published various English editions of his writings and Joseph Mazzini: A Memoir (1875).

Ward, Charles Augustus (1828–1914), vintner, author, antiquarian, and book collector; see 29:123–4TC to CAW, 6 July 1854. He lived at 1 Chapel St., Mayfair. His mother was Eliza, b. Wade (1796–25 Aug. 1864) and his father Charles Ward (b. ca. 1791). He often wrote under the pseudonym Feltham Burghley; see 36:262–64TC to CAW, 24 Sept. 1860.
Warren, Eliza (ca. 1816–1905), a widow with adult children, cook at Cheyne Row Nov. 1864–July 1866.
Watkins, John (1823–74), photographer, originally from Raglan in Monmouthshire; he and his brother Octavius Charles Watkins (1836–82) had a studio at 34 Parliament St., Westminster, 1851–65.

Welsh, Alexander (Alick) (b. 1816), son of JWC’s maternal uncle John; m., ca. 1849, Sophy, b. Martin (b. ca. 1824). Their children were John (Jackie) (ca. 1853–64), Isabella Helen (b. 1856; see 31:201JWC to TC, [29 Aug. 1856]), Margaret (b. 1858), and Jean (b. 1860).

Welsh, Ann (1799–1877), Elizabeth (1792–1877), and Grace (1801–67), JWC’s paternal aunts (see 14:67TC to JWC, 10 March 1842, and 16:219JWC to JW, 26 June 1843), living at Craigen Villa, Morningside, Edinburgh.
Welsh, Grace, b. Welsh (1782–1842), JWC’s mother; m., 1800, John Wel–3sh (1776–1819; see 1:202–3JBW to EWE, 5 Oct. 1819), JWC’s father, doctor in Haddington.
Welsh, Jeannie (ca. 1798–1828), JWC’s maternal aunt; for her death, see 4:358TC to JAC, 16 April 1828 and Carlyle, Reminiscences 127–29.

Welsh, John (d. 1853; see 28:286–87JWC to HW, [12 Oct. 1853] ), JWC’s maternal uncle, retired brass and copper founder, who had lived at 20 Maryland St., Liverpool; m., 1808, Mary, b. Colliver (d. 1838; see 10:200TC to AC, 15 Oct. 1838); their children were Helen (ca. 1813–53), Walter, Alexander, Jeannie (see Chrystal), John (1820–60), Margaret, and Mary.

Welsh, John Amelia (“Jackie”) (ca. 1812–64), illegitimate da. of JWC’s paternal uncle William (1790–1819; see 14:90TC to JWC, 25 March 1842) and Elizabeth Scott (b. 1782). Jackie lived in Haddington with her mother and her aunt Jane Scott (1787–1863).

Welsh, Margaret, b. Kissock (1803–88; see 13:44JWC to MW, [late Feb. 1841], and 20:128JWC to MW, [Feb.–March 1846]), widow of JWC’s paternal uncle George (1793–1835), living at 19 St. Johns Grove, Richmond, nr. London. Her son was John Welsh (1824–59; ODNB; see 15:37JWC to MW, [ca. 20 Aug. 1820]), F.R.S., meteorologist, whom JWC described as “worth all my cousins tied up in one bundle!” (35:58).

Welsh, Margaret (Maggie) (b. 1821), da. of JWC’s maternal uncle John; lived
in Auchtertool with her brother Walter; was JWC’s nurse, Dec. 1863–May 1864.
Welsh, Mary (1823–79), da. of JWC’s maternal uncle John; lived in Auchtertool with her brother Walter.

Welsh, Rev. Walter (1815–1879; see 16:12JWC to JW, 8 Jan. 1843), son of JWC’s maternal uncle John; minister at Auchtertool, Fife, since 1842. Two of his sisters, Margaret (Maggie) and Mary lived with him.

Whigham sisters: Mary (1821–1905), farmer and coal proprietor, Jemima Lucy Maxwell (1827–80), and Elizabeth (1833–1884), who lived at Burnfoot, Sanquhar, Dumfriesshire, and Georgina Helen (1829–1915) who m., 29 Sept. 1864, Rev. Henry Bowen Cooke (1797–1879), rector of Darfield, Yorkshire, 1834–79; das. of George Whigham (d. 1842), of Allanton, Dunscore, nr. Dumfries; see 10:191TC to JWC, 27 Sept. 1838. JWC visited them Aug. 1862; see 38:149JWC to TC, [19 Aug. 1862].

Woolner, Thomas (1825–92; ODNB; see 26:37TC to JCA, [21 Feb. 1851], and 29:176–77TC to LA, 20 Oct. 1854), sculptor and poet; he lived at 29 Welbeck St., London. He m., 6 Sept. 1864, Alice Gertrude, b. Waugh (b. 1845), da. of George and Mary Waugh. Their da. was b. 21 Aug. 1865.
Wynn, Charlotte Williams (1807–69; ODNB; see 19:102TC to JAC, 17 July 1845), diarist; she lived at 43 Green St., London.
